PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

1.Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2.We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3.This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brownhill (from 61 citizens) and Senator O'Chee (from 128 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 466 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 816 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our opposition to specific changes proposed to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and associated subordinate legislation in the 1993-94 Federal Budget introduced by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives on Tuesday 17 August 1993.
Specifically, we the undersigned oppose:
(i)proposed measures whereby students taking more than an extra semester to complete their first undergraduate degree accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 1.5;
(ii)proposed measures whereby students enrolling in second undergraduate degrees accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 2; and
(iii)proposed measures whereby the rates of prepayment increase from 2, 3 and 4 per cent of taxable income up to 3, 4 and 5 per cent for the three thresholds respectively.
We strongly urge the Senate to reject these measures.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio 6PR
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned call on the Senate to support the granting of a narrowcast broadcast licence, to allow Radio 6PR's talk back programs to continue broadcasting.
We understand that the failure of the Minister to grant this licence will result in job losses and the cancellation of vital afternoon talk back programs.

We believe that the Honourable Minister for Communications, Senator Bob Collins, should give his immediate and special consideration to the granting of a narrowcast licence to allow the vital role 6PR plays in Western Australia to continue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Detention of Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
the Australian Government's policy of detaining people seeking asylum has caused enormous hardship and misery for those detained;
the policy has contravened international obligations undertaken by Australia;
as a result of the detention of asylum seekers the Australian community has borne a considerable financial burden;
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
to end the policy of detaining asylum seekers, and
to release those asylum seekers still being held in Department of Immigration Processing Centres.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PETITION.PARA: The United Nations declaration on the elimination of all forms of intolerance and of discrimination based on religion and belief:
prohibits all forms of religious discrimination, thus potentially restricting the freedom of Australians to make any choices on the grounds of their belief;
could lead to US-style prohibitions on public Christian prayers, Christmas carols, or nativity scenes;
has the potential, according to the NSW Attorney-General, to restrict greatly the freedom of religious groups.
and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12-16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only the legally-weak term "respect" for the rights of parents in Article 5;
could result in Government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:

PARA.TAB: Act to disallow these two international instruments from the HREOC Act.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Exports to Indonesia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1.Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2.Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3.The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the scheduled fee.

4.The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5.The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6.Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.
We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.

PETITION.TITLE: Army Band
PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that the Regular Army Band based in Adelaide is

PARA.TAB: 1.an integral part of South Australian community life
2.a valuable contributor to nearly 250 charitable, civic and military functions per year
3.important to the morale and identity of Defence Force personnel
4.not adequately replaceable by a Reserve Force band

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will

PARA.TAB: 1.condemn the Keating Labor Government's decision to abolish the band
2.call on the Minister for Defence to retain the Regular Army Band in Adelaide

PETITION.PARA: and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Government Policies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and the members of the Senate in parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit:
That you have not kept promises made by you and your Government and that your policies are crippling business, small and large across Australia.
We demand:
Jobs for Australians and a freeze on migrants entering Australia
Incentives and assistance for industry

PARA.TAB: A referendum on the Republic, Mabo and capital punishment.
Lower sales tax on Australian made products

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: INTERSTATE GAS PIPELINES BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to implement statutory requirements for interstate gas pipeline operations, and thereby to facilitate the efficient and competitive development of the natural gas industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Natural gas has already gained widespread usage in the Australian community. It is an environmentally friendly fuel that is clean burning and produces lower greenhouse gas emissions than other fossil fuels.

Natural gas now accounts for around 17 percent of our primary energy demand, replacing more than 315,000 barrels of oil per day which we would otherwise have to import, worth $3.5 billion a year to our balance of payments.
Over the period to 2005, domestic gas demand is forecast to grow at an average of around 2—3 per cent per annum. By 2005, gas could account for 20 per cent of our total energy needs.
It is important that we are ready for this expansion and that the necessary strategies and legislative requirements are in place.
National Gas Strategy

Against this background of prospective growth in gas demand the Government announced the National Gas Strategy in November 1991. Essentially the Strategy's objectives are to remove impediments to the efficient development and delivery of natural gas in response to the needs of the market. The Government firmly believes that removing impediments is essential to ensuring optimal development of the natural gas industry.
The National Gas Strategy includes four key elements:
the development of free and fair interstate trade in natural gas
the development of an effective framework for interstate gas pipeline development
reform of the Pipeline Authority, and
removal of volume approvals for LNG exports.
The Pipeline Authority and the LNG exports approval system have already been reformed.

The recent decision by the Governments of South Australia and Queensland to agree to increased interstate gas supply is a welcome step in the expansion of free and fair interstate gas trade. The bill I am introducing today sets out an effective framework for interstate gas pipeline development and represents a further major step in the implementation of the National Gas Strategy.

This framework for interstate gas pipelines will provide the basis for continued growth of national gas pipelines, generate competition in gas supply, and encourage an economically efficient industry where environmental impact is minimised.
Sale Of The Moomba-Sydney Pipeline

It is the Government's objective to have the regulatory system for interstate gas pipelines in place before the end of 1993 to assist the sale of the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline. Mr President, the Government announced in the 1993-94 Budget that it would proceed with the sale of the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline System this financial year.

One of the most important outcomes of this bill will be that it provides a high degree of certainty for potential buyers of the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline by setting out clearly the regulatory environment that will apply to this and future interstate gas pipelines.

Contractual arrangements and undertakings relating to the future operation of the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline will need to be revised to facilitate the sale, and this will be addressed in the sale process currently being conducted by the Department of Finance's Task Force on Asset Sales.

Importantly, however, the statutory requirements set out in this bill will apply to all interstate pipelines, and will thus provide certainty for gas carriers and in particular, for gas consumers, who have expressed concern, mirrored on a number of occasions by such agencies as the Industries Commission and the Trade Practices Commission, about the possibility of pipeline monopoly abuse in the gas transmission sector.
Regulatory Framework For The Industry
The bill I have introduced incorporates four key elements:

pipeline owners will be obliged to provide access to interstate pipelines on negotiated commercial terms and conditions, subject to pipeline capacity being available, with the Trade Practices Commission to arbitrate where required, when negotiations over access break down

pipeline owners will be required to maintain and provide separate accounting and separate management control of interstate gas transmission pipeline operations and be required to provide financial statements and other information on an annual basis and as requested, to the Prices Surveillance Authority to enable the PSA to monitor haulage charges
pipeline owners will be required to provide haulage charges with underlying terms and conditions, to be available on demand, and
any pricing behaviour that may breach provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 will be matters for the Trade Practices Commission to investigate.

This bill, therefore, places statutory requirements on interstate gas pipeline operators that are intrusive only to the extent of providing to existing agencies the minimum of information necessary to protect the community against the possibility of monopoly abuse.

A number of other countries have taken a different path on pipeline regulation. In the United States, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission acts as an industry specific regulator and in the United Kingdom, the Office of Fair Trading and the Office of Gas Supply stipulates terms and conditions specifically for gas trade.

We will avoid the worst aspects of pipeline regulation in those countries. The approach implemented through this legislation will avoid a prescriptive approach to regulation of pipeline operations, at the same time providing mechanisms that ensure access to all interstate gas pipelines. This includes the capacity for the Trade Practices Commission to arbitrate unresolved access disputes.
Free And Fair Interstate Gas Trade
The Federal Government sees the promotion of free and fair interstate gas trade as central to the efficient development of our natural gas resources.

The costs of not implementing free and fair trade in gas would be unacceptably high. The Australian Gas Association estimates these costs could be as high as $4 billion in net present value terms over the period to the year 2030.

Recent studies by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics confirm that there are substantial benefits in the order of $1.4 billion to be gained from interconnecting gas pipelines and extending gas networks. If gas trade were to be restricted, these benefits would be foregone.

There can be no justification for a situation where we all pay higher gas prices because of monopoly abuse or impediments to free and fair interstate gas trade. This bill will ensure that at least there will be no such impediments to access to interstate gas pipelines.
Hilmer Report
The bill will also facilitate a competition policy environment fully consistent with the objectives outlined in Professor Hilmer's recent report to the Government on national competition policy.
As stated recently by Mr Bill Scales, Chairman of the Industry Commission, in commenting on the Hilmer Report with reference to the coverage of the Trade Practices Act:

"Additional measures are required to guarantee access to the services provided by true natural monopolies across Australia and to ensure an efficient level of pricing, in particular, to prevent monopoly pricing.
He went on:

"A key issue in this regard is where vertically integrated owners of essential facilities . . . refuse access to competitors . . . either as a result of anti-competitive intent or because of a routine inability to agree a mutually satisfactory price.
These are the main issues in relation to open access for interstate gas pipelines that this legislation addresses.
As the Industry Commission Chairman put it:
"The trick is to design a few good rules, but still give parties the maximum chance to negotiate mutually agreeable arrangements. This is the crux of a light handed regulatory approach.

The approach which the Government is taking in this legislation provides a framework which leaves gas carriers and gas users free to negotiate commercial terms, while at the same time providing for surveillance of haulage charges and arbitration of access disputes by the Trade Practices Commission with appeal to the Court only on matters of law.

This approach will assist the role of the Trade Practices Commission in relation to interstate gas trade. It is recognised that these roles of both the TPC and PSA may be replaced, in due course, by an umbrella body in the form of a general industry competition authority established following consideration of the Hilmer Report.

The Government considers that any delay in proceeding with the statutory requirements for interstate pipeline operations as set out in this bill on the grounds that the Hilmer Report has to be considered, and an approach agreed with the States, cannot be justified.
State/Industry Attitudes

Details of the framework embodied in this legislation have been forwarded to State and Territory Governments, industry and gas users for comment. Major gas users, represented by the Electricity Supply Association of Australia Limited and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, strongly support establishment of transparent mechanisms and a regulatory framework to ensure recognition of the needs of all gas users.

On the other hand, gas industry associations, representing producers, distributors and transporters, have stated a clear preference to rely on the industry's voluntary Code of Practice for Access to Inter-State Natural Gas Transmission Pipelines as the basis for an industry self-regulatory system.
I commend the industry for developing a Code of Practice and believe that this will be of considerable benefit in encouraging sound and effective industry practices.
However, the Code alone is not sufficient.
The Hilmer Report (page 246) comments on the Code, as follows:

"While the Code is an important contribution to the development of open access regimes, it does not provide any legally enforceable rights; it provides for a "right to negotiate" rather than a "right to access"; does not give guidance on pricing principles; and has no binding resolution mechanism.
The Trade Practices Commission also considers the industry's Code to be not adequate to properly address the competition issues arising from interstate gas transmission.

Moreover, the Code in its present form is not supported by gas users. The Government is therefore of the view that the statutory requirements of this bill will act to complement the thrust of the industry's Code of Practice and bring the certainty that pipeline operators and users will require in future.

Some States have suggested that the legislation should await the implementation of the Hilmer Report. To await full implementation of the Government's response to Hilmer's findings would unnecessarily delay the implementation of a national legislated right of access to interstate pipelines where a clear public interest exists—concepts clearly endorsed by the Hilmer Report. It would also unnecessarily delay the sale of the Moomba-Sydney pipeline.

The reforms and legislation that have been introduced today will facilitate a competition policy environment which is fully consistent with the objectives outlined in the Hilmer Report and will lay a sound framework for the efficient development and interstate delivery of Australia's gas reserves.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (ALLIGATOR RIVERS REGION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The Office of the Supervising Scientist, which includes the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute, was established by the Commonwealth in 1978, following the Fox Inquiry into uranium mining. The purpose of the office is to provide assurance to the Australian people that the environment in the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory is not being adversely affected by uranium mining. The Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute has now carried out research on the impact of mining on the environment in the Region for fifteen years and uranium mining operations have been underway for thirteen years. In this time much background data has been accumulated and the operation of the Ranger mine has been relatively trouble-free.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the continuing public sensitivity to uranium mining issues, the need to ensure satisfactory rehabilitation of mine sites, the special significance of the Kakadu region and the Commonwealth's undertakings to the Northern Land Council and traditional Aboriginal owners, the Government believes that a continuing Commonwealth role is essential. Nonetheless, after fifteen years there is room for adjustment without jeopardising environmental protection.

The Government has decided to streamline and refocus Commonwealth arrangements. The decision was made following discussions between senior officers from Commonwealth departments with the Northern Territory Government, the Northern Land Council and representatives of industry. I stress that following these changes there will be no diminution of environmental protection in the Region. This is of paramount importance to the Government.

Regulation of mining operations will continue to be with the Northern Territory Government and working arrangements are to be improved following consultations with the Northern Territory Government. There will be no lessening of the Commonwealth's commitment to ensuring environment protection in the Region. The Office of the Supervising Scientist will continue to play a key role in supervising and assessing any impact of uranium mining activities in the Region.
The essence of the changes is:
incorporation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (thereby reducing administrative duplication and achieving economies of scale),
refined mechanisms for consulting key stakeholders,
enabling the Minister to seek advice from the Supervising Scientist on environmental matters outside the Alligator Rivers Region,
allowing the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute to undertake research on matters outside the Region on a commercial basis, and
establishment of an independent review of the research now needed to meet the Commonwealth's environment protection objectives in the Region.

An independent consultancy to review the nature and priorities for research needed at this stage of uranium mining operations to provide a basis for maintaining a satisfactory level of environmental protection in the Region is being arranged. In recognition of the importance of continued protection of the environment to the Traditional Owners in the Alligator Rivers Region, the views of the Northern Land Council, as well as of other key stakeholders, will be taken into account by the independent review.
Implementation of some of these changes requires amendment of the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act and this is the purpose of the bill before you.

The Government has been working for some time towards strengthening its environmental management capabilities by consolidating various related organisational components. With this in mind, in 1992 the Supervising Scientist's head office was moved from Sydney to be co-located with the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency in Canberra. Complete incorporation of the office into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency will lead to direct and indirect savings in the order of $650 000 per annum from 1994-95 onwards.

Because of the integration of the office into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, there will be no further need for the Supervising Scientist to have the powers of a Departmental Secretary under the Public Service Act 1922 and the relevant section is repealed by this bill. The Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region will continue to be a statutory position with similar duties, powers and functions, but will now be an office in the Commonwealth Public Service and subject to the provisions of the Public Service Act in relation to remuneration and other conditions of service. The Supervising Scientist will continue to manage the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute.
There are considerable gains to be had by setting the operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in a broader context and making the expertise of the organisation more available to others.

Accordingly it is proposed to amend the Act to enable the Minister to draw on the considerable knowledge in the Office of the Supervising Scientist to advise the Government on environmental matters outside the Alligator Rivers Region. I stress that it is not the purpose of this proposal to promote uranium mining development, either in Australia or overseas, but to enhance the quality and scope of specialist environmental advice available to the Government.

While the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute will continue to provide the research basis in relation to the impacts of uranium mining in the Region, it will also be empowered to undertake scientific research on environmental matters outside the Region on a fee-for-service basis. By undertaking contract research, the Institute could earn up to 30 per cent of the Commonwealth contribution to its research program. Thus the Institute will be able to contribute more efficiently to the national research effort by making its considerable expertise available to others, while at the same time strengthening its own capacity for research.

The bill will also establish improved arrangements for consulting with key stakeholders and scientific and technical experts. The Co-ordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region will be replaced by two linked committees, the Consultative Committee and the Technical Committee.

The Consultative Committee will comprise the Minister's appointees drawn from key stakeholders, including Aboriginal and environment groups and an independent chair. It will provide a formal forum for policy consultation on matters relating to the effects on the environment in the Alligator Rivers Region of uranium mining in the Region, as well as commenting on, but not changing, recommendations to the Minister from the Technical Committee.

The Technical Committee will advise the Minister on the continuing nature and extent of research needed as a basis for maintaining a satisfactory level of protection in the Region and on the most appropriate organisations (including the Research Institute) to carry out the recommended research. The Technical Committee will have expert representation from the Research Institute, Northern Territory authorities, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the Northern Land Council and the mining companies. The chairperson and members will be selected by the Minister.

The Government believes these new consultative arrangements will more effectively meet the needs of the Commonwealth and the key stakeholders, by more specifically focusing on policy and technical aspects.

In summary, the bill before you will provide for a more up-to-date, focused and integrated approach to protecting the environment of the Alligator Rivers Region. It will also achieve cost savings in delivering this important service to the people of the Region, the mining industry and all Australians.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.
INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 is a portfolio bill which amends eight acts.

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Act 1903 is to be amended to change the title of the "Chairman" of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, adopting the gender neutral title "President".

The proposed amendments of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 will enable the Australian Industrial Registry to act as registry for state industrial bodies, including state industrial relations tribunals, industrial courts and workers' compensation tribunals. This measure complements steps which have already been taken in South Australia to co-locate the state and federal industrial registries. The proposed amendments will enable integration of the state and federal industrial registries to take place in any state where the federal minister and the appropriate state authority agree. In other words, the Commonwealth will not be able to impose integration on any state that does not want it. Negotiations are already underway with the South Australian government that may see the Australian Industrial Registry assuming state registry functions in South Australia.

In addition, amendments of the Industrial Relations Act are proposed to enable the rules of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to prescribe the period within which an objection to the variation of an award that is a common rule must be lodged. At present no such period is prescribed, and this can cause difficulties in relation to the enforcement of common rule awards.

The proposed amendments of the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973 will give the presiding officers of the Senate and the House of Representatives the same powers under that act as are currently held by the public service commissioner. This means that the presiding officers will have the power, in specified circumstances, to declare the position held by a female officer who is on maternity leave to be vacant, with the consequence that the officer concerned becomes an unattached officer. The amendments also give the heads of the five parliamentary departments certain powers and functions in relation to the administration of maternity leave in their departments. To date these powers have been exercised under delegation. The amendments are consistent with the intention that the administrative arrangements governing the parliamentary departments be independent of the wider Australian public service.

Minor amendments are made to the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 which contribute to the government's policy of ensuring adequate occupational health and safety protection for the Commonwealth's own employees. In particular the amendments:
.clarify the application of the act to employees who do not work in offices or factories;
.strengthen the reporting requirements in relation to accidents and dangerous occurrences; and
.broaden the regulation making powers under the act to allow the Commonwealth to meet its commitment to achieve a national, uniform system of occupational health and safety.

Amendments are proposed to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, to provide procedures for the removal of discriminatory provisions from determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal. The amendments will enable the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to refer discriminatory provisions to the Remuneration Tribunal. The tribunal will be required to conduct a hearing into the matter and, if it is satisfied that a provision is discriminatory, to take action to remove the discrimination. The process will be initiated by complaints to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner will have a discretion not to act upon complaints which, in the opinion of the commissioner, are frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance.

In addition, the Remuneration Tribunal Act is to be amended to require the tribunal, when determining the remuneration of executives of government business enterprises, to take into account the superannuation entitlements of those executives. The Remuneration Tribunal Act is also to be amended to change the title of the "chairman" of the Remuneration Tribunal, adopting the gender neutral title "president".

The proposed amendments of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 will assist Comcare and licensed authorities to recover certain overpayments which may occur when an employee who is receiving workers' compensation benefits retires and becomes entitled to superannuation benefits. The proposed amendment introduces a scheme that will enable the overpayment to be recovered from the superannuation fund concerned, rather than from the individual.

The scheme will only operate if Comcare or the relevant licensed authority seeks to recover an overpayment before the retired employee receives his or her first superannuation benefit payment. Other safeguards have been designed to minimise the scheme's impact on superannuation fund administrators and individual employees. In particular, I note that a determination that an amount of compensation has been overpaid and is to be recovered under the proposed scheme will be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The proposed amendments of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act 1946 will enable regulations to be made prescribing fees to be charged, on a cost-recovery basis, for certain functions which the Department of Industrial Relations performs in support of the local and central trades committees established by the act. Since 1989 the department has been charging fees, on a partial cost-recovery basis, to applicants for trade skills assessment under the act. The fees were imposed administratively and the department was recently advised that there is no statutory authority for them. The collection of fees ceased pending the coming into effect of the necessary legislation.
Financial impact

The bill will have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure. However, as mentioned in the explanatory memorandum, it is expected that the amendments of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act will result in the payment to the Department of Industrial Relations of fees totalling approximately $180,000 per annum.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (SEA DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The Government is committed to the protection of the Australian marine environment and has pursued the implementation of this policy on both the national and international fronts by participating in consultations aimed at producing agreed measures for the prevention and control of marine pollution.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 so as to enable Australia to ratify the Protocol for the Prevention of Pollution of the South Pacific Region by Dumping, which is commonly referred to as the SPREP Dumping Protocol. This protocol is one of two protocols to the Convention for the Protection of the Natural Resources and Environment of the South Pacific Region, otherwise known as the SPREP Convention. Australia has already ratified the other Protocol concerning Co-operation in Combating Pollution Emergencies in the South Pacific Region.

The SPREP Convention was ratified by Australia on 19 July 1989. It is a comprehensive, umbrella agreement for the protection, management and development of the marine and coastal environment of the South Pacific Region. It lists the sources of pollution which require control, such as pollution from ships, dumping, land-based sources, atmospheric discharges, among many others. The SPREP Dumping Protocol recognises the danger posed to the marine environment by pollution caused by the dumping of waste or other matter at sea, and places obligations on parties to prevent, reduce and control pollution in the Protocol Area by dumping.

The SPREP Dumping Protocol is essentially a regional agreement consistent with the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, also known as the London Convention 1972. Australia fulfils its international obligations under the London Convention 1972 through the Sea Dumping Act, which came into effect on 6 March 1984. As a great majority of the obligations under the SPREP Dumping Protocol are met by the provisions of the Sea Dumping Act, it is expedient that Australia join its Pacific Island neighbours in this regional agreement by amending the Sea Dumping Act. Also, the major overlap with the provisions of the existing Act means that the financial implications of ratifying the SPREP Dumping Protocol will be minimal.

However, there are some aspects of the SPREP Dumping Protocol which impose slightly different requirements from arrangements currently in place under the Sea Dumping Act. The major difference is that the SPREP Dumping Protocol covers a geographical area which is different from the definition of "Australian waters" in the Sea Dumping Act. However, there is no legal reason why Australia cannot choose to apply the additional requirements of the SPREP Dumping Protocol in waters to which the Sea Dumping Act applies. The practical effect of applying the SPREP Dumping Protocol to all Australian waters and the continental shelf is that it will be an offence to dump organophosphorous compounds in the Indian and Southern Oceans as well as the SPREP Convention area. Consequently, as Tasmania currently has the rollback provisions under section 9 of the Sea Dumping Act which allows it to administer the loading and dumping of wastes or other matter in its coastal waters, the Tasmanian Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1987 will need to be amended within 12 months to reflect the additional requirement of the SPREP Dumping Protocol. The necessary action is underway.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The sale of CSL Limited is an important part of the Government's micro-economic reform program. The decision to sell CSL by way of an initial public offering of shares is consistent with this Government's desire for Australia's pharmaceutical manufacturing base to grow stronger, with linkages to international markets.

SPEECH.PARA: For CSL to compete effectively in the international market place and to achieve its full growth potential, it requires greater financial and management flexibility to secure capital and pursue its internationalisation goals.
The public float of CSL will enable it to achieve this potential and will release the Commonwealth from its incongruous position of being owner, as well as customer and regulator of the company.

CSL was established by the Australian Government in 1916 to help meet the pharmaceutical needs of an isolated nation then at war. Following the implementation in 1989 of a reform package which corporatised its operations, CSL is now an unlisted government-owned public company with assets of $238 million and sales for last year exceeding $160 million.

CSL is an independent developer, manufacturer and marketer of ethical healthcare products. Its core expertise is in human and veterinary pharmaceutical and diagnostic products of biological origin, notably vaccines and blood plasma products.
CSL'S principle products include influenza and infant triple antigen vaccines, antivenoms and a variety of plasma-derived products.

Significant levels of resources have been directed to research, development and commercialisation of core products. More than $18 million has been invested by CSL in research and development during the past year.

The company is as export oriented as it is research based. It is actively internationalising its pharmaceutical, veterinary, diagnostic and plasma products business. Presently, 10% of its revenues come from export sales and there are plans for further expansion in the future.

Based at its 12 hectare site at Parkville, Victoria, CSL employs 1,200 people and has sales and distribution branches in each mainland state. In addition, the construction of a highly advanced blood plasma fractionation plant is currently nearing completion at Broadmeadows in Victoria.
Sale Strategy

The Government took a decision as part of the 1992-93 Federal Budget to sell all of its shares in CSL. After a detailed "scoping study" of the various sale options open to it, the Government announced in November 1992 that the sale would proceed on the basis of an initial public offering of the whole of the Government's 100% shareholding. The flotation will occur in the second half of this financial year, depending upon market conditions and sale preparations.
National Interest Provisions
The decision to float CSL was predicated on the company remaining independent, under Australian control, and continuing its key role in providing blood products to the Australian community.
The bill addresses these key issues by:
limiting the voting rights of significant foreign shareholders in regard to appointment, replacement and removal of company directors;
requiring that CSL's head office and principal fractionation activities be located in Australia; and
requiring that CSL remain incorporated in Australia and CSL's chairman and two thirds of the board be Australian citizens.
These arrangements will be complemented by an allocation of shares in CSL at point of sale as follows:
a limit of 5% on all individual shareholdings, domestic or foreign;
an aggregate limit of 15-20% on foreign shareholdings; and
preference for individuals and institutions over corporate shareholders.
This share allocation strategy aims to achieve a broad spread of shareholdings at the time of float which, combined with market based incentives, should ensure an independent CSL into the future.

Continued supply of plasma products post sale will be covered by a long term contract between CSL and the Commonwealth. Supply of these products is a key national interest issue. Accordingly, provisions have been included in the Sale Bill to enable the Commonwealth, through the Minister for Health, to have direct access to the Federal Court in the event of a breach of the contract, and for the court to make orders to ensure continued performance.

There is also a prohibition on CSL disposing of, encumbering or granting any interest in the plasma products facility at Broadmeadows without the Commonwealth's consent. The plasma products supply contract will also restrict CSL'S ability to dispose of plant and equipment which is necessary to enable them to fulfil their contractual obligations.
These provisions represent the best available protection of the national interest, consistent with the sale of CSL.
The bill now before the house contains the legislative changes that need to be made to enable the float of CSL to be finalised.
Much of the bill is concerned with the removal of CSL from the ambit of Commonwealth legislation so that, post-sale, CSL will be the same as any other Australian pharmaceutical or healthcare company.
Staff Entitlements

The Government is committed to the protection of all CSL employees' rights which accrue during the period of Government ownership, especially in cases where these rights accrue as a result of Commonwealth legislation.

To this end, the bill provides for a number of "savings" provisions in respect of a variety of acts, such as the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976 and the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. These provisions will ensure, in particular, that employees of CSL do not lose the benefits that they will have accrued prior to sale.

Rights under the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act will apply for 12 months post sale. In general, other rights not conferred by Commonwealth legislation will not be affected by the sale as the Government is selling its shares in CSL and the CSL Award will continue post sale.
Other Provisions

The legislation contains transitional arrangements to provide certainty that CSL is freed from all legislative constraints which apply generally to Commonwealth Business Enterprises and to clarify the position in relation to rights and obligations which arise prior to the sale day.

The sale of CSL could leave the purchasers of CSL shares liable for certain State and Territory taxes and fees. To avoid this liability, to reduce potential sale process complications and to increase the return to taxpayers, the sale is to be exempted from State and Territory taxes and fees.

Mr President, this bill puts in place a sound legislative framework to enable the public offering of the Commonwealth's shareholding in CSL to proceed. It provides the Commonwealth with security over CSL'S role in fractionation while freeing CSL from obligations to the Commonwealth other than those of any publicly listed company.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the bill.

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
This bill amends the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act 1988. Currently the Act provides for appropriation to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of duty on aviation gasoline.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the amendment is to enable duty on aviation turbine fuel (aviation kerosene) to also be appropriated to the CAA as part of the aviation safety regulation cost recovery regime.
Government Decision
In the 1992 Budget it was announced that the cost of aviation safety standard setting and surveillance would be jointly met by the Government and the aviation industry.
The Government will meet 50 per cent of the costs up to a limit of $22.8 million (in real terms).
Cost recovery of the industry's portion of these costs is being phased in over two years from 1993/94.
Cost recovery arrangements for 1993/94 involve a slight increase in duty on both aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel.
The required increase, which applies from 1 September 1993 is 0.264 cents per litre.
Because fuel used by Australian airlines on international services is exempt from duty, the CAA will introduce a fee for safety regulation in relation to these international operations.
In implementing these cost recovery arrangements for 1993/94, the Government has carefully noted the views expressed by the aviation industry.
Post 1993/94 Arrangements
The CAA is developing a long term funding strategy for aviation safety regulation to apply from 1994/95.

The development of the strategy will involve an examination of the economic ,and safety implications and impacts of possible mixes of charges and taxes on the aviation industry. The process will also involve extensive consultation with the aviation industry.
Financial Impact
The industry contribution to aviation safety standard setting and surveillance for 1993/94 will reduce Government outlays by $4.5 million.

Users of aviation gasoline recently benefited from a three cent per litre reduction in duty and the CAA is currently exploring the prospect for a further reduction following the introduction of new airspace management arrangements in November this year.
Given the very low rate of duty, therefore, the 1993/94 arrangements are not expected to result in any significant adverse financial impact on any particular aviation industry sector.
The post 1993/94 funding arrangements will take into account the effects on the industry of any new funding strategies.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.

The speech read as follows—
The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Departure Tax Act 1978 to provide that the rate of the tax be increased from $20 to $25 with effect from 1 January 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to increase the Departure Tax was taken at the same time as the Government decided to increase funding for tourism.
As announced in the Budget, an additional $80 million has been allocated to boost the development of new tourism products and for tourism promotion over the next four years.

This funding includes an extra $8 million in 1993/94 and $10 million per annum to 1996/97 for overseas market development by the Australian Tourist Commission which will help ensure strong growth in inbound tourism and add to job creation.
The increase in Departure Tax will help offset this additional tourist promotion expenditure.

At $25, Australia's Departure Tax will be around the same level as charges imposed on international travellers by authorities in the United States and Fiji and is below those levied in Japan, Hong Kong, Canada and in a number of European countries such as Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Greece and Germany.
The increase in Departure Tax is expected to increase revenue by some $11 million in 1993/94, $28 million in 1994/95, $30 million in 1995/96 and $32 million in 1996/97.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.

PARA.TAB: House of Representatives Message—

The House of Representatives, having considered message No. 98 of the Senate, acquaints the Senate that the House of Representatives has disagreed to the Senate's variation of the resolution of appointment of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and has made the following modification in place thereof:
Paragraph (2), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

INTERJECT.PARA: "(2) That the committee consist of 12 members, 4 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 2 Senators to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.".

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Faulkner)—by leave—proposed:
That the Senate—

(1) concurs with the resolution transmitted to the Senate by message No. 142 of the House of Representatives relating to amendments to the resolution of appointment of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.
(2) That this resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by message.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I have no opposition to the extension of the number of members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I wish to draw to the attention of my colleagues here today an aspect of the membership of that committee. Neither of the two parties that consider themselves the major parties have any women representatives on that committee. While there are two women members of the committee, Senator Lees of the Australian Democrats and me, the imbalance has just increased—unless the major parties take advantage of this opportunity to make sure that they have women represented amongst the contingents they provide from their parties.

PARA.TAB: There is a particular reason why this matter may be extremely useful to the committee: the committee has received a reference from the Senate regarding women, elections and parliament, with particular reference to, firstly, the reasons for the gender imbalance in the Australian parliament, secondly, strategies for increasing the number and effectiveness of women in political and electoral processes, and, thirdly, the effect of parliamentary procedures and practices on women's aspirations to and participation in the Australian parliament.

I believe that the argument may be extended that to have more than two women out of 12 may not reflect the representation of women in parliament. However, as that is the problem that is being addressed by this committee—the imbalance in the parliament that reflects the gender balance within the broader community—I believe it is extremely important that both parties, government and opposition, consider this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the gender balance in your party?

—We have a very good gender balance. We are trying to compensate for the over-representation of the male gender in this parliament. But the Greens, as a rule, take as an indication of the health of their organisation that 50 per cent of their candidates are men and 50 per cent are women. That is not contrived. It happens because we have a very healthy organisation which does reflect the broader community. That is what I wish to see in the parliament and on this committee as well. I therefore urge women members of the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party, in particular, not to let this opportunity for better representation of women on the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters slip by without their taking advantage of it.

PARA.TAB: Finally, because the reference on women's participation in parliament is due to be reported on in December and because the committee has not demonstrated a great urgency or eagerness to deal with it, I would welcome some supportive membership from women of the major parties, joining Senator Lees and me on this committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the amended proposition that has come back from the House of Representatives. It incorporates that which was passed by the Senate and adds to it in a way that restores balance to the committee. This is what we expected to happen and we are very glad that it has happened so promptly.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Debate resumed from 29 September 1993, on motion by Senator Panizza:

TAB.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report on or before the last day of sitting in March 1994:

PARA.TAB: The operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) and any other body, company or corporation which receives funding from ATSIC, with particular regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the accountability of ATSIC, ALS and ATSIC-funded bodies and individuals for the way in which they receive, spend and publicly account for taxpayers' money with particular reference to project grant money;

(b)whether there is an effective working relationship between the Department of Social Security and ATSIC and endeavour to identify the factors which have made some community development and employment projects (CDEP) successful whilst others have failed and the reasons for this;

(c)whether it is appropriate for ATSIC to continue funding all of its current programs, with particular reference to the CDEP, or whether greater levels of accountability could be obtained if responsibility for that program were transferred to the Department of Social Security;

(d)whether there are sufficient guidelines, controls, checks and acquittal procedures applied to ATSIC, ALS and other ATSIC-funded bodies to ensure that taxpayers' funds are fairly and properly applied for the purposes intended under the ATSIC Act, especially concerning the levels of spending approval authority and effective use of capital item expenditure;

(e)whether there are sufficient guidelines and procedures in place to control satisfactorily the expenditure of taxpayers' funds on travel and accommodation by ATSIC commissioners, councillors and staff, and by members or employees of any ATSIC-funded body; and

(f)whether ATSIC should continue to hold discretionary power to disregard non-compliance with conditions applying to grant money which it has distributed, or whether the ATSIC Act should be amended to require the refund of such money where grant conditions are not met.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be guided on this, Mr President. I presume that I have a right of reply on this, have I?
—If there are no other speakers, yes.

—I see that Senator Kernot is in the chamber. I think it is time we brought this matter to a head. I have been trying to come to a conclusion with the Australian Democrats on the situation for quite some time regarding some support for this motion. This motion relates entirely to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and its accountability. I have been branded as a racist by some people over this motion, in a situation where they think that I am attacking ATSIC and the Aboriginal people, and attacking the funding that goes to them. I have never ever done anything along these lines. I have simply asked for accountability. I really started with the Auditor-General's report. Ever since, I have had messages of support from right around Australia, which I have referred to before.

PARA.TAB: In relation to my dealings with the Democrats, Senator Kernot will know that I had agreed, at her request, to move an amendment, and that amendment was to restrict this inquiry to Western Australia. I had the amendment printed; I did not have it circulated; the amendment was at their request. I had promise of support on a Thursday about four weeks ago, if I remember rightly. By the next Tuesday that support was not quite so strong. Then it was suggested to me that we refer the matter to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs which I believe may have been a way to go.

Unfortunately, there is no way—or no-one has told me if there is a way—of referring any matter from this Senate down to the House of Representatives. I spoke to the chairman or one of the members of that committee, whose name escapes me. He said he would be willing to take it on but, unfortunately, the minister there sets the terms of reference. I believe this is an important issue that should be addressed on its own, not buried with something else. It is about the accountability, and accountability alone, of ATSIC; also the Aboriginal Legal Service. So I said I was happy to keep this reference in Western Australia: the Aboriginal Legal Service and ATSIC funded bodies—especially ATSIC funded bodies.

This morning in the Herald-Sun, there is a big article on what has happened in Victoria with an ATSIC related body. There has been another big blow-up which has got out of hand. That body should have gone into liquidation some time ago, but it has not done so. An administrator has been in there for a couple of years trying to improve the situation, but it has not worked.

There is another ATSIC related corporation in Wyndham in Western Australia into which ATSIC poured a vast amount of money but still could not keep it afloat. If ATSIC wanted to pour money especially into that one in Wyndham, that was its decision. I am concerned about accountability. The money was poured in and the corporation was kept afloat, so the local traders presumed that its standing was on a pretty even keel. Unfortunately, because it was kept going by ATSIC, more and more credit was given to it by the local traders, who presumed they were on safe ground. To my knowledge, the corporation has not been put into liquidation officially, but the traders have been left high and dry for whatever they had supplied over the last couple of years.

In a normal situation when a corporation gets into difficulties, there are very stringent laws. A corporation cannot trade after it becomes technically insolvent. In other words, if it owes more than it is worth, even though it is trading pretty well at that stage, it cannot continue trading. In this case in Wyndham in Western Australia, to my knowledge, the corporation has kept trading far beyond the time it ceased to be viable. So it has bought more and more people in. That is the situation, and it is time we got to the bottom of it. It is not only happening there; it is also happening in Victoria.

The other part of my concern is the Aboriginal Legal Service, especially in Western Australia. Some people on our side of politics in Western Australia have been trying for the past two years to get an inquiry into the ALS. Mr Eric Charlton, the Western Australian transport minister, who is a member of National Party of Australia, has been trying to get an inquiry for two or three years, but one cannot find out what is going on with the ALS money.

ALS money is allocated to defend Aboriginals in court. That is what it is there for. It is not there for anything else. I know, and others from Western Australia will know, that this year, not very long ago, the ALS funded a protest march. I wonder whether anyone in this chamber can tell me that that is a legitimate way in which to spend ALS funds. If so, I would ask them to please speak up. It is time we got to the bottom of that sort of thing. It has been going on all the time, and we have been spending around $1.3 billion on ATSIC's budget.

I have visited the communities around Western Australia and I have visited a few in the south of the Northern Territory. I have noticed that health, housing and education standards are going down more and more. Some communities, such as Warburton in Western Australia, are doing well. I visited Warburton once on the same day as Senator Beahan. That community has been going reasonably well because it had been hauled out of a very bad situation by a manager who was appointed 10 years ago. He is very dedicated and he is doing a very good job.

The Turkey Creek community in Western Australia is in the same situation, and I could probably name two or three others. There is quite a good one that I have visited in the Northern Territory at Docker River. That is run very well. But then there are the others, especially on the Strelley leases in Western Australia, where money has been wasted. On the Strelley leases, in the last two years $1.7 million has been paid in, yet the place has been abandoned and buildings have been wrecked and left to rack and ruin. I am looking at accountability to see what is going on in this situation. That is why I had asked the Democrats and the Green senators from Western Australia for support, but they refused flatly to support me.

It seems to me that if, in this place and other places, one questions or asks for accountability on anything to do with Aboriginals, one is branded as a racist and has to back off. They are untouchables. Yet, if I moved to have an inquiry into the accountability of any other ethnic branch in Australia when the Auditor-General had named it as needing an inquiry into its accountability, I would probably get total support.

At estimates we had the Auditor-General in front of us—only the second time, I think, that an auditor-general or his representative had appeared in front of an estimates committee. His representative said that the greatest condemnation that the Auditor-General can make of a department is to make a report. As to the rest, he said that it is up to parliament to do what it chooses if it wants accountability. Accountability is demanded in this parliament of all other departments and I cannot see why we should back off from asking it of this body.

After all, I am about accountability and nothing else. We should get away from the silly notion that, because it is about Aborigines, no-one is allowed to say anything. I believe it is time that the honourable senators who are in this parliament from all over Australia supposedly to keep people honest told Australia exactly how they stand in this situation. It is certainly time they did that. As I said, I had support from the Democrats in the beginning, when I agreed that, in the short time there was, this would be restricted to Western Australia. We were not able to reach the matter by 10.30 on the Thursday night; after the weekend, by the next Tuesday, their approach was lukewarm. It has been sidelined to go down to the House of Representatives committee. I have looked into that, in depth, and I cannot see that an inquiry like that would be sufficient. Would that committee have the time to do it or, if it did, get to the bottom of things?

This motion was supported by a lot of speakers on this side of the chamber. I had invited the Democrats to speak on it and the Greens, for that matter, and anyone on the side of the government who wanted to speak on the situation of accountability, but to date they have preferred to take a backward step. The Democrats are not yet beyond speaking. I am sure that, if they wished to seek leave to speak on the matter, leave would not be denied.

In conclusion, I have had the total support of my party on this motion. I have had the total support of my side of politics in Western Australia. I have had support from Queensland, where the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) comes from. I have had support from New South Wales. I cannot remember whether I have been contacted by anyone from Victoria. Someone from South Australia definitely contacted me and, of course, we in Western Australia are the ones screaming out.

I have also had it put to me that starting an inquiry now will interfere with the ATSIC elections coming up in December, and that I might have even worked with people towards that situation. That is something that I definitely did not do. I have had enough of seeing non-accountability for this budget and that is why I have progressed down this path. I reiterate that a lot of this $1.3 billion is being wasted. Everywhere I go I see declining health. Someone told me that he had been to a community where four young children had died because of the lack of health services, and that the doctors and nurses were overworked. Housing is going backwards. Also, $12 million of the budget was returned to the Commonwealth because it was unused. This is totally out of order. It is time that this matter was put to rest. I leave it at that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I need to clarify a few of the things that Senator Panizza has said. It is true that this matter has been the subject of constant negotiation. The Australian Democrats have no desire to shield any statutory authority from public scrutiny and we have no desire to treat ATSIC any differently from any other organisation. However, I think there are a couple of other facts that we ought to take into account.

PARA.TAB: When I persuaded Senator Panizza to confine the terms of reference to Western Australia, and to give specific focus to the Auditor-General's report, that was in the spirit of improving the scope of the inquiry and it was acceptable to Senator Panizza and to the Democrats. Subsequent to that, I discovered that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs is required to look at all Auditor-General reports that deal with anything relating to Aboriginal affairs. Therefore, the matter that Senator Panizza has brought up as a term of reference is already to be investigated by the House of Representatives standing committee. I am not sure that insisting that finance and public administration persist with this inquiry is not duplicating something that already exists.

The next thing I did was speak to the chair of that committee, Mr Garrie Gibson, and ask him whether there was any way in which he could take over the thrust of the terms of reference. He agreed that his committee would look at the details. He cannot take over the terms of reference word for word and the Senate cannot require that the House of Representatives committee do so. Because his committee is about to visit Western Australia, and because there are coalition members on that committee who can pursue Senator Panizza's questions, it seemed to me that we were being asked to agree to the expensive duplication of an inquiry. I do not think we should do that. My last suggestion to Senator Panizza was that we simply put down notice of a motion—drawing attention to his terms of reference—and request that the House of Representatives committee consider the issues raised in that notice of motion.

It is not true to say that the FPA is urging us to refer this matter to it. That leads us back to these questions. Can it be done? Is it being done? Does it have to be done by this Senate committee? It does not have to be done by this Senate committee. We can achieve the same purpose by letting the House of Representatives standing committee continue with its inquiry and pursue this matter there. In fact, there are Western Australian coalition members on that committee who will be in a perfect position to raise the questions.

I am not seeking to deny an inquiry but there is just one other thing. Senator Panizza has had a lot of correspondence; we all have. I do not think it is right for us to let any individuals seek to use the processes of the Senate to assist them as candidates in an election campaign.

I can only say to Senator Panizza that we cannot agree to duplicate expensive inquiry processes when we believe that the matter can be handled, and can be handled thoroughly, by an existing committee in the other place. That is not to give up our jurisdiction; it is simply to say that we should be sensible about these things. If Senator Panizza insists on pressing on at this moment, I regret that because we have not found a more cooperative resolution we will be forced to vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In response to comments by Senator Kernot, I do not think the honourable senator should discount the possibility of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration coming up with recommendations, for example, for a more efficient delivery of services to people within the Aboriginal community. —by leave—I have listened carefully to what Senator Panizza and Senator Kernot have said and to the brief intervention of Senator Watson on this occasion.
