DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present report No. 1 of 1993 of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the examination of annual reports.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the ninth report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Super—supervision bills, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Background

Following the Treasurer's statement entitled Strengthening Super Security—New Prudential Arrangements for Superannuation, seven Bills were introduced into Parliament on 27 May 1993. These were designed to strengthen substantially the framework of prudential supervision for the superannuation industry.
One of the terms of reference for the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation was to report on this legislation and related matters.
The fundamental objective of these Bills is to introduce a comprehensive regulatory regime for the superannuation industry. Such a regime is required for three main reasons:

PARA.TAB: . to ensure that the tax concessions provided for superannuation are used for the purpose they were granted, that is, genuine retirement incomes purposes;
. to ensure the stability of the financial system in so far as it relates to superannuation savings; and
. to increase public confidence and security in the superannuation industry and, therefore, promote increased superannuation savings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation Industry Supervision, (SIS) Bills as they are known, represent the most detailed and far reaching attempt in the history of superannuation in Australia to impose a common regulatory framework on the superannuation industry.

The importance of such an undertaking is highlighted by the sheer size and complexity of the superannuation industry. Currently, superannuation savings in Australia amount to $169 billion, which is equivalent to about one third of Australia's gross domestic product (GDP), and are growing at a rate which exceeds even rapid economic growth.

The need for a comprehensive regulatory framework is further evidenced by the failure of a number of collective investment schemes, including a small number with a superannuation focus, in the past five years and problems in superannuation regulation in overseas countries which also have trustee administration of pension funds. These themes have been addressed repeatedly by the Select Committee on Superannuation during its two year inquiry.
The SIS Bills are designed to provide the Government with a more proactive and flexible role in the prudential supervision and control of superannuation.
Report—overview
Of the seven Bills introduced on 27 May 1993, the Committee has recommended that four be passed without amendment, namely:

PARA.TAB: . the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1993 (OSSA);
. the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill 1993;
. the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1993; and
. the Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has recommended that amendments be made to the following Bills:

PARA.TAB: . the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) (SIS) Bill 1993;
. the Superannuation Industry (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993; and
. the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation Industry (Supervision) (SIS) Bill 1993

The SIS Bill is the central plank of the new policy platform. It contains provisions which will radically alter the way that superannuation funds operate. Given the magnitude of the proposed change it was not surprising that the Committee received a large number of submissions, 97 in all, and agreed to take evidence from more than 60 witnesses representing the interests of superannuation providers, regulators and consumers.

Under the SIS regime all superannuation savings will come under the control and supervision of the prime regulator, the ISC. All superannuation funds will be managed by a single entity, the trustee body. The trustee body is required to make an irrevocable election to be regulated under the aegis of either the corporations or the pensions powers of the Constitution. All public offer superannuation funds, formerly regulated by the ASC, will also move to single entity status. Previously they were managed under a dual entity arrangement whereby control was shared by the trustee and the funds manager.

In taking note of the enormity of change in the public offer funds area, the Committee has expressed a concern that transitional arrangements may result in some uncertainty which has the potential to affect the fortunes of more than 200 000 unit holders of ADFs valued at least $14 billion. Accordingly, in the interests of promoting certainty and stability within the superannuation industry, the Committee has recommended that funds managers and trustees be accorded at least equal status during the transition process. This will be achieved by providing both trustees and fund managers with equal rights to request the other's termination of appointment.

The most emotive and controversial aspect of the SIS legislation concerns clause 64, formerly clause 62, which prohibits superannuation funds from acquiring assets from members or members' relatives. In the course of its hearings, the Committee heard detailed accounts of abuse of the tax benefits afforded to superannuation funds. The Committee has noted arguments both for and against clause 64 and has recommended that clause 64 contain certain limited exemptions which will be accompanied by an increase in the powers of the sole purpose test. This will provide the Government with certain checks and balances to protect against the abuse of the concessional tax treatment afforded to superannuation funds.

A further deterrent for potential clause 64 offenders is the custodial penalty that is attached to the offence. Although the Committee agrees that in some circumstances a gaol sentence will be appropriate, it is concerned that in other circumstances this could be too harsh. For this reason the Committee has recommended that the penalty for an offence under section 64(3) be amended to be a maximum of twelve months imprisonment and/or a pecuniary penalty.

The Committee has examined in detail the provisions concerning the role of auditors and actuaries. Taking into account the critical role auditors will play in determining whether there have been breaches of the SIS legislation, the Committee has recommended that the Government countenance having set terms of appointment for auditors of superannuation funds and that consideration be given to the development of a register of auditors. The Committee has stressed that superannuation fund audits should be conducted in accordance with the Australian Auditing Standards.

Another major issue arising from the SIS Bills concerned their application to State and Territory superannuation schemes. The States and Territories raised concerns regarding the imposition by the Commonwealth on their own superannuation schemes which are already the subject of legislation and are required to undergo audits by state Auditors-General. In light of these views the Prime Minister has written to the States and Territories recommending that State and Territory superannuation schemes be exempted from the SIS legislation. The Committee understands that the states will work towards harmonising their prudential arrangements so that they are consistent with the SIS provisions.
The Committee has also recommended that certain amendments of a technical nature be made in the following areas:

PARA.TAB: . the definition of investment manager and custodian be clarified together with the restrictions on borrowing and the capital adequacy requirements for custodians;
. the provisions concerning the use of Tax File Numbers (TFNs) be expanded in relation to their date of collection and use;
. the provisions concerning public sector schemes, State rights, funds with Substituted Accounting Periods and regulated superannuation funds be clarified;

. the powers of the ISC with respect to exemptions and modifications be extended whilst the ISC and Australian Securities Corporation continue to liaise with a view to harmonising Commonwealth powers; and
. minor technical amendments be made to improve the clarity of the legislation in certain areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation Industry (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993

In the course of its on-going inquiry into superannuation the Committee identified a number of issues of particular interest to consumers where reform is required. These issues are of interest not only to consumers but also to those in the industry who seek to provide a high standard of service to their clients. Of paramount importance in this area, is the establishment, and effective operation, of the proposed Superannuation Complaints Tribunal.

The Committee noted in its first report that the predominant view was that there was a need for the establishment of an independent dispute resolution body—something that would provide an alternative to the court system. The Committee is pleased to be able to support this legislation that establishes such a body.

This body, the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal, will review decisions of trustees that have been the subject of a complaint, and have not been resolved by the trustees' internal dispute resolution mechanism.

The Treasurer has indicated that the review of some decisions will be excluded from the Tribunal's jurisdiction. These `excluded complaints' will include cases involving disability issues. The Committee has recommended that cases involving disability issues should not be automatically excluded. Rather, so-called disability cases, where the complaint essentially involves a procedural matter and cases that involve questions of legal interpretation should fall within the Tribunal's jurisdiction. It is envisaged that in procedural matters the Tribunal will use its power to remit matters with directions to the trustees.

In order to achieve a structure that provides a true alternative to the court system, the legislation, as a rule, does not permit legal representation before the Tribunal, although there is a discretion to do so.

The Committee received submissions concerned about this provision and gave the issue considerable examination. The Committee was concerned to ensure that there was an appropriate balance between the objective of a fair, economical, informal and quick dispute resolution mechanism, and the necessity that consumers have access to appropriate assistance and advice in the preparation of their matters before the Tribunal.

For this reason the Committee was particularly attracted to the concept submitted by the Consumer Credit Legal Service of Victoria and the Consumer Credit Legal Centre of New South Wales. They suggested that an independent consumer advisory service, whether legal or multi-disciplinary, be established.

The roles of such a superannuation advisory service would include helping consumers to understand how to go about making their complaints; helping them to determine whether or not they have a legitimate complaint; and helping them to prepare the documents, the arguments and the proofs relevant to their case. The service would also play a role in the `macro' picture. By obtaining statistics and complaint data and by negotiating complaints, the service would be in a position to negotiate with industry and government in relation to changes in practice and policy.

Although the ISC secretariat is required by the legislation to provide assistance to complainants the Committee believes that it is important that there be an advisory service that is independent of the ISC. The Committee foresees a community advisory service playing a vital role in providing complainants with assistance in preparing their matters for review.

The Committee agreed that initially this service should be funded by way of grants by the Commonwealth. In the longer term the Committee believes that consideration should be given to having the superannuation industry assist with the funding of the service.
Conclusion

The Committee convened public hearings on these bills in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. In addition, thanks to the cooperation of the Government, informal meetings were arranged between the committee members and officers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission at which amendments to improve the legislation were discussed. Most of the amendments in the report have the in principle agreement of the ISC.

By virtue of its length and attention to detail this report will assist Senators in understanding the parameters of the new superannuation regulatory regime. I believe that, between the efforts of the Government in developing this package and the work of the Committee in acting as a sounding board for the superannuation industry, which includes consumers and providers, to ensure that the proposed law is good law, we now have the right policy mix.

I commend the report to the Senate and in so doing I thank Committee members, Senators Sue West, Bruce Childs, Christopher Evans, Alan Ferguson, Cheryl Kernot, and the secretariat staff, Richard Gilbert, Krista Gerrard, Glenn Hunter and Cath Drinkwater, for their work in developing a comprehensive report on such complex and far reaching legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL LEGISLATION (REPEALS AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1993WOOL TAX (Nos 1-5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1993AUSTRALIAN WOOL RESEARCH AND PROMOTION ORGANISATION BILL 1993WOOL INTERNATIONAL BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 October 1993, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of eight bills before us will reshape the wool industry along the lines recommended by the Wool Industry Review Committee, known as the Garnaut committee. The aim is to reduce to two the number of bodies dealing with wool—one for promotion, research and development and the other to pay off the debt and reduce the stockpile by selling a predetermined amount of wool. When the debt is less than the value of the stockpile—hopefully by mid-1997—the latter body, called Wool International, will be privatised and owned by the very people who paid the debt taxes.

PARA.TAB: A glance at the history of the wool industry reserve price scheme reveals that it operated for some 20 years before encountering a combination of difficulties in the early 1990s. These difficulties can be traced back to the 1980s, when prices for wool at auction increased dramatically, peaking at around 1,100c per kilogram. The reserve price, instead of being synchronised with the long-term price trend, was increased by about 60 per cent over two years to 870c a kilogram, where it remained for two seasons.

This increase effectively converted the reserve price scheme into a price setter and altered the price ratio of wool relative to other fibres. Instead of wool being around its historical price level—three times as dear as cotton—it became six times as dear as cotton, causing trade to shift to other fibres. Unfortunately, this shift coincided with the start of the world recession and the break-up of the old Soviet Union.

Figures show that in 1950-51 the total world production of fibres was around 10,332 million kilograms, with wool holding around 10 per cent of the market; man-made fibres, 16 per cent; and cotton, 74 per cent. By 1991-92, the total world fibre production was 39,151 million kilograms, with wool accounting for just 4.4 per cent; man-made fibres, 45.1 per cent; and cotton, 50.5 per cent. The floor price for wool meant that it was the most profitable farming enterprise with a guaranteed return and, as a result, many grain and beef farmers started running sheep.

Production rose rapidly, from 700 million kilograms in the late 1970s and early 1980s to 1,100 million kilograms in 1989-90, when 5.7 million bales were offered for auction. The Australian Wool Corporation bought almost three million bales, or 52 per cent of the clip, that year. In 1990-91, production was 1,066 million kilograms, with 5.4 million bales offered for auction, and the AWC bought almost two million bales, or 35 per cent of the clip. The federal government moved to lower the floor price to 700c in 1990 and by February 1991 had scrapped it altogether.

For equity reasons, the government continued to assist growers who had to sell their wool for that season. The cost to the federal government was $300 million. By that time, not only had the Australian Wool Corporation spent the $1.8 billion of growers' money it had in reserve but it had also borrowed $2.9 billion. The stockpile reached 4.5 million bales.

The federal government then formed the Australian Wool Realisation Commission to handle the disposal of the stockpile and to pay off the debt. It was determined that woolgrowers, although being required to pay off the debt, would cede ownership of the stockpile to the commission. The government established also a research and development corporation and the separate Wool Corporation to handle promotion and quality control. AWC stocks were frozen for the remainder of the 1990-91 season, with the exception of some long-term contracts and processed wool in stocks overseas. The government also gave the AWRC $22.5 million a year for two years to prevent it from having to hold a fire sale of its non-wool assets. A seven-year fixed repayment schedule was established. The schedule, which provided for annual payments ranging from $20 million in 1991-92 to $559 million in 1997-98, aimed to clear the outstanding debt.

The system worked well for the first 12 months, putting the commission ahead of schedule. However, a significant decline in prices over the following 12 months led to renewed speculation about a fire sale. The federal government tried to overcome the problem by adding a year to the fixed disposal schedule and declaring that nothing had to be repaid this financial year. The debt is now $2.2 billion, the stockpile is 3.9 million bales, and production, estimated at 690 million kilograms, is still falling.

In order to quash continued fire sale speculation—and encourage the market to forward buy—this legislation adopts the Garnaut committee's suggestion of a fixed disposal schedule, rather than a fixed debt reduction schedule. The legislation also provides for fewer statutory bodies by combining the AWC and the AWRDC into one body called the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, and abolishing the Wool Industry Council.

AWRAP will be responsible for the allocation of research and development funds and generic promotion, while other functions will go to industry or government or be abandoned. The organisation will be encouraged to seek partnerships with commercial research and development ventures and to commercialise results as quickly as possible so that industry can obtain royalties, patents and other benefits to help fund further research. The $20 million given by the government this year for wool promotion runs out on 30 June. The minister has already said that the government will not provide further funds. However, I remind the government that in its primary industry policy for the last election it promised to ensure that the industry had sufficient funds for promotion.

The International Wool Textile Organisation said that it was prepared to put in $100 million for generic promotion, but has since reneged because the government and, indeed, the coalition are not prepared to introduce a wool export tax. Such a tax would end up being paid by growers rather than processors. However, if the wool industry is to get out of this mess it must sell its stockpile, and promotion is desperately needed to help with this task. The government should look again at funding promotion.

The other major body to be set up under this legislation is Wool International, which will manage the sale of the stockpile and the payment of debt. Initially, it will be a statutory body. Legal advice is that, under company law, if the debt exceeds the current value of assets the directors are obliged to call in a liquidator. Eventually, Wool International will be corporatised and then privatised by issuing shares to the people who have paid the 4.5 per cent wool tax since July 1993. The target privatisation date, pending legislation, is July 1997.

Wool International's immediate task is to develop risk management tools, such as futures markets, wool bonds and options, as well as introduce total quality management programs. Apparently the minister plans to establish Wool International as soon as legislation is passed to allow it to take over from the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. This will allow more time to develop forward selling and risk management tools and ensure that it is ready to start the fixed disposal of the stockpile from 1 July 1994.

Wool International will have to make a simple public statement, monthly and then quarterly, on its compliance with the disposal schedule, but not in relation to stockpile management. It will report confidentially and regularly to government while the government guarantee is in place or, in other words, until Wool International is privatised. Far from being a day-to-day trader or market speculator, Wool International will have the power to buy in wool only in specific circumstances where sales exceed fixed disposal requirements.

The government will continue to guarantee the borrowings and will include the hedging activities of Wool International, as these are related directly to the financial management of the stockpile. The guarantee will not apply outside stockpile management. The minister has agreed that, if the debt is reduced sooner than anticipated, as would be the case if the price increased dramatically, Wool International can be privatised earlier.

The Garnaut committee considered six options for dealing with the stockpile and found that the long-term demand for wool would improve if at least half the stockpile were sold off rather than destroyed. The rationale is that Australia will find new customers and new uses for wool and thereby increase wool's total share of the world apparel market.

Under arrangements outlined in this legislation, speculators will hopefully see that there is money to be made in wool and start to invest. There will be no such investment if people are worried about the possibility of wool being dumped on the market to meet a repayment schedule. My colleague in the House of Representatives, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), put it thus:

SPEECH.PARA: The Garnaut report now moves the wool industry into the commercial world. I hope the future of the wool industry is secure after 1997 with few statutory bodies; with quality standards enforced at the shed level and through processing; with wool growers maintaining their 4.4 per cent of the total fibre market; and with a free market for wool with no levies imposed by either the government or their own organisations.

PARA.TAB: I now wish to turn to the amendments that were moved in the House of Representatives. I am pleased that those amendments, which were foreshadowed by the coalition, were accepted by the government following negotiations with the coalition and input from the Wool Council of Australia. The amendments included the creation of selection committees to nominate persons suitable for ministerial appointment to the boards of Wool International and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, with the Wool Council nominating one member for each selection committee. Previously the minister was to appoint all board members. The amendments also included the retention of provisions allowing the Commonwealth to contribute money for wool promotion. Originally these were to have been phased out. The amendments also include calling on AWRAP, which is wholly funded by grower levies, to consult with the Wool Council of Australia regarding its operations, and extending the deadline for AWRAP to divest its quality management functions by one year to 1 January 1996.

Finally, I would like to reflect on the Senate's Rural and Regional Affairs Committee, which last week heard views from various people in government and industry ranging from selling the stockpile for 150c a kilogram to wanting none of the stockpile sold unless it made 600c a kilogram. Economist Mr Henry Haszler told the committee that wool used in insulation batts had sold at $1.50 a kilogram and that such alternatives were, in his words, `worth considering' in relation to the stockpile. By contrast, Mr Gregory Walcott of the Balmoral branch of the Victorian Farmers Federation argued that the break-even price for growers was about 600c. His counterpart, Mr Allan Small, also expressed concern about the level of wool debt and advocated that the government and industry take on, in their words, `combined responsibility'. Perhaps Professor Ross Garnaut best summed up the situation when he told the committee:

The preparation of the report itself and the subsequent discussion have occurred against a backdrop of deep economic travail in the wool industry and in rural Australia, and that made us very much mindful of our heavy responsibilities. We did not find a magic wand to wave and cure the problems.We did come up with a set of recommendations which, we judged, if implemented consistently and effectively, would give us the best path out of the current difficulties. Always judgments were on a balance of probabilities because there was no magic wand and there are uncertainties, but we were confident about our path being better than alternatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite many submissions, there were no new workable ideas at that hearing or at the 25 meetings held around Australia by the coalition shadow minister for primary industry, Mr John Anderson. We are pleased that the government has already accepted our amendments and that the Senate committee has returned the legislation without amendment. For these reasons, the coalition supports this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Legislation (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1993 and associated bills are to give effect to the popularly known Garnaut report. The Australian Democrats want to put on record their recognition of the amount of work that has gone into this and the dire situation that faces the wool industry unless quite radical measures are introduced as soon as possible. I refer to the Senate committee inquiry held last Friday and commend to honourable senators the report that came out of that committee as being very well worth reading. It gives a very good summary of the concerns raised at that inquiry. The report is worthwhile reading for anyone interested in primary industry and the wool industry in particular. I believe that all the witnesses helped our understanding of this important matter.

PARA.TAB: I note that serious concerns were raised in that committee hearing by the Balmoral branch of the Victorian Farmers Federation, the Victorian Farmers Federation itself, the National Council of Woolselling Brokers, the Australian Council of Wool Exporters and other people, including Mr Malcolm Fraser. On the other hand, the legislation as it is before us has been supported by many people, including the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Wool Council of Australia and most of the peak bodies, the government, the coalition and, of course, Professor Ross Garnaut himself.

The Democrats support the general thrust, but we do have some reservations, and I will detail these a little later on. Already, conversations with the Wool Council and the coalition, with our support, have resulted in amendments which I believe improve the bill. Two further amendments which I will move at a later date will improve the legislation even further, and I seek the support of the Senate for those. Parliamentarians of all political persuasions are committed to getting the industry back on its feet, and certainly the Democrats are. The plight of the industry is well known. In the first speech I made in this parliament, I detailed some of my personal contacts and the agony I experienced listening to people's stories. One cannot remain unaffected by the personal tragedies in the community which the legislation we are dealing with today seeks to mitigate.

I should like to read into the Senate Hansard some of the evidence given by a woolgrower from south-western Victoria, Mrs Margaret Watt, because I believe that, as she indicated to the committee, it puts a human face on our discussions. This is what she said:

The Garnaut report suggests a price improvement in the long term. Our real concerns are that as rural communities we are fighting to survive in the short term. There is a very real despair, a despair born of weariness and disillusionment, which is eating away at communities. Even reading the Garnaut report, far less trying to understand it, is beyond many. I am sure that I do not speak just for our woolgrowing community in that regard.

The constant pressure that is building up for farming people to meet their interest payments and their budgets is really eating in. Costs, therefore, are being cut back. The result of that is that ordinary working farming families are taking on heavier workloads. There is further physical exhaustion and mental exhaustion resulting. Government cutbacks are further eroding what were once very viable communities.

SPEECH.PARA: I want the Senate to know that this debate is being conducted against that background of rural communities which are past desperation point.

PARA.TAB: Let me turn now to some of the specific issues. In terms of the fixed release schedule, we support its general thrust but we still have some questions, and these were underlined by the evidence given in that Senate committee inquiry. The question we still ask is whether it is good commercial practice to determine months and even years ahead how much of the stockpile we are prepared to sell. Professor Garnaut and others believe that it is necessary to regulate the market in order to give it certainty. Others raise the problem of applying mathematical formulas to markets which do not respond to fixed mathematical regulation in this way.

There is a problem with the fixed release schedule. It does not take account of types of wool in the stockpile, and these ought to be in rough proportion to what the market requires. I am reassured by conversations I have had with representatives from the Wool Council—they have been most helpful—that they will take on board the concern about the types of wool, as part of the management of Wool International and its management of the stockpile. I note that there is a requirement for Wool International to report monthly to the minister.

I believe that our amendment strengthens the purpose of the fixed release schedule. It also provides two safety mechanisms. The first is an upper market indicator of 800c, if the market overheats. We know that overheating in the market is not good for market stability and people begin to shift to other fibres because of it. Our proposal would enable Wool International to release more from the stockpile to dampen down the market if this happens. The second safety mechanism, a lower market indicator of 400c—we hope the market will never again reach this low figure—will send a signal to the market that Australia will not permit a fire sale of its valuable asset.

The present decline in production was another concern that was raised. We believe that the legislation needs to send a signal to growers to maintain and lift production. These signals must give confidence to the market, and to growers, so that production will continue. Last year, production was a little over 800 million kilograms. This year, estimated production is around 690 million kilograms or less. It is important that we have signals to secure production, and these must be part of the whole exercise equation.

We have some concerns about Wool International. The legislation will give effect to the establishment of Wool International as a government instrumentality until the stockpile is under control, and then it will be privatised by issuing shares to growers and others in proportion to the amount of wool tax they pay. We have a concern that, if growers experience liquidity problems, they will sell the shares and that the very good thrust of this legislation, which places control and ownership in the hands of growers, will be lost.

We believe that, if non-growers begin to purchase the shares in Wool International, control will pass from growers and will be concentrated in, perhaps, transnational agribusiness or in the hands of a few of the very large growers. It seems to us that Garnaut even suggests that this could be desirable. On page 6 of his report he states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Price Scheme. . . discouraged the emergence of large, integrated multinational companies in the wool industry. The large integrated companies that play a major role in promotion, research and development in the cotton and synthetics industries, have no counterparts in wool.

Professor Garnaut then goes on to decry this. The Democrats do not accept Professor Garnaut's analysis of the desirability of having large integrated multinational companies in the wool industry. Indeed, we believe that the long-term best interests of the wool industry in Australia are assured by the present situation in which the majority of wool growers are family farmers and, therefore, part of the network of Australian small businesses. These concerns are expressed by this industry and other rural industries in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have been corresponding with people in Europe, in particular with a German economist and theologian by the name of Ulrich Duchrow, who has worked for the World Council of Churches and for the Lutheran Church in Germany. He has drawn my attention to the Aachen declaration, which was made in Europe in July 1987. It was a declaration by farmers and consumers for a new agricultural policy. This declaration is available, if honourable senators are interested in it, in both English and German. In commenting on the declaration, Dr Duchrow writes:

SPEECH.PARA: The capitalisation of agriculture has led to its industrialisation and to transnational agro-business, which results not only in hunger in the two-thirds world but also in driving farms (apart from big industrial ones) into debt and destroying them, in the progressive degradation of the land's natural basis, in dangers to the health of consumers and, specially in the EC, in the fleecing of taxpayers. This state of affairs is well known. It is equally well known who profits from this: agro-business, the banks and the big industrial farmers.
That sounds familiar. It will be an important debate for another time.

PARA.TAB: Other issues are the buy-back provision for Wool International to cover any shortfall in a fixed schedule period and the provision in the legislation for Wool International to initiate an active futures trade. The Australian Democrats' amendments seek clarification and an assurance from the government that it will cover any trading losses that occur in the trade of wool stocks or futures until Wool International is privatised. It is unrealistic to expect woolgrowers to fund these risky activities as they are being imposed on Wool International by the government and not by the growers themselves.

A parallel concern is that the 4.5 per cent wool tax has been accepted by growers as a necessary means of servicing the stockpile debt but not to fund risky Wool International activities. It is not too much to suggest that it may be more just to return surplus wool tax to growers than to allow Wool International to use the levy to play with the market. It is the belief of some that a viable futures market will happen when certainty is given to the market and the stockpile is reduced. In conclusion, I assure the Senate that the Democrats support all attempts to bring viability and profitability to the wool industry and to all rural industries. We support the thrust of this legislation. I call on all honourable senators to support our modest amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak on a wool matter, probably for the fifth time in the last three years, I must start off by declaring my interest as a woolgrower. The wool legislation is the fifth major package of legislation that has been in front of the parliament in the last three years. I know it is easy to say `I told you so', but I did say on those five occasions that we were not going down the right track.

PARA.TAB: I have just listened to Senator Woodley's contribution to the wool debate. Even though I agreed with most of what he had to say, because it is evidently the way we have to go following the Garnaut report—which I support, if not fully—I believe that he is attempting to go back to something we had in the past. What has been wrong with the situation we have had in the last five years, since that disaster of May 1988 when the decision was taken by the Wool Council to increase the reserve price from 690c to 870c? That was probably the most disastrous decision the wool industry in Australia has made. Unfortunately, it was supported by the minister at the time, Mr Kerin. I note that Mr Kerin spoke on the matter in the House of Representatives but he did not quietly back down or admit the mistake he had made.

To return to the point, Senator Woodley's amendments tend to do what we did before—leave a back door open for escape. Let us this time fix the situation forever and not leave a back door. If there is a back door for escape, world traders in wool will be waiting for us to open that back door and we will be off again. I believe we have got to stick fully with what Garnaut has said.

You do not need me to tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Australian woolgrowers are in an extreme situation, especially where there is no other industry they can turn to. There are not many woolgrowing areas of Australia where something else cannot be done, but there are some, such as the Murchison among the pastoral areas of Western Australia, where one cannot hope to run cattle. In certain rainfall areas of Victoria, as in South Australia and some of the medium rainfall areas of Western Australia, one just cannot run cattle and it is too wet for grains except maybe coarse grains.

For the farmers who cannot do anything else, the situation is very bad. There are farmers having either to move off the property or to find something else to do, hoping the wool industry will come back. The wool industry will come back. It has come back every time. With the right sort of legislation, the right sort of scheme, we will be able to do it.

At present we have a stockpile of some four million bales and a debt of roughly $2 billion. What has been driving the price down in these last few months is that we have annual repayments to reduce the debt. That may have seemed in order when we last debated here, but I certainly questioned whether it would work. As we approach that repayment schedule, the pressure is on. The buyers know that we have to sell more assets. Assets can be sold only once. We can sell more wool that is growing on the sheep's back—that keeps coming in, even if it gets less and less—but once the assets have been sold, they are gone for good. The government did alleviate that one payment last year. I thank the government for its consideration in doing that; otherwise wool would have been driven further into the ground.

We have to get away from that situation. The situation has been helped by the Australian wool production. I think Senator Woodley got his figures wrong there. We are down now to 690 million kilograms of production, and that has helped. We would have had to meet a debt rescheduling payment of $600 million this year—$200 million for interest and $400 million—which we would not have been in the position to do without driving wool production down.

The government could have imposed up to 15 per cent tax if we had stayed in that situation. It is presently at 12 per cent. We had a special one-off 13 per cent a couple of years ago and we have 12 per cent at present, but the government could go to 15 and then really drive wool through the ground.

The Garnaut report recommends reducing the bodies to one called AWRAP for promotion, research and development, and another one—Wool International—to take over management of the stockpile. It has already been pointed out that, when the stockpile is removed, that will go private. The shares will be issued according to tax paid by growers between now and 1996 or 1997, or whatever it is. I believe that is a top idea because they are the ones who have to meet the payments and take care of the stockpile. It is fair that they will be issued the shares, because the ones who built up the stockpile between 1988 and 1990 were fringe woolgrowers who came in from the cattle industry and other industries to get on board something that had a fixed price, a bottom price. Now a lot of them have gone.

I have no fears. There are a lot of fears being expressed around the country about Wool International but, as Senator Tambling pointed out, if the stockpile is in manageable proportions by then it can be privatised straight away. I am not one of those who believe that in two years time we will not be able to supply all the wool needed. Colleagues such as Mr Sinclair propose that; I normally do not disagree with what he has to say but this time I do. If we cannot supply it because of that fixed schedule of reduction, what a good problem to have. That is something we have to stick to. As I said, we cannot have a back door.

We have a fixed schedule of reduction by the number of bales. It is 27,000 to 29,000 per month between July 1994 and December 1994, plus or minus five per cent. Of course, they can sell more than that after 1 January 1995, but Wool International has to buy back what is coming off the sheep's back. That has got a side benefit that I have not heard mentioned yet: it freshens up the stockpile. A lot of the stockpile is deteriorating; it has been in store a long time and the steel bands are rusting and staining. If Russia comes in and wants a million bales, it can be bought fresh off the sheep's back. It does help to freshen that up, because I believe that is a problem.

There are a few things I would like to address quickly. Firstly, we will be helped by increasing our price if we can get the balance between what is going on in the market and the demand. Australia sold 890 million kilograms last year. We have been helped by the fact that Argentina has dropped production from 200 million kilograms to 90 million kilograms annually and South Africa has dropped from 100 to 65. We have been helped in all those areas, and I believe we should stick to this. Some of my colleagues believe we should have a minimum reduction schedule and not a fixed one. We cannot get away from that. I am on record as saying that, and I want to put it on record again.

I wish to express the worries of the wool industry about the ever rising costs. We did get extra costs put on us in the last budget sitting which, unfortunately, we have to accept. Shearing costs have to be looked at. This year, shearing costs are generally 40 per cent of the clip. I have declared my interest; I am a woolgrower, but in my family I have very little to do with the industry. One thing I do is write out the cheque at the end of shearing. I see the cheques that come in; I bank them when the proceeds of the wool clip come in. I know that 40 per cent is eaten up by that alone, whereas in New Zealand the costs are 33 per cent less. In Australia it costs roughly $3 a head to shear a sheep on full contract; in New Zealand it costs 60 cents. That is for shearing only. The cost is double that. So it can be done in New Zealand for $1.20. There is a vast difference between the two, and we have to look at a way to get that down, but not by cutting shearers' rates. The one lot in Australia who earn their money are the shearers. There are other ways, such as addressing the costs of transport and so on.

I do not want to delay the Senate. I fully support the position taken by the government and I fully support Garnaut. Let me stress again that we should not leave the back door open this time. Let us stay with it, and we will have a good industry again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to start my abbreviated contribution to the consideration of this package of wool bills by declaring an interest in the wool industry and by congratulating and thanking John Anderson, on behalf of all growers, on the effort he put into explaining and listening to growers right around Australia. In attending 25 or more grower meetings, and in countless other industry consultations, John Anderson set a standard of commitment to the Australian wool industry for which all of us—politics apart—should be grateful. He will be one of our leading ministers when we win the next election.

PARA.TAB: This thanks to John Anderson should also be given to him by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). If the minister had been prepared to explain Garnaut and foster the industry discussion that was necessary, it would have been very much appreciated. As for Garnaut's explanation to woolgrowers, Minister Crean was absent without leave. But I do congratulate the minister on his setting up of the review committee; its members, Ross Garnaut, Rod Price and Stephen Bennett; the general thrust of its reforms; and the speed of change that will flow from the recommendations.

Every one of the 65,000 woolgrowers out there has the capacity to contribute more to reducing our foreign debt and creating the common wealth of the nation than any government senator. Whilst Australia no longer rides on the sheep's back, it was a much more prosperous country when we did. Having said that, and with the reservations about the wool package, which I will highlight, the time for political and industrial debate is over for the time being.

These proposals have had over two months of intense industry and academic scrutiny. While there are various views as to how successful the stockpile reduction program will be, almost everybody agrees—from the peak grower body, the Wool Council, down—that the existing debt repayment schedule is not a goer. It is not sustainable, and has to be changed. The time to build up is now in the hands of the industry. At the same time, responsibility for how we descended into this awful crisis remains very much with this Labor government.

During 1989-90, as highlighted by my colleague Senator Panizza, the reserve price scheme came under extreme pressure for all the reasons well debated over the last four years. I understand the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, was advised that there was no way the reserve price could be reduced from 870c to 700c clean, and the scheme survive. Further, the minister said that the price of 700c clean was immutable. This famous political promise will live forever in the minds of growers and the world wool trade where, until recent times, your word was your bond.

The world wool trade, at the time, did not understand the concept of a political promise as the Australian Labor Party does. John Kerin, therefore, bears a very great responsibility for the debt, as does the government he served. After all, it is the debt and who will service it that is the problem—not the existence of the stockpile, which remains an asset. Whilst I favour the quantity based disposal schedule, some argue that any quantity to be sold from the stockpile, in any period, should be a minimum amount only, and that flexibility should be provided to allow additional quantities to be quit if market circumstances permit. This is the concern if there is an immediate boom in prices. There could be an indicator price that is going through the roof and there still be 3.5 million bales in the stockpile.

The opposite view is often taken, funnily enough, by the same people—that is that if demand is relatively weak, a fixed quantity disposal will only depress prices further. If the price of wool recovers too quickly, then Wool International can be privatised. Further consider that at a modest current value of $500 a bale—and there are nearly 4 million bales still in the stockpile—the market indicator only has to move a small amount from the current disastrous 470c clean to get past the current $2.2 million debt. So to give the stockpile a real value is only an eye blink away.

If the price is relatively weak, then the Garnaut proposals fall over. But I do not believe that the price will be weak because of the current fall in physical production. I do not believe that the downside risk is as great as the potential upside, and the most attractive option therefore is to go with Garnaut.

Even if there were a real and properly argued alternative to Garnaut, it would not stand up because this government will not bail the costs of the stockpile indefinitely. Growers cannot afford the present rate of wool tax so it is impossible for them to contribute more, as is permitted under the existing legislation—up to 15 per cent from the present 8 1/2 per cent that they are paying. I reiterate: the game is up for wool under the existing arrangements. This is the best alternative.

I see two requirements for Garnaut—firstly, from the growers' point of view, an early increase in price so that the industry can survive; and, secondly, from the trade point of view, a stable and steady price. To a large extent, the interests of both growers and processors should converge. Garnaut offers this chance because he offers a type of Clayton's stockpile—a stockpile you do not have when you do have a stockpile. It will allow market forces to be as close as they will be when the stockpile no longer exists. Those signals will be to both the growers and the trade. The amount of wool sold will depend, as always, on production and not on a fixed amount coming out of the stockpile. The `risk management tools' proposed by Garnaut will be an important part of reducing the effect of the release schedule's market influence.

By allowing a fixed reduction which, as I have said, is fortuitously attached to a substantially reduced physical production, with the threat that the stockpile can be used to fill immediately gaps between supply and demand—there is enough wool in the pile to fill an awful lot of gaps for a long time—there is little chance of a significant price increase. This will no longer be the case.

The big change between the start-up scheme of a debt repayment schedule and a stockpile reduction arrangement is this: in 1991 the government said to growers, `You pay off the debt but you will give the ownership of the stockpile to the AWRC'. Professor Garnaut says that, on the balance of probabilities, there will be value in the stockpile if handled the way he proposes. I believe him. It is only fair, therefore, that traditional woolgrowers—the only people still growing wool and therefore carrying the debt of those who have taken their profits in better times and have now left the industry—should have the chance of equity in their stockpile.

I turn now to some particular concerns about the proposals. Both the Garnaut report and the minister emphasised the need to make the wool industry `demand driven' rather than `supply driven'. However, it is extremely disappointing that a government which so vocally supports a demand driven wool industry has just ceased all government contributions to wool promotion, since this is a vital way the government can assist the industry. While the legislation has been amended in the House of Representatives to allow the Commonwealth to contribute funds for wool promotion, Minister Crean has made it perfectly clear that that will not be done. He says, `Rid me of responsibility for this troublesome beast. Rid me of any responsibility for wool'. This is despite Professor Garnaut having said on promotion:

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly unfortunate that at this difficult time Australian wool growers should be left to carry the burden of promotion alone.
The report went on to say:
This heightens the importance of contributions from textile manufacturers.

It surely does, but the government bears an enormous responsibility as well. It cannot and must not walk away from an industry that is gasping for breath, needs to be market driven and has paid a lot of tax when times were better, and whose prosperity is essential for control of government liability with respect to both RAS funding and social security payments.

PARA.TAB: I cannot leave promotion without making a personal comment about the vast amount of money—over $500 million since the 1980s—spent to promote wool. I wonder how much more successful the promotion would have been if performance based private firms had been given the task. As a woolgrower, I do not feel that I have had value for money. In fact, I feel the opposite. Let us hope that the IWS and other commercial promotions that come out of the AWRAP will be more successful.

I want to make some quick comments which are of great importance to the debate. An enormous amount of damage has been done to the wool industry and all export industries over the last few years by the sorts of economic circumstances in which the industry has operated. High levels of inflation relative to those of our competitors have pushed costs up at a time when growers have been least able to cope. The stripping out of the indirect taxes, as we proposed in Fightback, was of enormous attraction to growers. The cost savings which New Zealand has accomplished—as raised by Senator Panizza—through the implementation of a similar tax regime, has enabled growers there to be substantially more competitive, both in shearing costs, where about $100 million per year would be saved if that regime were implemented here, and in transport costs, which from farm gate to wharf are about two times less than in Australia.

There can be few pats on the back here for the government. When the minister talks in glowing terms about value adding, he knows more than anybody—as a former president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions—why Australian scouring, top making, spinning and weaving processors have voted with their feet and have gone offshore. They have gone because of our intolerable industrial relations record and work practices. The best thing he can do for value adding in this country is to clean out the industrial relations system.

I am grateful for the opportunity given to me by Riverina Wool Combing and Canobolas Top Making to see their operations. I commend them for the way they have shown initiative in this most difficult business, especially considering all the impediments put in their way. Riverina Wool Combing's spending of about $30 million to set up another scouring line is a remarkable vote of confidence in the industry at this time. It has great confidence in the future, as I do.

TALK.START.PARA: —If this package of wool bills goes anywhere near alleviating the appalling doldrums in which the Australian wool industry finds itself, it is timely that this legislation be passed. Unfortunately, the Australian Labor Party government has alarmingly demonstrated what it thinks of wool and the wool industry. We have seen the government put on the guillotine not once but on both occasions in recent times when wool bills have come before the other place. That is an indication of what the government thinks of the wool industry and those involved in it.

PARA.TAB: It is also regrettable that today in this chamber we have only limited time to consider key aspects of this industry which is of such great importance to Australia. This government has presided over some of the most appalling days of the wool industry's history. In the late 1980s, the floor price went from 460c to 870c a kilogram in just three years, at times when not only this government but industry members also participated in knocking the industry from its solid foundations. It does not matter how one looks at the situation, the government has a moral obligation and an economic responsibility to attend to the current crisis within the industry.

It has not just been the actions of those involved in the industry that have led to its current circumstances. Probably the worst aspect of the gradual destabilisation of the wool industry has been the interest rate regime of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who jacked up interest rates in past years. That was devastating to many industries but in particular to the wool industry, and it caused many of the growers to leave the industry. It has also crippled financially a good many of them for many years to come.

Australia has been left with a wool stockpile of over four million bales and the debt is still $2.2 billion. The cost of interest and storage on the stockpile alone amounts to about $200 million a year. Very little wool has been sold from the stockpile over the past year, predominantly because the Wool Commission only sells above the auction price and for cash. It is not so much a case of the nation riding on the sheep's back these days but more a case of the wool industry struggling to carry the entire weight of an overburdened and overtaxed nation on its own.

Such is the grim picture of the wool industry in Australia. There have been few moments in the six years that I have been in this place when the Australian wool industry has not found itself in the spotlight or in some difficulty or crisis. The Keating government itself once again realised that it was in strife in the wool industry when, a little over two months ago, yet another review into the wool industry was handed down in an attempt to reconcile the situation in which the industry and the government have found themselves.

An immense amount of hype has surrounded the industry in recent years. For a very long time, the industry has admitted to being production focused, concentrating on producing wool and improving quality. Brokers have focused on advancing the industry by making improvements to handling and sampling the product in wool stores. Exporters have concentrated on improving delivery while competing in an ebbing market with a diversity of customers, who range from those using very high-tech operations to those using 80-year-old equipment.

The Australian wool industry has been inward looking. It has been working to its own schedule and it has been fulfilling its own requirements first. As a result, it now rests in a precarious position. It has been suggested that the industry has not been able to deliver a product, either constantly or consistently, to customers' mills and that this has produced, in customers, a lack of confidence.

The report resulting from the Garnaut inquiry is set to restructure the industry and set it on its feet again—a feat that both the Hawke and Keating Labor governments have found impossible, despite repeated attempts to get it right. This Labor government has consistently got it wrong. Let us hope the improved industry communication will instil confidence and send a message to industry customers that we are now ready to meet their requirements head on.

Although woolgrowers are still in deep financial trouble, and have cut right back on wool production, there is still too much wool in the stockpile and too few serious buyers of the calibre that the industry needs to sustain it. Let us hope that the Garnaut report will set this situation right. Clearly, we have to sell the stockpile to revitalise the industry, otherwise the industry will never again enjoy the eminence that it once had in former days. This package of eight wool related bills seeks to restructure and streamline the industry so that it can begin its path to recovery and regain its premier position in the international textile market.

Despite numerous botched Labor government attempts to kick-start Australia to develop a sound manufacturing base, we are still relying too much on natural resources. We should be looking at value added industries developing from the resources themselves. The concept of value adding is a good one, but it must be done at competitive rates. Many countries buy our raw materials simply to give work to their own people. We run the risk of cutting off our markets if we deny them those raw materials. If we cannot value add here as cheaply as it can be done overseas we reduce the competitiveness of our raw products and that must not be allowed to happen.

We are an exporting nation. We should be able to emerge as the producer of superior quality value added products which attract premiums and deliver decent returns to producers. After all, we export virtually all of our wool and cotton. Only five years ago, we earned over $6 billion from wool: it was our number one export. Today that figure has been halved. Less than 18 per cent of the woolgrowers of Australia produce more than 100 bales of wool a year. That means that 82 per cent produce less than that each year. That is a lot of small operators and small businesses.

But the sad thing is that life on the land in many sectors of rural industry has deteriorated to a parlous state. About 28 per cent of farmers feel like giving life on the land away completely and 20 per cent would walk away if they could. Thanks to this government's mismanagement, farming profitability is at an all time low—rock-bottom. In the past three years, specialist woolgrowers have accumulated huge business losses of around $107,000 for each year. Specialist sheep producers will lose, on average, about $36,100 this year.

The essence of Garnaut and this legislation is to change the management of the stockpile. At present, the stockpile is poorly managed by the commission. Because it has an excess, buyers do not have to buy in bulk and they know that they can return for more at any time. Buyers are reluctant to hold their own stocks or buy well in advance. Last year only 20 million kilograms, or 100,000 bales, were sold. This represents only 1.15 per cent of the world's wool production. It is highly unlikely that the wool industry will recover until the stockpile is reduced by more than half, about two million bales.

Professor Garnaut and his colleagues on the inquiry put forward and analysed six options for dealing with the stockpile, but chose out of those options to recommend selling wool according to a fixed quantity schedule. The Garnaut view is that long-term demand for wool will be better placed if half the stockpile is sold, rather than destroyed—as some have suggested—since new customers and new uses for wool will be found.

Although some growers, as well as wool brokers and exporters, have reservations about the recommendation for fixed stock disposal, it is the best available option—25,000 bales a month, commencing next month, until June next year, then 55,000 bales a month from next July to June 1997, disposal being based on the tender process. This will account for 190,000 bales or 38 million kilos of wool, but disposal will be no longer be guided by a fixed repayment schedule. The debt repayment schedule will be abolished and Wool International will establish a wool futures market and improve other means of transfer of wool ownership, such as loans, options and bonds.

If the Garnaut report recommendations encourage people to invest in forward contracts and futures, and if speculators see that there is money to be made in wool and so invest, the stockpile will eventually dwindle. But there will be no investment if buyers worry that wool will be dumped onto the market just to meet the requirements of the debt repayments schedule. Given that woolgrowers throughout Australia know very little about the detail of what the Garnaut report contains or proposes, it is understandable from the meetings of growers that I have attended at Burra and Naracoorte, in South Australia, that they are concerned about the release system.

In world terms, supply is way down in comparison with recent years. In both South Africa and Argentina, our other major competitors in the industry, it is down 35 and 45 per cent respectively. In Australia it is down 69 per cent. If that is the case, wool may be in greater demand than the fixed release from the stockpile will supply before the financial year is out, because the fixed release scheme is based on the fact that the current annual production around the world is down to the point where a fixed release scheme does have a chance of working.

At any rate, given the misfortune that our once great Australian wool industry is now experiencing, the sooner the stockpile is released, the better the future prospects will be. The stockpile is costing growers money—to the tune of about $60 per bale or $200 million a year—to store. And it is costing growers in a psychological sense. It always hangs over their heads, and it psychologically depresses the market to know the size of this glut. The wool industry cannot afford to return to the old boom and bust era, where the price goes up if supply drops off and consequently no-one buys wool, so production falls and the price falls, ad infinitum.

The government must press on with reductions in protection, which impose enormous costs on woolgrowers. Wholesale sales tax puts an additional $200 million impost on our farmers—about $1,600 per farm per year. The government has added at least another 10 per cent a year to those costs in the current budget. We are certainly not doing much for the competitiveness of wool against other fibres by adding 5c a litre to the cost of fuel. And shearing currently takes about 40 per cent of growers' returns from wool.

Does the government honestly believe that the industry can soak up these costs when it is assailed by drought, international depression and recession, and international competition? The government taxes wool producers when it hits the transport industry at three times the rate at which it taxes other industries. Given the disastrous manner in which this government and past Labor governments have dealt with the industry, I can only hope that this package of legislation at long last will assist the industry in a speedy recovery. Therefore, the legislation is worthy of our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens do not intend to oppose this package of wool bills. We understand that the bills are designed to enact the outcome of the Garnaut report and it is my understanding that the Garnaut inquiry was designed to address some of the problems which are being experienced by the wool industry in Australia. The concerns that I express are not so much about what is in the report and, therefore, this series of bills, but what has been left out, either by the limitations of the terms of reference or by the fairly narrow, uncreative response to those terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: There are two questions I would like to ask: firstly, is there a wish to create employment in the wool industry; and, secondly, is there a concern about the viability of the industry? Obviously, those have been addressed, but I wonder whether all of the possibilities for either employment or viability have been canvassed in this solution.

One problem that has not been properly dealt with is the lack of recognition of the local market and value-added production, and regional based solutions to the wool stockpile. Like most people in this chamber, including Senator Chamarette, I have received briefings on the wool industry by the National Farmers Federation, by the Australian Wool Council and by government. I have been approached by a number of people who work in enterprises which use wool, an example being the Weavers Guild in Western Australia. Its members have told me that they find it very difficult to get hold of wool in the quantities they require. When they do get hold of it, it is extremely expensive. I cannot help but wonder why.

I have been told that it is not viable to sell wool in those quantities. In regard to the potential for highly value-added enterprise, I have been told that the local market is a very small proportion of the total market for wool in Australia. I agree, but I do not agree that that means that we take away the emphasis from promoting what is possibly a viable local market, with the potential for value-added industry and employment creation, for assisting regions where wool is a major industry, and for developing an export industry where exports are a major concern.

Export industries do not necessarily just develop as export industries. In Australia over the last couple of years, where people have decided to make highly value-added, high quality products from Australian wool, export markets have developed quite quickly. To me, the very narrow focus of selling the clip has overshadowed the fact that promotional funding for the local market means that one is jumping a step. The viability of the industry cannot develop bottom up; perhaps we are looking too much from the top down or looking too much for the big picture rather than looking at the potential for regional approaches which enable a greater spread of employment within the industry.

The kinds of enterprises that I am talking about also mean employment potential for women and young people within regions. This report has not adequately addressed those kinds of employment opportunities in the wool industry. They are just as important in providing employment. In my opinion and from the figures that I have seen, the industry holds the potential for greater employment than is currently available just through wool growing and concentrating on wool only as an export commodity.

It has been suggested that, while the stockpile is being privatised, there is no role for government in providing grants for new enterprises which are prepared to create employment in the wool industry. If the actual amount of wool on the local market is not very large, one would welcome the provision of wool grants by government to private industry to encourage new enterprises or enterprises which currently use wool to create employment and new products. The potential for government to encourage enterprise using wool grants, even if they are only temporary grants, is great. I have heard on national radio these kinds of solutions canvassed by women in the industry. It seems that the men are not listening because they feel that the greater picture is what they have to concentrate on and that the smaller picture is not worth looking at. I think that is a mistake. These other creative solutions have to be looked at more seriously and given more time.

I want to talk about the lack of recognition of the local market and the need for the wool industry to seek an integrated regional approach, to look at some of the problems on the farming side of things and with the industry's viability. People have heard me talk about agroforestry before. I know that it is not necessarily applicable in every area and to every climate type, but agroforestry—I saw it with my own eyes last week in Bridgetown—can increase farming income.

TALK.START.PARA: —You go somewhere else, not just Karratha, do you?
—Yes, I do.
—I thought it was Margaret River.

—Margeret River, too. I do a lot of travelling around my electorate, as it happens. Agroforestry has the benefits of providing extra income for farmers and extra environmental paybacks in improved land and water quality and viability in the long run. This report shows a lack of recognition of the environmental aspects of integrated land care and also of the economic aspects which affect the long-term viability of this entire industry.

PARA.TAB: The rangelands that provide ecological support for the wool and cattle industries in Australia comprise approximately 55 per cent of the land mass of our continent. Due to inappropriate management practices on sheep and cattle stations, it is now estimated that more than half of those rangelands are substantially damaged—much of it beyond repair. The destruction of the ecological systems in these areas should be viewed as asset stripping. Any management approach that advocates increasing stocking rates to improve profitability is a very short-term approach and is certainly not sustainable. Unfortunately, in recent times when prices have been high people have increased stocking. When prices are low people increase stocking. Eventually the land cannot take it any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you add fertiliser, too, when the stock goes up.
—That is right.
—It balances it out.
—In some ways. The ecologically sustainable working group report on agriculture states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is more important to plan a sustainable future, to understand that some current practices need to be discarded, that others need modifying to reduce or eliminate undesirable side effects, and that new and better approaches need to be developed. In particular a more holistic approach is promoted, using whole-farm and regional planning linked to a total catchment or similar identifiable ecosystem.

Industry, the environment and government work together. This is important. This is not just a farm issue, an industry issue, an environmental issue or an economic issue. It is the linking of those issues which seems to have been missed in this report and in these bills. In that context, I agree with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who stated in his second reading speech on the Wool International Bill:

. . . the food and natural fibre industries . . . present . . . the most exciting development opportunities for this country, with the potential to substantially increase value adding, exports and the jobs that go with such developments.

I would suggest, however, that such opportunities are at best short-term unless the pastoral industry acknowledges the need for an ecologically sustainable approach to its industry. As Richard Ledgar, an environmental scientist and land management consultant, stated earlier in the year on the Lateline program:

We are not taking seriously the ecological part of the sustainable development and sustainable land use that was the basis of the agreement between the conservation movements and the National Farmers Federation.
There are people talking about sustainable pastoralism but what we have got to talk about is ecologically sustainable land management.

The Greens would welcome government initiatives that assist the pastoral industry to move to an ecologically sustainable basis. Unless such initiatives are implemented as a matter of urgency, the wool stockpile that is subject to this package of legislation will continue to grow until such time as the ecological systems that support this industry collapse entirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have before us a package of eight bills to establish a new institutional structure and marketing arrangement for the wool industry. Before proceeding further, I wish to declare an interest as a very small wool producer. At the same time I wish to bring to this debate the perspective I have gained from over 12 years involvement in the wool processing industry. The enterprise I was associated with had 83 per cent of the schoolwear market in Australia and extensive exports to Japan, Hong Kong and elsewhere. I hope that that joint experience will bring a balanced perspective to what the government is trying to achieve.

PARA.TAB: The Wool International Bill 1993, the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993, the Wool Legislation (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1993 and the Wool Tax (Nos. 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1993 were introduced into the House of Representatives on 30 September. The package of bills establishes a new institutional structure and marketing arrangement in the wool industry. The four statutory wool industry organisations which currently have responsibility for marketing and promotion, research and development, and development of industry policy will be replaced by only two—the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, which will be responsible for generic promotion and research and development, and Wool International, which will market the stockpile and foster the development of risk management and marketing mechanisms.

Honourable senators will be aware of the approach I have taken and the concern I have had in relation to realisation of the stockpile in the past. It has not been a marketing exercise but it has been done on a liquidation approach, and I think that has been one of the devastating features of the previous arrangement. Currently, the wool stockpile is 3.9 million bales, or 693,000 tonnes, approximately one year's worth of production, and it carries a $2.2 billion debt.

Uncertainty was created in the wool industry following the issue of the Garnaut report on 30 August this year. There is stability in the trade at the moment and wool prices have risen, particularly from the perspective of my own home state where wool markets have turned around for the better and we now see wool on a slow climb, particularly for the finer micron fleeces. I believe that these bills will provide only an imperfect, short-term solution to the ailments of the industry, not a long-term solution. They do provide, nevertheless, a strategy for disposal of the stockpile, but I doubt whether they provide a strategy for the long-term planning of the wool industry.

This position was also recognised by Malcolm Fraser. In a recent article in the Australian he was reported as having made the comment that he believes the Garnaut report has the potential to damage the industry and he is concerned that that report has been so widely accepted. I share those feelings. It is almost like clutching at lifebuoys without being aware of the weakness of the rope that is intended to bring the survivors to the security of those who have been throwing out the lifelines. It is no use throwing out lifelines if that rope is too fragile and has the potential to break.

The various groups involved in the wool industry—growers, processors and exporters—have been vocal about their attitudes to the Garnaut report and the wool legislation. The concerns of wool exporters in particular should be taken into account more than they have been at the moment, because they are ones who every day put their capital on the line and manage the risk so that woolgrowers can, without risk, receive their cash on their wool sales within a few days.

For too long the wool producers and the wool exporters have operated independently of each other. These two groups need to cooperate and start working together for the benefit of all involved in the wool industry.
