The Australian Council of Wool Exporters has complained that the government's latest plan has ignored the views of all customers and will mean more volatility in the market. It is also concerned that Wool International is empowered to buy wool if its sales or deliveries against any of its forward-selling instruments exceed its schedule.

The establishment of Wool International is provided for in the Wool International Bill 1993, which sets out its functions, powers, membership and related matters. Wool International will be responsible for the selling of the wool stockpile, subject to the fixed disposal schedule, and fostering the development of forward and risk management mechanisms such as wool futures and marketing mechanisms. Initially, Wool International will be structured as a statutory body but along commercial lines to reflect its ultimate transformation, first, to a fully government-owned company and then later to a privatised company. The target date is July 1997.

At the time of its privatisation it is intended that shares will be issued to wool tax payers in proportion to the component of the 4.5 per cent wool tax they pay for debt management as from July 1993 and any voluntary contributions they make. But here I have a problem. The grower funds, compulsorily levied to fund the stockpile, are to be used to fund Wool International, a trading and financial corporation which is essentially going to compete with the private sector. The fixed disposal schedule suggested in the legislation introduces a slight variation to the Garnaut recommendations—27,700 to 29,100 bales a month from July to December 1994 and 182,000 to 192,000 bales a quarter from January 1995 to June 1997 or until Wool International is privatised.

I draw now on the experience of a very successful small private buyer with which I have a lot of association—Saunders Mitchell Pty Ltd. This firm has been a successful exporter from my home state. It has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Some important (and welcome) changes have been made to the conditions under which the stockpile is sold and to the prospective activities of Wool International. Thus the fixed schedule selling program will not commence until July 1994. Until that time the agreed and understood policies of the AWRC will be followed. This is just as well because under the original proposal only 40KT could be sold out of the stockpile. With a forecast clip of 690KT this would have given a maximum availability of only 730KT. Compare this with the 826KT sold to the trade last season, and we had the potential for a massive market squeeze.
Surely some flexibility in stockpile selling must be considered when we are looking at possible market opportunities out to four years hence! Not according to Mr Crean!

. . . Wool International will be still permitted to buy in to balance `excess' sales, this power will be `narrowly defined'. Wool International will not be involved in price support or day to day buying activities.

This `narrow definition' needs defining . . . Wool International will be a commercially-orientated organisation with a clear charter to reduce the industry debt—yet still not allowed to sell more than 33KT per quarter. It hardly makes sense.

As Malcolm Fraser points out, selling a certain fixed quantity of wool every month for the next three to four years, regardless of market circumstances in Australia and overseas, is an abdication of commonsense and a denial of the exercise of judgment which is very hard to comprehend. The Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association has expressed concern at the following:
. . . excessive control of the Government and the Minister of the day and the lack of opportunity for those operating in the industry to determine its future.

One of the association's major concerns is the board structure and the selection criteria for the boards of Wool International and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation. The New South Wales Farmers Association has also expressed concern over this issue. The TFGA has suggested the following:
. . . it is essential that beside the Chairperson there must be two persons on the Board of AWRAP with woolgrowing expertise . . .

. . . the bills be amended to provide for a selection committee process for the Boards, especially the Board of AWRAP . . . these bodies are grower funded and woolgrowers are seriously disenfranchised.

There is a need for balance. This matter has partially been addressed by the amendments to the Wool International Bill proposed by the government or perhaps pushed by my colleague the shadow minister, the honourable member for Gwydir, Mr Anderson, who has contributed significantly to this overall debate. I pay tribute to his work, particularly in discussing the issue with so many farmers all around Australia. My congratulations to Mr Anderson.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments to part 5 require the minister for trade to take into consideration nominations by a selection committee in making appointments to Wool International and the procedure for the establishment and operation of a selection committee. Also, proposed amendments to part 6 of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993 require the minister to take into consideration nominations by a selection committee in making appointments to AWRAP and to establish a procedure for the establishment and operation of the selection committee.

Even if these amendments are successful, growers and the trade will not have knowledge of wool sold and still held in the stockpile by Wool International. This cannot give certainty to the wool industry. The Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association was also concerned that there be continuing consultation between AWRAP and growers in the future and for Wool International to consult with the WCA during its period as a statutory body.

The government introduced a number of amendments to the bill whilst it was in the House of Representatives. The proposed insertion of clause 10A authorises Wool International to consult with organisations representative of different sectors of the wool industry, including the Wool Council. Proposed clause 10A of part 3 of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993 provides for a consultation by AWRAP with the Wool Council before giving corporate plans to the minister. Processors are fed up with the chaos created through constant change in government policies. They fear that the acceleration of stockpile sales would have a devastating effect on prices and push too many growers out of the market. The IWTO has said that a fixed quantity disposal policy is both bad marketing and bad debt management.
Woolgrowers, on the other hand, generally support the bills. I have received representations from the New South Wales Farmers Association stating:
The association is broadly supportive of the legislation and would wish to see it enacted as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the concerns of the NFA include the manner of appointment to the board of the AWRAP, that the provisions for performance of industry functions, including quality assurance, are not accurate, and that fellmongered wool and wool exported on skins have not been included in the collection base for wool tax for promotion. I ask the minister to consider the issues I have raised in this important debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because I think the issues in the bills and the main points behind them have been well covered. I wish to make a few comments in fairly general terms. I do not oppose the legislation; I am part of the organisation that has agreed to accept it. However, I am not keen on it because I do not think the legislation was framed with a view to trying to resolve the problems of the farmers. It was framed to try to get the government off the hook, and it does that satisfactorily. If it takes the government off the hook, there is no alternative than to believe that it puts the industry back on that same hook.

PARA.TAB: When I talk about the industry I mean the whole industry, from the people who grow the wool to the people who ultimately wear it. One of the problems we have suffered in Australia for many years is that the group who publicly consider themselves to be the industry—the growing part of it—are not doing justice to the people who look for the customers, do the manufacturing, get the product out, get the best price the market can stand, and so on. Greater consideration has to be given to the fact that we are all in this together. Whether they are fine producers, coarse producers or superfine producers, whether they are in knitwear or growing, whether they are scourers or weavers or shearers or breeders makes no difference. It is one industry from top to bottom, and the success or failure of any one of those sectors impinges on every other sector.

I believe that this has been one of the great weaknesses. Not long after I came into this place, I spoke on a wool bill and referred to the work being done by the processors. I was invited to the headquarters of the Wool Corporation for lunch. I thought it was very nice of them, as I had spoken on the wool bill only once at that stage. But I was called to the Wool Corporation to get a smack across the knuckles for having dared to give some credit to the wool manufacturers. I was told that Australia did not want or need a wool manufacturing industry; that it was our job to grow the wool and other people's jobs to manufacture it; and that I would be much more help to the industry if I ceased giving support to the processors.

All that did was encourage me to support the wool processors even more than I had in the past. I have supported them ever since and I will continue to do so while I am here and beyond. I believe that Australia has a tremendous potential. It is commonsense that we should improve our processing sector. We should give every encouragement possible to people who are prepared to add value to this great product. Not enough has been done in the past, and I cannot see that anything in this legislation will do anything to encourage greater on-processing than we have been able to get in the past. We have had these differences between the various sectors blown up in a way that tries to pass the responsibility or the blame from one to the other. Every time we do that, the whole of the wool process from start to finish suffers, and that achieves nothing for anybody.

I have been fortunate over the time I have been here, since 1975, to have spent a lot of time with the wool industry. It was a hot subject in 1976 and since then it has always been on the agenda. We have interviewed many people here and all over Australia. I have been fortunate to see the processing industry in different parts of the world. I have seen it in the United Kingdom, mainland Europe, North America, Taiwan, China, Japan, New Zealand and Australia. I suppose I have seen most of the wool manufacturing plants in Australia and a good few in other places.

We do not have any God-given right to produce wool, but we do have an incentive to use it and to see that others use it. However, it has to be demand driven. There has not been nearly enough concentration on seeing that we get the marketing and processing of wool in better shape. Right now we must get more wool into use. There is no point in doing a silly thing like stacking it up in sheds and pretending that it is not there, as we have done in recent years. We have to get it out and get it in use. We have to do more research, and still more research.

For goodness sake, let us not allow this present kerfuffle to restrict the research we are doing, or the research we have done in the past. We know what the pros and cons of wool are; we know the things the customer likes and dislikes. We are still not doing enough to remove the things that are causing difficulties with the marketing of wool. We have to do more in those directions. We have to work cooperatively with the growers, the processors and the customers.

I have discussed with buyers for some of the major retail chains in the world why they buy or do not buy wool. I have discussed with manufacturers the proportions of wool they use in their blends. I have discussed whether the proportions go up or down, and whether that depends on price, availability or what. I am concerned that the marketers of wool in Australia are not getting their wool close enough, early enough, to where the users are. It is all very well to have wool in the shed in Australia, but if the marketer happens to be in Northern Ireland or Czechoslovakia it is not much use to that marketer if he has to pay for it two months in advance.

We have to be more concerned about how we supply the needs of the people who want the wool. We have markets for hand knitted wool jumpers in Japan; we have markets for machine knitted jumpers in Switzerland and places like that. We have to look at every little niche that we can and encourage every producer to be more conversant with the market. We have been through a patch where for over 40 years the people who produced the wool had no idea. They had very little interest in what was happening, and that is not good enough. We must have the producer ready to take over and see that he is growing what the customer wants and marketing it in the form that he wants.

I do not care how the customers want it. If the customers want it done up with blue string, they can have it with blue string. If they want it in plastic bags, they can have it in plastic bags—anything at all. They are the customers. For too long we have decided that we did not really need the customer, that we were producing the miracle fibre. It is no miracle fibre to anybody down the line unless we make it so and unless it is delivered the way the customer wants it.

The Garnaut report will not fix anything in itself, but it does show the way that things can happen. All I can do is appeal to the various sections of the industry to work together, to cooperate more, and to regard the customer as the ultimate. If we do that, we still have time to make the wool industry the sort of industry that we would like to think it is.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in the matters of public interest debate to bring to the attention of the Senate a very serious matter in relation to the impact on the Australian pulp and paper industry of imported uncoated wood-free white paper, generally referred to as A4 copy paper. My concern is that it would appear that this product is being imported in a climate which affords unfair advantage to overseas producers and which places an unfair burden on local producers.

PARA.TAB: The unfair advantage I refer to arises out of a combination of factors. The first of these is that major importing countries such as Indonesia and Brazil benefit in the form of reduced tariffs from their developing country status in the Australian market, when at the same time the tariff is being progressively reduced to only five per cent by 1996. Direct subsidies by overseas governments to the paper making industries to assist exports are coupled with high tariffs protecting their domestic markets from imports, including imports from Australia. They also have less stringent environmental and labour force protection requirements. These factors combine to aggravate deliberate, aggressive marketing strategies, in effect dumping white copy paper in Australia to the detriment of local producers already suffering from the Australian and worldwide economic recession.

As members of this house are aware, I have long advocated the use of our natural resources in a manner which strives for ecological and economic sustainability and which maximises adding value to our raw resources—in this case, quality paper coming from our forests. Although in terms of action there is still a long way to go, it is fair to say that the states, the federal government and the forest based industries have come a considerable way in Australia in recent times in recognising the imperatives and the advantages of an ecologically and economically sustainable approach in the development of a national forest industry.

In addition to this, as encouraged by the federal government, the pulp and paper making companies have undergone extensive restructuring and rationalisation to become internationally competitive. In the case of APM this was effected by cooperation and negotiation with unions which accepted considerable job losses in the interests of the long-term viability of the industry. APPM unfortunately took a less cooperative path. It is untenable that these gains—largely at the expense of workers' jobs, but also through workplace reform management practices, multiskilling and improved health and safety results—are now being eroded by unfair competition.

It would appear that due to the combination of factors I have outlined this whole shift to more efficient production, more effective resource use and more environmentally friendly practices is being greatly jeopardised. Over the next few minutes I will expand on these factors one at a time. However, first I would like to bring it to the attention of the Senate that imports of white A4 copy paper have been the subject of a recent dumping inquiry.

The preliminary finding by the Australian Customs Service was that the Australian industry had suffered material injury caused by dumped imports of A4 copy paper from Brazil, Finland, Germany, Indonesia, South Africa and the USA. Pending final recommendations from the Anti-Dumping Authority, provisional anti-dumping measures were due to be imposed from 16 September 1993. These provisional measures are in the form of penalties to import companies, and are likely to be sufficient to prevent further dumped imports except in the case of Indonesia.

In the case of Indonesia, there is some concern that the information customs officers were able to collect was insufficient to make an accurate base calculation from which to assess the dumping margin. In addition, there has been considerable lobbying, such that the imposed penalty has been adjusted several times. It has been indicated by the Indonesian government that the penalties will be totally absorbed without changing the selling price. This will lead to a ridiculous situation whereby penalties imposed to overcome dumping actually increase the relative price advantage of one of the offenders. It has been put to me that there is a strong case for the Anti-Dumping Authority to undertake a fresh investigation with respect to Indonesia. I concur with that view.

I return to the factors that I outlined earlier. I raise in the first instance the matter of developing country preferences. The purpose of this scheme is to provide a margin of preference to internationally classified developing countries in the Australian market. Amendments in February this year removed the developing country preferences for a number of Australian industries—for example, clothing, textiles and footwear, chemicals et cetera—in all but the least developed countries. Pulp and paper were not removed.

It is contended by those who argue that they should be removed, that the pulp and paper industries in countries that benefit from developing country preferences—in particular, Brazil and Indonesia—are far from developing industries and by world standards are large, technologically sophisticated, and heavily capital-intensive. They are, in fact, highly competitive by international standards. In 1992, Indonesia accounted for more than 60 per cent of the paper and board production of the South-East Asian region, including Australia. Given that Indonesia and Brazil currently hold a significant share of the Australian uncoated, wood-free paper market—in the case of A4 copy paper, over 70 per cent—I tend to agree that the matter of the pulp and paper industry and developing country preference needs to be urgently reviewed.

I mentioned earlier that these overseas, large-scale operations enjoy considerable support from their governments in the form of subsidies, export incentives and tariff protection. As an illustration of the disparity on tariff alone, the tariff for A4 cut size copy paper from Indonesia to Australia is seven per cent. As it benefits from developing country preference, it has a 42 per cent cost advantage over other, non-privileged importers. In fact, Indonesia imposes an effective 45 per cent barrier on paper imports. Australia is the only country in the Asian region which has adopted a policy of zero tariffs. If Australian industry is to rise to the challenge that this policy imposes it cannot, at the same time, contend with dumped imports that undermine market share, and thus the ability to make necessary improvements or reinvest in local expansion.

This is a serious concern. Not only does this have economic impacts, but I suggest it has grave environmental and social impacts, both within Australia and in the exporting countries. In conditions of unfair competition, as stated, 700 jobs are directly at risk. In addition, many times that number in indirectly related jobs, and jobs from future expansion of the industry, are at risk. In terms of our foreign debt, expansion in this industry is very desirable. In 1991-92, imports of printing and writing paper totalled in excess of 490,000 tonnes with a free on board value of $670 million. The free on board cost excludes freight and insurance costs.

The continuing dumping of copying paper also has implications for our ability to increase the recycled content of our paper used in Australia. Of further concern is the environmentally damaging harvesting methods of countries such as Indonesia and Brazil. Critics have raised issues such as rainforest removal, social dislocation, loss of native flora and fauna, erosion and water pollution. These practices are coming under some pressure for change, but the less stringent environmental regulations currently afford further cost advantages. Similarly, exploitation of the indigenous work force means that wages are low and conditions are poor. By not acting to ensure paper products are not dumped in Australia, we are not only failing to protect our own economic, social and environmental interests, but failing to perform our international, environmental and social responsibilities as well.

In conclusion, if we were to take the actions I have outlined, I believe they would remove any remaining excuses that forest based industries have for not investing in paper making facilities in Australia, rather than seeking to expand exporting of woodchips. Instead of unions, environmentalists and large sections of the community opposing a proposed enormous woodchip mill in north-west Tasmania, all of those forces could positively combine to urge the company concerned to invest in a paper mill using less natural resources while producing more jobs and wealth for Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, on Wednesday evening, there was a fire on Beecroft Peninsula at Jervis Bay. It appears the fire started at about 8 p.m. when a so-called `star shell' from HMAS Derwent lobbed into bushland at Honeymoon Bay, a tiny and beautiful inlet on the eastern shoreline of Jervis Bay. An area of heathland measuring a little under one square kilometre was burnt out.

PARA.TAB: Beecroft Peninsula defines the north-west side of Jervis Bay. It is an area of substantial beauty and ecological value. It is also of great importance to the Jerringa people who live nearby and who have retained strong links with the area. Beecroft is rich with the relics of their ancestors, and has many sites of continuing spiritual significance to them. But Beecroft is also a defence area. About 10 per cent of the peninsula is a gunnery range which is regularly bombarded during naval and air force exercises. The remainder is used from time to time for army exercises in which such things as amphibious landings are practised.

Last week's fire was the result of a naval bombardment which went wrong. In fact, the star shell appears to have landed between three and four kilometres from the boundary of the impact zone. It is extraordinary that such a huge error was made. There is no official word on the damage that was done by this fire; although, we do know that new bushfire control tracks were hastily created to help put the fire out. We may never know the impact on the birds and animals in the area because a comprehensive fauna survey has never been conducted. It is likely that the burnt out area is a home for rare bird species, particularly the eastern bristlebird, which is the most endangered bird on the Australian mainland. There may also be endangered animals living there, but no-one knows for certain.

This fire could have been much worse. Had it occurred in summer, it could have affected a far greater area, like the January 1991 fire which destroyed 12 square kilometres. Had the wind been blowing in a different direction, it would have swept through areas which are of great significance to the Jerringa people. I am not suggesting that this fire was in itself a major disaster but it could have been. Furthermore, it is not an isolated incident; unplanned fires caused by naval bombardment have become an annual event. I have already mentioned the huge fire of January 1991. In December last year, about two square kilometres were burnt out when a navy target flare set fire to bushland during a period of high fire danger.

In May 1991, major environmental damage was caused by an army exercise called Operation Termite Spray. Army trucks removed sand from a beach; new tracks were bulldozed; trees were cut down; an Aboriginal midden at Honeymoon Bay was removed to make way for a shower/laundry complex; seagrass meadows were destroyed; and tracked vehicles were driven through wetlands of ecological significance. My colleague Senator Coulter had a lot to say about this at the time.

Some local defence people have tried to excuse the accidental fires by claiming that the area's ecology is fire dependent anyway. I will respond by making two points. First, fire dependent areas will only retain their value where firing takes place under an ecologically based fire management plan; where fires are timed to cause maximum benefit and minimum damage; where the area to be burned and the rate of burning are controlled; and where firefighters are on hand before a fire is lit. Random unplanned fires which require an emergency response are not the way to manage such an area.

Second, there are vegetation communities and endangered species on Beecroft which, if destroyed by fire, will not recover. There is a patch of remnant rainforest on the peninsula which is testimony to that fact. There used to be more rainforest on Beecroft Peninsula, but much has been lost through fire. I have a copy of a map of Beecroft which dates back to the 1960s and was produced by the Currarong Bowling and Recreation Club. There is a note on the map which laments:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the wholesale destruction by bushfires, numbers of which occurred between December 1942 and December 1946. Most, if not all of these were deliberately started by persons . . . or their agents . . . interested in obstructing the campaign for public parklands. Probably the greatest loss was the rainforest belt of Bindijine Heights and lower Duck Creek, and the flowering heathland [around] Currarong village. These things never can be replaced.

Last week's fire left local people asking whether history is repeating itself. Because of the frequencies of fires and damaging exercises, they are becoming convinced that Defence is deliberately degrading the area, with the aim of undermining the campaign to include Beecroft Peninsula in a Jervis Bay national park and marine reserve. I should make it clear that I have no reason to believe that the recent fires were deliberately lit, but I do ask whether the tempo of Defence activities on Beecroft has been raised to underline its control over the area.

PARA.TAB: In my view, Defence's use of Beecroft Peninsula is becoming increasingly inappropriate. The local Aboriginal communities, including the Wreck Bay people on the south side of Jervis Bay, have bitter memories of being driven from Beecroft by navy bombardment. It is an affront to the reconciliation process to continue the same offensive activities in the 1990s. It is an affront to the unique ecology and beauty of the area to continue to use it for military target practice. It is even more offensive that not only is the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) stepping up these activities but he is also pushing for the proposed east coast armament complex to be located at Jervis Bay, with Beecroft Peninsula earmarked as the site for the armament wharf.

The Democrats fervently hope that cabinet will make the minister see sense on this issue and strike Jervis Bay off the list of possible ECAC sites. That would remove a major obstacle which is preventing the resolution of the Jerringa people's land claim. It has also stalled the establishment of a national park and marine reserve. At present, there is a short list of four possible ECAC sites—Jervis Bay, Twofold Bay near Eden, Point Wilson north of Geelong and Port Curtis near Gladstone. Senator Ray has stated his intention to reduce the list to two sites and to subject them to separate environmental impact statements before making the final choice.

It is no secret that Senator Ray intends to make Jervis Bay one of these sites. There are rumours doing the rounds that the other one will be Twofold Bay. If that is the minister's plan, then it is a transparent attempt to give cabinet no choice but to select Jervis Bay as the ECAC site. As the minister knows from the recent interdepartmental committee which examined the ECAC alternatives, Twofold Bay is out of the question unless the Harris-Daishowa woodchip mill closes down in the very near future. As much as the Democrats might welcome such a development, we cannot see it happening in the near future, and I am sure the minister shares that view. A choice between Jervis Bay and Twofold Bay seems to us to be no choice at all.

Indeed, the minister's plan for two separate EISs on two sites is fundamentally flawed. Two independent studies will not allow the two sites to be compared and the best site identified. That can only be done by an integrated assessment. The Democrats favour an inquiry under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. We believe that the inquiry should be conducted by a three-member panel: a chairperson skilled at public consultation, one member with environmental expertise and another with a background in defence.

In our view, the inquiry should take a long, hard look at the merits of Port Curtis, particularly given that it could be an excellent long-term home for the east coast fleet. We believe it should also consider Port Wilson, but only with the strict condition that an ECAC at that site should not obstruct the relocation of Melbourne's Coode Island chemical storage facility away from urban areas. It should examine Twofold Bay, although, as I have said before, the prospects of an ECAC at that site do not look good. It should also have the scope to examine other sites and other proposals such as the Australian Conservation Foundation's suggestion of a purpose-built armaments facility. But Jervis Bay should be struck off the short list. It is time to recognise the unique beauty, ecology and heritage of the area and to provide the protection which is long overdue. The minister is right to point out that past occupation by Defence has saved Jervis Bay from—

—Yes, proceed, Senator Woodley.

—I take note of the point of order. I believe that the minister has been using the defence department for a certain purpose at Jervis Bay, which we disagree with. We hope that cabinet will act in the interests of reconciliation and the environment. The Democrats will continue the pressure to make sure that the right decision is made.

—I rise to speak about air safety in Australia today because I have got some real concerns about it. The fact is that the assurance of safety has been degraded by the actions of the Civil Aviation Authority in recent years. I am not saying that there are no safety procedures left in aviation. I am saying that the procedures and the practices, which provided a cushion for air safety operations in Australia, have been greatly reduced by the activities of the CAA in recent years. That is a tragedy: the primary role of the CAA—in fact the only reason that the CAA exists—is to provide safe air navigation within Australia. The drift that we have seen simply cannot be tolerated any longer.

PARA.TAB: Within the last week, we have seen reports of two very distressing accidents where a large number of lives have been lost. The first report relates to a Monarch Air Services flight flying into Young. The other report relates to two young Australians who lost their lives on a flight between Sydney and Forbes. Both of them relate to bad weather but, beyond that, there are great differences in the operations of the two flights. I will come to the Monarch flight at a future date.

I want to deal today with the loss of the two young Australians on that flight to Forbes. I believe it is a reasonable proposition that, since they survived the crash, they might well have been alive today if they had been found promptly. I stress that I do not know their condition after the crash—how badly injured they were—and it may well have been so bad that, even if they been picked up by a helicopter immediately afterwards, they would not have survived. But the general proposition is that, if someone survives an aviation accident, and if they can be found in time and get medical attention, there is a good possibility that they will survive. There is a tragic parallel here with the Stinson crash in the late 1930s on the Lamington Plateau. Again, you had bad weather and high ground. In the case of the Stinson, two did survive the crash but there was a very long delay in finding them. Surely we have learnt something, in nearly 60 years of aviation in this country.

My question to the Civil Aviation Authority is this: why was a flight plan not put in for that flight? The answer to that question is quite simple. People do not fly on flight plans today because it is too impractical to file one. The majority of people flying in Australia today are private VFR operators, which is what this pilot was. It is very easy for an airline captain, or an air force pilot or a charter operator to file a plan. Further, they are obliged to do so by law. However, private pilots are actively discouraged by the Civil Aviation Authority in filing a flight plan. They are told it costs the system $150 to file a plan. I find that a nonsensical statement.

The CAA must have looked at its bloated overheads, divided it by the number of operations that it can identify that it performs and come up with this figure. If it costs the CAA $150 to file a flight plan from me, it really ought to be shut down and put out of business. I reckon I could do it for no more than a dollar. But this is all part of the doctrine of affordable safety that Australian aviation is now suffering under.

Two days after this aircraft was lost, one of the papers reported that over 50 aircraft—fixed-wing and rotary wing—were involved in a search that extended over 40,000 square kilometres. How many years of filing flight plans would equal the cost of that search? And that was only the first two days of the search! It is one of dozens of searches that take place each year in Australia.

The great majority of pilots who fly in Australia fly in the category `private VFR'. Most of them spend their time flying in the circuit; they just do not have the money, with the huge cost of aviation today, to fly cross-country very frequently, and it is when they go cross-country that they get into trouble. They get into trouble because the CAA has changed all the air traffic control procedures, and has not had an effective education scheme to educate pilots about what the new procedures are. What the CAA is trying to do has my full support. I think that what it is trying to do is laudable, but the way it is going about it is absolutely horrendous. The way it has managed changes to the air traffic procedures in Australia is absolutely incompetent.

In Australia we have told generations of pilots that first of all they should get the weather information—and it is self-evident why one should get weather information before one flies long distances—and, secondly, that they should file a flight plan so that someone knows where they have gone. There are lots of benefits from filing a flight plan. First of all, one sits down and works out whether one can actually get to where one wants to go with the winds there are, and whether one has enough fuel on board. That is a very effective discipline in itself. It guarantees to some degree that the flight can be operated safely. The second thing is that if someone files a flight plan, it is a discipline on him to follow the tracks that he has put on paper. If he does not file a flight plan and he is flying from here to Parkes or Dubbo, he really is under no compulsion to follow a straight line or a predictable course because there is no reason to do so.

Before the CAA started these changes, in every airfield that had a manned tower, a pilot could walk in and get the weather, or could phone that tower and get the weather. A pilot could walk in and file a flight plan or could phone the tower there and lodge a plan. Most importantly, he could talk to a briefing officer. He could say, `I have not been into Rockhampton for 12 months. I want to fly from Archerfield to Rockhampton and I am going to go into Bundaberg for fuel. What do I need to know?'. In 30 seconds the briefing officer would say, `Your frequencies are so and so, call here and call there'. Not only would he be safe, but all other users of the airspace would be safe as well.

Nowadays, the system is totally different. I cannot go to an airfield in Australia and get the weather. I have got to have a PIN number, and I have got to have a fax machine. I have got the facility to phone for the weather information, but if I do that I will be talking to one operator dealing with a large part of the country, and I might wait for a very long while before I get through.

The same applies for flight plans. I have got to file with a fax machine. If I am travelling around Australia, perhaps staying in a motel out in a place like Forbes, I cannot communicate that way. Most of those places do not have fax machines. If I want to phone in I have difficulties, because the access is limited to one or two operators. If I try to do it by radio, I run into the problem that the CAA actively discourages people from filing a plan. I think that is totally unacceptable. People in the private VFR category now are not telling other people what they are doing.

We have to add to that the great changes that have taken place in air traffic control procedures. We have MTAFs and CTAFs and airways clearance procedures have been changed, and changed dramatically. And remember what I said before: a pilot can no longer go to a briefing officer at an airfield and be told what the changes are. He cannot even get a reference document.

Before the CAA messed all this up, we all had visual flight guides. A VFG was a simple book which, in plain language, dealt with every aspect of VFR flying in Australia. If a pilot could not talk to anyone, he could open the book up and be quite safe and be quite precise in what he was doing. The CAA got rid of the VFG. Somehow or other it just was not politically correct in the affordable safety, user pays doctrine that now governs the CAA. The authority issued instead RACOPS and the AIP.

I have been flying for 30 years, so I think I know a little bit about VFR operations, and I find both documents absolutely useless and incomprehensible. They do not tell me what I need to know to operate safely around the country. I will give a simple point on that. If I look up the index of one of these publications I find that it says `Documents to be carried in the aircraft in flight'. I turn to the relevant page and the relevant paragraph, and under `Documents to be carried in flight' I find `see Civil Aviation Order such and such'. That does not help me in any way at all.

Added to all of this is the fact that the user-pays doctrine has put quite a heavy premium on documents supplied inefficiently by the CAA. Most private pilots do not bother. I would be one of the few people around the place who pays $100 or more a year to keep up-to-date with documents, the great majority of which I never use and am unlikely to use.

Finally, there is the cultural change in the CAA itself. The aviation community, compared to other sectors of the community, is an above average and conscientious group of people. Their education levels, by the very nature of their occupation—whether they are maintaining aircraft or flying them—are above the community average. They are people who conscientiously want to conform and do the right thing. There are always a few bad eggs, but they stand out because the aviation community is so small.

Once upon a time the department of civil aviation worked in cooperation with the industry. It led by example, it counselled people and it advised them. We now have in Australia a totally aggressive CAA which will take people to court at the drop of a hat, fine them thousands of dollars for trivial things, pick on the weak and the harmless, and never go after the bad eggs that are around the place because they are too difficult to take to court. We have this openly aggressive situation now between the aviation community and the CAA which is totally antipathetic to good relations and safe operations. There is no reason for that at all.

I am astonished at the number of people who fly around Australia and who, in response to air traffic control inquiries, glibly give false call signs. They might say, `This is Bravo Alpha Whisky' when they are `Sierra Alpha November' or something. I got a bill for operations in Cairns and I had never been remotely near the area. The call sign of my aeroplane was given by someone else. I am incredulous that pilots in large numbers are using false call signs around Australia. It was absolutely unheard of a few years ago. The reason they are doing it is that they do not want any contact with the CAA at all. One opens journals like AOPA and finds correspondence there from honourable, respectable solicitors advising members of AOPA to have no contact with the CAA at all, to `maintain silence if they talk to you'.

We have to have a radical change in the way these things are done. Where we have fields with manned towers we have to have an easy and practical facility to be able to get a weather forecast and lodge flight plan; you need someone to talk to. At the same time, accessible phone links have to be established—not one person dealing with half the country—so that people can phone in or radio in for this information and file this information when they need it.

We certainly need a cooperative approach from the Civil Aviation Authority. We need a total revolution of the culture that Senator Collins has introduced and implanted in this society. We have to get a civil aviation authority that wants to work with, not against, the aviation industry. The nonsense that is going on today has to stop and it has to stop rapidly, otherwise a lot of people will die needlessly in the VFR field in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter that was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 23 October. The column `Inside Sydney' reported on a telephone conversation between the republican move-ment's chief tout, Malcolm Turnbull, and the monarchists' executive director, Tony Abbott. The article reported a complaint from Mr Turnbull that Mr Abbott was seriously misquoting him. The detail of the alleged misquotation was based on Mr Turnbull's view of codification of the reserve powers. `Inside Sydney' reported that Mr Abbott denied that he had misquoted Mr Turnbull. According to him, Mr Turnbull ended the call by saying, `I gather you are not disposed to apologise? Alright, I'm going to hang up now and you'll be hearing from me'. This is lawyers' love talk for `I'll see you in court'.

PARA.TAB: This is typical of the modus operandi of a bullying oaf. The only sympathy that I can extend to the republican movement is that Mr Turnbull is their chief exponent and what an unattractive salesman he is. Turnbull is only matched in his arrogance by his present—and I am sure temporary—friend, the Prime Minister. Mr Turnbull has the capacity to fall out with almost everybody. Bullying seems to have become the hallmark of the republican movement, especially now that its supporters appear unable to persuade us by rational argument. Whatever the misguided sincerity of many republicans, there is a bit of Brownshirt in Mr Turnbull. The republican movement has failed to convince us why a republic is preferable, what changes are necessary and how it will be achieved. So now it will get nasty.

The republicans are the strangers here. No-one is holding their passports; if they do not like Australia, they are free to leave. If they do not like our flag, they are free to leave. The gist of Turnbull's instability is that he is upset that his much publicised report has sunk without trace. I repeat: sunk without trace! Republicans infer Australians are not clever enough to understand their proposals. It is just that we are a wake up to Mr Turnbull. Turnbull said some time ago that the argument about whether we have a republic is over. He said that we are now only arguing about the form it will take. What arrogant nonsense. Mr Turnbull has not even got to first base and nor is he likely to.

I wish Mr Turnbull to know that I am going to put every obstacle in his way. He should give up this republican push. He is a loser, he is on a loser and the republican movement is on a loser with him. Mr Turnbull and Mr Keating can crash together, because success in constitutional reform is not determined by an aggressive crash through approach, which is favoured by both Mr Turnbull and Mr Keating. Mr Keating is a great divider and, on constitutional reform, one cannot be that.
Mr Tony Abbott has rightly pointed out that there is a growing mistrust of the republican idea. Any referendum in the medium term is now doomed to fail. And why? Mr Tony Abbott said:

SPEECH.PARA: Partly because of the arrogance and premature triumphalism of the republicans. . . and partly because of the unfair attacks on a system that has served Australia well, have rekindled pride in our constitutional achievements; but mostly because few people's attitude is—republic or bust—and Australians now know that becoming a republic could add intolerable burdens to an already overstrained society.

I suggest that Mr Turnbull take his republican document, which took over 500 pages to explain the minimalist approach to our 30-page constitution, and retire hurt from the public arena. At a cost, so far, of $500,000 this has been a very expensive, very divisive and very futile exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of very important conferences coming up for consideration in 1994 relating to population and development. In readiness for these conferences, it is important that Australia considers the population debate, particularly in the context of the reproductive rights of women. I am a little concerned that the United Nations seems to be overlooking the need for the reproductive rights of women to be central to the debate that will occur next April in New York and then finally at the conference in Cairo in October.

PARA.TAB: I have just received the suggested guidelines from the United Nations on how a developed country should prepare its national report on population. I know that the work on this is ongoing. A national committee has been set up by Senator Bolkus and it is working very hard on our report. I hope that the committee will go beyond the very narrow guidelines that have been presented by the United Nations.

I would just point out that it is a very bland coverage of the issues. The heading of point I is `The Demographic Context' and the following headings are `The Population Policy and Programme Framework', `International Cooperation in Population'—that is a very topical issue at the moment—and `Summary and Conclusions'. There is emphasis on maternal and child health, family planning service delivery and a related maternity benefits program. There is the role and relevance of the world population plan of action.

Try as I would, however, I could not find very much reference to the role of women in the preparation of the report as far as the United Nations guidelines were concerned. They do appear at page 3, where it is stated that an appropriate global strategy and plan of action for population for the early part of the twenty-first century can only be formulated with active participation and thoughtful contributions from all concerned—governments, communities, non-government organisations, scholars, individuals, men and, as we might have guessed, women. In all this documentation, that was the only reference that I could find to women.

That contrasts with a very important document that I can only very briefly summarise this afternoon. It was prepared in New York and presented on 1 June. It is Women's Voices `94: Women's Declaration on Population Policies. I believe that this document is much more central to many of the issues that should be being examined in preparation of Australia's population report. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Population policies and programs of most countries and international agencies have been driven more by demographic goals than by quality of life goals. Population size and growth have often been blamed inappropriately as the exclusive or primary causes of problems such as global environmental degradation and poverty. Fertility control programs have prevailed as solutions when poverty and inequity are root causes that need to be addressed. Population policies and programs have typically targeted low income countries and groups, often reflecting racial and class biases.

PARA.TAB: This is a very relevant issue for Australia to consider in the preparation of its national response, particularly as we have the opportunity to play a significant role in regard to increasing our funding as part of our aid program. Contrary to some of the media and, indeed, opposition speculation, I am assured by Minister Bilney that there is an absolute commitment. However, we believe that we should be open-minded and we should consider other issues, as is reflected in this report:

SPEECH.PARA: Women's behaviour rather than men's has been the focus of attention. Women have been expected to carry most the responsibility and risks of birth control, but have been largely excluded from decision-making in personal relationships as well as in public policy. Sexuality and gender-based power inequities have been largely ignored, and sometimes even strengthened, by population and family planning programs.
However, as women are involved directly in the organisation of services, research and advocacy, we should focus on the issue of women's reproductive health and rights.

PARA.TAB: I would like to detail the fundamental ethical principles that women would like to see reflected in all countries' responses in readiness for the population conference in Cairo. I have every confidence that these priorities will be reflected in Australia's population report. In fact, I am hoping that there will be a chapter solely devoted to the issue of women's reproductive health.
The fundamental ethical principles read:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Women can and do make responsible decisions for themselves, their families, their communities, and, increasingly, for the state of the world. Women must be subjects, not objects, of any development policy, and especially of population policies.

2. Women have the right to determine when, whether, why, with whom, and how to express their sexuality. Population policies must be based on the principle of respect for the sexual and bodily integrity of girls and women.

3. Women have the individual right and the social responsibility to decide whether, how and when to have children and how many to have; no woman can be compelled to bear a child or be prevented from doing so against her will. All women, regardless of age, marital status, or other social conditions have a right to information and services necessary to exercise their reproductive rights and responsibilities.

In this country, there are still women who do not necessarily have access to that vital information by virtue of where they live and—with every respect to you in the chair, Senator Herron—because some medical practitioners in this day and age in 1993 are still reluctant to give women the necessary advice, information and assistance they need in order to control their own fertility. It continues:
4. Men also have a personal and social responsibility for their own sexual behaviour and fertility and for the effects of that behaviour on their partners' and their children's health and well-being.
5. Sexual and social relationships between women and men must be governed by principles of equity, non-coercion—

a point that I am sure Senator Harradine would agree with me on even though he may not necessarily agree with other issues I am raising; non-coercion is absolutely fundamental to women's reproductive rights—

and mutual respect and responsibility. Violence against girls and women, their subjugation or exploitation, and other harmful practices such as genital mutilation or unnecessary medical procedures, violate basic human rights. . .

6.The fundamental sexual and reproductive rights of women cannot be subordinated, against a woman's will, to the interests of partners, family members, ethnic groups, religious institutions, health providers, researchers, policy makers, the state or any other actors.
The final point I wish to raise today reads:

7. Women committed to promoting women's reproductive health and rights, and linked to the women to be served, must be included as policy makers and program implementors in all aspects of decision-making including definition of ethical standards, technology development and distribution, services, and information dissemination.

I look forward to many of the women in this parliament, many women in the community as well as men who are interested—as they should be—in the issue of women's reproductive rights and how this influences population policies and the health of women around the world contributing to a wide ranging and responsible debate on this subject, particularly as we lead to the preparation of Australia's national response and the ongoing debate that I believe will occur in this parliament and in the community, particularly during 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about the appalling inactivity of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), who seems to be gagged on most major issues these days. Certainly he has not been allowed to speak on Mabo for some weeks. We can well understand his anxiety not to say very much in the area of communications, but I would have thought that at the very least he would be interested in—
—What about Bronwyn Bishop?

—We are talking about ministers and their contribution and their responsibilities. Senator Collins does have formal responsibilities for communications, even though we now know that David Beddall actually takes the submissions to cabinet and Senator Collins is anxious to say nothing in the area. But that does not excuse him for doing nothing in his own backyard. What has he done? Four years after the government promised that SBS would be extended to nine new regions, including Darwin, he was finally dragged screaming and yelling to the barrier and he came up with $5.3 million dollars to fund a new transmitter in Darwin. That is proceeding apace, to the delight of most of the local residents.

PARA.TAB: What it means is that Darwin is now getting something that Alice Springs and other smaller towns in the Northern Territory are clearly not getting and would like to get. An action group which was established in Alice Springs some months ago has been campaigning for a transmitter and indeed for funds to be provided by the government. The amount of money that it is looking for is a miserable $50,000. The group has been fobbed off in all sorts of amazing ways by the minister, to the point where he claimed in this chamber at one stage:

SPEECH.PARA: They—
the action group—

have written a letter to me, and that is as much as I know about it. I have not had a chance to talk to them yet, but I will talk to them. I think there has been a message from my office sent to them—this only happened last week—to that effect.

This is what he said back on 29 September. In fact, members of the group had contacted him some three weeks earlier. They had not heard one word from him. The message to which he referred was simply a press release which was faxed to them from Senator Collins, trumpeting his achievement in relation to Darwin. In other words, he was adding insult to injury. Not only would the minister not contact them but he had the cheek to claim that his office had been in touch with a message, which was really just to rub their noses in the dirt.

PARA.TAB: Since that time, the action group has tried to contact the minister's office on a number of occasions. On one notable occasion, after this matter had been raised in the Senate and Senator Collins had categorically ruled out any assistance to Alice Springs, his press secretary basically disowned his own minister by saying that Senator Collins really had not meant what he had said. He said, `You know Bob Collins. We are still having a look at it'. The fact of the matter is that they are not looking at it. They have decided against it. Their bottom line, I think, is clearly that they do not want to take any such initiative too far out from the next election. They want to wait until such time as they will get credit and it will be fresh in the minds of the local constituents. In other words, it was a classic political game playing exercise.

To suggest that somehow this might open the floodgates, as has been suggested to the action group, is again absolute nonsense. Probably only one or two towns the size of Katherine would be next in the queue. I trust that the minister has seen the quotation which has been provided from Farmer Electronics, which I think pares back the costs to the bone. It comes in at just under $47,000, a very small asking fee, I would have thought. The extraordinary thing is that the minister has not even been prepared to offer to fund on a matching basis. The very least I would have thought he would have done, if he was interested in providing assistance, was to provide it on that sort of dollar-for-dollar basis. Therefore, I think the action group is entitled to be outraged.

Some of the minister's comments were quite misleading, in any event. To suggest that they were proposing a low-powered transmitter facility which is just going to broadcast to the immediate local area with some sort of a signal completely understates the fact that what they have in mind is a total radiated power from the proposed transmission of 380 watts, as opposed to the present 250 watts from ABC and Imparja. We are not arguing over whether this is feasible, whether it is technically desirable or whether it is possible. The fact is that the Australian Broadcasting Authority granted the licence on 7 September last. So all the specifications have been approved. There is no technical problem. The South Australian and Northern Territory broadcast engineers have given it the all clear.

We are talking here about a project that is all ready to go, except for the intransigence of the minister who has had no compunction about throwing $5.3 million at his local constituents, but obviously could not give a damn about the citizens of the other major town in the territory. That is why Eric Poole was absolutely right when he called on the minister to stop playing games with territorians and bring SBS to Alice Springs. There is absolutely no good reason why this should not occur; it should occur immediately. Unless the minister wants to have yet another fiasco on his hands, then he ought to get off them and do something in this area.

While I am at it, there is another issue I want to raise in the area of communications. I think this probably falls more in the bailiwick of the Minister for Communications, Mr Beddall. Here we are. Here we are, always ready for a spar!

TALK.START.PARA: —Where's that wimp Tambling? Why isn't he raising this matter? Why are you raising it?

—Well, I was up there, and I was appalled at first hand. I saw the extent of the inaction and I could not believe it. When I talked to these people—very reasonable, sensible citizens—who made a very modest request, all I discovered was that this minister has virtually washed his hands of it, tried to fob them off in all sorts of ways and will not even make contact with them.
—Have you seen the first condition of a self-help licence?
—I have seen all the relevant information. I have read Senator Collins's release, and he has the—
—How much do you think they paid? Do you know how much they are paying for the licences? Twenty dollars. Do you know why they keep it at $20?
—So!
—They could raise their own. That is why they get a discounted licence.
—The minister was quite happy to contribute $5.3 million in Darwin.
—Absolutely!
—Absolutely. Of course, because that is the minister's home town—it was the home town decision. The fact that Alice Springs does not really matter very much for Senator Collins is utterly irrelevant.
—It has 75,000 people.
—They are all set to go.
—Is it irrelevant?

—The fact that they have got 75,000 people? They can have a service tomorrow. They have got the all clear from the Australian Broadcasting Authority. All that is stopping them is funding, and Senator Collins will not come to the party.

PARA.TAB: Now let me deal with Mr Beddall. What Mr Beddall has done in this area—he has done very little and what he has done has taken him a long time to do—is that he essentially has a different technology time track in three different areas. There are satellite licences which are currently dead in the water because no-one wants to touch them with a barge pole. Murdoch and Packer walked away from them months ago. There are people out there gold-digging and hoping that someone will desperately buy them out. Quite clearly, this process is going to drag on and on for months and months, and we will not have any satellite services up there in the foreseeable future. In any event, why would anyone in his right mind want to spend $500 million on something when he is likely to be trumped from Asia or likely to be encircled by cable and MDS? So it is quite clear that satellite licence process is going nowhere.

With MDS we are still awaiting details of the revised tender process, which the minister said would be forthcoming within three months—he said that about five months ago. We have had nothing since then except that we keep getting these sorts of leaks: `In a marked change of style the Keating government is considering quick closed bid one-day sales in individual cities to dispose of the remaining MDS pay licences'. Then at the very end it says that, of course, this has not actually gone past the minister.

Clearly, there is an enormous level of frustration within the department if those people are proposing these sorts of revisions of the process. If they have got a concept in mind, why is it that Mr Beddall has not yet approved the redesigned sale process? Why has he not addressed the fundamental issues? Most importantly, of course, why has he not addressed the question of why there could conceivably be three different types of pay television delivered by three different technologies starting up at three different times?

This was highlighted this week by a letter of absolute anguish from a local tourist channel operator in Cairns who wrote to Mr Beddall some weeks ago asking why it was that he was not going to be able to start up on MDS because there is no licence process in place. He was told the likelihood is that he will have to wait until at least the start of 1995 before he can get under way. Yet he finds that, not only is there a Canadian company called Paynet which has taken out cables licences, but now another crowd called Rowcom has taken out cable licences as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no cable, Senator.

—But they have got the licences, and having got the licence people are able to go off and do the deals, get backers, arrange finance, order the equipment and get the show on the road. But if they cannot—

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely. Why does Senator Collins think they have the cable licences? Why does he think they bothered to take out the licences? It is because they want to be in a position to get going. They have been granted the licences. One has to give the licences to them over the counter. Something like $785, it costs—
—And you only need 20 million bucks worth of cable for Townsville—

—So? The fact is that these people have got their licences and they can make commercial decisions. But this other poor unfortunate, if he were to be granted an MDS license—and he has one at the moment for tourist purposes—would have to pay a $23,000 annual licence fee. Why? We are talking about delivering the same service simply by a different technology. Why should someone get a cable licence for $785, full stop, and the other have to pay $23,000 a year ad infinitum? Why indeed. I would be delighted if the minister, if he has any knowledge of this subject, could explain to me why we need all these separate licences for each service.

PARA.TAB: Again, as Fred Brenchley quite rightly points out, the department—presumably aided and abetted by the ministers—is in the business of drawing this distinction between narrow cast and broadcast, which will again become the classic boundary dispute. We will have jurisdictional arguments time and again and all the flash lawyers will be needed to try to sort it out. Why do we need to have all these separate licences? They are supposed to be national licences, but as soon as one broadcasts a slightly different service in a geographic area one has to have a separate licence. So Rowcom finds that it needs 28 pay television licences, 10 for terrestrial rebroadcast, six for the broadcast of one local cable television service in each area and 12 to allow for the introduction of additional services as the system develops. Why does one need this plethora of pieces of paper? Why cannot we simply say, if it is a national licence, `If you are a fit and proper person or if'—according to the latest suitability test—`you are a suitable operator, if you meet the minimum requirements, you can have your ticket'? But no, one can have a whole range of tickets if one pays a relatively small amount for each one and gets going with cable. Who knows? If Telecom really got stuck into it, presumably it could get cable on the road within the next 12 to 18 months at the very latest—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you talked to them?
—Yes, I have talked to them. I had a big briefing from them yesterday—
—What did they say?
—It is all a matter of negotiation. It may well be that Paynet and Rowcom have to lay their own cable.
—It will be 1995 at the earliest.

—Senator Collins must believe his own propaganda. It depends entirely on the resources that one devotes to it, the area that one wishes to cover, and how much money one wants to invest in it. These are all matters for negotiation. Senator Collins does not seem to appreciate that Paynet or Rowcom could lay their own cable, but they face all the problems of having to get environmental consent from local councils, whereas Telecom and Optus can do it immediately. The negotiations that will take place will obviously involve a timetable. If they wanted to pay up-front and get it done immediately it could be done in a relatively short space of time. Most importantly, it could be done well before the start of 1995, which is the earliest on the current timetable that one could get an MDS licence. As Fred Brenchley rightly says, why do we not talk about narrowcast licences? Telecom has been given one for a trial project, which is essentially broadcast in every respect, again special pleading—

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Collins is in any position to try to explain the legislation to anyone. He does not bother reading documents. He clearly does not even want to get advice on what the legislation says. He has done everything to wash his hands of this whole area. I am really directing my remarks to Mr Beddall, as I made clear at the beginning of my speech.
—It was a waste of time coming down here.
—No, Senator Collins was dealt with in the first part. I just hope that he will see the light and recognise the equity of providing very modest assistance to the citizens of Alice Springs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Sit down, Bob!
—I can speak in this debate.
—You are not on the speakers' list.

—So what? I will be brief to allow my colleague to speak. Senator Alston specifically invited me in the address that he just delivered to respond briefly, and I will respond briefly to one of the items that he raised.

PARA.TAB: The facts are—and I will be brief—that whilst the Broadcasting Services Act provides for potentially different start-up dates for cable, MDS and satellite delivered pay TV services, it is totally inaccurate to say that those companies that have been allocated cable pay TV licences are `free to start a cable channel right away'. Cable delivered services are licensed under section 96 of the act. Whilst there are no timing constraints on the issue of these licences, there is a range of regulatory conditions that apply and a number of quite significant technological and commercial limitations, which include the dependency of a cable service on broadband capacity into homes, which is a labour intensive, time consuming and very expensive exercise; the cost for the roll-out of a hybrid coaxial optical fibre system; and the need for cable operators to obtain program rights, establish studios, subscriber management and retail infrastructure, and undertake marketing.

It should be noted that licences for services using MDS and cable are issued subject to suitability requirements in a Trade Practices Commission report. The application fee for each licence is $785, with a maximum of $1,570 payable where more than one licence is involved. As Senator Alston said, cable operators will also either have to bear the cost of laying out the cable infrastructure themselves, which is very significant, or have to lease it from a telecommunications carrier, which would have to be struck at a rate that gives the person who lays the cable a commercial return on the layout of that cable.

I am advised that the assertion that has been made that `Telecom is on the verge of making an offer to Paynet to cable Cairns and Townsville' is also totally inaccurate. Telecom has informed me as of yesterday that, even on its most optimistic calculations, significant numbers of households will not be able to be cabled until 1995.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We get a lot of interesting mail in our offices here but nothing could be more interesting than a copy of a letter I received this morning entitled, `A letter from Janine Haines'. I would like to quote a portion of the letter. It was addressed to the Winegrape Growers Council in South Australia and was written on 8 October. Former Senator Haines says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been out of parliament for a few years and on the whole—like most sane people—I don't miss it.
But some things still make me angry. Enough to want to go on fighting. The Wine Tax is one of them.
In the ten years I served in the Senate, the Democrats stood alone in fighting for the Wine Industry.
Labor's tax hikes in 1984 & 1986 were rammed through the parliament with the support of the Opposition—despite their public criticism!
Now it's third time lucky. This time (and it's about time) the Opposition parties have decided to oppose some things in fact as well as in rhetoric and the wine tax is one of them.
I am comforted to know that Democrat Deputy Leader Meg Lees not only succeeded me in the Senate, but has willingly taken over the baton on this issue, and has led the fight against the 1993 tax hike.

Because of her campaign it is now clear that the proposed wine tax increase will not pass the parliament. Nevertheless the Labor party appears to be unable to accept the clear industry policy arguments on this issue.
In fact, I wouldn't be surprised to see the 20-31 per cent proposal return in future budgets with the Government hoping to wear down the Opposition on this issue as they have done before.

However, there is a simple way that you can deliver a clear message to the ALP to back off—a way to tell them to go back to the drawing board and design a Wine Industry policy, not just a Wine Tax policy.
You can do this by contributing to the Democrats campaign to replace ALP Mps with our Mps in the upcoming SA election. This is expected within 60 days.
Former Senator Haines then goes on to ask the recipients of her letter to send financial contributions to the Australian Democrats in the envelope provided. I am totally staggered by this letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you sent your money in?

—Not yet. I am staggered by a couple of the claims she makes in this letter. Obviously, as well as being very misleading, it is deceptive and ill-conceived. She obviously had no idea how she was going to be let down by her former colleagues in the Senate. Despite what Janine Haines said, Senator Lees has not led the fight against the 1993 tax hike. Senator Haines said that, because of her campaign, it is now clear that the proposed wine tax increase will not pass the parliament. We all know that the Democrats backed off under pressure and gave in for a compromise package which will see the sales tax on wine creep up slowly, but creep up nevertheless. We all know there is no reason why the Democrats could not have chosen to vote with the opposition and defeat the increase in sales tax on wine completely.

PARA.TAB: This is obviously what Janine Haines expected the Democrats to do when she wrote her letter to the winegrape growers on 8 October. We can imagine how disappointed, embarrassed and angry she must be that her own colleagues let her down and voted for increased taxes on wine. She says early in her letter:

SPEECH.PARA: In the ten years I served in the Senate, the Democrats stood alone in fighting for the Wine Industry.

I have never heard such an outrageous claim in my life but it does prove one thing: when the Democrats stand alone, they can do nothing. They can do absolutely nothing on their own. If it were not for the fact that the coalition had made a decision that they were going to oppose wine taxes, the Democrats would not have been left with a leg to stand on. It would have been like their previous, much publicised fighting for the wine industry; they could have achieved absolutely nothing at all. It is only with the support of the coalition that they are ever able to do anything; they can do nothing on their own. In this situation we see them back off and back away from their original stance—the very thing that Janine Haines says they have never done and has accused the opposition of doing.

PARA.TAB: Janine Haines also gives the Australian Labor Party a bit of a bucketing—something that her federal colleagues in the Senate seem very reluctant to do—saying that the Labor Party appears to be unable to accept the clear industry policy arguments on this issue. Perhaps if former Senator Haines was still leading the Democrats they might have shown a bit more backbone and the wine tax might have been defeated in its entirety. What I thought was most interesting was that the former leader says that winemakers and grape growers can deliver a message to the ALP, in her words, `to back off', by contributing to the Democrats' campaign to replace ALP members of parliament with Democrat MPs in the upcoming South Australian election.

She does not make any mention of the Liberal Party of Australia because she really only wants to replace Labor Party members with Democrat members. This, perhaps, gives us some indication that Senator Haines has had a change of heart in many areas and now believes that the only alternative government is the Liberal Party, particularly the Liberal Party in South Australia. Honourable senators would have to ask whether Janine Haines wants the Labor Party out of office in South Australia so badly that she is prepared to tell Democrat supporters that they should be giving all their preferences to the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're going to make her Governor—you have bought her off!

—Make her Governor! Where did the minister find that one? He would be the only one who would have thought of that. Concerning the letter that Janine Haines has written to the Winegrape Growers Council, let me come back to the fact that the former leader of the Democrats has been let down badly by her colleagues—or her former colleagues—when she says that they will always stand up for the wine industry. They backed off at the last minute. In no way did Senator Lees lead the fight against the 1993 tax hikes. When the budget was announced, within a couple of days the coalition announced, clearly and concisely, those parts of the budget that it intended to oppose. The Democrats thought about it for two or three weeks then decided what their position would be once they knew they had a base to stand on. That base for their opposition was provided by the strong stand that was taken by the coalition.

PARA.TAB: So I hope that wine and grape growers in South Australia will take no heed of the letter from former Senator Haines when she asks them to donate to the Democrats' election campaign. As is the case in the Senate, the same thing happens in South Australia; the Democrats can do absolutely nothing for the people of South Australia. As soon as they realise that by directing their preferences in totality to the Liberal Party, there will be a change of government and South Australians will be better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m. I call on questions without notice.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications.
—I can tell you're excited.

—I am almost overcome, but it is not from the sight of the minister.
