I refer the minister to a report in this morning's Age which contains outrageous, irresponsible and inaccurate remarks by the managing director of the ABC, David Hill, on the republican issue. Does the minister agree that Mr Hill has clearly defamed the Governor-General? Does he agree that Mr Hill's comments are in direct conflict with the ABC charter, which obliges all journalists to be fair and impartial and not impose their personal views? In view of this appalling and unforgivable outburst, why should Mr Hill not resign immediately?
—This is one of the thinner attempts that Senator Alston has made in here for some time.
—Have you read it?

—Yes, I have read the comments. I will decline Senator Alston's invitation for me to give a legal opinion in the Senate in question time as to whether the remarks are defamatory. Firstly, I am not a lawyer. Secondly, the standing orders preclude even the lawyers in here from giving legal opinions in question time, although I know that Senator Alston is certainly always free with his. I am sure that he is now much freer than he was when he was at the bar.

PARA.TAB: I clearly saw from the remarks made by Mr Hill, which I did read, that they were clearly made in his capacity as Mr Hill. They do not reflect—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why those opposite are getting so excited about it. Frankly, I personally regard Mr Hill's remarks as being remarks of passing interest. I do not know why it always whips coalition senators into a frenzy every time the monarchy, the republic or whatever is mentioned. They seem to get profoundly more excited about it than anybody on this side of the chamber.
—It must be the system we live under.
—The system that we live under is called democracy, which contains a right of free speech. Those opposite observe that only when it suits them.
—What about Henry Bosch?

—I am interested in that interjection. Senator Parer might like to refer to the public statements I made about Mr Bosch's views which were on the public record. Senator Parer might also like to ask Mr Bosch about the nature of the conversation that I had with him privately. I invite Senator Parer to do so. All that will do is confirm the views that I have just put about my particular adherence to the right of free speech. Mr Bosch is still not only a serving member of the CAA board but also the deputy chair of the CAA board and was present when I met with the CAA board yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The remarks that Mr Hill made clearly do not represent any position of the government on this issue and nor do they represent any position of the ABC on this issue. I do not think that any further action is required on them. It is a matter between Mr Hill and the Governor-General. I am sure that both of them are big enough to sort it out between themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister seriously suggesting that, on the one hand, the ABC charter can make it clear that journalists are not allowed to have their professional judgment influenced by their personal views and that, on the other hand, David Hill has the right to rabbit on about any issue as a private citizen quite divorced from his role as managing director of the ABC? Is he saying that no responsibilities attach to the head of the ABC, there is no suggestion of the ABC being compromised and there is no need for the ABC board to make it clear that he was speaking in his private capacity? I would have thought that that is an outrageous proposition.

—Firstly, it is news to me that David Hill is a journalist, so I am not quite sure what the references to journalists are. Secondly, as I say again, I have read the comments; I frankly do not know why Senator Alston is getting so excited.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the minister aware of public concerns about the sacking of Moira Rayner through the abolition of her position as Victorian Equal Opportunity Commissioner? Is the minister aware of the legislation currently before the Victorian parliament to change the Victorian constitution so as to strip Victorians of their legal rights to appeal to the Supreme Court without state government approval? Do these decisions of the Victorian state government raise Australian government concerns? What are the implications for Australia's commitment to human rights and civil liberties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Carr for raising an issue which I believe is not only of concern to the government and to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission but also of concern to democratically minded Australians wherever they live in this country. What we are seeing in Victoria is an attack not only on the rights but also on the structures that are there to protect the rights of individual Australians. Of course, that is of concern to us. We also note with concern that there are reports on the abolition of the position of the Victorian Equal Opportunity Commissioner and reports of amendments proposed to the Victorian equal opportunity legislation. They are not minor changes—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This particular question and the answer has nothing to do with the responsibilities of Senator Bolkus. I ask you to rule that the question and the answer are out of order.

—This is very much within my responsibility representing the Attorney-General. Senator Kemp knows that. Not only is it within my responsibility as representing the Attorney-General, but also it is within my responsibility as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. HREOC, an organisation which has direct involvement with the structure in Victoria, as a partnership, is also within the Attorney-General's responsibility.

—Order! I listened carefully to the question. I thought the first part of the question was out of order. The second part of the question, however, did talk about the Australian government's involvement and on those grounds I will allow it.

—I was going to go on to say that it is of concern to us and a serious disappointment to us and, of course, to the federal human rights commission that the changes have been announced without any consultation with the Commonwealth, despite the fact that there is a formal agreement on cooperative arrangements which provide for consultation and arrangements on these matters. There is a formal agreement under which the federal government pays some 30 per cent of the funding of the Victorian commission. There is a very clear nexus between us federally and the Victorian commission.

PARA.TAB: But my concern and that of the government is also shared by the president of the human rights commission, Sir Ronald Wilson. In a news release of yesterday he expressed serious reservations concerning the proposed changes to the Victorian equal opportunity act. He is concerned, `in the light of the long and constructive relationship with the Victorian equal opportunity commission'. But the concern of both Sir Ronald and the government is that what we are doing here is impinging on universally accepted standards of independence and access.

The changes contemplated go to the heart of the process. Sir Ronald's particular concerns, which the government shares, are that the conciliation function in Victoria will no longer be an independent process because the chief conciliator is, under the proposed legislation, to be subject to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is very clear from the minister's answer that it has nothing to do with the Commonwealth government at all. I now ask you to rule the answer out of order and to sit him down.

—Mr President, this is just a continued act of frustration. I have already established that there is not only direct responsibility through the Attorney-General's Department, but also that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has a formal arrangement with this commission, an arrangement to implement federal imperatives, which is very much at threat because of the action of Senator Kemp's colleagues riding roughshod over democracy in Victoria.
—Order! I will allow Senator Bolkus to continue. I ask him to relate his answer to the question that he was asked.

—I am doing that, Mr President. Senator Carr shows concern about the sacking of the commissioner. It is a concern which is shared by the federal government. We are also concerned about the processes that are being jeopardised in relation to independence and costs. This loss of independence is of serious concern. It has led to a statement from the federal sex and race discrimination commissioners, who have said that they will no longer be prepared to have complaints under federal legislation handled by the new Victorian commission.

PARA.TAB: The human rights commission has also expressed grave concern—which I am sure is shared by every person concerned about human rights—about the Victorian government's proposals that costs be awarded against unsuccessful complainants in other than exceptional circumstances. This means that those who will be most disadvantaged in our community—here we are talking about the protection of basic human rights—are the 30 per cent of Victorians who are of non-English speaking backgrounds. The protection of them against racism will be jeopardised by this particular act of the Victorian government.
This concern of the government is one that is shared by Sir Ronald Wilson. In a statement put out yesterday he said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is highly unlikely that the potential complainants will use the legislation once it comes into effect because of the cost imperative imposed by the Victorian government.

Most complainants are young and with few resources. If they are faced with the possibility of having to meet fees for a phalanx of lawyers should they not be able to make out their complaint, they are unlikely to lodge a complaint in the first place.
These changes go to the heart of independence and costs and access. I am sure they will not be appreciated by the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What are the implications for Australia's international obligations to human rights conventions?

—Members of the opposition come in here from time to time when it suits them and invoke the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and Commissioner Burdekin. Commissioner Burdekin has already written to the Victorian government saying that he is disappointed at the way in which this process has been undertaken. We are concerned federally that universally accepted basic rights—rights of protection and rights of access—are being imperilled. We have to consider our position.

PARA.TAB: Because of the attack on the independence of the commission and the other regressive and unacceptable aspects of the proposed changes, we will need to seriously consider the feasibility and desirability of continuing with the existing cooperative funding arrangements for Victoria. We will also have to consider what continued presence we need to have in that state.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the government intend in its Mabo package to prevent state courts from applying the normal rules of evidence to native title claims?

—There are no provisions that I am aware of in the draft outline legislation that would go to evidentiary rules and their application in state courts. I cannot imagine any context in which it would be necessary to address that issue.
—Orally.

—I am indebted to Senator Alston for that constructive contribution. There are plenty of ways in which, under the existing rules of evidence, particular kinds of evidence, including of an oral kind, can be taken. It is essentially going to be a matter for the state courts systems themselves to determine how their processes work.

PARA.TAB: If there is anything that needs to be added to that answer, I will be happy to seek further information and reply to it, but I cannot offhand think of any context in which it would be necessary for any change in the rules of evidence to be made that govern these cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. In the last budget the government announced that a Commonwealth telecommunications group would be established within the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services to provide a whole of government approach in telecommunications to departments and agencies. Can the minister advise the Senate what progress has been made with this initiative?

—This is an important part of the continuing debate about purchasing in Australia and by the Australian government, in particular. We have established a telecommunications group which was proposed in the budget. This is part of the push to ensure that taxpayers' money is spent effectively and responsibly and that the objectives of better value for money are achieved.

PARA.TAB: The first activity of this Commonwealth telecommunications group—CTG—was finalised recently with the signing of an agreement with Telecom Australia to provide custom net horizon services to Commonwealth departments and agencies. It is estimated that this will realise savings of about $4 million per year and provide a platform on which further important business solutions for Commonwealth agencies can be developed.

The group is negotiating further agreements with Telecom, Optus and other telecommunications service suppliers. It is an initiative which has broad ramifications for Australian industry. I know this is of interest to Senator Murphy, and he is quite correct to be interested in it.

The Commonwealth currently spends more than $325 million a year on telecommunications products and services and expects it to increase to $400 million by 1997-98. Therefore, how this money is spent is very important, both in terms of the efficient use of taxpayers' money and in terms of industry development. The CTG provides a central focus for suppliers and the group is working with local industry.

As many senators would be aware, the telecommunications industry is more than just a couple of high profile carriers—a large number of small to medium size local companies are involved. Some of these companies are at the leading edge of communications technology development and it is important that they get the opportunity to make the maximum contribution. The government intends to maximise the opportunities for local industry participation in this important initiative.

The Senate will recall—how could it forget—that I announced yesterday the establishment of a task force within my department to review purchasing policy generally. This initiative is a good example of the benefits to be gained from strategic purchasing. In the context of a task force review, I will not only be taking a close look at this important area of telecommunications purchasing but also ensuring that opportunities for local industry can be maximised within the framework of competition.

I think the balance between taking good care of the taxpayers' dollar in purchasing and maximising the opportunities for Australian industry is never going to be easy to achieve. A lot of work has been done on it over the years. We need to build on it as it develops. This is another important initiative on the road to building that relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Minister for Trade. Does the minister accept that the trade related intellectual property rights, the regime outlined in the Dunkel draft text of the Uruguay Round, has been of particular concern to southern nations? Secondly, although the government has taken the view in its own patents legislation that life forms are no different from non-living things and can be exclusively owned for the purposes of commercial exploitation, does the minister at least agree that commercial ownership of life forms raises profound ethical and moral questions? Accordingly, does the minister consider it appropriate to impose, through the medium of a trade agreement such as GATT, a system of ownership and exploitation of life and genetic material which is at variance with the ethical views and cultural traditions of so many of the world's people?

—The draft trade related intellectual property rights agreement, or TRIPS agreement, deals with matters of intense interest to both developed and developing countries—countries of the north and the south. The agreement will help to strengthen the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in trade related activity. It will provide minimum standards for the protection of intellectual property in a wide range of areas, encompassing patents, copyright, trademarks, industrial designs, integrated circuits, geographical indications and trade secrets. Intellectual property protection, through the various means covered in the agreement, will help the growth of technology based industry, in particular, and certainly sharpen the competitive edge of domestic products from countries making them in global markets.

PARA.TAB: Better defined and workable global rules for the protection of intellectual property rights will also stimulate innovative economic activity by guaranteeing a financial return to, and a recognition for the creative efforts of, investors, artists, technicians and other innovators. Again, that is true of people in those categories in both developed and developing countries. Certainly, the developing countries have much to gain from a successful outcome to the Uruguay Round, including the TRIPs agreement. That was reflected most recently in the CHOGM declaration, initiated by Prime Minister Keating.

As to the questions about patentability of life forms and the implications of that in this context, in its own patents legislation the Australian government has taken the view that patents are available for inventions in all fields of technology—both biological and non-biological. I am advised—there is a marvellous solemnity about this bit of my briefing note—that human beings and the biological processes for their generation are not in Australia patentable inventions. No doubt it is a matter of profound relief to us all to know that. I can think of some people whose performance one might want to patent, but be that as it may.

There is no necessary inconsistency—I hope Senator Coulter would agree—between the research and commercialisation of particular matters and the reflection of ethical values in the patent system governing that research and commercialisation. The TRIPs agreement does not distinguish between inventions of a product or a process, nor does it make a distinction in the type of technology used, whether it relates to life forms or not. The text does provide members with the flexibility to exclude from patentability inventions which might otherwise, I am told again, challenge public order or morality. So it is not written in a way which would cut across the ongoing debate to which Senator Coulter obviously refers in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I cannot let that answer go unchallenged. Based on cultural reasons, in the Third World there has been the development, particularly in the area of agriculture, of a wide range of seeds and genetic strains which are no less important to the people of those countries than the variations which might be worked on those same genetic strains in First World countries that get access to them. How is it that that does not raise profound questions of intercultural conflict and profound questions of the difference between morality and the ethical approach to the exclusive ownership of that genetic information for commercial gain?

—All I can say further is that the specific text of the agreement notes that members may exclude from patentability inventions in order to protect public order or morality, including to protect human, animal or plant life or health. The text does allow countries to exclude from patentability plants and animals, but countries do have to provide some kind of protection for plant varieties. It is an old and familiar debate about plant variety rights and the issues of principle that are associated with that.

PARA.TAB: Maybe there is some continuing ground for argument about that in Senator Coulter's mind. But I would have thought that the larger ethical and cultural questions that he regards as being raised or somehow concluded by this international treaty negotiation are not really addressed by the treaty, as I understand it, given that it does allow room for countries to make their own rules in those particular areas. If there is anything else that the department or Senator Cook's aspect of it wants to add, I will bring that to Senator Coulter's attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health able to indicate whether there has been a dramatic increase in measles and whooping cough cases in Australia this year? If so, what action can be taken to increase immunisation levels of these potentially deadly childhood diseases?

—I can indicate that there has been an alarming increase this year. That underlines the need for a national immunisation strategy, about which I have been speaking to state health ministers during the last few months. So far this year 1,725 cases of whooping cough have been reported. Not only is that five times the number for the same period last year but it is also more than any number reported in the whole of any one year since records were first kept 15 years ago. Between January and the end of September more than 2,000 cases of measles were reported to the communicable diseases network of Australia. That is three times the number for the same period last year.

PARA.TAB: Between May and August more than 600 measles cases were reported in Tasmania alone, with 500 notified in western Sydney since the middle of June. Over 40 children have been hospitalised and four of those have been admitted to intensive care. Increases have also been recorded in Queensland, Victoria and the ACT. That, of course, is pretty depressing news but it highlights our need not to be complacent.

I share the concern of all of the state ministers about the drop in immunisation rates. I do not know whether it results from one or all of parental complacency, ignorance or just some kind of wilful defiance of all the health warnings. But one thing is for sure: that drop in the immunisation rate is selling out our children's health.

Measles is a serious and highly infectious childhood disease with one in every 1,000 cases causing serious complications such as pneumonia and inflammation of the brain. Latent complications can lead to deaths many years later. Whooping cough is a highly contagious bacterial disease which causes severe bouts of coughing and may last for weeks or even months. It is particularly serious in young children who sometimes need to be hospitalised when they have difficulty in breathing.

State health authorities have issued any number of warnings and alerts to parents to ensure that children are immunised on time, specifically against measles and, through the triple antigen shot, against whooping cough, diphtheria and tetanus. I can only urge parents to heed all of those warnings because the tragedy is that these diseases are preventable. Our success over many years in dealing with these diseases has caused people to forget just how devastating they can be.

To try to combat this problem, we are cooperating with the states in an attempt to set up a national immunisation program from 1 July next year which will ensure that children are protected as early as possible. A working party has been set up and that will report to the meeting next week of the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council. The starting point for the program is an acceptance of NHMRC guidelines on childhood vaccinations. That includes not only infant vaccinations but also booster shots for children at later stages.

Realistically, we are talking about a program that will cost many millions of dollars. Both the states and the Commonwealth are determined to take that program on. This is a public health cost that we cannot escape from. Whatever money needs to be found to bring our immunisation rates into line, even with countries like Vietnam these days, will have to be found immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Native claims have now been made over all the export coalmines in the Bowen Basin in Queensland, representing some $4 billion worth of exports. As the minister has said on numerous occasions in this place, the government does not believe these sorts of claims will succeed. I ask the minister: what action, if any, is the government considering to deter costly ambit claims? Will the government's Mabo legislation address ambit or mischievous claims, which are doing untold damage to investor confidence and customer perception of Australia as being a reliable supplier to steel mills and other users of Australian coal around the world? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the difficulties in conducting this debate is the constant claim by the opposition that they have not been—
—Give us an answer to the question.

—Hold your horses and curb your hormones; just relax. Those opposite will get an answer to the question. One of the difficulties is that there is a constant reference to not knowing enough about the detail of the proposed legislation. Senator Hill went so far as to claim in this place a couple of weeks ago that there is some sort of conspiracy of silence so far as the original outline document of 2 September was concerned. In that particular document of 2 September, which has not changed in any relevant respect as a result of the later debate, a very detailed set of provisions were laid out as to the way in which claims which were manifestly vexatious, frivolous and unsustainable would not in fact be registered in a way which would allow them to proceed.

PARA.TAB: I refer to paragraph 95 of that document and subsequent provisions which bear directly upon this. The paragraph states:

ANSWER.PARA: Where a claim for native title has been received, the Judge may determine—
that it not be registered if:

PARA.TAB: (a)the claim is not made in the prescribed form;
(c)the claim fails to disclose sufficient information as to the ongoing traditional connection with the land by the claimants;
(d)that the claim fails to disclose evidence of the representative capacity of the claimant or claimants;
(e)the claim is in relation to land already the subject of a determination;
(f)the geographical boundaries of the claim have not been specified with sufficient precision; or
(g)the claim is vexatious.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a further provision that enables things to be ruled out if native title has been extinguished over the land or any part thereof. There is a further note in paragraph 96 which addresses the question of the means by which that particular issue might be resolved, because that obviously raises slightly more complex questions than the others.

PARA.TAB: We are, of course, conscious of the possibility of frivolous and vexatious claims, and that is one of the reasons that these provisions are very much part of the outline as it has been anticipated. In the Bowen Basin we have a further issue, which has some people excited, about the fact that there is some overlapping of the claims that have been foreshadowed or made at the moment. Obviously, we have not yet got in place this system of registration, but it will need to be addressed in this way. But the overlapping of two claims is really no different from the sorts of disputes about the exact position of boundaries that occur between land-holders or claimants in other litigation context all along.

To attempt to deny potential native titleholders the right to be involved in decisions about proposed uses of the land, to attempt to deny them, moreover, the right at the threshold, even to pursue claims in situations where it might well be thought that the case was unsustainable and the result likely to be negative, is, of course, to get us right back to where we were debating this a couple of days ago. What the opposition has made clear is that it wants different rules for white people in this country and for black people, and that simply is not a sustainable proposition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand exactly what the minister is saying. But in a related comment today, Mr John White of the New South Wales Farmers' Association said:

QUESTION.PARA: The present public funding of Aboriginal land claimants, while defendants with limited resources remain unassisted, is grossly inequitable and will inevitably lead to an avalanche of claims funded by the public . . .

What does the government intend to do to deter the frivolous ambit claims? The minister's response dealt with what one does after one gets to court. If public funding is to be made for frivolous claims, will public funding also be provided for those people who are defending frivolous claims?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is really no other interpretation that one can glean from that question other than that the opposition does want a completely separate system of law to apply for black Australians as compared with everybody else. Of course, everyone contemplating litigation of any kind is subject to rules about frivolous and vexatious claims in court procedures. To help the process of determining what is a frivolous, vexatious or manifestly unsustainable claim that will waste everybody's time, we have gone further in spelling out some of the criteria which should be taken into account in a registration process.

PARA.TAB: If one wants to go further, the kind of criteria I have just indicated will be taken into account. The only further direction that we could take is to rule out absolutely the possibility of Aboriginal litigants bringing claims at all. This government is not going to go down a path which says, `If you are white, you can litigate—if you think you have got a prima facie case, however quixotic that might be. But if you are black, you cannot'. We are not going to be a party to that kind of discrimination and we never will.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Could the minister inform the Senate of the progress of Australia's negotiations to have magnesium car parts manufactured in Australia? What expectations does he have for the development of the magnesium and light metal smelting industry? What role does he expect the proposed Gladstone smelter to have in the future of this industry?
—I have been given some information about what is a very full answer. It is thoroughly fascinating.

—I can understand those opposite not being interested in this because this is basically a good news story about a wholly new Australian industry. Let me tell them a little about it. The global market for light metal components for cars is already substantial and it does hold very great prospects for the future. The search for improved fuel consumption flowing from reduction in vehicle weight and greater recyclability of materials are key factors giving rise to this market opportunity. Several private sector and government agencies have been working to ensure that Australia is well placed to capitalise on this opportunity.

PARA.TAB: Australia contains, in fact, one of the world's richest magnesite deposits at Kunwarara in Central Queensland—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to tax it?

—I would have thought Senator Macdonald might have just stopped talking for once in order to listen to something that is of enormous significance both to his constituents and to the Australian economy as a whole. Proposals to develop this deposit are well advanced. Downstream processing capability for this site is planned to be based at Gladstone in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: In 1991, the Commonwealth and Queensland governments agreed to contribute $20 million and $5 million respectively to the Australian magnesium research and development project to develop a process and to construct a pilot plant to process the high grade magnesite deposit I have referred to, to turn it into magnesium metal.

Last July, in Gladstone, my colleague Mr Griffiths launched a report entitled Magnesium opportunities for Australian industry, which spelt out in loving and elaborate and considerable detail precisely the scale of the opportunity that is involved here whereby Australia can become a very major player in the world marketplace.

Action is being taken on a number of fronts to capitalise on this prospect. Minister Griffiths and his Queensland state counterpart, Mr Elder, have announced that the two governments will jointly provide $300,000 to assist a pre-feasibility study for a major die-casting facility in Gladstone. We are also funding a study by the Australian Automotive Technology Centre to determine which components are most suitable for conversion to magnesium. Minister Griffiths has also written to the chief executives of the world's automotive companies advising them of our potential as a supplier of magnesium vehicle components.

Austrade is implementing a marketing strategy which promotes Australia as a future source for light metal automotive components, including from magnesium. That marketing strategy is being implemented in partnership with the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, the CSIRO and the Queensland government. DITARD is also holding discussions with the die-casting industry, the Queensland government and other stakeholders to ensure that a comprehensive development strategy is in place to help position Australian industry to capture a significant share of the expanding market for magnesium components.

The future processing of magnesite from the Kunwarara deposit, whether Senator Ian Macdonald is interested in it or not, will add value to a very significant natural resource. Installation of the greater value adding capability in Australia will be critical to the Australian automotive light metals component manufacturing industry becoming a major world player. It will provide substantial markets for Australian metal and add further value to that resource.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I remind the minister that only $600,000 of the $40 million of better cities funding allocated to the MFP in the One Nation statement has been spent so far and that the department has advised the Senate Estimates Committee E:

QUESTION.PARA: Given the lack of progress it was agreed that 1992-93 funding for the MFP/Northwest Crescent area strategy would be redirected to new and existing area strategies in South Australia

I ask the minister: which new and existing area strategies will the 1992-93 funding of $10.2 million be redirected towards? Is this $10.2 million now lost to the MFP? Is the federal government withholding the remaining $29.8 million? Under what circumstances will the funding be released?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howe is the minister in charge of the Better Cities program and Senator Richardson represents Minister Howe in this chamber. The use of better cities money for the development of the MFP site at Gillman, which was a decision taken nearly two years ago, has been a matter of negotiation—at times, I would have thought, undue lengthy negotiation—with the state government. I understand that in the last week there have been discussions between the MFP and the state government, and between the federal government and the state government and the minister for housing in charge of this funding, to get final agreement on the expenditure.

PARA.TAB: As Minister responsible for the MFP, I have encouraged a speedy outcome because I would have to agree with Senator Ferguson that at times there has been undue delay in reaching agreement about the expenditure of that money. Senator Ferguson asked about $10 million being redirected—I do not have that information with me, but I will get it and report back to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question I really wanted the minister to answer was: is the $10.2 million, which was to have been allocated in the One Nation funding, now lost to the MFP if it is to be redirected to new and existing area strategies? Does it mean that that $10.2 million is no longer available to the MFP project?
—As I understand it, until these negotiations are completed, I do not believe it will be lost to the MFP.
—When will they be completed?

—As I say, those negotiations have been taking place only in the last few days. Of course, people opposite, as part of their election strategy to assist Mr Brown, will do everything to talk this down or create apprehension that the MFP is not going to work as a major project. As I have said, the negotiations have been going on in recent days, and I am not going to chance my arm in here without getting information about the outcome of those negotiations. When I do, I will report back to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Did the minister see the story on Tuesday evening's 7.30 Report concerning the Australian National Maritime Museum? Is it the case that the Australian National Maritime Museum has no floating exhibits which preserve historic methods of sailing and maritime maintenance, and that it does indeed amount to `a gigantic audio-visual display . . . a colourful shopfront lacking soul'? Is it also the case that the Australian National Maritime Museum has no ties to the Sydney Maritime Museum? If it is the case that it has been left to the Sydney Maritime Museum to preserve our maritime heritage, what steps is the government taking to ensure that either the Sydney Maritime Museum receives funding or the Australian National Maritime Museum is adequately funded to carry out that role?

—That program was, I think, a very sad affront to a lot of very dedicated staff, volunteers and members of the National Maritime Museum. It is extraordinary that people think that all preservation of our maritime heritage happens in Sydney. There are people all around Australia working in voluntary maritime museums doing an enormous amount of work, including in the Sydney Maritime Museum. The last thing I want to do in defending the National Maritime Museum is put down the citizens who put in a lot of good work with the Sydney Maritime Museum and work very cooperatively with the National Maritime Museum. I think it is a great pity that the 7.30 Report did that because the evidence is that it should have known better.

PARA.TAB: There are hundreds of volunteers and thousands of members giving lots of support to the maritime museum. It seems very strange that the 7.30 Report, as I understand it, was commenting about the fact that there were not any vessels, as it put it, like the Lady Hopetoun—which was the one it was displaying on the screen at the time—at the maritime museum when, in fact, as I am advised, the program had filmed it at the National Maritime Museum wharves. So it is a bit hard to understand how the 7.30 Report makes that point. The connection between the two is lost on me, but it was not lost on the viewers because the program did not tell them that that is where it had filmed it.

There are 13 Australian heritage vessels, power and sail, displayed by the National Maritime Museum. I do not want to mislead the Senate. I am advised that the Lady Hopetoun is the Sydney Maritime Museum's vessel but it is on display under charter at the National Maritime Museum. To say that we will not find anything like that at the National Maritime Museum is wrong, because that is exactly where we would go to find it, along with 13 other Australian heritage vessels.

The 7.30 Report went on to say that the Australian National Maritime Museum does not display the real living maritime traditions. I am not quite sure what that means, and I am not quite sure what it says about the staff and the volunteers who sailed one of the maritime museum's fishing boats in a regatta last weekend. Whether those people are not living or those things are not exhibitions at the maritime museum, I am not sure, but neither fact seemed to disturb the 7.30 Report one bit. There may be a few people around here who will not be surprised about that, but I do not want to comment on that; that is someone else's responsibility.

There has been an enormous amount of acclaim for the National Maritime Museum. It has been established and recognised as being in the top echelon of maritime museums worldwide. Last week in a public lecture in Sydney the senior curator of the Royal Naval Museum at Portsmouth lauded the maritime museum for the exceptional, high-quality displays which it presents.

It is a pity that when we are developing an important national heritage institution our national broadcasters should fail to take into account the positives. No institution should be exempt from criticism, including the maritime museum. It would be the first to say it is in the development stage and needs to improve. It is improving and it will continue to improve. But it is important that, if people want to criticise it, they get the facts right and look at the positives as well.

In response to another part of Senator Bourne's question, it does work very closely with the Sydney Maritime Museum, and I welcome that. I am advised that it also has been giving heritage advice to an interviewer from the 7.30 Report about his personal motor launch restoration project. He has received considerable assistance from curators at the National Maritime Museum, but the 7.30 Report did not mention that either.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Did the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services express a view to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority as to the propriety of purchasing the Spanish hull and having it fitted out as a replacement for the Cape Moreton? If it did express such a view, what was it?

—Not only was DAAS involved in this exercise but there was also close consultation with the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development. The answer that I gave yesterday to Senator Vanstone on the same question provided information that, effectively, the hulls concerned were bankrupt stock. That is, in fact, the case. At the time that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority conducted a worldwide search for suitable vessels and these two hulls, which were precisely in accordance with the requirements of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, were found, they were in the hands of liquidators. Extensive consultation was conducted between the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and the departments that I have just mentioned.
—What was the advice?

—I will provide it to Senator Vanstone. A thorough search of Australian shipyards was conducted. In fact, AMSA was offered two partially built vessels by different overseas shipyards at extremely competitive prices. The hulls were at such a stage that only the early fit-out had commenced and AMSA was in the fortunate position of being able to commission the remaining fit-out to precisely its needs.

PARA.TAB: AMSA became aware of these vessels. Prior to that, it had considered an extremely wide range of options for servicing the navigation aids network and concluded that the most cost-effective alternative to continuing with the 30-year-old ship that it had was to charter another vessel for the next three years. However, after this search, which I referred to yesterday, AMSA was unsuccessful in finding a suitable vessel for charter. But it was during the search for this vessel that it discovered the availability of these partially built vessels overseas that were then in the hands of liquidators.

As I said, AMSA had consulted major ship builders in Australia to ascertain whether they could offer a competitive proposal. None of the Australian companies was able to make a competitive offer on either price or delivery date. The Australian Shipbuilders Association wrote to me in May this year. I provided a comprehensive response to it at that time, which gave a detailed explanation of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority's actions in this regard.

AMSA has an obligation to provide the most cost-effective services to the Australian shipping industry that it can; that is part of its charter, which is no doubt fully supported on convenient occasions by the opposition. The difference in rough terms is that it will be able to take delivery of its vessel at a fully capitalised cost of something less than $19 million. Providing exactly the same vessel to the same requirements at a fully capitalised cost from an Australian shipbuilding yard would have cost somewhere between $25 million and $30 million, which is an extremely significant difference. I am not talking about price margins of five per cent, 10 per cent or even 20 per cent.

Under those circumstances, AMSA was in a fortuitous one-off situation. It would have had to expend in the order of $10 million to $11 million in additional capital to commission such a ship in an Australian shipyard. Under those circumstances, AMSA took the correct decision.

My office advised a journalist from the Australian Financial Review last night not only of this information but also of the name of Mr McGrath of AMSA and his home and work telephone numbers. That journalist did not bother contacting him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister indicated that the first most cost-effective option decided on by AMSA was the charter of an alternative vessel for three years. Will he provide the Senate with information as to the cost-effectiveness of all the options considered by AMSA? Did the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services wholeheartedly endorse the proposal? I note he was kind enough to say that it was consulted but not kind enough to indicate what it said in response to those consultations. The minister was also kind enough to say that he will offer its advice. Will he also offer to me the advice given by DITARD? Lastly, will he provide to the Senate the information that he gave to DAAS and DITARD on which they formulated the view that they gave back?

—The last part of the question was a complete nonsense. Senator Vanstone should have stuck to her original script. Senator Vanstone has got a bit of publicity, which she is obviously pleased about, from a newspaper that, in respect of reporting anything concerned with me, has abandoned any pretence of objectivity in what purports to be a news article.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the full details were provided by me to the Australian shipbuilding industry in June. I will provide Senator Vanstone with the material that she is seeking. I say again that full consultation was engaged in by AMSA with both those departments. All Australian shipbuilding yards that were capable of providing this vessel were approached by AMSA and invited to submit designs and prices. As I said to Senator Vanstone in the Senate, the price for the vessel it now has came in at the fully capitalised cost of something under $19 million. To buy the same vessel from an Australian shipyard would have cost somewhere between $25 million and $30 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I direct my question to you. I ask whether you have had the opportunity to give further consideration to your ruling of last Thursday night during the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1993, in light of the considerable controversy which that decision generated?
—I thank Senator Colston for giving me some notice of this question. I have been approached by a number of senators from both sides of the chamber—
—Give me their names.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them are sitting quite close to you. I have been approached by a number of senators from both sides of the chamber to clarify some of the issues raised last Thursday night during the debate. I do not intend to do so at this stage, but I have had a paper prepared. With the concurrence of the Senate I will incorporate it in the Hansard. I think that will give all senators an opportunity to examine some of the issues that were involved.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: Since the proceedings in the Senate on 21 and 22 October, I have further considered my ruling and the matters which were raised in debate, and I have concluded that the ruling was completely correct and appropriate.

The rationale of the ruling is that a clear majority is required to make an amendment or request to a bill when the bill is first considered, and therefore a clear majority should be required to insist on an amendment or request which has been disagreed to by the House of Representatives. If the majority which was required to make the amendment or request in the first instance is no longer in existence, clearly the amendment or request is lost. Much of the debate was not directed to this fundamental logical proposition.

Much attention was given in the debate to the last phrase of section 23 of the Constitution: "when the votes are equal the question shall pass in the negative"; but insufficient attention was given to the first sentence of the section: "Questions arising in the Senate shall be determined by a majority of votes". The procedures of the Senate are designed, and should be interpreted, to ensure that positive decisions, such as amending or passing a bill, are made only by a majority.

I circulated to party leaders and to independent senators on 18 October, 3 days before the ruling was given, the advice which I had received in anticipation of the situation which eventually arose and the ruling which I proposed to make in that situation. Senators therefore had the opportunity to consider the ruling in advance. There was nothing different about the situation which arose on 21 October which affected the logic of the ruling or which required any change to the ruling.
I take this opportunity to respond to the following points which were raised during the debate:

It was stated during the debate that my ruling was predicated on both questions, that the requests be pressed and that the requests not be pressed, having been negatived in committee of the whole. On the contrary, the ruling was not predicated on both questions being negatived, but clearly indicated that the conclusion must be the same regardless of which question was put and negatived. The voting on either question indicated that there was no longer a majority in favour of the requests. As I indicated, I gave the ruling on the substantive question of the effect of the committee's votes before the vote had been taken on the second motion in committee, in response to invitations from Senator Evans and in response to canvassing of the issue by Senator Hill and other senators.

Reference was made to the fact that the passage in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice which I quoted in my ruling refers to amendments and not requests. I acknowledged this in my ruling. The point is that the statement which is made there must as a matter of logic apply to both requests and amendments. Both require a majority to be carried.

Reference was made to the ruling by President Young, also referred to in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, that if the question that requests not be pressed is negatived the requests are pressed. That ruling, however, clearly refers to a situation in which the motion is negatived by a majority. That result would not be changed if the question were put in the alternative form, that the requests be pressed. As I pointed out in my ruling, with equally divided votes the situation is quite different, and the effect of the Senate's vote cannot be held to depend on which motion is moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the federal budget's massive increase in wine tax and petrol tax and the extraordinary damage this will cause to my own state of South Australia. I ask: is it true that no access was given to the South Australian state Labor government in the decision-making processes for the federal budget? If it is not true, what were the representations the federal government actually received from the South Australian government about the wine tax and the petrol tax? Is it not true that the only reported effort Premier Arnold has made and the only reported access that he has been given was in a public verbal brawl with John Dawkins, when Mr Arnold said:

PARA.TAB: I have to say those two issues anger us in South Australia, they come at a time when the economy did not need it.
So much goodwill has been destroyed by those two taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that Mr Arnold is a very powerful and effective advocate for South Australia. I have never been in any doubt about that. It is very bipartisan and honest of Senator Teague to raise this matter. I think it is a noble exercise of bipartisanship to raise this effective advocacy by Mr Arnold on behalf of South Australia in these two matters. Over all the years that I have known the various members of the South Australian government, it has been my experience that they are effective advocates for their state—even when I disagree with them. Sometimes I find them much too effective advocates for their state and I wish they were not. It is certainly true about Lynn Arnold in his public comments with regard to both these matters. He raised those issues forcefully.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the specifics of Senator Teague's question, the South Australian government, as far as I know, got exactly the same access to the budget process as all the other state governments. But, after the budget, when the matter was public and open for debate, I suspect that no-one would be in any doubt that, on these two matters, the most effective premier on behalf of his state was Lynn Arnold. If we compare his performance on the wine tax with that of Jeff Kennett, John Fahey—both of whom represent states with a substantial wine industry—or Richard Court, they were invisible. The evidence which I cite is that which Senator Teague quoted in such an effective and bipartisan manner, and I thank him for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has not referred to one specific effective outcome of any representations made by the failed Labor government in South Australia. I again put the question to the minister and I ask him to give a specific answer. Is there any evidence of any effective representation that has been made by the state Labor government in South Australia—this failed government—on either the wine tax or the fuel tax? Is there any evidence that the minister can now demonstrate that has been in fact taken into consideration by the Labor government in the way it has punished my state of South Australia? This is a failed premier who has been ineffective in putting any views to this government.
—I think it is much too late to retrieve the situation from Senator Teague's first question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the minister aware, firstly, that a secondary life insurance market has existed in the United Kingdom for more than 100 years; and, secondly, that such a market has now been established in Australia through the Life Insurance Policy Exchange? The business of the exchange is buying and then reselling mid-term life insurance policies. Thirdly, is the minister aware that the exchange claims: to offer to buy from consumers mid-term life insurance policies at a higher price than that offered by the insurance companies and, in doing so, to give the policyholders a choice of a higher price for the policy if they wish to dispose of it; that the sales of the policies by the exchange offer a further investment alternative to the Australian public; and that the Australian insurance companies, including the AMP Society, are moving to prevent or stifle the growth of this secondary life insurance market by misinforming policyholders who inquire—
—Order! Will you finalise the question? Time has run out.

—The advice to backbenchers is that they should give ministers more notice of their questions so that we can edit them, I suppose. I understand that the issues underlying Senator Beahan's question relate to a complaint by the Life Insurance Policy Exchange that some Australian insurance companies may be engaging in anti-competitive behaviour. My attention has been drawn to that complaint. It is a complaint which was directed, as would be appropriate, to the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear, in his capacity as the minister responsible for the Trade Practices Commission. In accordance with the normal practice, Mr Gear's office has referred this matter in the standard manner to the Trade Practices Commission and it is being considered by the Trade Practices Commission. It is not a matter on which I think I can comment any further.

PARA.TAB: The facts, as outlined by Senator Beahan at the commencement of his question, about the international experiences are, as I understand it, correct. As to whether Australian insurance companies have been engaging in anti-competitive behaviour, that is a matter on which the Trade Practices Commission will deliberate and make a finding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During question time on 26 October, Senator Campbell asked me a question in relation to which I undertook to obtain further advice as to, first of all, a reported comment by the Treasurer on the size of the possible compensation bill for Mabo regarding validation of title; and, secondly, the question of how compensation payments will be treated for taxation purposes.

PARA.TAB: As to the first part, Senator Campbell's question was predicated on the report of the Australian Financial Review of 26 October that the Treasurer had estimated that compensation costs arising from the Mabo decision would be around only $100 million. I am informed that this was a misrepresentation of what the Treasurer actually said, which was along the lines that the total compensation cost was difficult to estimate but was likely to be in the order of hundreds of millions rather than a billion. This was a general statement, heavily qualified, in accord with the views previously expressed by other ministers, including me, and was not drawing on any particular analysis prepared by the Treasury.

As to the second matter, the question of how the compensation payments will be treated for the purposes of taxation is yet to be considered definitively by the government. Since it is likely to be some time before any compensation for extinguishment or impairment of native title is required to be paid, there will clearly be time for balanced consideration to be given by the government to all relevant issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some further information to provide to Senator Watson in respect of the question he asked me yesterday about the impact that industrial action is having on branches of the Australian Taxation Office and revenue. The Australian Tax Office advises that there are 24 branches processing tax payments. Industrial action is affecting only nine of those branches; the remaining 15 are not experiencing difficulties. Since the bans were applied on 13 September, a total of $9.2 billion has been processed, of which $8.3 billion has been banked without obstruction, leaving some $850 million not banked. There has not been any significant or real threat to the revenue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 September 1993 I undertook to obtain further advice for Senator Boswell about the impact of native title on the rights of Aboriginal people who reside on land of which they are not the traditional owners. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker) have provided the following information. Because it is somewhat lengthy, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: "The Government has consistently made it clear that the existing rights of all title holders will be protected. Furthermore, there is a provision in the Outline of Proposed Legislation on Native Title released by the Government on 2 September 1993, at paragraph 21 (c), which makes it clear that where there are reservations or conditions for the benefit of any person, including any Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person, in a grant then any rights and interests protected by that reservation or condition will continue.

The Federal Court found recently in the Pareroultja case that native title is not extinguished by grants made to Aboriginal people under the Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act. It would appear likely that, in general, grants made under laws for the special benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will not have extinguished native title. It is therefore quite possible that native title will continue to exist on at least some DOGIT land in Queensland.

In these circumstances where Aboriginal people who are not the native title holders have a right to reside on the land, that right and any other rights flowing from it will be able to be confirmed as a result of the Commonwealth legislation.

It should be borne in mind, of course, that where a grant of title is valid there is no legal question about the ability of the title holders or anyone else with rights under the grant, native title holder or not, to continue to enjoy all the rights that they do now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked by Senator Patterson whether the Office of the Status of Women was consulted about the review of population programs for developing countries. My response is that the office was not consulted.

DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF PENSION INCOME AND ASSETS TEST

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement about the tabling of the draft terms of reference for a review of the pension income and assets test.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) announced a review of the pension income and assets test on 19 October this year. The review will be undertaken by an independent consultant who will be selected through an open tender process. The reference group, made up of experts drawn from peak retiree and veterans groups, the finance and superannuation industry and the relevant Commonwealth departments, will provide advice to the consultant.

PARA.TAB: Today I am tabling on behalf of the Minister for Social Security the draft terms of reference for the review. The review will examine the conceptual framework, design principles and the actual operation of the income and assets test. The review will also examine the interaction of the social security and taxation systems, assess current provisions, including the treatment of investments against the design principles, and identify options for change to the current income and assets test.

The minister is continually consulting older people and their representatives about the review. He will be in Brisbane tomorrow to meet with the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation. He will be discussing the terms of reference with them and other groups over the next week. At the end of that time the minister expects the terms of reference to take account broadly of the views of such groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As Senator Richardson indicated, the draft terms of reference have now been tabled. This is obviously in response to the resolution of the Senate that there should be an overall review of income and assets tests as the means of assessing eligibility for the pension. We have had the debacle, which has gone on for some months now, in which many older people have been very distressed because they are unable to understand their position. This review is taking place not before time.

PARA.TAB: I would like to put on the public record that yesterday I received what I think is a very sad letter from a couple who are both over 80 and live in New South Wales. They expressed their gratitude to me for having pressed the issue and for being instrumental in having an inquiry set up to investigate why the government in part decided to overturn its decision to treat unrealised capital gains as income for the purpose of assessing the pension.

This couple said they were concerned that the Minister for Social Security, Mr Baldwin, was to review the matter. All of us in this chamber must be conscious of ensuring that this review does not cause pensioners more concern about the possibility of further uncertainty. It should be made clear that what we are trying to do is make the system as fair as possible.

I hope Mr Baldwin will put to rest any fears that older people have—especially the people in their 80s and 90s who have written to us—about being threatened yet again by more changes. I do not know how we can do that, but we should all attempt to make sure that this review does not produce uncertainty and we should give assurances to those older people that as far as possible things can remain predictable for them. We should all do this because a number of older people have expressed concern. The way this couple wrote their letter made me realise that it is all very well for us to talk about reviews but they are on the receiving end and feeling very threatened and vulnerable.

I hope the government will consult with the Democrats, the Independents and the coalition about those terms of reference. I put on the public record that I have a number of concerns about the terms of reference. I think the objectives of review, which come under dot point two, should be expanded to add `and the treatment of capital gains on shares and managed investments'. Dot point one, dealing with the scope of the review, should be amended to replace the word `retaining' with `maximising' in the line `retaining incentives for self-provision'. Also dot point two should be expanded by adding at the end `in lieu of the decision not to take all pensioners out of the tax system by 1995'. I am not sure that the government will agree to that point.

A further dot point should be added under the scope of the review and should read `the need to increase national savings'. The specialist reference group suggested in the draft terms of reference appears to me to be somewhat Public Service dominated. While the coalition recognises that there should be Public Service involvement with a specialist reference group, the involvement should be minimal. There is no mention in the draft terms of reference as to how the specialist group will be selected. I believe it ought to be selected independently of the minister. The government must have a resolution passed by the Senate within five sitting days which approves the terms of reference and the reporting date or, on the basis of the resolution which was agreed to some weeks ago, the Senate will set up its own independent inquiry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I welcome these terms of reference. They have taken on board most of the issues that the Australian Democrats have raised. I wish to point out that we have been pushing for this inquiry to go ahead. I note with interest that the Liberal Party also decided to do this.

PARA.TAB: We need to get away from this continuing battle of who thought of what first and start considering what we are doing to the pensioner community. It is the messages we are sending out that are putting pressure on the pensioners. It is now up to our various offices to write back to people to assure them that this inquiry is about getting the certainty that they are so desperately seeking.

I put to all honourable senators that we must sell this as a positive and that we must put the minds of pensioners at rest. We still have problems within the system. I emphasise again that the capital gains problems with pensioner shares and, in particular, with managed investments are causing a lot of that uncertainty. We cannot ignore the fact that the Liberals supported that in last year's budget. That is something that they would like to forget, but I do not believe that they should be allowed to. I welcome this inquiry. I hope that we are able to work cooperatively to make sure that these terms of reference take into account everybody's concerns as much as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to statements by the ABC Managing Director, Mr David Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly want to take note of this answer because of the scant and shabby disregard that Senator Collins had for the concerns that are raised in this matter. It is fair enough for David Hill to have personal views on the republic. It is fair enough for him to be a staunch advocate of the republic. My understanding is that, prior to his unloading himself to the Age, he had been at a meeting that night where he very extensively spelt out his private views. But it is a fundamentally different proposition for him to then choose to give an interview to a journalist of a national newspaper in which he makes clear, in very strong terms, what his views are on an issue of great controversy in this country.

PARA.TAB: We can all disagree, but it is an absolute fiction to pretend that the Managing Director of the ABC can somehow have a licence afforded to him to speak publicly as a private citizen. It is simply not on. It would be like Senator Gareth Evans getting up and saying that he privately agrees with the Liberal Party on an issue—I know that he would never be caught doing this—and then saying, `How outrageous of anyone to quarrel because I was not contradicting party policy; I was speaking as a private citizen'. One cannot do that. The fact is that Mr Hill is presiding over an organisation—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about when he talks about rugby league, particularly North Sydney, which is broadcast by a commercial network?

—That is not compromising the ABC. You are a silly fellow. If Mr Hill got up and said, `I think that Australian Rules ought to be outlawed in this country', then I would have a lot more to say about it. But if he simply says that he is a follower of rugby league, even though he has got a record that goes close to emulating Collingwood in terms of losing streaks, he is entitled to barrack for the wrong team; he is entitled to back a loser.
—What about when he attacks the tobacco industry?
—Order! There are too many interjections, Senator Schacht. I wish I could send someone to the sin-bin.

—All journalists working for the ABC have an obligation to pursue their trade in a manner which is utterly impartial—which is not influenced by pressures from political, commercial or other sectional interests or their own personal views. If it is good enough for them, why can it be good enough for the managing director to get out there and talk in the most extravagant terms?

PARA.TAB: A matter of concern to me is that I wrote to Mr Hill on 29 September—that is four weeks ago. I complained to him about the conduct of one of his senior political journalists and the way in which she aired very one-sided views on the political process. I have not had the courtesy of a reply. In other words, Mr Hill is too busy to reply to that sort of issue, but he has plenty of time to get out there and make statements which are fundamentally wrong.

Even Senator Gareth Evans would know that, when Mr Hill is quoted as saying that the minimalist position put in the Turnbull report was `mind-bogglingly simple', he has got it absolutely wrong. The Turnbull report is an options paper; it does not contain a simple proposition. Indeed, Turnbull himself has said that there is no such thing as a minimalist position. For Mr Hill to get out there and express his views is one thing; to express them wrongly and in a partisan fashion is another. But to pretend that somehow he is a private citizen when he takes sides in the most extreme fashion is totally unacceptable.

The ABC has been bedevilled by divisive comments. Over the last six months or so the place has been seething; there has been absolute turmoil. What the ABC needs above all else is someone who brings a calm and reasoned hand to the tiller—not someone who picks up an ashtray whenever he is provoked, but someone who is capable of ensuring that the ABC does have—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want a eunuch like yourself?
—I would dispute that. Come outside and I will deal with you.
—You are lucky you are not in the navy.
—I will hit you with a writ—nothing else.
—Order! This is hardly lifting the standard of debate.

—It is therefore, I think, totally unacceptable to imagine that Mr Hill can be allowed to continue in his position without the ABC's integrity being compromised. It has a reputation for impartiality which no doubt the board wants to see upheld in all circumstances. Yet here we have the managing director of the ABC indulging himself in the most partisan and extreme manner. It is simply not good enough. It is certainly not good enough for Senator Collins to pretend that this is not a matter of concern. It certainly is; we will hear more of it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion to take note of an answer given by Senator Collins. I could not believe that the first question the opposition asked today in question time was this one about Mr Hill's remarks on the republican issue.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has gone on at length saying that the number one issue to deal with in Australia is the economy—the social issues and so on. It says that the republican issue is a side issue which we are raising to divert attention away from the economic issues.

If that is the case, why was this the first question asked in the Senate today by the opposition? If those opposite think that we are creating a diversion with the republican debate, why did Senator Alston not get up here today and ask the first question about an economic issue? Why did he not get up and ask a question about the excellent CPI figure that came out yesterday?

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—These are the economic issues that I thought those opposite would have been interested in raising.
—Is that a matter of controversy? It is a good figure.

—We have consistently said that the Australian people can deal with a number of issues at any one time. Those opposite have gone around saying, `The republican issue is a diversion; let's just stick to economics'.

PARA.TAB: The first question today in the Senate was about what Mr Hill said on the republic. Those opposite cannot keep away from the republican issue. They are like Pavlov's dogs. As soon as someone mentions `republic', they all froth and jump on it. They do not want to talk about the economy any more; it has improved. We got excellent figures yesterday on the CPI. They do not want to talk about it, so they are relying on the republican issue to keep themselves from talking about the economic issue.

Now let us talk about the issue that those opposite are so concerned about. Are they saying Mr Hill, identified today in the Melbourne Age as a member of the Australian republican movement—he has been a member since its foundation, a fact which is publicly known and open to debate and comment by anybody—does not have the right, as an Australian citizen, to be a member of the Australian republican movement?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not entitled to express partisan and extreme views in a public forum on this matter.

—Now we get Senator Alston's formula: you can be a member of the organisation but you cannot express a view. If Senator Alston were consistent, he would say, `You should not even be able to join an organisation that may be controversial, like the Australian republican movement'.
—It would be much better if he didn't.

—Now we are hearing it. Senator Alston is suggesting that Mr Hill cannot even join the organisation. I must say this just shows how far the Liberal Party has come in Australia. The Liberal Party that for so long did have an element of small-l liberalism about the issues of individual conscience and freedom of speech has now got to the stage where a senior spokesman for the opposition is suggesting that a private citizen, Mr Hill—
—But he is not a private citizen; that is the whole point.
—does not have the right to join an organisation.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Schacht raises the issue of freedom of speech but he seems to omit the fact that he was the one who tried to censor the clerks from writing articles.
—Order! There is no point of order. I wonder, without my being overtly interfering, if you could direct your comments through the chair?

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President. Now we are getting the suggestion—from a Liberal Party so fallen, so bereft of the old Liberal ideology—that you cannot join an organisation unless it fits the Liberal ideological prescription. Mr Hill, they now say, should not have joined the republican movement. They are also saying that he cannot publicly comment. The real question is: do those opposite have any evidence that they can put before the board of the ABC that Mr Hill's personal views about a republic are affecting the content of the ABC's programs on the republican issue?

PARA.TAB: If the opposition has that sort of information, it should make the allegation and take it up with the independent board—a cross-section of the community—to see whether the ABC is being biased in reporting the Australian republican movement or any of the remarks made by any of the protagonists on either side of the debate. That is the issue. But what the opposition wants to do is play the person—play the man, as they say in Australian Rules football—rather than play the ball.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Schacht's time has clearly expired.
—Order! Senator O'Chee, I am capable of reading the time. I was allowing Senator Schacht, as I do all senators, to conclude his sentence.

—I rise to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Alston. A lot of comments have been made about how weak this front bench in the Labor Party is. Every time Senator Schacht stands up he demonstrably proves the weakness of the front bench and the Keating government.
