PARA.TAB: This is a serious issue; it is not a trivial issue, as Senator Schacht's comments suggested. It involves ethics. I know that it is always difficult for the Labor Party to grapple with ethics. It is always a problem for Senator Schacht. When an ethical issue is raised, he always has great problems, as do most of his colleagues on the front bench, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about ethics: give us your position on pecuniary interests.
—Isn't he pathetic! We will go about that next time. If Senator Evans wants to raise that debate, we will get on to it.
—You are a bunch of spivs.

—Mr Deputy President, could you give Senator Evans a valium to calm him down so we can proceed. There is a clear issue of ethics here. A major political issue now facing the country, raised by Mr Keating, is whether or not we should become a republic. Mr Keating has put this on the agenda. He has spent hundreds of thousands of taxpayers' dollars in promoting this particular political agenda. There is no question that this is a political issue. It is a political issue because of the way Senator Schacht's colleagues and his Prime Minister have behaved. That is the first point.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that there is clearly a problem when the person who is charged with running the national broadcasting service becomes involved directly in one of the major political debates of the day. If the comments that are published in the Melbourne Age are correct, he has indulged in some rather extremist views, I would have thought. Nonetheless, the person who is running the national broadcasting service is adopting a highly partisan line in relation to a major political issue. Senator Schacht cannot see a question of ethics there and I believe that he cannot see a question of ethics there because he is always blind to ethics. Nothing would be further from his purview than ethics.

I also point out that not only is Mr Hill adopting a highly partisan approach from his position of running the national broadcaster, but also he is indulging in a quite unfounded attack on Mr Hayden, the Governor-General. The irony of this position is that it was Mr Hill's national broadcasting service which sought out Mr Hayden, the Governor-General, to appear on the ABC's Four Corners program. The ABC promoted extensively the interview with Mr Hayden. Having promoted it extensively, Mr Hill proceeded to bag the Governor-General. I believe his behaviour is quite out of court. It is a great pity that Senator Collins, in his comments today, totally failed to address the very real issues which have been raised.

Let us look at some of the extremist comments that David Hill makes. He calls this the monarchist position, the greatest manifestation of the Australian cultural cringe, and he says that Australians are not quite good enough and cannot be trusted enough to shape their own destiny. I point out to the Senate that that is an extremist position. It is very clear that Australia has been an independent nation for a long time.

If Senator Evans were worried about the cultural cringe, if he were worried about Australia having the capacity to control its own destiny, he would not involve Australian domestic disputes in UN committees, and that is what he has done. He has overturned the whole philosophy of the Australia Act. If he really believed in Australia being an independent country, if he really believed that Australia was to control its own destiny, he would not have taken the actions he has taken. If the ABC's David Hill really was concerned about the cultural cringe, he would be concerned about Senator Evans's cultural cringing to the UN on every occasion. If David Hill was concerned about Australia controlling its own destiny, he would be very concerned about the fact that Senator Evans has overturned the philosophy of the Australia Act and he has opened up appeals to UN committees to deal with domestic human rights disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite astounded by the waffle and the garbage we have just heard from Senator Schacht, on the other side of the chamber. Senator Schacht does not understand this issue at all. That is perfectly clear. There are three issues of principle involved. Senator Schacht may not have the ability to count three issues of principle—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator O'Chee talks nonsense wherever he stands, but is he not talking nonsense in the wrong place at the moment? In his capacity as the whip he can sit there, but normally he has to sit over on the back benches where he belongs, does he not?
—Order! My understanding is that he is the whip and that it is the normal practice to speak from where he is.
—On matters of principle—

—Order! I am advised that it is not the normal practice for the acting whips to speak from that position. I wonder whether the Senate might indulge Senator O'Chee because he is on his feet on this occasion. But the rule in the future shall be that he shall speak from his own position.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Senator Schacht cannot count three points of principle, but I am going to give them to him anyway. There are three points of principle involved in this and, if Senator Schacht just keeps quiet a little, I will give him the first point. The first point of principle relates to this man, Mr Hill, who heads up the ABC. The ABC does not allow its journalists to express extreme party political points.
—He is not a journalist.

—I know he is not a journalist, but listen to this point: he heads up the organisation. What Senator Schacht is saying is, `Look, it's fine for David Hill to do this because he's right at the top, but if you happen to be a journalist somewhere underneath and you have to take Mr Hill's orders, well tough luck. You have got to follow the rules but, if you're the head of the organisation, you don't have to follow the rules'.
—Imagine what will happen now to some of those blokes down below.

—Yes, imagine what will happen now to some of those fellows. What is good for the goose is good for the gander. Senator Schacht does not agree with that. He thinks he can have one rule for the fellow at the top and another rule for everybody underneath. I suppose that is the first lesson in republican rule—throw out the rules and do it all by whim. That is what Senator Schacht is advocating in his defence of Mr Hill's despicable attack on the Governor-General. Senator Schacht is advocating that we throw out the rules. So that is it—that is very clear. Now we know where the Labor Party stands.

PARA.TAB: But let us remember one other thing: this is a despicable personal attack on the Governor-General; a personal attack on the Governor-General's bona fides; a personal attack which is quite clearly defamatory; a personal attack which is designed to engender hatred and intolerance. That is all that the other side stands for.

This was not a sane, reasonable and rational argument. He called the Governor-General a hypocrite and all sorts of things. Why? Because it suited him. That is how we find the argument conducted on the other side—not on the basis of logic but on the basis of personal attack and personal vilification of the Governor-General, who is the effective Australian head of state.

Senator Schacht might want to consider this third point of principle: if this is what will happen under republican rule, how bad will it be if we have an elected president? If we cannot even have a little bit of respect for a Governor-General who is non-partisan, who does not represent a political viewpoint, how riven with division will this society be if the people on the other side have their way? Nothing will be sacrosanct; we will be able to say whatever we want about the head of state. Will this make us a more united country? The answer is no. If even a little bit of respect cannot be given to a non-partisan Governor-General, who could say nothing else, quite clearly the divisions which will arise in this country if the republican rabble on the other side have their way will be quite frightening.

All we are asking for is a little bit of decency, a little bit of consistency. What is good for the goose is good for the gander. If the journalists in the ABC have to follow some ethical standards, we would expect that the head of the ABC would do so as well. But under this government, of course, it seems that rules go out the door, depending on one's political preference or, rather, on one's political prejudice. Senator Schacht has always left the facts, reasonableness and commonsense outside the door when his prejudice has stepped in the way. That is what we are seeing in this chamber today: Senator Schacht getting up, as rabid as usual, to defend the indefensible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Carr this day, relating to the Victorian Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Ms Moira Rayner.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been indicated today that Moira Rayner's dismissal has reflected yet again the increasing authoritarianism that occurs within Victoria whereby people who take different political positions, while exercising their proper and legitimate legal statutory function, are dismissed.

PARA.TAB: The President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Sir Ronald Wilson—a prominent jurist and leading church member in this society—has indicated just how crook this situation is. There are currently 320 federal cases being handled by the Victorian Equal Opportunity Commission, and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission provides some 30 per cent of the funding for the Victorian commission.

What Jeff Kennett has miscalculated is that the present commissioner, one he is trying to dismiss, is, in fact, legislated a delegation of power by this parliament. That power cannot be removed by an action of the Victorian government. In some respects, one has to question just how carefully this proposition has been thought through.

We saw in the Age this morning that Mr Gude recently demanded that the Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Moira Rayner, supply him with the full and complete details of the confidential complaints being made against the Victorian government's new employment laws. Of course, this was her major crime. She first of all suggested, on the basis of a referral from the former Labor government, after a two-year inquiry, that the Fairlea prison should not be closed down because it was discriminatory against women. Some months later she went on to suggest that there were some problems in Victoria as a result of there being a 50 per cent increase in the number of job related complaints to her commission because of changes to the employment laws in that state. What we are seeing is a vindictive, vicious government in action, seeking now to remove her from her position. As I indicated, the human rights legislation of this parliament provides some protection for her. It will be interesting to see just how far the Victorian government is prepared to go in contravention of that legislation from this parliament.

This is particularly important in Victoria, where 30 per cent of the population comes from non-English speaking backgrounds and where significant questions are now being asked about the human rights violations of industrial laws that are being implemented. Just this week we have seen legislation before the Victorian parliament which tried to deny people rights of access to the Supreme Court of that state without the permission of the education minister.

In Victoria we are seeing judges dismissed and injured workers denied legal representation. We are seeing the Law Reform Commission abolished. We are seeing a plethora of actions being taken by a government that is preoccupied with crushing dissent and crushing people who have a different point of view and who stand up for basic human rights. Despite the legal implications, the Victorian government is prepared to press ahead with it. One can only suggest that this is a matter that will come full circle. I trust that the Australian Labor government will take up these matters because they are fundamental issues that go to the question of civil liberties in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —After all the hot air, froth and bubble we have heard from Senator Carr, would he believe that the Labor government is trying to sack the federal Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin? Considering the stories that have been raised in the newspapers in the last couple of weeks, it is an astonishing touch of irony that Senator Carr now jumps up in this chamber and tries to drum up a big issue about the changes to the arrangements of the Equal Opportunity Commission in Victoria announced by Premier Kennett.

PARA.TAB: I listened very carefully to what Senator Carr said, and I listened very carefully to what Senator Bolkus said in his answer to Senator Carr's question. I could not hear any complaints that the five new commissioners will be any less independent and I did not hear any attacks on the standing of those people. The case that Senator Carr was trying to drum up and get so excited about was not made out.

This Labor government will be changing the structure of the federal Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. We all know that Commissioner Burdekin is on the nose with ministers. I would not take bets on Mr Burdekin being reappointed, and I guess Senator Carr would not either. It always amuses me when Senator Carr gets up to talk about human rights. He is the sort of person who believes that people must join unions. He wants to force people to join unions. He wants to force people to go on strike. He is the great promoter of those particular rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have amused the little acolyte.

—It is well known around this chamber that Senator Ray is not Senator Carr's greatest fan. He probably feels about Senator Carr exactly the same way that I feel about Senator Carr. He should really keep quiet. For Senator Carr to be talking about human rights, with his record on industrial disputes and his record as a key adviser to the Kirner government, which has mortgaged the future of all of Victorians, is an irony.
—If your dad didn't own the think tank, maybe you would have had to earn a living.
—There is a further irony in all this.
—He had to earn a living, not like you.

—If Senator Ray keeps calm, we might even get to that irony. Senator Carr had to earn a living! He was on the payroll of the Kirner government for nine years and I do not think anyone would describe that as earning a living.

PARA.TAB: When Labor Party members attack the Kennett government and the restructuring of the Equal Opportunity Commission in Victoria, one thing it is alleged they are most worried about is that this may breach international standards on human rights. These are the independence boys who constantly assert, like the good republicans they all claim to be, that Australia must be independent, and they have signed us up to the UN like no other government in Australian history. As I pointed out to Senator Gareth Evans, and got him very excited a moment ago, they have overturned the philosophy of the Australia Act. UN human rights committees can now involve themselves in Australian domestic disputes.

Senator Carr and his colleagues are the very last people to run the independence line for Australia. They have sold this country out time and again. Whatever feelings that a pre-war monarchist may have had for the British empire, it is nothing like the adoration that Senator Carr and his colleagues feel for the United Nations. They have shown their willingness to involve us ceaselessly and unthinkingly in UN human rights conventions, to trade off the independence of this country and to allow Australian disputes to go to UN committees quite contrary to the philosophy of the Australia Act. Senator Carr has no role in standing up in this chamber and speaking about the independence of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to Senator Kemp analysing the issue. I suggest to him that there is a difference between this issue and what we might or might not do with Mr Burdekin, a person for whom I have great respect. Mr Brian Burdekin will not be dismissed in the middle of his term. The most that can happen is that he will not be reappointed.
—Ha, ha!
—Even Senator O'Chee would understand that there is a very big difference between that and firing people when they are halfway through their term.

PARA.TAB: Moira Rayner was appointed in 1990 for five years. She was fired in circumstances that suggested she was sacked because of the approach she took in standing up to the government, which introduced proceedings that were clearly objectionable. If a government is going to sack people because they do not do what it wants, that government is a tyrant. That is an altogether different issue—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cooney, the time allotted for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on a national drought policy. I seek leave to incorporate the document and a tabling statement in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON RURAL AND REGIONAL AFFAIRS (SSCRRA) REPORT ON A NATIONAL DROUGHT POLICY

1.The Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs tabled its Final Report on a National Drought Policy in July 1992. The Government did not respond formally to the report at that time because action was being taken to implement a National Drought Policy which is supported by the recommendations and conclusions of the Senate Standing Committee report.
2.Key conclusions of the SSCRRA report are:
.National Drought Policy (NDP) should encourage a self-reliant approach to drought.
.The policy should ensure adequate maintenance and protection of livestock and other resources to ensure early recovery from drought.
.Drought should not be reinstated within the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements (NDRA).

.That a number of problems with the Rural Adjustment Scheme, which is the principal source of Commonwealth assistance to farmers in financial difficulties due to drought, should be addressed in the 1992 Review of the Scheme.
.The Commonwealth should provide financial incentives for the preparation and management for drought.
.An effective Income Equalisation Deposit (IED) scheme should be introduced.
.The Government should review taxation arrangements for drought preparedness related expenditure, including the introduction of tax credits.
.Consideration should be given to the introduction of transitional arrangements for Commonwealth drought assistance pending the full implementation of the NDP.
.The IED review should consider the extension of income smoothing and tax averaging provisions to non-farm rural businesses.
.New approaches to self-reliance should be accompanied by information programs and relevant advisory services and training programs that develop farm business and financial management skills.
.Resources should be directed towards research into climate prediction and resources should be extended in this area.
.Commonwealth Government has a responsibility to provide additional assistance during severe drought to protect and maintain Australia's agricultural base and productive capacity.
.Assistance in severe drought needs to be consistent and clearly enunciated.

.Minister for Primary Industries and Energy should urgently consider the proposals presented by the National Farmers' Federation and the Cattle Council of Australia to alleviate the effects of extreme drought.

3.The National Drought Policy which was agreed by the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand in July 1992 was announced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon Simon Crean, in August 1992. The policy sees drought as a normal feature of Australian agriculture which should be treated as such. The main focus is on farm management which takes into account the risks associated with drought and adheres to the principles of sustainable agriculture. The Drought Policy Statement is at Attachment A to this response.
The issues raised by the SSCRRA and the Government's response are set out below.
National Drought Policy should encourage a self-reliant approach to drought.

4.The National Drought Policy (NDP) encourages self reliant approaches to drought by treating it as one of the many risks for which managers of the farm business must prepare. The Policy seeks to address the past approach of reliance on Government assistance during drought periods by removing the emphasis on transaction based subsidies and drought declarations. The NDP seeks to improve farmers' management skills so that they can make appropriate business decisions in a deregulated economy. This will be achieved by providing farmers with property management planning training.
The policy should ensure adequate maintenance and protection of livestock and other resources to ensure early recovery from drought.

5.In encouraging farmers to take a self reliant approach to managing the risks associated with drought, farmers are being encouraged, through property management planning training, to take the necessary steps to protect their basic resources including the land and their livestock. Farmers are being encouraged to develop management strategies which establish agricultural production levels in accordance with land capability and practices which ensure conservation of natural resources and ecosystems. Under these strategies, farmers are urged to undertake appropriate management actions, such as destocking in time of drought. Support may be available to farmers to assist them to recover following a period of exceptional circumstances, such as severe drought, as well as obtaining support through the period of downturn. Under the exceptional circumstance provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme, eligible farmers may be able to access up to 100 per cent interest subsidies on finance to make productivity improvements, including restocking and pasture replanting. Drought should not be reinstated within the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements (NDRA).

6.The National Drought Policy confirms that drought will not be reinstated within the NDRA. The Drought Policy Review Task Force recommended against the reinstatement of drought within the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements as this approach "would be anathema to a more equitable, efficient and environmentally responsible policy framework and in promoting a more self-reliant approach to the management of drought". This recommendation was endorsed by Commonwealth and State agricultural Ministers and forms the basis of the National Drought Policy.

That a number of problems with the Rural Adjustment Scheme, which is the principal source of Commonwealth assistance to farmers in financial difficulties due to drought, should be addressed in the 1992 Review of the Scheme.

7.The comprehensive review of the Rural Adjustment Scheme undertaken in 1992, examined all aspects of the Scheme's operation. In particular its recommendations focused on the mechanisms for achieving structural adjustment in the rural sector. In considering these recommendations, the Government assessed their appropriateness within a rural policy framework for the development of a more forward looking and resilient rural sector. This process was instrumental in ensuring that Government involvement in providing support to the rural sector, particularly in time of severe downturn, is consistent with meeting overriding objectives of sustainability, productivity and profitability. Subsequent to the review of the Scheme that saw new arrangements for it put in place, a feedback process has been established whereby Authorities responsible for the administration of RAS in the States will be able to better tailor assistance according to actual effectiveness and emerging priorities.
The Commonwealth should provide financial incentives for the preparation and management of drought.

8.The Commonwealth and State Governments gave serious consideration to this recommendation in formulating the National Drought Policy. Although some States indicated a preference for financial incentives, the general consensus was that they should not be offered as such incentives tend to distort the decision making process in favour of particular activities which may or may not be suitable to the circumstances affecting individual farms. For this reason, Governments agreed not to provide financial incentives but instead decided to provide farmers with training and general incentives to improve productivity through changes to the Rural Adjustment Scheme. Subsidies available under the Scheme may support eligible farmers to undertake drought preparedness measures, such as improving fodder and water storage. Importantly, grants are available for farmers to improve the financial management of their enterprises by accessing training and obtaining professional advice through RAS. Training is also available through the Property Management Planning campaign. These latter measures are seen as being important tools for achieving a more self-reliant farming sector.
An effective IED scheme should be introduced.

9.Changes to the Income Equalisation Deposit (IED) Scheme, including the implementation of a new Farm Management Bond were implemented by amending the relevant legislation in December 1992. The adjustments to the IED Scheme were aimed at improving its operation and making it more attractive so as to encourage greater self-reliance during downturns. In particular, Farm Management Bonds are a more concessional tranche within the overall IED Scheme, expressly designed as a provision against hardship arising from natural events such as drought.
The Government should review taxation arrangements for drought related expenditure, including the introduction of tax credits.

10.The Government has already implemented a number of measures to ameliorate the impact of drought on farmers. In deciding upon appropriate assistance measures, the Government analysed the scope for using tax measures to encourage drought preparedness and concluded that the taxation system is not the most effective mechanism to deliver assistance for farmers to undertake drought related expenditures.
Consideration should be given to the introduction of transitional arrangements for Commonwealth drought assistance pending the full implementation of the NDP.
11.The Government considers that such transitional arrangements are unnecessary now that a National Drought Policy has been agreed and is being implemented.
The IED review should consider the extension of income smoothing and tax averaging provisions to non-farm rural businesses.

12.The income smoothing and tax averaging provisions were examined in the course of the IED Review. The Government has decided that the existing tax averaging arrangements should be retained. Problems will be experienced in defining eligible enterprises if the Scheme is extended to rural non-farm businesses. This situation could result in inequities in regard to other non-farm businesses suffering variable fortunes.
New approaches to self-reliance should be accompanied by information programs and relevant advisory services and training programs that develop farm business and financial management skills.

13.As part of the package of measures announced in the National Drought Policy, the Government has provided funding for a strategy to communicate to farmers the need for more self reliant approaches to risks such as drought which are part of farm management. Funds have also been provided for a Property Management Planning campaign in association with the National Landcare Program, to train farmers in improved property management planning, including the management of risks such as drought.
Resources should be directed towards research into climate prediction and resources should be extended in this area.

14.The Bureau of Meteorology received Commonwealth funding of $136 million in 1992-93, of which some $64 million was for operation of the basic national meteorological data collection and processing infrastructure. This supports the full range of Bureau services including the national climate monitoring and prediction service which costs an additional $1.2 million per annum.

15.The Bureau also maintained a program of climate research, costing approximately $1 million in 1992-93, directed towards improved climate prediction on seasonal to interannual timescales relevant to drought. The ongoing CSIRO drought prediction research program expenditure in 1992-93 was also approximately $1 million.

16.The Australian research on climate prediction, involving the Bureau of Meteorology, CSIRO and the universities, is carried out within the international framework of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP). A major international WCRP initiative in 1992-93, involving 20 countries and costing about $US50 million, was the TOGA COARE (Tropical Ocean Global Atmosphere Coupled Ocean-Atmosphere Response Experiment) co-ordinated from an operations base in Townsville. It has contributed to increased understanding of the role of the Western Pacific Ocean in influencing the variability of climate on timescales of months to years.

17.Australia is currently near the forefront of nations providing operationally useful climate services on the basis of present understanding of the global climate system. The Bureau of Meteorology's Drought Watch Service which has been in operation since 1965 was upgraded in 1989 with the commencement of a routine Seasonal Climate Outlook Service, including an indication of likely rainfall trends for several months to season in advance. The Bureau and the US National Oceanic and Atmosphere Administration are jointly examining the scope or implementation of an operational system for climate prediction on seasonal to interannual timescales for the Western Pacific region in association with a proposed International Research Institute for Climate Prediction, possible located in the United States.

18.The Government has also provided $2.1 million in additional funding to the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation to fund drought related research. Some of this research is in the area of climate prediction.
Commonwealth Government has a responsibility to provide additional assistance during severe drought.

19.The Government recognises that there will be droughts of such severity that property managers will not have been able to plan effectively for them. Under such circumstances the Government has used the exceptional circumstances provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme, which, in conjunction with State Governments, may provide severely drought affected farmers with up to 100 per cent interest subsidies. In 1992-93, the Commonwealth Government provided $16.5 million for eligible farmers experiencing the effects of prolonged drought in Queensland and western New South Wales. A further $11 million has been allocated for this purpose in 1993-94. Assistance in severe drought needs to be consistent and clearly enunciated.

20.By its very nature severe drought is an exceptional circumstance for which special assistance is required and as such assistance needs to be tailored to meet the special circumstances. To the extent that it is appropriate, however, such special assistance is provided in a consistent and predictable manner. The exceptional circumstances provisions of the RAS have been clearly enunciated and when ever they are invoked, due attention is paid to ensuring that affected people are informed of the arrangements.

Minister for Primary Industries and Energy should urgently consider the proposals presented by the National Farmers' Federation and the Cattle Council of Australia to alleviate the effects of extreme drought.

21.In developing the new arrangements for the Rural Adjustment Scheme, which is the major delivery mechanism for assistance during severe downturns including drought, the Government considered submissions from a broad spectrum of interests including peak industry organisations. Special assistance for severe drought may be provided under the exceptional circumstance provisions of RAS. The Government bases its consideration of the introduction of increased support under the RAS exceptional circumstance provision on the receipt of advice by the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council. The Council has representation from State and Commonwealth Governments, the National Farmers' Federation, and people with expertise in economics, financial administration, banking, sustainable agriculture, farm management or training. In preparing its report, the Council is required to consult with interested parties. The Council's recommendations will include recommendations on the level and duration of support that may be provided to eligible farmers appropriate to the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report by the Schools Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, entitled Five to fifteen—Reviewing the `compulsory' years of schooling, was written after a two-year review of the compulsory years of schooling in Australia. It advocates a national policy framework. Many of the reforms that have been advocated in this report rely on the Commonwealth government taking a leading role in the quality of teaching and learning in schools in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The report stresses the need to reduce unnecessary interstate differences, such as the school starting age, and calls for the establishment of a national framework for the monitoring and reporting of educational outcomes. Perhaps controversially, recommendation four of the Five to fifteen report addresses the issues of primary and secondary schooling. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Schools Council recommends that the Commonwealth encourage the Australian Education Council to consider the merits of relinquishing the `primary/secondary' description for the stages of schooling in favour of a categorisation which reflects the following three phases of children's and young people's development:
. childhood;
. adolescence; and
. young adulthood.

The second and third parts of the report address the issues of curricula, teaching and teacher education. The report advocates the use of a national curriculum statement and profiles to achieve greater continuity between the different stages and levels of schooling from kindergarten to year 12. It stresses the need for language and literacy to be more substantial and a compulsory part of training for all teachers and the need for the upgrading of teachers of science and technology in our schools.

PARA.TAB: Of particular interest to me is the section on access and equity. I would like to highlight the recommendation made by this report which calls on the Commonwealth to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . continue to support the development of a National Strategy for Equity in Schools which includes the following elements:
.the harnessing of Commonwealth, State/Territory and non-government resources to the achievement of nationally agreed priorities;
.the establishment of a national database which makes possible the comparison of the range of educational outcomes of disadvantaged groups with that of the average student population;
. the publication of information on the resources, from all sources, which are being allocated to the achievement of equity outcomes.
Given the way in which the Schools Council is trying to find out exactly how much money is spent on access and equity, the report is an important contribution to the national debate.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the report highlights the need for an analysis of the resource differentials between the schools providing compulsory and post-compulsory education. It endorses the Commonwealth's commitment to examine the level of funding for public primary schools with a view to improving early literacy learning.

This is a very progressive report which contributes in important ways to the national debate about the future directions of our schools. Unfortunately, it comes at a time when some state governments are cutting drastically and very severely the provision of resources available to schools. We are seeing quite dramatic reductions in the number of teachers that are available for the teaching of children in this country; the closing of hundreds of public schools; the withdrawal of curriculum support services; and, in the case of Victoria, severe restrictions on the legal rights of members, parents and teachers of school councils to go through the legal system to try to prevent the closure of community schools.

In this context, I am pleased that the Five to fifteen report advocates a greater national focus—a focus which recognises the national role in determining the national education agenda. The Commonwealth's role in ensuring education equity, with an emphasise on equality of opportunity, is fundamental to this approach. It is on this basis that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) has highlighted, in recent times, the great disparities that exist within the Commonwealth about the way in which resources are being allocated. While the report indicates that the primary focus of education administration in this country will always be the state, it is important that the Commonwealth take an increasing role to ensure and guarantee that basic educational rights for all children in this country are protected, and so that we do not see the undermining of the very valuable and high quality state education systems that are being provided.

Today's Age contains reports which contrast that sort of attitude. We see in Victoria the report indicating that there are increasing resources going to the private sector at a time of massive reductions in the resources available to the public sector. This report by the Schools Council is a timely report. It is an important part of the national debate. I would hope that, at the national education minister's meeting that will occur in December, serious work will be done on establishing of a national agenda to ensure that these recommendations are acted upon.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 8 of 1993-94: Project Audit—Civil Aviation Authority—Centre for Air Traffic Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Audit Office probe into the relocation of the Civil Aviation Authority's Launceston based air traffic services centre has found that a lack of cooperation between the Tasmanian university and the Civil Aviation Authority contributed to the centre's demise in Launceston. I am concerned at that lack of cooperation between the two parties—each of which had their own agenda. The lack of determination by all parties to make the course succeed was largely the reason why Launceston has lost the course to the mainland.

PARA.TAB: Given that the establishment of the centre in Launceston in 1989 is now described as being experimental and did not rule out different arrangements in the future—which is, in fact, news to me—it was vital that the university ensured that the course was well run, properly evaluated, and met the requirements of the Civil Aviation Authority. Sadly, the report reveals that the university failed to do this and, therefore, probably never had any chance of retaining the course—especially when we recall that there was considerable angst in the Civil Aviation Authority, at some levels, at the course being located in Launceston in the first place.

It is clear that the Civil Aviation Authority did little to really change this unsatisfactory situation. Once again, its poor administration has been highlighted. Over recent years, a number of instances of damning reports of the CAA's incompetence over a prolonged period have come before the Senate. A more determined approach on its part may have stopped the problem from developing.

The report reveals that the program received limited modification after it was inherited from the Civil Aviation Authority. Thereafter, there were few attempts by the curriculum advisory committee, the Civil Aviation Authority or the university to ensure that an adequate evaluation program had been established for the ongoing review, revision and development of the course.

The program appeared unable to adequately integrate job theory with job requirements. The management of the training program was poorly defined. There was open conflict of interests at the Launceston campus between academics and the coordinator and the teaching staff, and between the Civil Aviation Authority and university management. Trainees were placed in the field without adequate performance, assessment and evaluations.

Most damning of all, in my view, is that the report discloses that there was evidence that the need for course refinement and revision of administrative processes was recognised, but requests to the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology, as it was then called—it is now a university—did not result in action being taken to ensure that the training program satisfied the Civil Aviation Authority's requirements. As a measure of the inadequacy of the course as it was allowed to develop, of the 160 students who commenced the first three courses only 70 were able to get jobs as air traffic controllers. All this incompetence cost the long suffering taxpayer almost $17 million.

The report also highlights the fact that, while the Civil Aviation Authority is trying to sell its building, it does not own the land on which the building is situated. So its ability to sell to anybody very meaningfully is very much restricted. It is interesting to note that the ground is owned by the state of Tasmania and the University of Tasmania has made it very clear that it will take a dim view of it being sold to anybody else as it is on its campus.

Inevitably, therefore, the taxpayer will not get much return from a building in which taxpayers' funds were substantially invested. Any dollars which the University of Tasmania pays to buying the building which is effectively on its land will be dollars which are also contributed by those same long suffering taxpayers. The taxpayers had better be warned that the federal government's intention, in closing down the course in Launceston, is to relocate it in two facilities on the mainland, which will mean that those same taxpayers will get some more big bills soon.

At a time when our region is desperately trying to find industry and activities which promote growth and jobs—the focus of the government's efforts at the moment is supposed to be to try to create jobs in regional areas—to lose a national course which attracted students Australia-wide and which, sadly, had unrealised but great potential to attract overseas students, in these circumstances is unforgivable and I will never forget it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on video and computer games and classification issues.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES
REPORT ON VIDEO AND COMPUTER GAMES AND CLASSIFICATION ISSUES OCTOBER 1993
TABLING STATEMENT BY COMMITTEE CHAIRPERSON, SENATOR MARGARET REYNOLDS
In the report tabled today, the Committee has examined two issues: the availability of unclassified video and computer games and the system for the classification of films and videos.

In relation to video and computer games, the Committee's concerns are directed at the proliferation in Australia of games with unacceptable levels of violence or sexual activities as their themes. The Committee's concerns are shared by the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers, the meeting of Federal, State and Territory ministers with censorship responsibility. At their meeting in June 1993 the Ministers announced that they had agreed to bring video and computer games under the control of the national censorship system, and requested the Chief Censor and State and Territory officials to formulate a scheme for regulation to be presented at the Minister's next meeting, to be held on 4 and 5 November. The Committee has expedited its inquiry in order to bring down this interim report for the consideration of the Censorship Ministers at that meeting.

The Committee's recommendations envisage a scheme of regulation of the content of video and computer games with the classification set by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. The Committee concluded that the absence of classification of such games, and reliance only on industry self-regulation, threatens to undermine the community's efforts to regulate the availability of graphically violent and sexual material in games to minors.

The Committee will monitor the decisions of the meeting of Censorship Ministers, and will continue to take evidence in relation to video and computer games, and will be in a position to report to the Senate on progress.

The Committee's concern about the system of classification of films and videos was prompted by the decision in January 1993 of the Film and Literature Board of Review to release the film Salo with an `R' rating, overturning a decision of the Film Censorship Board to maintain a ban on the film's release of 17 years standing. The Committee's terms of reference include a requirement that it consider whether material which would be classified in the `R' and `X' categories should be permitted on pay TV. The Committee was able to use the consideration of Salo by the classification authorities as a "window" into the operations of the system which has the potential to eventually permit `R' or `X' material onto pay TV.

The Committee's inquiry highlighted a number of systemic flaws in the classification system and its report has recommended the implementation of a number of important remedial measures, particularly in relation to the restructuring of the Office of Film and Literature Classification, which is the umbrella Commonwealth agency housing the Film Censorship Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review. The Committee recognises that the adjudication of community standards will always fall to certain individuals tasked with that role and that there will inevitably be differences of opinion about decisions which arise from such a system. The Committee was concerned, however, about the idiosyncratic nature of the current system, which gives little certainty to the community about what material will or will not be released. The Committee's recommendations are directed at ensuring that the classification system, as far as possible, meets prevailing community standards.

The Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers is scheduled to discuss these issues at its forthcoming meeting in November, when it will examine in detail the proposals of the Law Refom Commission for greater uniformity in film and literature classification as contained in its September 1991 report Censorship Procedure. As with its recommendations in relation to the regulation of video and computer games, the Committee urges the Ministers to agree to the early implementation of the Committee's proposals for reforms in the film and video classification system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate, but I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Senator Reynolds and the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies for what I see as a long haul that it has undertaken, so far quite nobly. It gives some hope to families who are struggling to raise children in this society who feel threatened on all sides by violence and pornography. Parents feel that it is very difficult these days, with the information explosion and new technologies, to protect their children as they would have been able to in the past. Wherever we go in this country, parents particularly, as well as others, talk of this problem and wonder how they as small people can make a difference.

PARA.TAB: I think this committee which Senator Reynolds chairs—once again, it put out a unanimous report—is making a difference. Its first reference related to the 0055 sex lines. I am very glad that it achieved something meaningful in that area. I have been very concerned about that and have brought many thousands of petitions to this place over that issue. I am glad that it has gone on and continued to look at ways in which this Parliament can help those parents protect their children until they reach maturity. I commend it for its work.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank Senator Newman for her comments. Too often in this place we focus on our differences rather than those areas on which we agree. This issue of community standards relating to the utilisation of new technology is just one area where we do agree. Because of the heavy workload of the Senate, I had not chosen to speak today but I look forward to speaking on a later occasion.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Newman will welcome the committee's recommendations. We have timed this report so that it can be taken into account by the federal and state ministers responsible for censorship at their meeting next week. We hope that they will take note of our recommendations in their deliberations. The work of the committee will continue as we monitor the outcome of the censorship ministers' recommendations and the response of the community.

I assure Senator Newman, on behalf of the committee, that we welcome her support and the support of many other honourable senators. We will continue to ensure that regulation of video and computer games is maintained in the best possible form, notwithstanding the difficulties given the nature of the technology.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the United States of America, June-July 1993. I seek leave to move a motion and make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset we were received as old friends. There was no doubt about the American and Australian respect and affection for each other. We were able to strengthen ties between the two countries further. We certainly put forward in a very forceful way our views about the agricultural subsidy scheme, the export enhancement program, and its effect on Australian agriculture. It is true that not all Americans understand what is happening in regard to the damage to our industry and in terms of the price they pay as taxpayers of that nation. There are a couple of recommendations in the report which are very important and very sensible. One of them states:

The Delegation recommends that the Australian Government commission a detailed study of the costs to American consumers, and to producers in related industries, of the current United States agricultural subsidies and import restrictions on agricultural produce.
The results of the study should be
.made widely known amongst United States Congressional representatives as well as to members of the wider community who are adversely affected by these protectionist agricultural policies;
.used to identify sectors of the United States community with whom strategic partnerships may be fostered to promote alternative agricultural and trade policies that would benefit Australia.
That is a practical way in which we will begin to turn around the unfortunate position we have in regard to our agricultural production and how it suffers because of the policies of the EEC and USA.

PARA.TAB: We also looked at the way in which Austrade operated in America. We made a further recommendation which relates to looking at some of the old areas in which Austrade has operated for so many years. Those resources could be better utilised in other areas which have a very promising future—that is, the area of Seattle and on the west coast of America on the Pacific rim. These are a couple of very useful recommendations which should go into the record.

We had access to some fairly influential people in the US, including the leaders of each of the parties in the Congress and the Senate. We spoke to Vice President Gore who showed a great deal of understanding and knowledge of a number of matters including world population growth, environmental pollution and unemployment, which I believe are three very important issues that concern everybody throughout the world.

He went further to talk about security which was also of concern to the delegation and our country. He clearly said that the US would continue to be involved in the Pacific as our allies and it would continue to provide its contribution to the security of that area, which is so important to us. He said that all areas of cooperation between our countries were vital and that we must not only continue that but also enhance cooperation and make it stronger.
In closing, I reiterate that I think it was a very useful visit. I hope that in two years time a similar visit can take place and it can be even more productive than the one that has just concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to concur with the comments made by my colleague Senator Burns, and at the same time say that of all the meetings and delegations that have visited the United States in recent years, this particularly delegation, headed by Speaker Martin and accompanied by representatives from both the House of Representatives and Senate, has been one of the most successful of all in terms of modifications to US policy. I hope that as a result of this visit we will be able to not only strengthen our ties with the United States but also ensure that Australia's vital interests are protected as a result of a better communication process between the two countries.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) (EXEMPTION OF COUNCIL ALLOWANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of Senator Ian Macdonald's private member's bill which I believe remedies a defect and fulfils a promise that was made by the government during the passage of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill. I would like to point out that the position of councils at the present time is quite unfair. It is this unfairness that my colleague Senator Macdonald, a Liberal from Queensland, seeks to rectify.

PARA.TAB: He wishes to ensure that the superannuation guarantee levy can be paid on behalf of elected councillors and aldermen. As a result of this contribution on their allowance, they could be ineligible for deductibility for private superannuation, particularly if 10 per cent or more of their income comes from a source which provides employer superannuation support.

It could have the impact of discouraging people from volunteering their services to become aldermen or councillors. This is unfair. It is something that the government never intended. It is something the government indicated quite strongly it intended to rectify but has not done so. I pay tribute to Senator Macdonald for his initiative.

It is appropriate that I begin with a reference to page 145 of the second report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. There the government made a formal response to the issue of local government councillors and the operation of the superannuation guarantee legislation—an issue which I must acknowledge was raised by the Australian Democrats at the time. This response was instrumental in gaining the Australian Democrats' support for the superannuation guarantee charge legislation package last year.

At the time the government publicly stated, by means of this response, that it intended to move an amendment to the superannuation guarantee charge legislation to remove what the government itself characterised as a technical defect. The government said that it `seemingly brings local councillors automatically within the definition of employee'.

The government's response went on to state that local councillors who received a monthly payment for attending meetings would not be covered by the Superannuation Guarantee Administration Act. These statements were made in a report issued June 1992, some 15 months ago or more. The government's apparent intention at the time to exclude these particular councillors is clearly set out in a letter that the former Minister for Local Government, the honourable David Simmons, wrote to local councils in July 1992. His letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Local Government elected members are concerned the new superannuation arrangements will only apply to councillors who are in receipt of salaries.

Honourable senators should note the distinction between that and allowances. Yet section 12(10) of the Superannuation Guarantee Administration Act unequivocally states that a person who holds office as a member of a local government council is an employee of that council. Further, the definition of local government councillors' salaries or wages in section 11(1)(e) is so wide as to include mere allowances paid in respect of attending council meetings.

PARA.TAB: What conclusion can then be drawn from the sharp contradiction between the legislation and the government's statement which has been made more than once on the public record. It is generally accepted that the government's failure to effect its promises on this particular issue is not a result of political dishonesty. Is it just pure indolence?

What is the government undeniably guilty of? Is it incompetence in drafting and promulgating legislation contrary to its own publicly declared position and intention? Or is it indolence in failing to act or even to show the slightest inclination to act to remedy this incompetence or defect? It is difficult to decide what sort of culpability is worst—dissembling and dishonesty or indolence and incompetence. I leave the government to judge that.

It confers no credit on a government when an opposition has to be relied upon to repair legislatively the damage wrought by the government's inability to execute properly its own promises. It is fortunate that the opposition's spokesman on local government, Senator Macdonald, has proved to be equal to the task of remedying the government's carelessness. He has introduced a bill which effectively and succinctly removes those local government councillors who receive only limited allowances arising from the execution of their duties from the operation of the superannuation guarantee legislation. Such a result is consonant with the reasonable and intelligent view that councillors whose substantive form of employment or work is not with a council of which they are members and whose payment reflects this reality, cannot then be considered, according to Senator Macdonald, as employees.

The Income Tax Assessment Act articulates this view of their proper status by virtue of section 221A(1). This interpretation section specifically excludes payments by way of remuneration or allowances to a member of a local governing body from the meaning of `salary or wages' under the PAYE system. Therefore, to argue that to remove local government councillors of the type with which we are concerned from the ambit of the superannuation guarantee charge is discriminatory or confers some sectional interest is to misapprehend the nature of their employment as well as their remuneration.

In conclusion, while this is just one problem caused by the superannuation guarantee charge, it is a problem which I believe is very easily remedied by this private member's bill introduced by my colleague Senator Macdonald. I believe that there are greater and more serious problems with compulsory superannuation, but their very gravity means that they are more intractable, at least in so far as it is within the opposition's power to effect a change in the short term. Further, it is a problem which the government has admitted and has promised to fix. The government should, on the basis of its own words, have no difficulty in accepting the amendments in Senator Macdonald's private member's bill.

We cannot afford, in effect, to penalise those who seek to serve the community as local government representatives for no real remuneration. This clearly is what the present provisions do. I therefore commend the amendments in this private member's bill, organised by my colleague Senator Macdonald, which overcome this very unsatisfactory situation. I commend the private member's bill to all my colleagues in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Amendment Bill, and I would expect the government to support it as well. As indicated by Senator Watson, this matter was the subject of the deliberations and the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I make no apology for reminding the Senate, as did Senator Watson, in part, of the recommendations of the committee. I will quote extensively from the committee's recommendations because I think they need recognition. Point 2.9 on page 145 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats propose that:
. local government councillors be exempt from the SGC unless they are on normal salaries; and
. the contractors provision be clarified.
These are two of several proposals that the Democrats put forward. Under the heading `Local government councillors', the government response reads:

The Government intends moving an amendment to the SGC legislation to remove a technical defect that seemingly brings local councillors automatically within the definition of `employee'. The Australian Taxation Office has advised that the word `payment' in the relevant clause of the Bill be changed to the word `remuneration'.
I will say a little more about that soon. The government response continues:

. . . this amendment will result in local councillors who receive salary or wages being covered by the Superannuation Guarantee. Other local councillors, who typically receive a monthly payment for attending meetings, will not be covered by the Superannuation Guarantee.

Senator McMullan, as parliamentary secretary, clarified and confirmed that when speaking on this matter on 24 June 1992. Senator McMullan was granted leave to incorporate a document in Hansard. Under the heading `Minimising impact on employers', the document stated:

As a result of consultations with the Australian Democrats and the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee, the Government has decided to move certain amendments to the Bill with the object of reducing the initial impact on employers.
The current exempt salary level below which contributions do not have to be made for an employee will be raised for $250 per month to $450.

That is relevant to local government councillors. It is a first step in looking at the typical sort of salary that the legislation would refer to. It is also an indication of the degree to which the government had consulted and made moves to change the way that this superannuation guarantee was to be applied. Further down, under the heading of `Local councillors', Senator McMullan's document stated:
The Bill presently defines "salary or wages" to include payments to local councillors.

The amendment proposed will replace the word "payment" with "remuneration" to make it clear that only payments for work done by councillors will be salary or wages. This amendment will also apply in respect of other Commonwealth, State or Territory employees.

I do not know whether the effect of that was fully understood by those who were required to interpret it, but I remind the Senate of the genesis of that movement. We were told—and I have just quoted this statement:
The Australian Taxation Office has advised that the word `payment' in the relevant clause be changed to the word `remuneration'.

Those of us who read and took note of that comment—this included Senator Cheryl Kernot and Senator Richard Alston—rightly assumed that that would be the way to get the technical defect addressed. But it seemed that it was not. When speaking on 24 June 1992 during the committee stage consideration of superannuation legislation, I thought Senator Alston interpreted the position correctly when he said:
The same can be said in relation to local government councillors. Our fundamental objection—
that is, that of the coalition—

is that a whole series of people are being unnecessarily swept up in this legislation to the extent that we will have many more inaccurate accounts than ever before. To the extent that this amendment at least makes it clear that only payments for work done by councillors will be salaries or wages, it is an improvement and is in line with the representations that have been made to us. We therefore welcome that amendment.

Senator Alston correctly interpreted from what had been said by Senator McMullan and from the recommendations that had been made that the amendment would be able to redress the situation. At the time, Senator Kernot said:
I agree with the comments of Senator Alston in respect to payments to a complying fund, local councillors and the consequent technical amendments.

I would have thought nothing could have been clearer. I would have thought nothing could have been clearer to anybody who was required to read the second reading speeches and interpret the intent of the government. However, as Senator Macdonald has explained—he is to be congratulated for bringing this matter forward—and as Senator Watson has observed, this interpretation has not been shared by the Australian Taxation Office. For the life of me, I cannot understand why because it was the Taxation Office that recommended this course.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Watson noted, Mr Simmons, who should have known exactly what was intended, wrote to councils expressing the opinion and the intent of the government. I have a copy of the same letter that Senator Watson quoted from; and I think it is worth quoting from another part of that letter. The very first sentence reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to dispel any concerns your Council may have concerning the application of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill.
The intent was to dispel concerns. The paragraph after the one that Senator Watson quoted reads:
The Government avoided arrangements that would have characterised elected members as employees of councils.
What could be clearer than that?

PARA.TAB: I have been contacted by the Hobart City Council which has had a very blunt and clear communication from the Australian Taxation Office which flies in the face of the express intent of the government. The rulings that have come from the Taxation Office in relation to the Superannuation Guarantee Act deem—there is that famous word. It seems that it is possible to deem so much these days which is not fact. For the purpose of the convenience of those who are administering things, it seems too easy for deeming to ignore what is fact and certainly to ignore what is the intent of the government.

The taxation ruling that I was shown by the Hobart City Council directly contradicted the Taxation Office's own recommendation to this government that the word `payment' in the relevant clause be changed to `remuneration' to indicate that those who were in receipt of those payments were not in fact employees of the council. As a matter of fact, the coincidence here is that before I came to this place I was an elected member of the Hobart City Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't apologise!

—I do not know whether to apologise or to spend time regaling the Senate with the wonderful time that I had there. One of the things that gave me the experience to comment on this particular situation is that the assumptions made in much of the decision making connected with this matter do not apply to that council at least. Even payments for attending meetings did not exist. The elected members of that council were not in receipt of such payments. In fact, no cash payments whatsoever were made. However, some benefits were derived. One was simply the replacement of petrol used in travelling on council business and another was the sharing of council meals during meetings. I would be struggling to evaluate those benefits. I hardly think that would qualify the elected members to be classified as employees.

PARA.TAB: The intent in that situation was that those who were serving the community were in fact doing that and not receiving any payment whatsoever. I do not know how many other local governments in Australia are in a similar situation. I do not think it is right to assume that all elected local members are paid sitting fees. I think that is a pretty broad assumption and one which certainly does not accord with my experience or the experience of those who have spoken to me about this matter.

I do not think there is any need to elaborate on this matter. The more talking we do on it, the more confused those who are trying to interpret the intentions of the government might become. I would have thought that the few things that I read were patently clear. How they can be interpreted in any other way beats me.

The addition of a considerable amount of administrative mumbo jumbo, the cost to the community, the inconvenience to individuals and to local governments and discouragement from serving local communities—all those factors—have derived from this clumsy attempt by the Taxation Office to cover a loophole which I do not think exists. If the amendment moved by the government did not have the effect that it was supposed to have, I would also blame the government to some extent for not getting it right in the first place. I think that continuing the debate would only serve to confuse the matter.

However, I cannot conclude my speech without making one observation. I think it is fair to make this observation because it is supported by Hansard. Normally, it is quite easy to induce a sort of Pavlovian response from Senator Ian Macdonald by saying the word `Democrat'. We usually get a lot of fuming, fussing, scratching of the ground, pawing of the dirt and steam escaping from the orifices. That is something which is fairly predictable; it is a Pavlovian response. But in this case, we have an initiative—which was a Democrat initiative—and we have a wonderful response from Senator Macdonald. I cannot let this opportunity go without congratulating him for seeing the benefit of some of the actions that we have taken.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin what will be one of the briefest contributions that I have ever made in this chamber by apologising for the fact that Senator McMullan is not here. Senator McMullan is away on ministerial duty for a few minutes. I think he underestimated my ability to move the rest of the business through to get to this particular point in the proceedings.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that Senator McMullan would have wanted to address the points made by Senator Ian Macdonald in his second reading speech, which I have just had the great privilege of reading. I also listened to the views of Senator Watson. At least I know that there is nothing shonky in the bill; otherwise Senator Watson would not have supported it. I note that the Australian Democrats are again supporting the Liberals on this particular matter, which must cause Senator Macdonald enormous grief, given his previous public stance on the Democrats.

In terms of the substance of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Bill 1993, the general attitude of the government is that it would rather have those matters covered in superannuation legislation that we produce. Because this is a private member's bill introduced in the Senate and I think it has the numbers to be assured passage—I do not intend that my colleague Senator Richardson will obstruct the matter in the committee stage—it will go to the House of Representatives.

The government can then make up its mind as to whether or not it proceeds—we do have that power in the House of Representatives. If we in the government are minded to remedy the matters that Senator Macdonald has raised, we may do it through our own legislation, or we would always have the option of resurrecting this legislation at any particular time and putting that through. We have both options. I undertake to send the remarks made by Senator Ian Macdonald, Senator Watson and Senator Bell to the relevant minister so that he can make a mature judgment on all these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading stage of this debate on the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Bill 1993 and for the support for the bill given by my colleague Senator Watson and also Senator Bell. I am sorry that the Australian Labor Party has not treated this with any seriousness at all. The bill was introduced on 1 September. The government has had every opportunity to look at this matter since that time.

PARA.TAB: It really shows that the government, in spite of all its rhetoric, treats local government with some derision. I would have hoped that the government would have either indicated support for this bill or come up with some amendments of its own. I acknowledge that bit of light-hearted comment from Senator Robert Ray—and from Senator Bell to a certain extent—about the fact that the Australian Democrats are supporting the bill.

I want to emphasise that this is a very serious matter. The only reason I am raising it in this bill is that it specifically and very seriously affects local government, although perhaps not in Hobart City Council's case. As Senator Bell rightly said, some councillors in some states do not receive any `payment'—whether it be remuneration, allowances or reimbursements. I do not want to confuse things by picking a word and so I will simply say `payment'.

I acknowledge that some councils throughout Australia do not receive any payments. But in some instances elected representatives of local government do receive payments, usually a very small amount such as $3,000 or $4,000 and perhaps even $6,000 to $10,000. Of course, there are some, like the Brisbane City Council, whose elected representatives receives salaries equal to those received by federal parliamentarians. There are other councillors who receive various intermediate amounts.

As my friends Senator Watson and Senator Bell have pointed out, the anomaly which came to light still has not been corrected in this legislation. This is in spite of the very clear intention of the government and in spite of assurances by Mr Simmons before the election, in a letter which we have tabled previously, and in a press release which I have only recently come across and which I might seek leave to incorporate later on. The government introduced some amendments which it thought—and I concede that we and the Democrats thought—might fix the issue, but they really have not.

The matter was referred to the Taxation Office for a determination. That determination said: `No. It doesn't do what everyone thought it would do'. The effect of it, very briefly, is that those councillors who receive a payment and whose councils pay the superannuation guarantee charge on that payment are then prevented from claiming their own contributions to their own personal superannuation schemes as a tax deduction. For their contribution to society and for being good people and making a contribution in their own local community they are being penalised. I think that is terribly unfair.

That is why I have introduced this private member's bill—to try to get the government to do something about it. If the Democrats first thought of it—and perhaps they did—that is great and I give them every credit for it. Senator Watson, of course, as even Senator Robert Ray acknowledges, has seriously looked at this issue and understood it—and many do not understand taxation or superannuation issues. We all know that if Senator Watson understands it and makes a contribution, we are going on the right track. But I present this bill in a genuine attempt to help local government and local government councillors to do the sorts of things that I think, in all truthfulness, everyone set out to do but which has not been done.

The Labor Party has been told about it time and time again. It has refused, for reasons that we do not know, to do anything about it. That is the purpose of this private member's bill. It will, I understand, pass through the Senate. As Senator Ray quite rightly says, the matter then has to go to the lower house where, obviously, the Labor Party has the numbers. But I do urge Senator Ray, Senator Richardson, Senator McMullan and particularly the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, whose responsibility is local government, to seriously look at the issues and to do something to correct this anomaly.

It is a very technical matter. I will amend my own bill in the committee stage because, since introducing the bill, I have had a further look at it. I have had some advice and I have spoken to the local government peak bodies around Australia and they have made some suggestions to me. As a result of that, we have drafted some amendments, but the effect of the amendments will, together with the original bill that I have presented, try to fix the anomalous situation that has resulted.
