In the interests of local government—a very important level of government, a very important sphere of government in the Australian system of government—and the interests of the people who, in many instances, voluntarily or at very small payment contribute to their own local communities, I urge the Senate to support this bill. I certainly would hope that the government will adopt it in the lower house as well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 4, page 2, paragraph (b), proposed paragraph 11(1)(f), omit the proposed paragraph, substitute the following:
"(f) remuneration of a person referred to in subsection 12(10) who has made an election mentioned in that subsection.".
2.Clause 5, page 2, proposed new subsection 12(10), omit the proposed paragraph, substitute the following:
"(10) A person who holds office as a member of a local government council is not an employee of the council unless the person has elected to the contrary in writing addressed to the council.".
Because it seems that the bill will be passed, and obviously the Labor Party has no position on this issue, I have prepared a speech which is, I might say for me, practically devoid of politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's unusual for you.

—It is unusual for me. In this instance, it is. I have not distributed a copy, but I seek leave to simply incorporate my speech notes, rather than read them out. They have, as I say, passing references of a political nature but, generally speaking, they explain what the bill and the amendments are all about.
—Surely you're not asking us to trust you?
—Yes, I am. I have one copy only, unfortunately, which I could produce to Senator Bell or to Senator Richardson.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading of this Bill, I highlighted the anomaly that exists relating to the existing Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 (SGAA), requiring the Superannuation Levy to be paid to elected Councillors and Aldermen who receive allowances. The result is that Councillors and Aldermen then do not comply with the definition of an "eligible person" in Section 82AAS(2) of the Income Tax Assessment Act (ITAA) and cannot claim a tax deduction for any personal contribution.

Only an "eligible person" can claim deductions for private superannuation and you are not an "eligible person" if Lo% or more of your income comes from a source which provides to you employer funded superannuation support.

This consequently disallows Councillors and Aldermen from claiming in their income tax return, a deduction of up to $3000 plus 75% of any amount above, for their own personal superannuation contributions.

Therefore we have a situation where an Alderman could receive a Council allowance of $6000, have self-employed assessable income of $50000 and would not be entitled to claim any private superannuation contributions as a tax deduction, due to the Council paying the princely sum of $300p.a. in compulsory superannuation.

It is completely improper and ridiculous that many hard-working community conscious citizens are actually financially discriminated against by this Federal Labor Government, preventing them from claiming the tax deduction they would get if they weren't on their Local Council.

Local Government strives to be a partner in governing the community while the Federal Government appears to be working against this concept. The Government continues to impose rules and regulations on Local Government that make its task difficult and sometimes impossible to administer.

In his press release dated 2nd July 1992, the then Minister for Local Government, the Hon. David Simmons said "The approach taken by the Government (regarding the SGAA relating to Councillors) is consistent with that taken in respect of Fringe Benefits Tax, which does not apply to elected members because they are not employees of councils.

Now we are already into the second financial year since this legislation took effect and Labor's attempt to overcome this anomaly, was to change the word "payments" to "remuneration" in the definition of salary and wages in the SGAA. This has only created more confusion and concern, leading to the Australian Taxation Office issuing a Draft Superannuation Guarantee Determination, SGD 93/D4.

In this Determination the Taxation Commissioner has ignored the clear intention of the Parliament and deemed in the strictest technical sense that Local Government Councillors are in the employ of the Council and allowances paid to Councillors are salary or wages for the purposes of the SGAA.

This actually contravenes some State Local Government Acts which specifically provide that a Councillor cannot be in the employ of the council with disqualification as the penalty. Employees of Councils are also expressly excluded from standing for election to the council by which they are employed.
Clearly, the relationship between a Councillor and a Council bears little resemblance to that existing between an employer and its employee.
The two tests at common law show why councillors should not be regarded as "employees".

There is no Master/Servant relationship and most Councillors are employed in another occupation or are involved in other activities. Council work is therefore not the predominant activity more an extracurricular activity, where they are giving up the free time to benefit the community in which they live.

The Government has agreed Councillors are not employees and the former Minister for Local Government has also stated "As far as Local Government is concerned, the new superannuation contributions will apply only to Brisbane City councillors who are in receipt of salaries." At least, that was their stated intent—but their legislative changes have not achieved this.
So the Labor Party has still not lived up to their promise to move amendments that overcome anomalies in the SGAA relating to Local Government members.
Council members who are not full-time in the job and whose main source of income comes from their own business activities should not lose their ability to deduct private superannuation contributions.

Given that none of these payments are "salary or wages" under ordinary concepts, and the fact that Councillors are not "employees" at common law, the neatest approach is to allow Councillors to elect whether they are caught by the SGAA without using such terms as "allowance" and "fee" which vary in usage from State to State.

Therefore the SGAA should allow Councillors to elect whether they are caught by the SGAA to extinguish the present injustice denying Local Government Councillors the right to claim their personal superannuation contributions as a tax deduction. This then allows Councillors who wish not to be paid the SGC the opportunity to opt out.
This can be achieved by amending my Private Senators Bill as follows:
1. Clause 4, page 2, paragraph (b), proposed paragraph, substitute the following:

PARA.TAB: (f) remuneration of a person referred to in paragraph (12)(10) who has made an election mentioned in that paragraph.

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 5, page 2, proposed new subsection 12(10), omit the proposed paragraph, substitute the following

PARA.TAB: "(10) A person who holds office as a member of a local government council is not an employee of the council unless the person has elected to the contrary in writing addressed to the council.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment allows individual Councillors to determine what is best for them in their particular individual circumstances and would result in the following 3 scenarios.

1. If a Councillor's pay from a Council is less than 10% of that persons total assessable income, and the Councillor elects to be an employee, then payment by the Council of the SGC does not remove the Councillor from the definition of "eligible person" and the Councillor can therefore claim a tax deduction for his own superannuation contribution and he or she still gets the SGC. (The only change from the present legislation being that an election must be made).

2. If a Councillor's pay from a Council is more than 10% of that persons total assessable income, then if that person elects to be an employee the Councillor will get the SGC but will not be an "eligible person" and can not claim tax deductions for his own superannuation contributions. (The only change from the present legislation being that an election must be made).

3. If a Councillor's pay from a Council is more than 10% of that persons total assessable income, and if that person does not elect to be an employee, then the Councillor is still an "eligible person" for the purposes of the ITAA and can claim as a tax deduction his own super contributions, but would not of course be eligible for any SGC contribution by his Council. (This corrects the current inequitable situation whereby such a person is not eligible for a tax deduction and therefore is discouraged from service as a Local Government Councillor).

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just take 30 seconds of the chamber's time for Senator McMullan and Senator Watson to have a look at a related matter. It is not a matter directly on the bill I have presented, but it is related. I would just like to note that there also seems to be an anomaly in section 82AAS(3) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which allows a tax deduction for personal superannuation contributions where employment income is less than 10 per cent of the person's assessable income.

PARA.TAB: The problem that arises is that non-employment income to be included in assessable income for a sole proprietor is gross sales, yet for a partner in a partnership it is the net partnership distribution. Therefore, a person in a partnership is severely disadvantaged compared with a sole proprietor. I ask Senator McMullan to have a look at this when he is looking at this situation.

It is not directly relevant to the bill before us but it does relate to the question of assessable income for personal superannuation contributions. It is an anomaly. I am not sure whether it has been brought to the government's attention yet. It was just something that I thought I might throw in whilst my colleagues were having a glance at my notes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support my colleague Senator Macdonald on this matter because of my former interest in local government. I did not want to speak in the second reading debate; Senator Macdonald was not looking for any extra speakers. But, if I remember rightly—and I have not checked Hansard—when we debated the Superannuation Guarantee Levy Bill, I thought the minister gave some undertakings with regard to local government.

PARA.TAB: I would like the government to look at those undertakings again to make sure that it did not give us any undertakings that have not been carried out. I thought that the undertakings that were given to us at the time were virtually covered by what Senator Macdonald's bill is all about. I support the bill. I believe that it should proceed and that the government should take it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza, who always has a big interest in local government because of his very distinguished service in local government in the past, understands this and supports the bill and I thank him for that contribution. He reminded me that I should have also indicated to the Senate that the amendments I proposed are totally supported by the Municipal Association of Victoria and by the Local Government Association of Queensland specifically, the states which this legislation specifically involves. Generally, I am informed that the Australian Local Government Association and other state peak bodies support the proposal as well.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUDIT (AUDITOR-GENERAL AN OFFICER OF THE PARLIAMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 October (on motion by Senator Watson):
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill reported; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Watson) proposed:
That the bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on record the Australian Democrats' support for the Audit (Auditor-General an Officer of the Parliament) Amendment Bill 1993. It is the duty of the Auditor-General's office to scrutinise government on behalf of parliament. We all know that in the last few years the power of the executive government has risen tremendously and that the Auditor-General, basically, was caught between two conflicting duties: firstly, to the executive government, which had the purse strings and had the control of the resources available to the Auditor-General; and, secondly, his acknowledged duty to provide reports on scrutiny of government departments and the activities of government generally to the parliament. It is therefore very fitting that the Auditor-General be made an officer of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that this issue has been on the table of this parliament for some time. In March 1989, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts argued in its report No. 296 on the Auditor-General that a strong audit office is essential for the maintenance of accountability of federal government organisations and officials to parliament.

The two main difficulties that that report identified were the resource constraints that I have mentioned—and successive Auditors-General have seen fit to draw attention to that—and the fact that the Auditor-General really must, in particular, examine the unit that allocates resources, that is, the Department of Finance.

The public accounts committee identified five major reasons underlying the Auditor-General's main problems. The first is parliamentary complacency. The second is the conflict between the two duties to the legislature and to the executive. As Senator Watson says, complacency of the legislature is something that this bill seeks to remedy and that is why the Democrats are supporting it. Another is the lack of a mechanism which, according to the public accounts committee, would allow parliament to assume responsibility for the office. Clearly, this is something that we are rectifying today. There is also a lack of awareness of the importance of the audit of government activities.

I wonder whether that latter point has not gradually over the last few years become less apparent. It seems to me that the tabling of consecutive audit reports in this chamber at least has drawn attention to the work of the Auditor-General. The importance of the work of that office in keeping a tight check and scrutiny of government activities has, I think, been reinforced. I do not wish to detain the chamber. I repeat that the Democrats will, for all the reasons I have outlined, support this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of legislation to replace the Audit Act is currently being drafted and is expected to be introduced into parliament in the current sittings. The government has consulted the Joint Committee on Public Accounts on the content of the proposed bills and the committee has indicated that it accepts the general thrust of these pieces of legislation. That is why I have been saying no. Senator Watson looked perplexed; that is the answer.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes:

(i)the joint statement issued by the Ministers (and representatives) for Industrial Relations from Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, Tasmania, and the Northern Territory, with regard to the Government's proposed industrial relations legislation, and

(ii)in particular, that the statement reported, that `if the legislation proceeds in its present form it will jeopardise any national recovery', and the `protection of trade union interests is the clear purpose of the legislation';
(b)agrees with the statement by the State Ministers; and
(c)condemns the Federal Labor Government for its total lack of consideration for the points of view of anyone other than the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Friday, ministers or their representatives from the coalition states met here with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) on the proposed industrial relations legislation. At best, I believe it can be described as a fiasco or an exercise in futility. The points the ministers or their representatives put and the concerns they had were not given consideration. In fact, they went away, having been told that the legislation would proceed regardless of their states' views. I want to touch on the key points of concern that they raised with regard to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the proposals will not bring the flexibility so urgently needed in the labour market. Regrettably, the proposals will allow enterprise agreements only when they relate to the equivalent of over-award payments—and I emphasise that point. Secondly, the proposed system is extremely complicated and will not assist micro-economic reform or aid real change in the workplace. Thirdly, the bargaining position of unions has been greatly enhanced, and the totality of the measures has placed employers in a vulnerable position. This will not encourage employers to hire additional labour.

Fourthly, the watering down of the current sanctions relating to secondary boycotts and their removal from the Trade Practices Act is not warranted. The 72-hour provisions are unacceptable and could lead to the businesses of employers being unnecessarily harmed. Fifthly, meaningful recognition has not been given to the needs of the large non-unionised section of the work force. Sixth, the complexity of the various layers of awards and agreements with seemingly different procedures applicable to each will create confusion and will be an unnecessary burden. Those are the key points from that meeting. To me, they are the crux of the requirements if we are to address proper flexible market labour reform in this nation.

The first point I make is that Mr Brereton, the Minister for Industrial Relations, promised all state governments the opportunity for consultation. Mr Brereton used the words `detailed and meaningful' when referring to that consultation. This offer was made in April 1993. This consultation has never occurred—and I emphasise that—and yet today, the industrial relations bill was brought into the other place. It is because of this lack of consultation that the states' views have not been taken into account and, as a result, the states have become very irritated. All this is from a government that consistently talks about the consultative approach, about negotiation, about coming to an agreement and about taking into consideration all the various points of view that are raised.
I will quote some comments about this legislation. Minister Kierath from Western Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is an indictment of Industrial Relations Minister Brereton that this agreement has been cobbled together without any input from or consultation with the states or employer organisations . . .

He went on to say that enterprise bargaining arrangements for the non-unionised sector represented a gross intrusion by unions into workplaces where they had no membership and no legitimate role. Minister Gude of Victoria said:
There is no consultation, there is no consideration of our point of views at all and the legislation is to go through . . .
The New South Wales Industrial Relations Minister said:
. . . the states had wanted time to review the legislation before reaching a decision—
a very reasonable consideration, I would suggest—
but this had been denied by Mr Brereton.

PARA.TAB: It's impossible, absolutely impossible for the states to consult until we have seen the whole of the package.

The concern we have got is that the commonwealth through Mr Brereton is using bully boy tactics to force the states into accepting their position without truly taking into account the concerns of the states and without consulting with the states.

SPEECH.PARA: I will go a little further and look at some other points of view from people outside the state governments and turn to industry organisations. The NFF attacked the government's consultative process, and said it was:
. . . disgusted by the way Mr Brereton ignored the views of employers.
Mr Spicer of the ACCI said:
However to date discussions have been a dialogue of the deaf; our views have been ignored and we have not even been informed of what the government's latest secret deal with the ACTU is.
Minister Gude of Mr Victoria said:
This isn't just about industrial relations it is about absolute power corrupting.
Again from the ACCI; Mr Noakes, whom we all know well, said:

There will be an enormous amount of employer anger not only about the way they have been treated but also the outcome and the extent to which the government has been driven off course by the ACTU . . .

As we work through this process we find there has been a total lack of any meaningful consultation as far as this legislation is concerned; in fact, it is just a ramrod exercise. But we find it extends a little further. Just last month, the Victorian, Western Australian and Tasmanian labour ministers met and issued a joint statement attacking Mr Brereton for `failing to consult with them on industrial relations reform'. When looking through these comments we find that it is not only the coalition states which are raising concern as to this particular legislation, it is also the Labor states.

PARA.TAB: We know from that statement by Labor ministers a month or so ago that they have now had the opportunity to provide input into the legislation, but none of the conservative states have. So I say to the government, and to Mr Brereton in particular, `You will listen to your mates but you won't listen to all the other people with regard to this legislation and how it impacts on the states and what will come out of it'. I have no doubt that the way this legislation has been handled will not improve the position with regard to enterprise agreements; it will not improve the culture in the workplace; it will not encourage non-union work forces to go into enterprise agreements—the legislation will, in fact, make it totally unattractive for them to go into enterprise agreements.

Minimum standards set by the federal government overriding state legislation is wrong. This issue should be solved between the federal and state governments cooperatively and harmoniously by negotiation, by discussion, by consultation, by give and take, and by all the things that are needed to get all parties working and pushing in the same direction. That will not come from this. Over the coming 12 to 18 months we will see this legislation being challenged consistently through the courts of this land. If that is the direction this government wants to take, it will be detrimental to our capacity to deal with some of the broader important issues such as unemployment.

It is unacceptable that the federal government is using a big stick approach to impose industrial relations issues on the states. Part of the big stick approach is the use of the alleged ILO inconsistencies and external affairs powers. As I have said before and I will say again, we in this country should be capable of putting together our own domestic law without going offshore to find out what we should do. I find it absolutely remarkable that those on the other side of this chamber and in the government in the other place have neither the brain power nor the will to address these problems without having to go somewhere else to get judgments to find out what to do; in other words, to get their marching orders. This whole approach defies commonsense.

The federal government should be asking the states what they are doing and what they are planning to do, particularly in matters such as minimum wages and leave. I ask government senators who speak to this motion to tell us what consultation has taken place, what discussion they have had and what they really know about the detail of what is occurring in the states that have been prepared to look at labour market reform, move to do something constructive about it and not use the sledgehammer approach. That will be a real challenge for them, and I believe it is a challenge that they will not accept. They will not be able to answer those questions because there has been no consultation, no discussion and no communication.

I will highlight a couple of examples of situations in my state where there has been a lack of consultation and discussion in addressing the issues of parental and paternal leave. In the Western Australian legislation there is also a proposal, which was debated in the state parliament last night—all night, in fact—with regard to adoption leave. That is just one aspect which I doubt government senators know anything about, purely and simply because they address only one side of the equation.

Yesterday, Mr Kelty attended a meeting of our industrial relations backbench committee. We had a very useful, helpful and informative discussion. From the comments of Mr Kelty, I am sure that he found the meeting invaluable—as, of course, we did. But that does not happen with members of the government. They do not believe in taking into consideration all points of view and all aspects of a particular debate. They just do not carry that purpose through. In fact, they are moving more and more—and I will come to this later in my speech—to the sledgehammer approach.

The way in which the non-union sector will be treated is unacceptable. The fact that a union must be involved whether or not an employee is a member of a union is absolutely intolerable. The government talks about using the ILO conventions. But, when it suits it, the government conveniently forgets and ignores the convention that relates to freedom of association.

All that these restrictions, barriers and red tape that have been put in the way will do is scare off not only employers but also employees. Something like 70 per cent of the employees in the work force do not want to be part of the union movement, and that is their right. Equally—and we have said this consistently—it is their right to join a union if they wish. This means that proper and serious involvement in true enterprise bargaining will be very limited. This element, along with many others, is and will be very limiting and inflexible. The coalition states feel that flexibility is an absolute must in this area. Of course, the Commonwealth government, by trying to override them by using the external affairs power, will limit this flexibility.

A further example of inflexibility is the requirement for the agreement of at least 51 per cent of employees. What happens if 49 per cent do not agree? Why should they not be allowed to enter into an agreement separate from the 51 per cent, and the 51 per cent be allowed to keep working under their current conditions? I think that is a reasonable proposition. I would like to hear the arguments against it. I believe that if part of the work force wishes to take that action, it should be able to. That would be a modern approach to industrial relations—not the sort of approach we are getting now.

I want to make some comments about sections 45D and 45E allegedly being put into the Industrial Relations Act. I will not debate the merits of what is being done. I have done it before and will do it in the future. I am told that the MOLAC meeting on Friday could not even be given the details of those amendments because they had not been finalised. That is another typical example of the incompetence of this government in dealing with these matters.

It must be of great concern that, although the state ministers or their representatives came here last Friday, there was not some meaningful discussion before the legislation was introduced about what these proposals will mean and how they will operate. This is, once again, typical of the situation which exists. The ACTU knows what the proposals are and what they will mean, but the states, which will be greatly affected by this legislation, cannot even be told.

There are many other aspects to be considered. I know that my colleague Senator Chapman wishes to speak on this motion, so I will limit my comments to two or three other matters. We could talk all day about the incompetence of this government and the way it has handled this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wouldn't necessarily be true.

—Senator Burns should take the time and trouble to go through the phrases the government espouses about being a consultative government and a communicative government. The government has consistently said that. This is a classic example of it not doing what it has said it would. The government had the opportunity to do so. It had plenty of time to do so. It did not have to rush this legislation through in the way that it is. But the government chose to adopt this course.

PARA.TAB: I will run through two or three other examples of the government's sledgehammer approach. When it came to changes to the state traffic laws, the government threatened not to give the states—and my state in particular—full road funding unless they complied with its position. That is not a way I would suggest a federal government should do business with a state or states.

I emphasise very strongly that the Western Australian government was elected with a far greater mandate than the current federal Labor government. Yet, when the Western Australian government moved to remove from students the financial burden of compulsory guild fees, the federal government, with its negotiation style, turned around and said, `We'll reduce some of your education funding if you go ahead with that'. That is a typical thuggery approach—`You do what we say or we will remove your funding'. We got that again on Tuesday in answer to a question regarding the Mabo legislation. Minister Crean said, `If you don't agree to our proposals, we're going to take away your soil conservation funding. We're going to put at risk the landcare program'.

Western Australia led the national soil conservation program—the landcare program. It was the first state to amend the Soil Conservation Act. This took place back in 1981 or 1982, when Mr Dick Old was the Minister for Agriculture. We were the first state to put in place soil conservation districts. Western Australia has the most soil conservation districts. In fact, I understand that all the pastoral areas and some 80 per cent of the agricultural areas are covered by soil conservation districts. The federal government is once again saying, `If you don't do what we say, we will take your money away from you'. That is how this government operates. As Minister Gude said, this is all about power corrupting. It is about time this government took seriously a proper approach to Commonwealth-state relations.

I would say that this arrangement really started to go backwards when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as Treasurer, stabbed the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in the back. Before that time there were some meaningful negotiations going on about the future of the relationship between the federal government and the states. We are now seeing a big effort to centralise all power in Canberra. From my point of view, and from the point of view of most Australians—certainly thinking Australians—centralised power would be totally and absolutely detrimental to the federation of Australia.

This government has shown total disregard for any real consultation or proper negotiation in terms of these bills, which were introduced into the House of Representatives by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton. Ever since the day the ACTU booed Mr Brereton at its conference, he has bent over backwards in terms of its wishes and concerns, at the expense of the states, employers and the people who perform in the workplace. It is a disgrace and a crying shame.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is an absolute disgrace that this Keating Labor government today introduced legislation in the other place to make major changes to industrial relations law when that legislation is supported only by the leaders of organisations which represent less than 30 per cent of private sector employees. That is why Senator Crane has moved this motion today, which I support, with regard to the concerns expressed particularly by the industrial relations ministers of Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that the government's industrial relations package is supported by the trade union movement and no-one else. Less than 30 per cent of workers in the private sector are trade union members. Even if their leaders support this package, it is unlikely that all their rank and file members do. The business sector, encompassing both large and small businesses, is implacably opposed to the changes in their present form. But has the government consulted with business and adopted proposals to allay its fears? Not on your nelly. But it did consult with, and listen to, the unions. At their behest, it made significant changes to its initial proposals.

The major effect of the changes which it has made at the behest of the unions is to further entrench union privilege and power at the expense of the broader Australian community. Why not consult with business? It is the government's responsibility to govern for the whole Australian community.

Employers have legitimate concerns about important aspects of this package, but the only contact they have had from the government is to be told what is in the package. There has been no cooperative discussion or attempt to negotiate about differences between business and government over the package in the way there was between unions and government. There has just been dictatorial advice about what will be introduced. It is no wonder that employers are concerned. A majority of state governments are expressing similar concerns.

As this motion, which my colleague Senator Crane has moved, clearly highlights, the ministers for industrial relations in Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory published a joint statement last week detailing their concerns about the federal government's industrial relations package and, like the employers, concerns about the lack of consultation in the development of the package. Among the points made in the statement, they have highlighted the fact that the ACTU—the union movement—is the only group that has been permitted to have any real say on the package. Thus the protection of trade union interests is the clear purpose of this industrial relations package.

The state ministers have also concluded that the legislation, if passed in its present form, will jeopardise any national economic recovery, and they are correct. Australia desperately needs much greater flexibility in the labour market to enable genuine enterprise agreements to be freely negotiated at individual workplaces between employers and their employees.

Australia's greatest need is to dramatically improve labour productivity. From 1982 to 1991, Australia's overall labour productivity grew by less than nine per cent, which is less than one per cent per year. This is less than half the rate of increase in labour productivity of the G7 nations—the major industrial countries—for that period. No wonder our standard of living has fallen under this Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shocking management; that's why.
—I see that Senator Burns is stirred up again. One can be sure that he will always defend the 19th century attitudes of the trade union movement.
—I am opposed to the 19th century attitudes of your mob.
—We are for a new approach—a 21st century approach—which this country desperately needs.
—Tell us about it. You haven't so far.

—I am telling the Senate about the concerns which the state industrial relations ministers have expressed about this package of legislation. It would do Senator Burns well to listen to those concerns. He might then be able to bring some influence to bear on the government before it is too late so that it will make the changes that are needed. As I was saying before Senator Burns interrupted, it is no wonder, with that lack of growth in labour productivity, that our standard of living has fallen under this Labor government or that real wages have gone backwards.

PARA.TAB: Productivity improvement requires that an employer and his employees develop a shared vision for the business on which they are all dependent. It requires an end to the `us and them' mentality, which has bedevilled Australian industrial relations for a century and which is fostered by trade unions, because they know that that is the only way they can remain relevant. The introduction of genuine voluntary agreements through enterprise bargaining, without the unilateral right of uninvited third parties to be involved, is the best way of achieving this.

But all we get from this union dominated government is the use of award flexibility provisions for workplace bargaining. In other words, under these proposals, enterprise agreements will only be allowed as the equivalent of over-award payments. This could best be described as a Claytons enterprise agreement, because it is certainly not the real thing.

While non-union members will be able to achieve such deals, which they are currently prevented from achieving, they will still have to be approved by the Industrial Relations Commission. Also, uninvited by the particular workers involved, trade unions will have the right to argue before the Industrial Relations Commission that the deal should not be approved.

The proposed system is highly complex. It is no way to get real change in the workplace. Changing workplace arrangements will require weeks and months of negotiation, a process of detailed bureaucratic and quasi-legal procedures and compliance with finely detailed legal requirements. Nineteen separate tests will be required to be passed, with the trade union agreeing before employees and their employer can make a deal about their working arrangements in, for example, a small business, perhaps in the southern suburbs of Adelaide, or anywhere else for that matter.

We will have greater complexity, if that is possible, with various layers of awards and agreements and apparently different procedures applying to each. This is a recipe for confusion and the creation of a burden on employers that will effectively prevent many of them achieving enterprise agreements. No doubt this is what the union troglodytes hope will happen.

The package clearly enhances the position of trade unions and makes employers more vulnerable. It will certainly not encourage employers to take on additional employees. Surely that ought to be a major aim of any changes to industrial relations and its structures in Australia.

The existing system has delivered 11 per cent unemployment. One million Australians are unsuccessfully seeking work and many more are discouraged from even looking. These changes will do nothing to arrest that tragedy. Indeed, they will make it worse.

The use of the external affairs power, as provided in the legislation to come before us, not only breaks new ground in Australia but also clearly demonstrates the incapacity of the federal government to work with state governments to achieve sensible progress on industrial relations reform. That is central to our motion today.

Is it not ironic that, at the very time Prime Minister Keating is bleating loudest about the need for Australia to assert its independence by becoming a republic, he is handing unprecedented control over the lives of ordinary Australians to the International Labour Organisation and its conventions? Senator Kemp, only last night in this chamber, highlighted a number of fields in which this abdication of our independence to international bodies and conventions linked with the United Nations is being fostered by the Keating government. He documented that quite clearly. It undermines the whole of the government's argument for a republic. Industrial relations is just another example of this.

This government is simply not interested in genuine consultation with anyone except its union mates. As with the business sector and employers earlier, last Friday's meeting between the federal Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) and the state industrial relations ministers was designed to give the appearance of consultation. But the reality of consultation was not there. It was all a facade. At their April meeting, all states offered to talk and work with the federal government to reach agreement for national uniformity, particularly with regard to minimum employment standards, in the development of this industrial relations package. But this government is having none of that. Instead, it has adopted threats and a big stick approach in ignoring legitimate concerns expressed by the states.

Perhaps the greatest failing, among many, of the Hawke-Keating Labor governments is their failure to deregulate the labour market while deregulating other aspects of our economy. The government and trade unions must accept that, if the standard of living of all Australians is to improve and we are to climb back up the international ladder as far as our standard of living is concerned, productivity must improve. That requires a new approach to industrial relations as we enter the 21st century.

The structures that we currently have, which are based on 19th century experience and thinking and on an industrial relations culture largely based on the judgments of Higgins early this century, simply will not do. That is why the government's proposed package will not do and that is why this motion moved by Senator Crane, which particularly highlights the legitimate concerns expressed by those state ministers, ought to be supported. I certainly wholeheartedly support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take up much of the Senate's time with respect to this motion because it is not worthy of taking up much time; nor are the statements that have been made by Senator Crane in support of his motion, backed up by Senator Chapman. However, I cannot really let it go unaddressed. Let us look at the motion which purports to represent state ministers. It is funny; it seems to have left out two states—Queensland and South Australia. It mentions only those states with Liberal governments. Those particular states have a really good record in the area of consultation. We only have to look at the state industrial relations legislation introduced in New South Wales, followed by Victoria, to demonstrate just how democratic those Liberal governments really are in the area of consultation with workers and, in fact, with anybody else.

PARA.TAB: I will go straight to the question of consultation, which is the crux of the issues raised by Senator Crane, who says that both the government and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) never consulted with the states or, indeed, with any of the employer representatives or organisations around this country. The Prime Minister announced on 2 December 1992 that the government would legislate to guarantee workers' rights to fair minimum wages, equal pay for work of equal value, and protection against unfair dismissal. This legislation was to be based on relevant International Labour Organisation conventions using the external affairs powers of the constitution. These issues were discussed at a meeting of state premiers in Perth later in December.

The then Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, convened a special Ministers of Labour meeting on 16 December 1992 to provide state ministers with more detail of the proposed legislation. The legislation was again discussed at the Ministers of Labour Advisory Council—MOLAC—meeting in Brisbane on 30 April 1993. State ministers were given an assurance that they would have an opportunity to comment on the legislation before it was introduced into the parliament. State department of labour officials were given a detailed briefing on the legislation by officials of the minister's department on 8 September 1993.

Minister Brereton wrote to all state ministers on 14 October providing a copy of the latest draft of the minimum entitlements legislation. This was to ensure that the states had sufficient time to examine the legislation before the MOLAC meeting on 22 October. Minister Brereton again wrote to state ministers on 19 October advising of the latest changes to the legislation. In addition to that, he has had individual meetings with all state ministers and there have been exchanges of correspondence with state ministers during the development of the government's legislation.

The Minister for Industrial Relations has had extensive consultations with the state ministers on the development of the industrial relations legislation since the process began, essentially, in April 1993. By way of example, the minister has had nine meetings with the ACTU's negotiating committee over this period. This compares with 16 separate meetings with the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, and the Metal Trades Industry Association. More than 100 separate meetings have been held with employers, the states, unions and interest groups. I would like honourable senators to compare that with what happened in the Liberal states when they introduced their industrial relations legislation—zilch to 100.

The government's reforms essentially provide for a framework for the further spread of enterprise bargaining throughout the Australian economy. I pick up on what Senator Chapman said about the small business people. The small business people I have spoken to essentially believe that there ought to be the maintenance of an award system, simply because that is the easiest way for them to operate. They may never seek an enterprise agreement.

The one fundamental difference between our position and that of the coalition at the last election was that those opposite were going to do away with the award system, as has happened in Victoria. They want to pay young people under the age of 21 three bucks an hour; that is really good for the economy, really good for jobs. Many people whose children were attending tertiary education and working part-time came to me and told me just how their children would manage to get by on three bucks an hour—they would not have been able to do it. They would have had to have discontinued their education.

The Government's proposals build on the reforms of the last decade. They allow Australian workplaces to implement cooperatively and constructively the changes needed to compete with the best companies in the world. The legislation provides employers with the flexibility they need to improve productivity and compete internationally while recognising—a very fundamental point—that employee protection is crucial to the success of enterprise bargaining. Nothing that Senator Crane or Senator Chapman said reflected that. They said that we have to free up the labour market and make real change. What does real change mean to those on the other side of the fence? It means cutting wages and making sure the boss has the upper hand and has the whip over his workers.

The legislation clearly distinguishes between the bargaining stream, where an increasing number of workplaces will determine their actual wages and conditions and the arbitrated award safety net. Again, there is a substantial difference here between what the government proposes and what was, and is, proposed by the coalition where we would have no award safety net—none.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.

—It is very true. The statements of Senator Chapman and Senator Crane make it correct, otherwise the opposition's position must have changed. The legislation revises the current regulation of industrial action to ensure that there is a fair and effective regime, recognising the particular requirements of enterprise bargaining.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, the legislation provides strong safeguards to ensure that the increasing emphasis on the workplace is not at the expense of wages and conditions of ordinary Australian workers. In particular, it strengthens the award safety net for employees and ensures that all workers in Australia have access to key minimum entitlements required by international conventions which apply to Australia, and it maintains a `no disadvantage' test for employees moving to enterprise agreements.

Senator Crane raised the issue of requiring 50 per cent plus one before there can be an enterprise agreement. I find it interesting that he condemned that particular aspect of the legislation when he seeks to champion the New South Wales state government and its legislation. Perhaps if he had done a bit of checking he would have found out that the New South Wales legislation requires 65 per cent of people at the workplace to agree with any proposal for an enterprise agreement before it can be put in place.

That is not the situation in Victoria where we have no award system and public holidays are taken away; we know exactly what the process is there. It gives us a clear indication of what the coalition's real position is on industrial relations. The workers did not vote for it last time and they will not vote for it in the future. Some time ago the employers made very substantial statements about commencing a campaign of advertising, et cetera, against this legislation. I noticed in the newspapers either yesterday or today that they will have a further meeting to consider their position with respect to any advertising campaign.

We must reiterate the types of proposals that the coalition took to the last election and put before the Australian working people. It proposed that people under the age of 21 be paid $3 an hour. Quite frankly, that would have been a disaster for the economy and for employment. Had the coalition won government, we would have had a system that would have seen workers competing for jobs. People would have had to tender for a job. The boss would be sitting behind a big desk saying, `What am I bid for this particular job?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish.
—That is exactly what would have happened. It was clearly rejected by the workers and the people of Australia generally, and that is why we are still sitting over here.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the issue of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. I find this rather intriguing because in question time yesterday Senator Chapman asked a question about unions receiving federal government money with regard to amalgamations with other unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deregistered unions.

—I am glad Senator Parer raised the point about deregistered unions because they are not deregistered unions; they are state registered unions which are fully entitled. If members of the opposition took some time to check the facts about industrial relations legislation, they would know that these unions are entitled to receive money under the act. They are not deregistered; they are still state registered organisations. It is a pity that Senator Parer did not check the facts. Sometimes it would greatly assist the Senate and honourable senators on the other side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The issue of sections 45D and 45E has been going on for a long time. It was clearly the majority view of the committee that inquired into it that it has been used as a big stick and as a punitive measure against workers pursuing their legitimate rights. It is now going to be put in its right place—that is, in the Industrial Relations Act. That is where it should be dealt with because it is clearly a much fairer way of dealing with the legitimate rights of workers to pursue the issues that are important to them, such as their working conditions. It also provides protection for workers who may well be in a situation where the Industrial Relations Commission is not able to settle the issue. The 72-hour issue is, quite frankly, a very fair proposal. If we looked at all of the disputes that have happened over the time of the Industrial Relations Act, we would find that in many instances, even in the case of actions under sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, they have been resolved outside 72 hours.

I do not intend to take up much of the time of the Senate dealing with this motion because it really is misinformative in its content and, quite frankly, we will have the opportunity to debate the legislation in this chamber. Senator Crane's claims were quite unfounded because he has not seen the legislation. He made a lot of assumptions. Quite clearly, it is pointless for us to continue with a worthless debate about a worthless motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support Senator Crane's motion. Irrespective of the flowery words of people such as Senator Murphy, this government is seeking to entrench union power in the hands of a few union heavies—no more, no less. That is what it is all about. It is all about a pay-off for the most dishonest campaign run by the union movement for the last election. We all know what happened; we were there. We saw them go to the workplaces; we had people phone us up. Nurses came to see us and said, `Do you know the union came to see us and said, "If you vote Liberal you're going to lose your job"?'. That is totally dishonest—the normal way the trade union movement operates in this place.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that everyone is aware of is that 70 per cent of people in the private sector are not union members, and they do not want to be. In my lifetime I have worked in all areas of the economy. I have worked in non-union shops and I had my own business at one time where a number of employees were union members and they continued to be union members because they were in a trade where they required a union ticket if they wanted to go back to it. They had to go back to a closed shop. It was the ultimate lack of freedom.

I should tell Senator Murphy what our policy does. It simply entrenches the right of individual Australians within this society to decide whether they want to be a union member or whether they want to resign. I would have thought that that was a basic freedom that a democratic country such as Australia desired. What is the government frightened of? Why are the unions frightened? Why is the government entrenching union power? If it was good enough, people would willingly join. There is nothing more coercive and more of an attack on the freedom of individuals in this country than a closed shop.

I listened to the claims of honourable senators opposite—the union apparatchiks—the other day. I do not want to name them because I might be wrong; it might have been Senator Burns. They were saying that union membership was not compulsory. What a joke! This is what the whole enterprise bargaining system is about. The so-called free enterprise bargaining of the non-unionised sector is saying, `Yes, you can apply for an enterprise agreement but we are going to get a union heavy there and if he doesn't like it, he will have the power of veto'.

If Senator Murphy were genuine about doing the right thing by the 70 per cent of people who do not want to be members of unions, he would facilitate their ability to make an agreement with their own employer on the basis that the relationship between an employer and employee is important. They know that if they are successful and their business is successful their jobs will be secure, rather than the opposite, which would occur under the government. But they do not want that.

In his speech Senator Murphy said that Queensland was not mentioned. I was delighted to hear him say that. Senator Burns will attest to the fact that about 80 or 90 per cent of the employees of the Metway Bank in Queensland decided they wanted to have an enterprise agreement with their management. What happened? The unions put on the greatest stunt we have seen in our lives. They demanded that there be union representation. They tried to get them pushed into the federal jurisdiction, as honourable senators opposite are probably aware. They tried every trick in the book. The members themselves hung out because they knew they could get a better deal. The Metway Bank then came under sustained attack by the monkeys in Queensland—the members of the Labor Party—at the request of the organ grinders in the trade union movement who said, `You've got to get Metway because it will not allow the unions to participate in this process'.

The unions got the bank money-wise. They used a piece of legislation to take from the Metway Bank $18 million which rightfully belonged to it. The ironic part of all this and the thing that has amused me is that I happened to see an annual report the other day from Metway Bank, and guess who is a fairly large shareholder. The ALP itself! It is an amazing set of circumstances.

The thing that genuinely concerns me about this legislation is that everyone would agree that what is necessary in this country is an increase in the number of people in full-time employment. We have around one million people out of work because of the recession we had to have. The man who is now the Prime Minister of this country pulled the levers, jacked up interest rates to stop imports coming into Australia, shot all the innocent bystanders and created unemployment. That is exactly what happened. I do not think anyone would dispute that.

This legislation encourages employers—and we should bear in mind that the majority of employers in the private sector are in the small business sector—to put on casual and part-time labour, not full-time labour. I read the other day in the paper that there is concern in the community that if the people who work overtime did not do so, the employers would put on full-time labour.
I have never said that the hourly rates of pay in this country are too high. In fact, with the reduction—

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard has.
—He has not. That is not true. I have never said the hourly rates of pay are too high.
—Where do you get the three bucks an hour?

—If Senator Murphy listened instead of gabbling on, he might learn something. This is typical of a union meeting. If anyone says something in a union meeting that the other members do not want to hear they turn off the microphone or shout that person down. This is the typical bullying that one expects from a closed shop union meeting. If someone stands up and says something that the others do not like, they either shout him down or turn off the microphone so he cannot be heard. We all know about that old tactic.

PARA.TAB: The point I was making is that this is a disincentive. It is not simply a matter of the rates of pay per hour; it is a matter of unit costs of production. I think Senator Burns will know about the worst aspects of many awards. I think he will look back and say, `Why did I do that in the good old days?'. I can see the look of guilt written all over Senator Burns's face. He did things because he could get away with them in affluent times. Over the passage of time those actions created unemployment. Conditions of work destroyed the productivity of this country. We have also seen—

TALK.START.PARA: —Management practices.

—Oh my goodness me! Senator Burns certainly comes from the last century if he blames management practices. The next thing he will talk about is putting kids up chimneys. If there is genuine concern about the lack of employment opportunities, it is important that this government address the problem in a way that will fix it instead of bowing to the industrial arm of the ALP, the union movement, and entrenching its powers, which will be to the detriment not only of existing employees in Australia but, more importantly, those who cannot get a job.

PARA.TAB: I am indebted to a recent report of the Business Council of Australia which tracks in chronological order the events that led up to the introduction of this legislation. This shows the utter chaos of this government. The Prime Minister has a habit of lifting the expectations of everybody. He has done it with Mabo and he has done it with the industrial relations policy. He says that everyone is going to be a winner. That results in a whole lot of disappointed people. The Business Council's report states that on 21 April:
The Prime Minister, in a speech to the Institute of Directors—

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose he is covering his options in case he wants to choose the Paris option—

presented a model where enterprise bargaining would be the primary determinant of wages and conditions of work, with simplified awards continuing only to provide a safety net for those few employees unable to make workplace agreements. Enterprise bargaining would be accelerated and would result in agreements that were full substitutes for awards rather than add-ons, the Commission would use its arbitral powers only rarely,—
This is the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, speaking in April, just after the election—
mechanisms would be introduced to enable agreements to be effectively enforced. . .
The report then states that on 16 June:

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Industrial Relations, in a speech to the Confederation of British Industry, supported and enlarged on the Prime Minister's vision. New elements added were protection against unfair dismissal and provision of unpaid parental leave as minimum standards, the right to strike, and the need to spread enterprise agreements to non-union sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is what is going to happen.

—Senator Murphy says that is what is going to happen. It is not going to happen because no employer or employee will go for an enterprise agreement when they know that standing there will be a union heavy who, win or lose, will turn up the next day and say to the fellows, `Comrades, you better join the union because if you don't we will make life so difficult for you that you won't even get your supplies delivered to the premises'. That is what happens in the real world and that is the monopolistic attitude of the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: On August 10 the Business Council made a submission and followed it up. One can see the evolution of the process. The report states that on 20 August:

The Minister for Industrial Relations, in a speech to the Trade Union Promotion and Publicity Campaign Seminar, unveiled his specific proposals for change. The original proposals had become substantially modified—

SPEECH.PARA: surprise, surprise—

awards, "suitably updated," were to become the safety net for the enterprise bargaining system, and "appropriate access to arbitration" retained; rather than enterprise bargaining providing the overwhelming avenue for wage increases, two parallel streams of enterprise agreements and awards were envisaged; "Non-union deals would not be allowed to undercut award minima" . . . In addition, sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act were to be transferred to the Industrial Relations Act . . .

When sections 45D and 45E were introduced in the 1970s the then leader of the ACTU was Mr Robert Hawke. It is on record that he told the then minister, who introduced the legislation, `If you go ahead and do this, I will ensure there will be blood on the streets'. Mr Hawke said to Mr Howard that there would be blood on the streets. Of course there was not blood on the streets. What happened with the passage of time was that sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act became a deterrent to militant unions taking secondary and primary boycott action. That is exactly what happened.

PARA.TAB: I recounted in here the other day—and I will not go through it again—the experience I had with the matter. It was not a punitive thing at all; it was a matter of last resort. The other day, as a result of an interjection, I asked Senator Murphy which union he was in and he told me. I congratulate him for telling me because when we asked Senator Cook last year he would not tell us. He ducked and weaved all over the place. At least Senator Murphy told me.

Senator Murphy is a member of a mega union consisting of forestry workers, miners and all those sorts of workers. It was interesting that only about a month ago his union decided to pull every coal miner in Australia out on strike. They went on strike because they did not like the price that BHP was getting for coal being exported to Turkey. Every coal miner in Australia went on strike. I was contacted by miners from the Hunter Valley and from the Bowen Basin, which is in my state. They said to me, `We do not know why we are on strike, but we are going on strike because the union leaders told us to'.

CRA and one other company decided to use sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. The unions said that if they wanted to do that they could. It was nothing to do with them because they had not sold the coal to Turkey. The coal miners were pulled out against their will, production was down, our reputation as an overseas supplier suffered yet again and the union decided it would not have a four-day strike, it would have a three-day strike. I understand that the companies have withdrawn the section 45D and 45E process and have not proceeded with the damages, but it was there as a deterrent. That decision was made on 20 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it worked.
—Yes. The report states that on 20 August to 2 September:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary of the ACTU—
here comes the organ grinder—
in various media interviews, categorically opposed significant parts of the Minister's proposal, particularly the opening of enterprise bargaining to non-unionists.

There is the rub. There would be no enterprise agreements between 70 per cent of the private sector work force because the ACTU did not want to see the power slip away. It wanted to put itself in the position of unionising people who do not want to be unionised. In other words, it wants the power of economic life and death over individual people.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the electorate say at the election? That was in our election manifesto.

—I already covered that before Senator Sherry came into the chamber, so I will not go over it again. We know about the campaign of lies run by the labour arm of the Australian Labor Party. The Secretary of the ACTU would not let it be open for non-unionists. The report states that on 5 September:

SPEECH.PARA: Media reports indicated that the Government and the ACTU had agreed on six areas of change—
What a farce this is! Are those opposite the elected government of this country or not?

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right; we are.

—No. They have to rush off and get permission from the non-elected ACTU before they can bring in legislation that will improve the lot of every Australian and, I might add, make it more likely that we could get the unemployed into productive jobs. The people in the business community who employ real people in real jobs are reading about this in the paper, irrespective of what Senator Murphy says about consultation. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ACTU would be pressing hard on other issues, including the repeal of section 118A—
The report states that on 6 September:

The Business Council issued a further media release pointing out that the ACTU proposals and their apparent endorsement by the Prime Minister were missing the real point about the need for fundamental reform to the industrial relations system—
That is what is needed—fundamental reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?
—It means freedom—the freedom of people to make their own decisions; the freedom of people to decide willingly and voluntarily whether they want to be a member of the union or not.
—Coercion!
—Coercion. That is exactly what this legislation is about. The report states that on 17 September:

SPEECH.PARA: The media reported that the Minister and the ACTU had reached "a deal" which further entrenched union power and did nothing to facilitate effective enterprise bargaining . . . the Government seems to be talking only to the ACTU and to be caught up in its thrall.

I will conclude with those remarks. I reiterate that, if this government is serious about tackling unemployment, creating real jobs, creating real full-time jobs and not giving incentives to people to go for the casual and part-time work, it must grasp the nettle, make its own decisions and not do things simply at the whim of a couple of union bosses who are not interested in their own workers and who are not interested in the unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —During his contribution, Senator Parer said that this debate sounded like a union meeting. If it were a union meeting, you, Mr Acting Deputy President, having been involved in the debate, would not be allowed to sit in the chair and make rulings in this debate. That is how democratic the trade unions are.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Burns should voluntarily withdraw those remarks. It is a standing procedure of this Senate. It happens consistently on both sides of this chamber. It is an outrageous suggestion that you are doing something that is wrong. It is a slur on you in your position in the chair. I ask that it be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—I suggest that Senator Burns might be more circumspect in his remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make it a bit clearer. I said if this were a trade union meeting—
—Which it is not.
—I agree, but Senator Parer said that it was like a trade union meeting. I wanted to make that point, with no reflection on the standing orders of the Senate.
—It is a total slur on the Acting Deputy President. It is outrageous.

—The Acting Deputy President has made his ruling. Historically the trade unions have played a role in society because of the dictatorial attitudes of employers. They had to come into existence to protect the rights of employees, were given pretty poor wages and unsafe and unhealthy working conditions. So the unions had to come into existence to protect people in that area.

PARA.TAB: There have been years of struggle with the gradual building of awards and minimum wages and a safer and healthier working environment. This was done through confrontation with employers. Since the election of the Labor government we have had an accord—an accord which those opposite said would not work. It has worked for 10 years. It is still in place. Their analysis of the situation by those opposite has been proved wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the one million unemployed? Ask them.

—Senator Crane says, `What about the employers?' The employers were invited to be involved in the first place. They opposed any such agreement and did not want to be involved. So that is the answer to Senator Crane's query.

PARA.TAB: I want to answer some criticisms that have been made by Senator Parer. He talked about compulsory unionism. It is true that in some awards there is preference to unionists at the point of engagement and at the point of dismissal, but certainly not during the period of employment. There is no law which says that someone should be in an union, but it is also true that there are certain agreements in some workplaces where people are expected to join the union and, indeed, give an undertaking to do so voluntarily when they join that organisation.

I have had experience in these matters; no-one on the other side of the chamber has. I recall going to a metal workshop in Brisbane. I sought to convince people that it was in their interests to join a union. Those workers said that they did not want to join the union, that they had a good employer and that they were happy the way they were. So I left the workshop. There was no further action or no further request made to them. But six months later, when that employer behaved badly towards them, they rang the union office and asked to become members. I went out there and, on their behalf, took up the problems they had and I was able to solve them. Those people are members of that union today.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is irrelevant to this motion.

—No, it is not irrelevant. Those opposite say that the government is concerned about the interests of trade unions. It is true that the government is concerned about the interests of trade unionists and the interest of non-unionists. Proposed new clause 170RA.(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) because some of those employees are members of an organisation of employees while others are not members of such an organisation—
then the employer shall not discriminate. It is very clear: there will be no discrimination.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer also talked about job creation and unemployment reduction. These are quite different in this day and age because while many hundreds of thousands jobs have been created in recent years, they have not reduced the unemployment level for some time because of increased productivity, better management practices and better technology. So, creating jobs does not guarantee any reduction in unemployment. I have not heard anyone talking about labour costs being a problem. That is probably because labour costs in European countries and Japan, for instance, are much higher than they are in Australia. In fact, we are in a fairly competitive position.
There have always been penalties for stoppages at work in awards and there are, even in the current proposal. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 178 of the Principal Act is amended . . .
if the breach is of a term of an award constituted by a certified agreement or enterprise flexibility agreement and continues for more than one day—the total of

PARA.TAB: (B) $2,500 for each day for which the breach continues . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The penalties are in there. Do not tell me that is mollycoddling trade unions. During the years of the Menzies government and following years, there were always penalties in the Industrial Relations Act which made it illegal for workers to go on strike. That included safety issues where people's lives and health were at stake. The penalty was there. People were not entitled legally to go on strike even to protect their health or their lives. That has changed since the Labor government has come into power and there is now an opportunity to discuss the issues on merit and reach some conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like to bring to Senator Burns's attention that this motion is about the lack of consultation with the state governments in particular, and others in general. At no stage during his address has Senator Burns made any reference to the motion before the chair. I ask you to bring him to order on that point please.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—I suggest that Senator Burns directs his remarks to the motion before the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did refer specifically to the words `protection of trade union interests' which I think is quite an important point made in Senator Crane's motion. I just ask Senator Crane to be relevant when he gets up and speaks about matters. I believe I am being relevant.

PARA.TAB: On the question of consultation, if the brains of those opposite were working as efficiently as they should be, they would realise that coalition state governments are ideologically opposed to the trade union movement and the federal Labor government has sympathy with the interests of trade union members and workers in the community.

It is not reasonable for some people to consult on some matters about which they are diametrically opposed. For instance, I point to the introduction of individual contracts by the National Party government in Queensland. If it was prepared to consult with the trade unions or with the federal government, it would have been on the basis of did they want to be hung, and just how high and on what day. The National Party just brought that legislation into law against the wishes of the trade union movement and it would certainly have been against the wishes of the federal Labor government.

Those opposite talk about consultation. Did Jeff Kennett consult people when he took two statutory holidays off workers in Victoria? Did he consult people on his current laws on industrial relations? No, he did not; he moved unilaterally. The federal government would have realised that it would have to move unilaterally but it was quite prepared to talk to those state governments which had some common views about the matter, even though they might not agree absolutely with what was being done.

While we were having a confrontation position—which Senator Crane's motion suggests should continue—other countries were developing better attitudes to industrial relations. They were gradually increasing productivity and building their economies while our situation was one of confrontation. I must say that that was not by choice. The trade unions would certainly have preferred to do it in other ways and, indeed, moved to an accord at the first opportunity.

Other countries were able to build their economies based on the fact that they repressed trade union activity and made it illegal. Those countries were able to utilise and exploit their work force. Even in those countries, as they have become more prosperous and their economies have grown, wages have risen and conditions have improved, which has given them fewer advantages when competing for economic trade.

We are not rooted in the past, as has been suggested by those opposite. The trade union movement wants to look at new ideas, but we want to do it on the basis of equality. We want to see a situation where negotiations are carried out in good faith and are not backed up on one side by penalties that create a situation within which those people who do not want to negotiate meaningfully can say, `To hell with the workers. If they go on strike we'll use penalties against them. We'll use the law against them. Why should we negotiate?'.

If somebody asked a reasonable question about the future policy of the company, costings or other management issues, those employers would say, `That's our business. That's a management prerogative. Why should you know? Why should we tell you anything? It is an interference in management'. We want a situation where employers are prepared to tell people where the company is going and what its policy is, so that in negotiation the trade unions can make an objective decision that we believe would be in the interests of both parties and also the public interest.

I reject totally the ill thought out and ideologically bankrupt motion of Senator Crane and some of the absolutely negative and unhelpful remarks made by other opposition speakers. I suggest that when the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 is passed it will be a boon for this country and we will see productivity increase and even less confrontation in the future.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
