DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Sherry) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Sherry) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I table the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Mr President, this bill follows on from the changes to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 which were passed by the Parliament during the Autumn Sittings earlier this year and more recently at the commencement of the current Budget Sittings. It gives effect to the remaining major changes to the Act that are necessary to implement the totality of the reform package flowing from the Commission's review of the operation of the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments in this bill, together with those which have already received Assent, establish a leaner, tighter and more effective organisation, with devolved decision making going hand-in-hand with improved accountability. As a result ATSIC's ability to provide a vehicle for indigenous self determination becomes even more firmly established. As we have seen in the last few weeks that means ATSIC's evolution as an organisation able not only to manage Commonwealth programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities but also to negotiate on policy with an independent and forceful political voice.
This bill provides, in essence, for:
major changes to arrangements for the Torres Strait, including the establishment of a Torres Strait Regional Authority (TSRA);
streamlining the financial provisions of the Act, one of the effects of which will be to facilitate the further devolution of authority to Regional Councils;

PARA.TAB: strengthening the role of the Office of Evaluation and Audit; and
establishing an independent Electoral Review Panel.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable Senators will recall that when the second package of amendments was introduced at the commencement of the current Sittings, it was foreshadowed that a further bill encompassing these further reforms would be introduced during these Sittings.

This third package of amendments, like those introduced earlier this year, flow from recommendations contained in the Commission's report to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on the operation of the Act. These amendments, which build on the reforms already agreed to by Parliament, will further enhance the representative nature of the organisation, strengthen the role of the Regional Councils as the linchpins of empowerment for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and reinforce the Commission's established commitment to high standards of scrutiny and accountability.
The reforms are based on the Government's commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self determination and our confidence in indigenous people managing their own affairs.

I turn now to the major provisions of the present bill and in doing so I draw to the Senate's attention that the bill is large and it is not possible to set out in great detail many of the changes. Those that are of a substantive nature I will deal with more fully.
Office of Evaluation and Audit

The bill substantially widens the powers of the Office of Evaluation and Audit, increasing the ability of the Minister and the Commission to have examined the financial management of ATSIC funded organisations.

It provides for an expansion in the functions of the Office of Evaluation and Audit to include the evaluation and audit of the operations of Aboriginal Hostels Limited, the Commercial Development Corporation, and the proposed Torres Strait Regional Authority as well as the Commission.

Additionally, the bill includes provision to enable the Minister and the Commission to direct the Office of Evaluation and Audit to investigate the operations of Regional Councils, in addition to the above bodies, and in certain cases, ATSIC and TSRA grant and loan recipients. Provision is also made for the Director of Evaluation and Audit to have greater powers to examine documents.

The bill also includes a number of clauses relating to the Director of Evaluation and Audit amendments including provision for the period of appointment, remuneration and allowances, leave of absence, disclosure of interests, resignation, termination of appointment of the Director of Evaluation and Audit, aligning these with similar provisions for other full time statutory officer holders under the Principal Act. Provision is also made for an acting Director and for the Director to be immune from personal liability in an action or other proceeding for damages in relation to anything done in his/her official capacity. These provisions are largely administrative in nature and serve to correct an anomaly in the existing Act.
Chief Executive Officer

The bill amends the period of appointment of the Chief Executive Officer by setting a maximum period of appointment rather than a minimum. This is in accordance with standard appointment provisions in most legislation establishing statutory appointments. It also requires the CEO to report his/her interests to the Commission Chairperson rather than the full Board of the Commission.
Advisory Committees

The bill includes amendments relating to membership of Advisory Committees and the members of the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board. The amendments include provisions for the disclosure of interests at meetings, resignations, and termination of the members of these bodies.
Amendments relating to Regional Council Administrators

Provision is made in the bill to set the terms and conditions for an Administrator to hold office. This was omitted from the Principal Act and is largely an administrative matter. The provisions include full-time appointment consistent with the move to full time Regional Council Chairpersons, disclosure of interests, resignation, leave of absence, and suspension and termination of appointment.

Consistent with the Government's commitment to greater self determination and self management, provision has been made for the Commission rather than the Minister to appoint Administrators. Provision is also made for an acting Administrator and for the Commission to appoint a replacement Administrator if there is a vacancy in an office of the Administrator.
Commercial Development Corporation

There are a number of amendments relating to the CDC. These are largely technical in nature and tidy up the Principal Act to bring it more into line with current drafting procedures. The bill provides for at least one Director to be an ATSIC Commissioner, for the period of appointments not to exceed five years, and for the termination of appointment of a Director of the Corporation.
Taxation

The bill includes provision for exempting ATSIC from the payment of excise duty which would otherwise be payable by the Commission, or by any other person, on goods that are for use by the Commission. The current arrangement whereby ATSIC is required to pay excise duty is inconsistent with other Government agencies and it is only reasonable that the Act be amended to bring the organisation into line with other Commonwealth Departments and agencies.
Aboriginal Hostels Limited

It is important to note that AHL is not a statutory organisation established under the Principal Act, but a company funded through ATSIC. The Government considers that it is essential that AHL be subject to the same level of scrutiny and accountability and to the same administrative review mechanisms as ATSIC. Provisions are included in the bill to this end.

Honourable Senators will note that the bill before them includes provision for Division 2 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901 to apply to Aboriginal Hostels Limited and that certain decisions of an administrative character made at the Director level are made subject to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
Secrecy Provisions

In the interests of privacy and in recognition of the very sensitive personal information that may become available to certain office holders within ATSIC, the Government has agreed with the Commission's proposal that section 90 of the Principal Act be extended to apply to the Director of Evaluation and Audit, a member of the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, a Regional Councillor, a member of an Advisory Committee established under section 96 and an Administrator. It will also extend the secrecy provisions to the Torres Strait Regional Authority when it commences on 1 July 1994.
Regional Council Estimates Processes and Reporting Requirements

The bill includes provisions to strengthen the annual reporting requirements of Regional Councils. As a result of the proposed amendments Regional Councils will be obliged to provide to the Commission an Annual Report dealing with the operations of the Regional Council during the year, the implementation during that year of the Regional Plan, details of grants made from Regional Council budgets during the year and any other matters relating to that year as the Commission determines in writing. The Annual Report and Regional Plan are required to be made available for inspection and purchase by residents of the Region.

Additionally, provision is made in the bill to require Regional Councils to have regard to their Regional Plans when preparing their Draft Budgets. This linkage is considered necessary because of the increased powers which Regional Councils will have over the disbursement of Commission funds.
Delegations

The bill makes provision for a number of changes to the power of delegation under the Principal Act. Some of the changes relate to administrative matters. I refer in particular to the proposal to enable the Commission to delegate to the Director of Evaluation and Audit its powers for the appointment of Consultants under Section 56 and also to enable the Chief Executive Officer power to sub-delegate functions or powers to a member of the staff of the Commission. However the more important aspect of the amendments relates to the enhanced responsibilities given to Regional Councils.

One of the key recommendations of the Commission in its report to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs was the need for greater empowerment of Regional Councils. The bill provides for the Commission to delegate to a Regional Council its powers to approve funds and issue guarantees.

These powers are not unfettered. It is important that Honourable Senators note that these delegated powers will be subject to any written directions by the Commission and are accompanied by sanctions to protect the interests of the Government, ATSIC and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. Provision is also made to empower the Commission Chairperson to suspend delegations to Regional Councils in certain cases.
General Funding Powers

Another of the key recommendations of the Commission was the need to simplify funding powers of the Commission. This bill spells out the new and simplified arrangements. I must reiterate to Honourable Senators that it is neither the Commission's nor the Government's intention to in any way water down accountability requirements either to the Parliament or to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people whom the Commission represents. Indeed the effect of the amendments is to enhance that accountability.

We are concerned, however, over the current complex and inflexible provisions and propose that they be amended to enable the Commission to more successfully fulfil the functions imposed upon it by the principal Act. As the Government has stated on a number of occasions, true self-determination is fundamental to the success of the Commission and it is in pursuit of this that these amendments are put before the Parliament.

In essence the changes enable the Commission to make a grant of money or grant an interest in land or grant an interest in personal property or make a loan of money to any body corporate or unincorporated organisation. In certain cases this power extends to individuals. Regional Councils and the Torres Strait Regional Authority cannot be recipients. This provision is accompanied by a requirement that such grants, loans and guarantees may only be made for the purpose of furthering the social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

For purposes of enhanced scrutiny the bill also requires the Commission to formulate decision making principles about the giving of grants, loans and guarantees. Funding must only be made in accordance with these decision making principles. The Chief Executive Officer must cause a notice of the making of decision making principles to be published in the Gazette. He must also ensure that copies of the decision making principles which are in force are given to each Regional Council and are available for inspection and purchase at each of the Commission's offices.
Corporate Plan

One of the important technical amendments which the Commission has suggested is the need to remove the direct link between the Commission's Corporate Plan and the procedures for the engagement of Consultants. The bill proposes that this link be severed. Instead, the Commission will be required to set out the criteria and standard terms and conditions for the engagement of Consultants by way of written instrument and to notify the making of the instrument in the Gazette.
Staff and Consultants

In the second amending bill passed earlier in these sittings wards were created for the purposes of electing Regional Councillors. This present bill includes consequent provisions which prohibit a member of the staff of the Commission or a Consultant to the Commission standing for election, or being elected, as a member for a Regional Council Ward.
Draft Budgets

The bill provides for simplification of the draft budget, and the estimates processes involved, for both the Commission and Regional Councils. Consistent with the proposed streamlining of funding provisions, the bill reduces the number of elements required in the Commission's estimates of expenditure.

Equally important, the bill facilitates a greater devolution of funding to Regional Council budgets by enabling the Commission to earmark elements of Regional Council allocations for particular purposes.
Removal of Regional Councils

As I have mentioned earlier, both the Commission and the Government wish to maintain and enhance the accountability requirements. Included in this bill are amendments which strengthen the responsibility of the Commission and Regional Councils. The bill provides for the Commission to remove Regional Councils from office in certain situations. These include the Regional Council's failure to perform its functions, failure to comply with the Draft Budgets requirements, failure to meet the Annual Reporting requirement, or contravention of a delegation from the Commission.

The provisions require that, before this power is invoked, the Commission must provide the Regional Council with a notice setting out the reasons for its proposed course of action and giving 28 days in which to show cause why the Regional Councillors should not be removed. It is hoped that any dispute in connection with these matters can be resolved within the 28 day period and that it will not be necessary to remove the Regional Councillors.

Provision is also made for an appointment of an Administrator to administer the affairs of the Regional Council where the Regional Councillors have been removed from office. It is the intention of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to make Election Rules to provide for a by-election to be held within a period of twelve months from the date that a Regional Council is removed under the new section 123A.
Provisions relating to Torres Strait Islanders

This is perhaps one of the most significant changes proposed in the bill. The Government is taking up the Commission's recommendation that the Torres Strait region be dealt with separately from other Regions and has included in the bill clauses establishing a Torres Strait Regional Authority. This Authority will supersede the Torres Strait Regional Council. This section of the bill is quite lengthy and I ask that Honourable Senators study it carefully as it is a significant demonstration of the Government's commitment to the empowerment of one of Australia's two distinct indigenous peoples.

In effect this will give significantly greater powers and impose significantly higher levels of accountability upon the Torres Strait body. The Torres Strait Regional Authority will now have powers and functions similar to those enjoyed by the Commission in relation to indigenous people in the Torres Strait.
Independent Review Panel

As foreshadowed by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs when he introduced the ATSIC Amendment Bill No. 2 earlier in the current sittings this bill contains a further major reform in the establishment of an independent electoral review process. The Review Panel established by this bill will have two distinct functions, firstly to review and determine the boundaries of the regions and wards and the grouping of regions into zones, and secondly to review and report to the Minister on the electoral systems established by the Act.

As far as the review of boundaries is concerned, the panel will call for submissions from interested persons and make draft boundary recommendations. An augmented review panel will then consider appeals against the draft boundary recommendations and make final boundary recommendations. The Minister will be required to give effect to the final boundary recommendations.

The boundary review process is modelled on the redistribution committees established by the Australian Electoral Act and is designed to ensure that the panel and the augmented panel are not only independent and objective but are seen to be independent and objective.
Conclusion

Mr President, this final package of reforms gives effect to the remaining aspects of the major changes to the Act contained in the Commission's Review Report to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on the operation of the Act. I am aware that the bill is quite a complex one, ranging from minor technical amendments to fairly significant changes. As a whole it fulfils the Government's commitment to implement the Commission's recommendations in relation to the operation of ATSIC.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the information of Honourable Senators, and commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL LEGISLATION (REPEALS AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1993WOOL TAX (Nos 1-5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1993AUSTRALIAN WOOL RESEARCH AND PROMOTION ORGANISATION BILL 1993WOOL INTERNATIONAL BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering this legislation at a time when, for various historical reasons, the wool industry is probably in the trough of the worst depression it has ever known. The legislation which we have before us is an attempt by the government to try to improve that position and, with some reservations, I believe that it is a step in the right direction.

PARA.TAB: Wool recession conditions, particularly among some of our biggest wool customers such as Russia and China, mean that the demand for wool during the last two or three years has not been as high as previous levels. However, medium- and long-term predictions for demand indicate that demand for the product will be reasonable. When we take into account that income growth in developing countries, especially in cold climate countries such as China, Turkey and Korea, will be considerable in the next decade, there is a great opportunity for the marketing and promotion of this great fibre.

I do not propose to rephrase the arguments put forward by my coalition colleagues for the adoption of this legislation. As a woolgrower, I must declare my interest in this debate, but as a patriotic Australian I must also declare my interest in the promulgation of soundly based principles to help put the industry back on its feet.

The establishment of Wool International has already been described by previous speakers. It is hoped that the intention of the government to make this a strongly commercially oriented organisation will be carried through in practice. It is also to be hoped that the commercial flavour of Wool International will compensate for the drop in funding for promotion and that every effort will be made by the authorities involved to expand the international trade in wool and wool products.

I do not wish to discuss further the details of the major issues contained in the legislation, but I would wish to place on record that, after many lengthy discussions with woolgrowers in my own state of Victoria and after hearing the thoughtful statements presented by those who participated in the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs last Friday, some further points should be noted. The industry has been in the doldrums now for at least the last two years, and in a state of heightened and unrealistic expectation for longer than that.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industry must accept that the world will no longer buy wool because it exists, but the world will need to be persuaded to buy wool because it is competitively priced and can be adapted to compete with and surpass man-made fibres in a variety of uses.

PARA.TAB: The recommendations made in the Garnaut report and the legislation emanating from it point the way towards a better structure for the sale and marketing of wool. With the eventual privatisation of Wool International, government will be removed from the process.

The provision of a fixed release schedule of wool from the stockpile has also provoked a great deal of discussion. At this stage, it is impossible to forecast whether the amount will be too much, and further depress demand, or too little so that it would not be possible to satisfy potential customer demand. If it were possible to forecast future events in market movement, the debate today would not be necessary.

Obviously, there are real concerns about whether demand will go up or down and the effect of that movement on prices. However, to my mind the legislation provides a framework for future developments within the industry that has not been present before. I hope that the legislation will position the industry to take advantage of movements in world demand and prices for wool.

I commend the work of Professor Garnaut and his committee. I believe that the legislation has more positive aspects than negative ones and has the potential to restore this great industry to a profitable position in world trade and textile manufacture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of bills is a reflection of the increasing and continuing difficulties being experienced in the wool industry right across Australia and, to an extent, around the world. Wool has always enjoyed a special position in the hearts and minds of all Australians and for years the claim that Australia was riding to success on the back of our sheep industry was as popular as it was true.

PARA.TAB: Australia is the largest wool producing country in the world and is also the largest exporter. Our production accounts for 30 per cent of the world production and just under 60 per cent of all exports of wool. Over the last 50 years, sheep numbers and wool production have fluctuated due to a range of factors. Prices have moved similarly, moving as low as 354c a kilo in 1970 and something like 690c a kilo in 1987-88. Let us not forget the floor price of 870c a kilo just prior to the big crash at the end of the 1980s.

The 1980s will long be remembered as some of the most heady years in the history of wool. Demand was strong and the reserve price scheme was in operation and climbing and few stopped to think that it would ever collapse. Indeed, just prior to the series of events that ultimately saw the collapse and the removal of the reserve price scheme in 1990, ABARE was advising growers at its 1989 outlook conference:

SPEECH.PARA: While wool prices have receded from the record levels of last April, they are projected to remain relatively high into the 1990s.

That was only three years ago. It was only three years ago that we debated what we thought then was the most difficult piece of legislation affecting the industry. I said in the Senate during the debate that the words spoken in this chamber would long be forgotten while the impact of what has been decided lives on. I said then that the stockpile was overhanging the market and that we must have a look to our consumers. These sentiments apply also to the legislation before us today. This package of eight bills may well be as momentous and as history making as the collapse of the reserve price scheme was in 1990.

PARA.TAB: History will record that this legislation is supported by all the major parties. I hope history also records that as legislators we had to do what we thought collectively was best at the time and that, like ABARE, we are not infallible. The Senate, quite appropriately in my view, referred this package of bills to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for review. It did that notwithstanding that the legislation was not opposed. By doing so, it reflected a concern both within and outside this place about aspects of the legislation.

That opposition and concern was well highlighted in the hearings last Friday when representatives of growers, processors, marketers and exporters came and put their views to the committee. Those views could best be summarised as caution about the role of Wool International, the buyback provisions of Wool International and the fixed disposal schedule. Given that time is short, I will keep my remarks brief.

The Wool International Bill establishes a fixed schedule for the disposal of the stockpile by Wool International. The Wool Council of Australia, representing growers, is very happy with this. It supports a fixed schedule because it sees real benefits in it. Professor Garnaut told our committee last Friday that he supported a fixed schedule and was opposed to a minimum schedule because it removed any possibility of an upside, which a fixed schedule provides. DPIE also supported a fixed schedule.

Opposing such an arrangement was Dr Lionel Ward of the National Council of Wool Selling Brokers. He rejected the view that a fixed disposal schedule offered certainty of supply. He was supported by the International Wool Textile Organisation which suggested:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the worst of all systems is a fixed quantity disposal policy which is implemented in October 1993, starts in July 1994 and cannot be changed for three years.
Don Booth from the Australian Council of Wool Exporters said:
. . . a fixed disposal schedule will not lead to certainty in the market, but rather will lead to greater price volatility.

In all of this, it is essential to remember that while Australia can produce wool better than anyone else, it matters little if we cannot sell it better than anyone else. As Sir William Gunn, the one-time chairman of the Australian Wool Board and the International Wool Secretariat, said in 1990:

I have to say as strongly as I possibly can that no marketing system will survive, it doesn't matter how efficient it is, if there is not an adequate demand at the consumer level for the product you are trying to sell . . .

Dr Lionel Ward reiterated these sentiments last Friday in response to one of my questions, `Can you regulate the market?'. His reply was, `No, you cannot'. That is the crux of the matter and the crux of the dilemma. On all sides you have well-informed, well-intentioned people offering a view. Time alone will tell who is right. My concern is that growers should be aware that this legislation will not alone save the industry from further pain, that actions of the 1980s and the impact of other world events outside the control of Australia must have a consequential reaction and those consequences will be seen during the next few years as we try to get wool production and selling back to a more profitable level.

PARA.TAB: The government has a part to play in this. It must get the infrastructure of our economy right—the infrastructure in terms of our transport, our waterfront and all the other imposts government puts on the farming community. Just look at what the government did to fuel in the last budget. It has put up the cost of fuel, which will put up the cost of transport.

Agricultural consultants take a pessimistic view of the proposed outcomes for wool as seen by the Garnaut report. They make the point that the supply-demand situation will remain for the foreseeable future—in the next year or two—which will not give the growers the price increase they need to stay in a sustainable position in the industry. They also worry that at the end of the period the wool industry will not have enough supplies to supply the consumer, which might mean that some people in the processing area will turn to synthetics. As I said earlier, only time will tell.

My recent trip to Europe, on which I spoke with various wool processors, brought home to me again and again that the industry must become more commercial in its approach by developing a more market driven response to consumer demands. We have to do a lot more with research; we have to do a lot more with promotion. With our research we must work to make sure that we can have a wool which can be sold to a consumer that is not prickly, that is washable and that can be tumbled dry. All those things that the researchers have done something about already have come through, but are they affordable for the end user?

The Garnaut report, as Senator Troeth said a moment ago, is a report that has gone into the industry in depth. It also suggests a similar goal as far as those consumer demands and research and promotion are concerned. My concern is that the whole matter is a complex one and that, frankly, we cannot afford to get it wrong. Instability is a deathtrap for any product and any industry—and wool is no exception. As stated in a paper by Hassall and Associates, a firm of farm consultants:

SPEECH.PARA: There is an urgent need for all political parties to recognise the impact of the frequent changes to wool regulations on the level of uncertainty in the market and that increased uncertainty leads to lower wool prices. Most importantly, future changes should be contemplated only if they facilitate improved marketing, including development of the newly emerging private wool marketing and processing organisations.

These bills and the amendments which have been suggested by the coalition are designed to strengthen and make the industry much more stable. To quote one last time from our report—and I know that Senator Crane had some input into this part, as did the rest of the committee:
The Committee urges the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to consult fully with the industry on the further development of Wool International.
The Committee urges the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to give further consideration to the Government's position on the future funding of wool promotion.
That is very important. Let us hope the minister takes it on board.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day, the buck stops with the growers. Their representative, the Wool Council of Australia, has endorsed these bills as being the right formula for the industry. On that basis, it is not for us as politicians to ignore those wishes; indeed, it is imperative that we listen to them. It is their industry and their financial future at stake. I congratulate John Anderson, the shadow minister for primary industry, for the amount of work he did in listening to grower groups all over Australia and for the way in which he consulted with the industry. On that basis, I support this package of bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what I hope will be the last debate that we have on wool. We certainly have been having them regularly over the last 2 1/2 years. I think, if we were to read Hansard, we would see very accurately chronicled what has happened to the wool industry. The wool industry was faced with the economic recession which affected the whole world with high interest rates. But, as well as high interest rates and the price crash, it also had a drought to contend with in most areas of this country—and that probably was just the icing on the cake that was not needed in the wool industry.

PARA.TAB: Before us tonight we see the results of what is commonly called the Garnaut report. This is a report commissioned earlier this year by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). It is a result of consultation that was undertaken by the members of the Garnaut committee. The committee received in excess of 120 submissions from individuals and organisations. That is a very good level of consultation to commence with.

Following the Garnaut report's publication, there were consultations. We have heard tonight that Mr Anderson, the honourable member for Gwydir, the shadow spokesman on primary industry, went around and consulted with various wool growing groups and organisations and those in the industry right across Australia. Also we must not forget the consultations which were undertaken by the Minister and his staff with all the interested and involved parties.

Recently I was privileged to participate in one of the consultative meetings which the minister undertook in Dubbo. The contribution on those members of the industry who participated was excellent. It was a well considered discussion. They presented well considered arguments and reasons why they supported the Garnaut report. They were not necessarily happy with everything that was going to happen and how tough it was going to be for them in the next little while, but they were very realistic about the future of their industry and what they had to do to work towards the future—because it does have a future and they recognised that.

We met people from a very wide cross-section of New South Wales—from the area that Senator Brownhill comes from, around Quirindi and places such as that in the northern tablelands, down into the western plains south and west of Dubbo. So it was a wide cross-section in geographic terms and also in terms of the interests which those people represented, from the Merino Breeders Association through to ordinary members of grazing organisations—ordinary, average woolgrowers who do not have studs or the elite line. So we saw a good cross-section.

This consultation was very important in enabling the government to prepare the legislation and in enabling the minister to take it to cabinet for approval. We have seen consultation continue as well. We have heard tonight about the opposition amendments. Of course they were moved following consultation with the opposition, the government and the industry; they were actually moved by the minister in the lower house. So they have become the government amendments. They were amendments which were made and passed unanimously. That has been a very important aspect of this legislation. There is being given to the outside world a vision and a confirmation of unanimity of purpose; that there is agreement on the aspects of this legislation; that the government is wanting to portray certainty and stability to the industry, the buyers of this product—and that is of vital importance.

We certainly have heard people talking about the schedule. I personally favour very strongly a fixed schedule because it gives people an indication and certainty of what the supply coming out of that stockpile will be. We know that the markets are very sensitive to a number of factors, but I think one of the areas—and we must never forget it—is that supply sensitivity is of crucial importance in this industry. Prices can be hedged against in the futures markets. With supply sensitivity the manufacturing industry has to know what will be available so that it can do some forward planning, and this legislation will make that possible.

On the price side, I have not seen any major price differentiations or fluctuations in the commodities, in the garments that we actually buy. It has not mattered that the price of wool has been at 900c a kilo or at 350c a kilo. It has not made any difference to the price the consumer is paying. Therefore, to me, the price side is not as important as the actual maintaining of very keen and very careful certainty in the supply side.

For me also, the most important group in this industry is the growers, the producers. They are the ones who are bearing most of the price sensitivity. If their prices are not good enough, if they are not making enough money from their wool to live, they are going to be forced out of the industry and that is going to have an effect on supply.

This bill is what those in the industry are asking for; it is what they say will enable them to move with some certainty in the industry. It has been a long and tortuous course for them in the last 2 1/2 to three years and I think we can now say that hopefully the worst is over. They know they still have several seasons where life will be tough. But they now have certainty; there is direction within the industry and they are very pleased about that.

To all who have participated in the consultation, I think the industry must say thanks. There has been a very keen willingness on the part of all involved to consult and bring some sort of consensus to the final outcome.

I have heard people today talking about infrastructure and other aspects of government policies that might affect it. We also need to remind the states that some of the things they do have an impact upon the infrastructure and the industry. I know only too well what has happened in my own state as far as rail infrastructure goes; that has been absolutely withdrawn and decimated. There is no rail line between Burke and Nyngan; all of the wheat—and there is not much wheat—wool and cotton coming out of that area has to come by road. It is not a terribly economical way to transport those large, bulky commodities.

I have also spoken recently of the huge price differential between the cost of fuel in country areas and the cost in city areas. This is being addressed by this government in the setting up of the Industry Commission inquiry. I again urge people who are concerned about fuel costs and the differentials to participate in that inquiry because it has been well recognised that that does have an effect on these commodities. There are a number of areas that need to be looked at, not just the government impost but also the problems that have been caused by others who are manipulating and playing with issues.

We know that in New South Wales the transport costs of fuel are something like 4c a litre. That does not account for the differential that is occurring in a number of these places of up to 12c or 15c. I hope that the Garnaut report will shed more light on this issue to enable us to address this problem so that the woolgrowers will have fewer overheads when getting their wool to the markets. I also urge the states not to destroy their infrastructure and their rail systems, so that life is not made more difficult for woolgrowers, all of whom have to transport their clips.

In conclusion, I congratulate all of those who have been involved in the consultations. They have made what I think is good legislation, because agreement and consensus have been reached across the board within the industry and the political parties as well. I think that leads to good government and good legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to this package of wool bills, I once again declare my interest in this subject, being a woolgrower, but I doubt whether anybody in this chamber is not aware of that by now.

PARA.TAB: In addressing this legislation, I want to look more at the future than the present, but in the 10 minutes available to me there are a couple of things about the present that I would like to comment on as well. Firstly, I believe it is tragic that, once again, we are back in here debating the future direction of the Australian wool industry, the greatest industry this nation has ever had. I have no doubt about the future of it. It will return, in due course, to its greatness in the Australian economy for its contribution as an export earner and also, very importantly at this time when we have such high levels of unemployment, to the pride of place it once held amongst the industries that provide direct employment and, as a flow-on, indirect employment. I have no doubt about that at all.

I would like to make a couple of points about what Senator West said, particularly with regard to price. If price did not matter, if it was not important, why did the stockpile blow out as it did when the reserve price went to 870c? The simple fact is that, through the changes that were made to the wool legislation in 1987 and the flow-on from it, we priced ourselves out of the contemporary market in a very competitive textile world market scene. Price does matter. It is vital. If the competitors—to us that means the cotton industry, the synthetic industry and others—are given a price advantage in the marketplace, purchasers of wool, and, ultimately, consumers, will shift. The price on the garment will not change because it will be made out of something else and purchasers will not be buying wool.

I certainly accept Senator West's proposition that what state governments do is important, but what federal governments do is also fairly important. The decision in the government budget with regard to putting up fuel excise and sales tax will impact very dramatically on the wool industry in the component of transport. That will flow directly back to the producers and make the recovery of the industry more difficult.

In talking about the future, which I think is very important, I refer to the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs which was held last Friday. I want to deal with two of the committee's recommendations. The first is the one urging the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to consult fully with the industry on the further development of Wool International. As we know, the bills on Wool International are skeleton bills. They have to have the nuts and bolts and detail put into them.

I do not accept the proposition, as has been stated by previous speakers tonight, that there was full and proper consultation with the industry. In the industry I include the processors and the exporters as well as the producers. I think it was Mr Lionel Ward, who gave evidence at the committee hearing last Friday on behalf of the processors, who said that if this opportunity for consultation had taken place some months ago, we would have been much better placed in terms of dealing with the problems from the processors' point of view. This was confirmed by Mr Booth, President of the Australian Council of Wool Exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very true.

—I thank Senator Woodley for that interjection. It is a fact. I think it is wrong of Senator West and others to come into this place and commend people for that consultation process when, in fact, that consultation process was very poor and very weak. I urge Senator Sherry, in his capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, to take this message back to the minister, because I think it is important in the next phase that that consultation process is improved. I say that in a genuine endeavour to make sure we get it right, not to criticise, because that is past us. The future of one hell of a lot of people is depending on what we do tonight and over the next two or three months.

PARA.TAB: Even with the welcome rises in price we have seen in this selling season, wool producers cannot go on losing $4 or $5 per head. As a wool producer, on my own figures last year, which fit with the figures from ABARE, I can tell the Senate that the losses are about $5 per sheep on the current market price. On 10,000 sheep, that means a loss of $50,000 a year. That just cannot go on and emphasises very strongly why we have to get this legislation right. The part that Wool International will play, coming out of the Garnaut report, must facilitate all the links which exist in the wool industry, because they all depend on one another—right from the lamb, when the wool is grown, to the finished garment, when it is worn in Paris or elsewhere.

My next point relates to the third recommendation in the report regarding the future of funding for wool promotion. I think it is absolutely vital and imperative—I cannot stress this enough—that the government reconsider its position on promotion. It is vitally important. When I look at the money that the government makes available in a whole host of areas in our economy, for the wool industry to be told that this is the last year in which the government will be providing funding for promotion, is a situation that cannot be allowed to continue.

Even with the current situation, with the growers losing money they are still putting 3.5 per cent of their gross proceeds into promotion. It is almost impossible to get a direct contribution out of the other components of the industry, such as the International Wool Textile Organisation, that will make any significant difference to the IWS, which is the International Wool Secretariat.

One thing that is crucial to this recovery phase is the government's reconsideration of its position on promotion and its continuation of its contribution. If these bills are to be a confidence builder and provide stability, as other speakers have mentioned, it is absolutely crucial that the government shows the same sort of confidence and makes a commitment for at least another five years. I know that we did not win the last election, but the coalition made an ongoing commitment at the last election.

I very strongly urge Senator Sherry to do all that he can to have this aspect of the wool industry reconsidered; as I have already said, it is imperative. At the end of the day, I came down slightly in favour of the Garnaut report after what occurred in our hearings the other day. I certainly had a leaning towards a minimum schedule with a price penalty on top of any wool sold above the schedule. But, after considering the explanations that Professor Garnaut gave us and the various aspects of all the evidence and information that we received, I think that probably the best track for us to be on is the one that we are now going down, subject to these couple of points that I have raised.

Finally, we cannot be in this place next year or the year after debating this issue again. We have made a decision, and we must stick by it. The Wool Council of Australia has said that it will stick by the decision that has been made. There have been too many statements in the wool industry, such as the one that the 700c price was immutable and would never be changed. One could go through a list of them.

This legislation is now before us. We are making a decision about a fixed schedule for Wool International and it must stick. We cannot accept the situation whereby 12 months or so down the track we will have another inquiry and the whole thing will be rewritten, because that will destroy the wool industry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a pleasure to be able to follow in this debate a wool producer of the prominence of Senator Crane. Senator Panizza is in the chamber. He is also a very big and successful woolgrower. I will endeavour to pick up some of their remarks, as I believe they really know the industry from having lived with it.

PARA.TAB: Today, the future of our great Australian wool industry is being debated in the package of wool bills that is before us. These bills will put in place some of the recommendations put down by the Garnaut report and reduce the number of bodies that we have at present from four to two. There is absolutely no disagreement about that amongst primary industry representatives and woolgrowers.

One body will be the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, whose functions will be to promote research and development. It will have problems because it will have very little funding. The other will be Wool International, whose job will be to pay off the debt and sell the wool from the stockpile.

Many of us here tonight have some reservations about the totality of the Garnaut report. Neither the industry nor the opposition has a lot of choice; it is one of those things where one takes it or leaves it. We either accept the recommendations or continue to go down the path of uncertainty and instability with the wool industry using a system which has returned the worst real prices in its history. We certainly cannot continue to allow that to occur.

I suppose that I am no different to other honourable senators who have had woolgrowers approach them and say that many aspects of the Garnaut report are causing them concern; they want a trigger price or a variation of it. They have spoken to me for hours over the phone. I have told them that they do not have that luxury; they have either the Garnaut report or what they have at the moment. I do not think any of them have said to me, `Let's stick with what we have'. They all want to avoid it and get out of it.

The present situation of the wool industry is desperate. There are 3.9 million bales with $2.9 billion in the stockpile. Last year, wool producers lost an average of $33,700, and 91 per cent of the growers made a loss in the industry. The dramatic fact is that on 30 June 1994, the wool industry will have to meet its debt of $600 million, with a $400 million debt repayment and $200 million in interest and storage and handling costs. That is a fact of life.

If we continue to go down the course that we are now going down, the wool industry will have to find $600 million. The debt can be met only by either raising taxes—the industry could not afford another half a per cent rise; it could not afford any extra tax—or dumping the $600 million worth of wool on the market. I do not know how much wool one would have to dump on the market to raise $600 million, but the more wool is dumped, the flatter the price will go. I estimate that the price would be pushed down—Senator Panizza might have an idea—to around the 350c mark, and that is totally unsustainable.

TALK.START.PARA: —You may as well give it away.

—Senator Woodley is right. We may as well give it away, because it would then be well under the cost of production. Either way, if we raise more taxes or dump the wool, the grazier loses money selling the wool under the present system.

PARA.TAB: If we maintain the rate of sale that we have at the moment, the holding costs—the interest, repayments, handling and storage costs—will rise to between $700 million and $750 million in the next four years. So every year we would have to find about $600 million. That is just not sustainable.
The government, under legislation, can tax the industry 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't want that.

—As Senator O'Chee quite correctly said—it was wisdom beyond his youth—we do not want that and we certainly could not sustain it. I said a few moments ago that the industry cannot pay anything more. The costs would escalate. So we just cannot stay on the present course.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Wool Realisation Commission has played a cautious game over the last 12 months, releasing only a limited amount of wool to hold the market price at a reasonable level. But even that has not worked, with the indicator going down to a record low of 381c. The AWRC has some formula whereby it releases wool onto the market when a certain moving average is reached. The effect of that is that as soon as the price rises, wool gets released and the price is pushed back again, so there is no increase in price. As soon as the market rises, wool is released from the stockpile and the back the price goes.

The new body, Wool International, which is to be established as soon as this legislation is passed, will manage the stockpile and debt repayment. It will place on the market 55,000 bales a month, commencing in July 1994, until June 1997 or when the debt is less than the value of the stockpile. At that time, Wool International will become a privatised company owned by the producers. There is great fear in the industry as to whether a commissioned company, such as the Wool International, will be able to do the things that Professor Garnaut wants it to do. There is doubt; still, there is hope and expectation that it will achieve what Professor Garnaut wants it to achieve.

Commentators such as Malcolm Fraser, whose opinion I greatly respect, believe it is impossible to pre-determine what amount of wool should be placed on the market. I know that is a matter which concerns a number of my colleagues, including Senator Brownhill; Senator Sandy Macdonald, who is a wool producer; Senator Winston Crane; and, Senator John Panizza. I think they have all expressed concern in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think Senator Panizza did.

—Senator Panizza may not have, but he has privately expressed concern to me. The big advantage of the implementation of the Garnaut report and this legislation will be that the debt schedule of $600 million—
—He is coming over to square off.

—Maybe he wants me to withdraw what I said. The big advantage will be that the wool industry will not have to pay the $600 million. That is the sweetener that the industry wants. It does not want to have to meet this debt of $600 million.

PARA.TAB: Wool International will be set up as a futures market, and that is of great concern to the graziers. A futures market was set up before the floor price was implemented in the late 1960s and the early 1970s. I understand from talking to the people who used that futures market that most of them got their fingers badly burnt. It was a disaster. So there is a fear in the industry that a futures market may not achieve what Professor Garnaut would really want.

This is the second attempt to set up a wool marketing scheme since the collapse of the floor price two years ago. That really sent shock waves right through the industry and they are still being felt today. At that time, Mr Kerin—and I believe this was the rock on which he perished—promised that the floor was rock solid, immutable, set in cement, and then he walked away from the industry. As I said, Mr Kerin never recovered from that position.

The consequence of that action was that the government wiped out $1.8 billion of growers' funds, then borrowed another $2.9 billion dollars, and ended up with a stockpile of 4.5 million bales. The government at that time made a huge mistake and the graziers are still paying for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who advised the government?

—I can assure Senator Murphy that it certainly was not the graziers. The graziers said, `Hold that floor at any price'. It was not only the graziers, it was everyone in the industry, from the spinners to the producers. All the overseas people said, `Hold the price. Hold the floor'. What happened? The government walked away and then crashed the industry. That is history, and looking back does not take us very far.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the issue of promotion, which was raised by Senator Crane. This industry indirectly and directly employs around 600,000 people. Last year the government gave $25 million for promotion; this year it was $20 million; and next year it will be nothing. That is a very short-sighted and uncaring attitude for the government to take when this industry has provided so much for Australia and can again provide so much. To drop promotional funding away to nothing when the industry cannot afford to raise a promotion levy is to walk away from one of the greatest industries this country has ever had.

The total revenue raised by levy for world promotion was $70 million. My colleague Mr Anderson in the other place pointed out that Coca-Cola spends $60 million in promoting its product in Australia, whereas the wool industry has only $70 million to promote its product right across the world. Mr Crean has promised Senator Sherry funding for a three-year package. I expect Senator Sherry to hold him to that promise, because I will be holding Senator Sherry to the promise that holds him to the promise. I had a call today from the wool industry asking me whether we could get this legislation through tonight. We have only 10 minutes each in which to speak, and I believe I am the last speaker.

The industry indicator went up by 17c yesterday, reaching 485c today. The wool price is on the up and up. If we can get it up by another 50c, it will be getting somewhere near to the cost of production. This package has given the wool industry a lift; it has given it a bit of confidence. I had been critical in this place of Professor Garnaut. I have some misgivings about certain elements of this legislation but I hope, for the wool industry's sake, that he is right and that this industry—this great Australian industry that has given us so much prosperity—returns to a healthy position. I wish it all the best. I hope that we have another speaker on this legislation and that it will all be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In essence, this package of bills we are debating tonight represents a fundamental restructure of the wool industry in two particular ways. Firstly, the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill deals with the functions, powers, membership and related matters of the newly established Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, which really replaces, as other speakers have said, the four statutory wool industry organisations that currently have responsibility for marketing, promotion, research, development and industry policy. I place no greater significance on this than to say that it is just a good administrative move, and that, quite frankly, is all it is.

PARA.TAB: What is of profound significance is the second bill, the Wool International Bill 1993. As has been widely publicised, this bill replaces the Wool Realisation Commission that manages the wool stockpile and the debt. The explanatory notes to this bill tell us that Wool International will market the stockpile and foster the development of risk management and marketing mechanisms.

Wool International has been initially structured as a statutory authority, but along commercial lines to reflect its ultimate transformation to a privatised public company. That process will be triggered at a time when Wool International has a strong, positive net worth, a manageable debt profile and a sound capital base. The target date for privatisation is mid-1997.

Behind this legislation is an industry in crisis, in very grave danger of never coming out of that crisis until this legislation before the parliament and the recommendations of the Garnaut report work—a simple word, but it is most necessary that it work. There is nothing tangible in the Garnaut report and in this legislation to assure the industry—in particular, the farmers—that there will be an immediate solution to the crisis, particularly as the Garnaut report does not take effect until July 1994.

There is diverse opinion over the disposal of this massive stockpile of 3.9 million bales. The Garnaut solution, under the management of the new body, Wool International, is to release the bales according to a fixed disposal schedule. Garnaut argues convincingly that the rigid schedule will stop the speculation over amounts to be released from the stockpile, which has been affecting the price on the auction floor and, further, that the fixed schedule will assure a certain reduction in the stockpile over time. These are very vital market signals. It is believed that this course will smooth out the boom and bust cycle that has plagued the industry over the past years. It does so at a rate of 27,000 to 29,000 bales a month from July through to December next year and a release from January 1995 of some 132 million kilograms.

The Garnaut committee believes that it will not be difficult to sell this amount of wool as last year sales amounted to 820 million kilograms. With this demand and production predicted to be only 690 million kilograms in the next year or two, it will leave about a 130 million-kilogram gap to be filled by the release of the stockpile. The movement away from the Wool Realisation Committee and its flexible release of the stockpile was due to the fact this system allowed for wool to be dumped on to a rising market, depressing wool prices simply to meet an arbitrary debt repayment scheme. This gave all the wrong signals to the buyer and seller.

The Garnaut report is not without its critics. Its critics say that this method of selling the stockpile is also giving all the wrong signals to the market. They believe that the stockpile should be sold as it is now when the demand makes it a reasonable thing to do. I tend to agree with the critics when they say that this is treating the stockpile more as an asset than does the fixed schedule. The critics go on to say that the best policy would be to establish a base price under which wool would not be sold from the stockpile. It would provide more certainty to the industry than the present decision and would enable the stockpile to be managed as an asset.

It is my opinion that the Garnaut solution to the massive wool stockpile will work provided one important variable holds up—that is, the current demand of 820 million kilograms per year. While prices are low due to the stockpile, this is a very significant demand. There are probably only one or two

SPEECH.PARA: patches in the history of wool sales that have matched this volume of exports that we are currently experiencing. Should this variable fail, Garnaut fails, and we will be back in this parliament rewriting the legislation again. The point is that we cannot afford such an error. We cannot afford to be wrong again. Australia's greatest industry is at stake. It is definitely now dying. We have no second chance any more. Farmers' net profits are as follows: in 1991-92 they were minus $40,810; in 1992-93 they were minus $34,400; and it is forecast for 1993-94 that it will be minus $39,000. Even those farmers with a mixture of sheep and beef are forecast to lose at much as $27,500 and those with a mixture of sheep and cereal are forecast to lose $9,000.

PARA.TAB: Confidence in the rural sector does not match the confidence being displayed in the business sector. A recent farm survey undertaken by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy stated that 35 per cent of farmers interviewed believed that they would be forced to leave the industry or they had serious doubts about their ability to survive. We should keep in mind this 35 per cent possible exodus because this is over and above those already forced or evicted from the land. It is a misconception to believe that the farmers enjoyed the 1980s boom period that those entrepreneurs, marketeers and agents and the mining sector enjoyed. Those prices never reached the farm gate because they were faced with high interest rates, agent fees and all sorts of overheads and costs. Those boom years never reached the farmer and his family. Today's prices are the lowest since the Great Depression. Australia has travelled three generations to reach a point where the Australian wool farmer is worse off than in the Great Depression.
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a chart which gives evidence about the prices from 1930 to 1992, discounted to today's prices.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: [CHART OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 2816]

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. For the 53,000 farmers involved in wool production in this country, living very poorly and under the constant financial pressure which these conditions inevitably bring, a great deal hinges upon their public representatives tonight to get this legislation right and to help them in so many other ways. I am not just talking about the 53,000 farmers but the 53,000 families and the hundreds of thousands of people employed in the small towns to service those farmers.

PARA.TAB: It is this government that has had the most serious destabilising effect upon this industry and it has contributed to the depression within the wool industry. We have used the word `recession' quite frequently to sum up the whole economy but within this micro-economy it is a depression. That chart I tabled will prove that. This is the fifth restructure of the industry that has been undertaken by this government. It is an industry in which Australia dominates. We have some 80 per cent of the apparel wool market. What South Africa is to diamonds, Australia is to wool. We have just wrecked that industry. Yet we have seen the greatest price collapse of this industry since the Great Depression.

History may show that the legacy of the Labor Party in government was the highest unemployment rate and the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. In fact, we have had the worst Prime Minister since Billy Hughes in the 1930s. But the blackest spot in the history of this government and its worst legacy will be the dismantling of the Australian wool industry. This is the industry on which Australia, quite frankly, built its character. It has a worldwide reputation. It produces billions of dollars of export income. It has created an infrastructure for rural communities and towns, it has formed the foundation of postwar increases in the standard of living and it has even stimulated art, poetry and legendary characters. Yet it is being driven out of existence. It has consistently ranked as the first or second of our top exports; it has now been driven down to sixth and is still falling.

My colleagues have mentioned the government's lack of funding for promotion. I find this extremely unusual. It is fair to say that the government has completely and utterly walked away from this industry. Yet the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Alan Griffiths, has announced a review of government industry policy in which he claims he seeks `an activist policy' which is light-handed. He means that certain industries will be selected and sought out for concessions and support that will stimulate them. It seems to me that the wool industry, our finest industry, will be left out of this new found policy of the government.

As Senator Boswell said, this incompetence goes back to 1990 when John Kerin was minister for primary industry and oversaw the destruction of the wool floor price, bringing the greatest instability to this industry, the effects of which we are still experiencing today. John Kerin may have failed as Treasurer of this country but his biggest failure was as primary industry minister, if only because he had more time to wreak havoc. The floor price scheme that had worked so well in this country for decades deserved far greater support than was given by this government. Before he leaves parliament, John Kerin has to face the truth that he played a great part in wrecking this fine industry.

There is probably little more faith in the competence of Mr Simon Crean, the current Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. But I will say that we all join him in crossing our fingers today as this legislation goes through the parliament in the hope against hope that we have the remedy to restore the livelihoods of those involved in this great industry and, in particular, the farmers of this industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank members of the government and particularly members of the opposition for their generally positive responses in this debate. I have to say that the first line of the last contribution was a pledge of support for this legislation but the arguments in support of that pledge of support rapidly fell away as the contribution from Senator McGauran progressed. I am going to deal with a couple of the points he made shortly.

PARA.TAB: I also want to acknowledge the contribution made by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs in its examination of this legislation. I will be drawing on a couple of the comments in its report a little later in my concluding remarks.

As the Parliamentary Secretary handling this matter, I have to acknowledge the very wide support for the government's approach in dealing with this legislation which arises from the recommendations presented to the government in the Garnaut report. I will stress one issue that is very important. The government realised that it had to move quickly to implement the recommendations of Professor Garnaut, and that is why the legislation is before the Senate this evening. Generally, the market reaction to the government's initiatives and legislation has been positive.

Some honourable senators from the National Party might find these figures quite interesting. Since the government announced its support for the package on 8 September, the wool price has improved. Prior to 8 September the wool price had been on a progressive decline. In the week ending 29 July this year the wool price was 449c a kilogram clean. It then went down to 438c, 432c, 430c, 413c and then 412c per kilogram clean. Then, bingo, on 8 September the government announced that it would implement the Garnaut package and from then we have seen a progressive increase in the price of wool. In the week ending 10 September the price for wool was 423c per kilogram clean. The following week it was 430c, 433c, 434c, 444c, 451c and then 461c per kilogram clean. I understand that as of 7 o'clock this evening the price had reached 492c per kilogram clean. That is a very significant increase.

It would not be fair to directly attribute the whole of that price rise to the government's announcement, but it certainly had some impact because it provided a positive undertaking to the market about the direction the government intended to take. That has had an effect on the price of wool. The price rise in wool over the last three months has been approximately 20 per cent. I acknowledge the positive impact that the wool industry and the opposition, to its credit, have played in adopting a generally bipartisan approach to the package when it was announced on 8 September.

The Garnaut report is all about getting the market signals right and removing government intervention from that market. That is really the basic philosophical principle underpinning the legislation that we are considering this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ran away in `90.

—I will traverse back to 1990 briefly later. This legislation provides a clear market signal which will impact—and it is already having an impact—on all aspects of the wool industry right through to farmland, environmental management and integrated land care issues that were raised earlier today by Senator Margetts. I will make a few comments about her contribution later.

PARA.TAB: I indicate that the government will not be accepting the two amendments moved by Senator Woodley. I apologise to Senator Woodley that I was not here during his contribution early on in the debate. However, I have sat through most of the debate over the last couple of hours. I was regrettably detained listening to some particular problems that the apple and pear industries have and could not be here for Senator Woodley's contribution.

Basically the approach Senator Woodley is advocating in his amendments is that he wants a more interventionist approach to be taken to the wool market. That is the philosophy underlying his approach. He is seeking to have this legislation send signals to growers to secure production, but at the same time he is proposing a price band approach to the fixed schedule which will mask the signals that the market should be giving to the growers in any free market that is responding to legitimate supply and demand pressures.

The first amendment that he is proposing is a price band. The government and opposition are supporting a very specific fixed schedule. That amendment has the effect of a fixed disposal schedule operating within a band of 400c to 800c per kilogram. That would be used to smooth out the so-called price extremes in the sale of the stockpile.

This price band approach would run directly counter to the basic intention of this legislation and to the policy recommendations of Professor Garnaut. It does that in two ways. Firstly, the introduction of price bands would be a direct contradiction to the Garnaut report's intention to stimulate, as far as possible, real market conditions. That is quite critical.

The price band would retain the scope for a government agency to exercise a market smoothing policy. I commend Senator Panizza for strongly supporting this fixed schedule rather than supporting some variant in the pricing band as is being proposed by the Australian Democrats. In a strong market a ceiling approach could dampen potential market demand for forward purchases and create speculation as the ceiling is approached. We believe that is highly undesirable.

The second reason for opposing the first amendment is that the market culture and the change to wool ownership transfer and risk management would be significantly impeded by a price banding policy because it implies a floor price and a price ceiling mentality. When the stockpile has been eliminated the industry will have to live with market supply and demand shifts without price smoothing policies.

The price bands proposed by the Democrats have the potential to master market signals to buyers and sellers. The key point in opposing the proposal by the Australian Democrats is that the fixed schedule proposed by the Garnaut committee is central to the development of a market and a risk management mechanism which may otherwise be hindered by a price band approach. That is a quite critical issue.
This matter was canvassed by the Senate committee. On page 14 of the report, Professor Garnaut said:

SPEECH.PARA: I know there is a view that it is a bit of a waste to have a strong demand for wool reflected in a higher price for a while. I do not think it is, because I think that the balance sheets of our farming community are so weak that cash in there is cash in a good place.

What Professor Garnaut was pointing out was that we have a fixed schedule and as supply decreases demand should increase—and that is already happening—but if we have a price banding mechanism then presumably there would be more wool released from the stockpile and that would deflate the price that the market is paying for that wool. That would take away from growers some of that price—it may not be the price that they would like—improvement resulting from an increasing demand for wool. We strongly oppose the first amendment moved by the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment proposes to cover Wool International's so-called trading losses. None of the wool tax for debt management will be used for risky wool international commercial activities, as was alleged by Senator Woodley in his speech today. The debt management will simply not be used for that purpose. There is certainly some flexibility within the legislation for some overselling and underselling of the schedule, but it is very minor. Only particular contracts that may require that will be taken into account. It certainly is not going to occur in any significant way. That will be very closely scrutinised by the industry, by the minister and certainly by Wool International.

The government has made specific arrangements for funding commercial activities by agreeing to allow the revenue stream from non-wool assets managed by Wool International to be used to develop new risk management tools such as futures. So there is provision for those non-wool assets. I would assume that the non-wool assets would include primarily property, warehouses and the like that Wool International may choose to sell. In any case, the risk management mechanisms are designed to reduce risk—not increase risk. I think that is quite a critical factor in the farm business. So it is not inherently risky, as has been suggested by Senator Woodley.

The wool debt is clearly regarded by the Commonwealth as an industry debt for which the industry is ultimately responsible. At the time of privatisation, the government has confirmed its commitment, through its legislation, to issue shares in Wool International to wool taxpayers. I think that is a commendable approach.

The government already covers by guarantee the entire debt associated with the wool stockpile, which currently amounts to $2.2 billion. So it is not appropriate to provide an additional guarantee over and above the existing guarantee, as is proposed in the amendment moved by Senator Woodley. Once privatised, Wool International will operate as a full commercial company under the corporations law. The sooner the body accommodates activities in the commercial environment, the stronger it will be at the time of privatisation.

When I commenced my speech, I referred to some comments by Senator McGauran. I want to say very briefly that there can be no absolute guarantee for the future of the wool industry. But this legislation provides much greater certainty for the markets in their assessment of the future supply of wool and, therefore, the likely demand and price for wool producers. Senator McGauran tabled a document which says that today's wool price is at a record low and is equivalent to prices during the depression. That is simply not correct. This was certainly true up until six months ago and it was certainly true in the last two years. But the price in the last three months is not far from the average price that was being received from 1975 through until 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh yes, but—
—I am not saying that that price was necessarily a great price, but certainly Senator McGauran's assertion is incorrect on that point.

PARA.TAB: I also want to rebut Senator McGauran's criticism that Mr Kerin, a member of the other place and the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, presided over the dismantling of the Australian wool industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did.
