—Let us be fair to Mr Kerin, Senator Boswell. There were not too many people criticising Mr Kerin up until 2 1/2 years ago. I certainly did not hear too many critics in this place. There were not too many critics out there in the wool industry.

PARA.TAB: I do not think anyone could have foreseen the collapse in demand, which was brought about—this was not the only factor, but it was certainly an important factor—by the collapse of the communist regime in the Soviet Union. One of the ironies of the position we are in today is that the collapse of the former centralist and planned economy of the Soviet Union has led to the end of centralised buying of wool in that country, and I think it will be a long time before it recovers. So in making a criticism of Mr Kerin, let us at least be a little balanced in acknowledging that there were other factors. From my conversations with Mr Kerin, I think he does acknowledge that he made some errors during that period.

I would like to thank various members of the opposition. I have already thanked Senator Panizza for his contribution. He picked up a very vital point that was made in the Senate report. I think the point was made by none other than one of the critics of these proposals, Dr Lionel Ward, who speculated that we could have a shortage of wool. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: You could have a situation in which prices, internationally, for Australian wool, not only rise to the level desired and sought by Australian woolgrowers, but rise to a level which makes wool uncompetitive and causes a substitution out of wool before we have had any decent recovery.

I found that a rather fascinating criticism of these proposals. Senator Panizza quite rightly picked up that point. The honourable senator made the very vital point that if we cannot supply the market we will be in a good position because the price will be very much higher. I see Senator Panizza nodding; he is spot on. I do not think that can be a legitimate criticism of this legislation, as was outlined by Dr Ward before the committee.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza drew attention to the costs involved in the production of wool. I again pay him credit for pointing out that, whilst he was concerned about shearing costs, he did not necessarily see that that could be addressed by reducing the pay rates of shearers, whom he acknowledged are amongst the hardest workers in our Australian community. I certainly endorse those comments.

Senator Sandy Macdonald referred to the work of the opposition in looking at the legislation. As I have said, I commend and thank the opposition for its support. I think Senator Macdonald made some grossly unfair criticism of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean. I thought it was very unfair to condemn him for being absent without leave. I have been with Minister Crean on a number of occasions over the past couple of months when he has held consultations with the wool industry. Within the confines of the minister's very busy schedule—the minister deals with energy issues and other primary industry, resource and forestry matters; it is a very heavy set of commitments—the government consulted as widely as it could, having regard to the necessary time frame which required a reasonably quick response.

The government's consultative process commenced within half an hour of the public release of the Garnaut committee's report, and it continued. The process took place over a 2 1/2 month period and involved the minister, members of the minister's office and officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Meetings were held with representatives of all the wool industry sectors, including producers, traders, processors and manufacturers. Meeting were held with both domestic and overseas representatives of the processing and manufacturing sectors. The Wool Council of Australia also carried out its own consultative process. So I cannot accept Senator Macdonald's criticism of my minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have one minute to go.

—Thank you, Senator. I want to make a couple of brief points. Senator Margetts drew attention to a whole range of environmentally sustainable economic development issues. They are legitimate issues. But, frankly, if we had to deal with the sorts of issues that Senator Margetts wanted Professor Garnaut and us to consider, I suspect that we would be writing this report for the next 10 years.

PARA.TAB: Finally, on the issue of wool promotion, $277 million has been provided over the last 10 years. As Senator Boswell pointed out, there will be a package presented by the minister. He has been exhaustive in his work overseas in this area. This is an integrated package. It represents a significant watershed for the industry. It creates opportunities; it creates a strength for the future of the wool industry. I commend it to the Senate. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: WOOL INTERNATIONAL BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 20, page 11, subsection (1), line 28, omit "Wool International's", substitute "Subject to section 21A, Wool International's".
2.Clause 21, page 12, subsection (1), line 18, omit "If", substitute "Subject to section 21A, if".
3.After clause 21, insert the following clause:
"21A. (1) In addition to the disposal schedule provisions in sections 20 and 21, beginning on 1 July 1994 Wool International is to dispose of stockpile wool in accordance with this section.

"(2) For any period during which the Market Indicator equals or exceeds 800 cents, Wool International is to dispose of stockpile wool without regard to the disposal schedule provisions in sections 20 and 21.
"(3)For any period during which the Market Indicator falls below 400 cents Wool International is to suspend disposal of stockpile wool.
"(4) In this section "Market Indicator" means the Wool Market Indicator as generally understood on Australian financial markets.".
4.After clause 56, page 26, add the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Payments to off-set losses by Wool International

SPEECH.PARA: "56A(1) An annual payment is to be made to Wool International equivalent to the value of any loss set out in each set of annual accounts and records under section 50 that is attributable to trading by Wool International under section 20, 21, 21A or 54.".
(2) Payments under subsection (1) are to be made out of money appropriated by the Parliament for that purpose.".
5.Clause 69, page 30, after paragraph (3), insert the following paragraph:
"(3A) Section 56A ceases to have effect at the commencement of Part 12.".

I have listened to almost all of the contributions today because this is a very important issue that we are dealing with and one that is very close to my concerns, and I have been a little confused by my National Party and Liberal Party colleagues because I sensed that at times they were saying different things. If I heard some of the National Party senators' contributions correctly, they really were speaking in support of the amendments which I have just moved, but I suspect that come voting time they probably will not vote for the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Wool Council want your amendments?

—No, I was not referring to the Wool Council. I was really wanting an indication from opposition senators. I would hope that in this place Senator Boswell and his colleagues would make up their own minds, according to the speeches they made night.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) was saying, I believe that my amendments not only take account of the Garnaut report but also give to Garnaut a further modification or way of improving his proposal for a fixed release schedule. We are not wanting to do away with a fixed release schedule, but we want to make a moderate amendment to that schedule so that there would be price indicators to the market. These indicators would establish an acceptable range within which the market ought to operate. I accept what Dr Ward said in his submission that, if the market overheats to too large a degree, there will be a transfer of buyers, processors and consumers away from wool to other fibres.

Our proposal to have a market indicator of 800c provides a means of dampening down an overheated market and enables it to continue within a range that is both acceptable to growers and to the market itself. The bottom price, a market indicator of 400c, sends the right signal to everybody that Australia is not prepared to treat this asset as a commodity to be sold in some kind of fire sale.

The second amendment clarifies the role of government until Wool International becomes privatised. Obviously after that, it will operate fully as a grower owned and controlled instrumentality. But until that time, it is the responsibility of government to assure woolgrowers that any losses incurred by Wool International while it is still a government instrumentality will be covered by government. Those are the reasons why I press these amendments. I trust that the chamber will support them and see the sensible modification that they make to Professor Garnaut's proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the issues that have been raised today specifically by the Australian Democrats in the form of these amendments, it is necessary to take the committee back over some of the discussion that has happened throughout the day, the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs last Friday and what has been argued throughout the industry over the last few months. The Australian Democrats, through Senator Woodley, have chosen to present—both in his speech on the second reading and in his comments to the committee—what I think the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) described as an interventionist stance.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley is reflecting sectional interests and responding to the arguments of a minority view on this particular issue. To a certain extent I think the proposals he put forward attempt to second-guess the Garnaut report in some respects. It was interesting to note that, in this very comprehensive and wide ranging debate which has engaged the Senate for most of today, there were 15 speakers other than the minister in reply.

It was very interesting to note and appreciate the views that Senator Woodley put forward on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I respect those views, the stance that he took today and his participation in last Friday's special committee meeting. Of course, senator Woodley was very honest in that he handed down a dissenting view to the committee's report and, therefore, we did know his stance.

Senator Margetts made reference to the stance taken and a number of issues raised by the Greens. There were 11 speakers from the coalition parties. It is significant, in view of the importance of this issue, that those speakers should range over a number of issues and reflect the diversity of views across the electorate and the industry. We have been able to come to a decision which I do not think Senator Woodley will like because we are not going to support his amendments.

The other comment I would make is to express my disappointment that, in this comprehensive and far-reaching debate today, Senator Sue West was the only Labor senator other than the parliamentary secretary to speak on these bills. It concerns me that the Australian Labor Party has not participated more in this debate to express its various views and opinions. I appreciate that Senator West did take an interest in last Friday's committee. She was a bit hasty at the end of the day when she attempted to pre-empt the committee while we were trying to reach a conclusion. Nevertheless, Senator West did participate and she came in here today and reiterated those views. But not one other member of the Australian Labor Party was prepared to come in here and speak in representation of this important industry.

I will turn to the points that have been raised by Senator Woodley in his amendments. The whole concept of the Garnaut plan is to operate the industry as if there were, in fact, no stockpile. As long as people think they can buy from the stockpile if they run short or, in this case, if the price goes to 800c, the incentive to buy forward is reduced. People will only buy forward if they think the price may go up or that there will be a shortage. If we set the price between 400c and 800c and ensure there will be never be a shortage, what incentive is there for forward buying?

This amendment would undo the very fabric of the plan. It would ensure that the stockpile still hung over the market and would doom growers to continuing low prices. We know that Wool International will try to sell its fixed amount ahead of time. This will ensure that there is a shortage of wool in the auction system and this will cause the price to rise.

Professor Garnaut told the Senate committee last week that no-one was really thinking that the price of wool next year would be the price that it was in 1987. He said that anyone who thought that this was a substantial possibility would be buying and stocking wool in order to make a fortune and that would be lifting the current price right now. Professor Garnaut said there was a bit of that going on, which is one of the reasons the market is currently strengthening. But if it was a dominant view, the market would be behaving differently from the way that it actually is.

We also need to think about the future. We need growers to know the true market value of wool long before the stockpile is gone so that they can gear production up or down. It would be silly to put selling the stockpile above keeping woolgrowers on their farms. If we keep the prices depressed, growers will go out of farming and then, when the stockpile is sold, there will be a critical shortage of wool and the price will go high and we will not have any more wool to dampen the price. Therefore, it seems sensible that we have the price rise now, rather than some years down the track.

With regard to the second issue raised by Senator Woodley, that of the government guarantee, the government is already guaranteeing the money owed on the stockpile and should not be forced to also guarantee private negotiations. The Australian Democrat amendment would give an unfair advantage over private companies. For those reasons the coalition will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the Senate very long. I must clear up any misapprehension that I may have caused when I queried the fixed schedule reduction scheme. I stated quite clearly in my speech on the second reading that I believe that whatever we sell on the fixed reduction scheme, we stick to it. Who is to say whether Professor Garnaut and the government, in formulating this legislation, have hit on exactly the right sort of schedule? But I am prepared to accept the schedule that is contained in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The reduction scheme should remain fixed because, as I said this morning, if we leave a back door open, something will happen. If the door is there, if an escape route is there, someone will find an excuse to use it. We have had five schemes in the past where that escape door has been left open and something has happened. Let us not do it again.

I would like to look briefly at the situation that Senator Woodley told us about. He is more or less advocating that the higher the price the more we can let on to the market, and the lower the price the less we can let on to the market. I am afraid that that is not going to work, for reasons that Senator Tambling and others have already canvassed.

I have been quickly trying to show in equation form how the scheme would work. I used a comparison with the pressure-volume equation in hydraulics where the higher the pressure through the aperture the greater the volume delivered, and as the pressure comes down the volume delivered is less. Senator Woodley left world demand out of the equation. That will interfere with it.

The other element of that equation is temperature. I relate temperature to world demand. If we do not take into account all those other considerations, including world demand, it will not work. It is a good attempt to please everyone—the buyers, the sellers and the brokers in the middle—but it will not work. Let us back the Garnaut system and have a fixed schedule and stick to it. Otherwise, as Senator West said, we will be back here next year debating some more.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond quickly to two issues. I think Senator Tambling made some unfair criticism of government speakers on this side, Senator West and me.
—One speaker!

—Senator West as well. She always makes an effective contribution. Firstly, in terms of the record of this debate, I should point out that there are always pressures on time in this place. This is the last night of sitting for this fortnightly period. The government members are always conscious of that. I commend opposition members for being conscious of that too in shortening their contributions.

PARA.TAB: Minister Crean is going overseas tomorrow and part of the very important work he will be doing overseas—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fixing up the barley problem, is he?

—I do not know about barley, but wool is high on his agenda. I know that he would like this legislation to be passed because it would give a very effective signal to the international markets that Senator Panizza quite rightly referred to. Secondly, this is government policy. It speaks for itself. It is our policy that we are implementing, and I commend those opposite for congratulating it. Frankly, we do not need to talk about it all night. It is our government policy. It is standing there clear and as a result of the Garnaut report.

PARA.TAB: I thank Senator Panizza and Senator Tambling for their support, particularly Senator Panizza who I commended in the second reading debate. He is spot on. If we are to have a moving band of sale of the wool stockpile, when the price goes up presumably we will sell more from the stockpile and the price will drop. We do not want that to happen at the moment because whatever gains we can make in price increase should go to the grower, and that is what the growers require at this point.

The other thing is, of course, that people out in the market would speculate. They would see that the wool stockpile could be released outside a fixed schedule and they would then wait till the price reached a certain level and speculate against the wool stockpile. The basic intention of this legislation is to let the market signals dictate the price, particularly the international market, not to let legislative signals dictate the market. That is the wrong approach. We have tried that once already with fairly calamitous results.

The second matter that Senator Woodley referred to is the notion of a further underwriting of industry debt. As I and others have said, the Commonwealth is already underwriting the entire industry debt to $2.2 billion. We do not intend to further underwrite that debt with yet a further commitment from government. On behalf of the government I oppose the two amendments. I commend the package and I thank other senators for their contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong the debate, but I just want to say something about Senator Sherry's comment. The point I am trying to make is that the control of how much wool is released still remains with Wool International. If someone is trying to speculate in the market, it is within Wool International's control whether or not it releases wool beyond the fixed schedule amount, so it has control of the price beyond the 800c. I do not think people would be able to speculate because Wool International still has control of the amount of wool beyond the fixed schedule which comes on to the market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —As chairman of the committee that reviewed the legislation, I want to make a comment. The legislation came about as a result of discussions with the growers' representatives. It was not just something that the government put down as what it thought to be the best proposition. It was made clear by those same people that it was important that people knew what was happening and how much wool would be sold out of the stockpile. They wanted that. The previous system had not worked and to their knowledge this was the best system that could be organised collectively, and that is reflected in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Why would people from the Labor Party come in here and waste the time of the Senate when they knew the legislation had been supported in the House of Representatives by both sides of the chamber and was going to be supported here? I certainly do not believe that the propositions put by Senator Woodley are really in the interests of woolgrowers. Therefore, I oppose the amendments and support the legislation.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Woodley's) be agreed to.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL CORPORATIONS (TRANSFER OF ASSETS AND LIABILITIES) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Bill 1993 derives from the Treasurer's Banking Policy Statement of 18 June 1993, and relates to the Government's decision to liberalise foreign bank entry, announced by the Prime Minister in the One Nation Statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The Banking Act 1959 has already been amended by the Banking Legislation Amendment Act 1992, which received the Royal Assent on 21 December 1992, to give effect to the Government's decision in One Nation to liberalise foreign bank entry. Those amendments enable foreign banks, whether they have been operating in Australia or not, to apply for a banking authority under section 9 of the Banking Act 1959; and permit foreign banks, which are authorised under the Banking Act, to operate as banks in the form of a branch.

The purpose of the current bill is to facilitate the transfer of certain assets and liabilities from foreign bank subsidiaries in Australia to new branches. These subsidiaries will have been in existence prior to 18 June 1993 and may be either authorised banks under section 9 of the Banking Act 1959, or money market corporations registered under the Financial Corporations Act 1974 (or any subsidiaries of those bodies which are registered under the Financial Corporations Act 1974). In a limited number of cases the transfer may be between a pre-existing subsidiary and a new authorised bank subsidiary.

To be eligible to transfer assets and liabilities under the proposed legislation, foreign banks will have, from the commencement of the legislation, three years within which to apply for a banking authority, and up to six years to effect the transfer. The proposed legislation will minimise administrative procedures, and waive the payment of both Commonwealth and State transfer fees and charges. Without these changes foreign banks would be inhibited from responding to the Government's policy decision to encourage increased effective competition and efficiency in the Australian financial sector.

The Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Bill 1993 will facilitate the establishment of branch operations in Australia by ensuring that foreign banks currently operating an authorised bank subsidiary or money market corporation are not disadvantaged compared to new foreign bank entrants when establishing branch banking operations in Australia.

The bill also makes a number of changes to the income tax law to ensure that the tax consequences that would normally arise on the transfer of business from foreign bank subsidiaries to branches are deferred, and that double taxation and double deductions do not arise.

To do this, the bill places the branch in the same position as the subsidiary would have been had its assets and liabilities not been transferred. This treatment will extend to all assets and liabilities transferred under this legislation, including debts owing to the subsidiary that are transferred to the branch and are subsequently written off as bad. Also, any interest paid on borrowings transferred to the branch, which would have been exempt from interest withholding tax under section 128F of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 if paid by the subsidiary, will be exempt under the same provision.

To further assist the smooth transition from subsidiary to branch banking, the subsidiaries of foreign banks will be able to transfer existing tax losses to branches of the banks. In this way, the ability to claim deductions for past tax losses will not be disturbed by the transition to branch banking.

The Government believes that these changes will bring competitive gains and efficiencies to the banking sector; greater flexibility in the provision of finance; and cost advantages to Australian clients. The measures contained in the bill should also further improve the international competitiveness of the Australian financial system.
Mr President, I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanation of the provisions of the bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The purpose of this bill is to implement the EC/Australia Wine Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: On 6 December 1992, I jointly announced with our wine industry that Australian and European Commission officials had negotiated the text of a bilateral wine agreement aimed at improving our bilateral wine trade. This announcement attracted wide media attention, rightly so, as the European Community is Australia's largest export market for wine. During 1992/93, Australian winemakers exported 44m litres worth $144m to the EC, or almost half of our total exports of $293m. This Agreement will guarantee our continued access to the EC market which will remain the key market as our wine industry strives to lift exports to $1 billion by the year 2000.
This legislation enables the Agreement to enter into force and our winemakers to enjoy its benefits.

The Agreement provides for the mutual recognition of each Party's winemaking practices and standards; it affords mutual protection to each Party's geographical indications, that is, the names of our wine regions such as Coonawarra and Hunter Valley; it reduces the number of analyses the EC requires of Australian wines from 8 to 3; it allows Australian winemakers to market wines in the EC labelled with multi-varietal and multi-regional blends; and it allows the export of Australian sweet wines such as the justly famous De Bortoli "Noble One" to the European Community—previously not permitted. Importantly, it prevents either party from introducing additional certification requirements on imports of each other's wines.

The Agreement recognises the importance of European geographical indications to the European Community. It also recognises the widespread use of EC names on Australian wines. The Agreement provides for the gradual phase-out of our use of EC geographical indications according to their commercial importance.

There are four tranches of EC names to be protected. A list of thousands of EC geographical names which are of no commercial significance to us will be protected immediately the Agreement enters into force. The second tranche is of little used names such as `Frascati' and `White Bordeaux'; these will be phased-out on the 31 December this year. A further group of names of some importance to us such as `Chianti` and `Madeira' must be phased-out by 31 December 1997. The last tranche includes names which are widely used by our winemakers, names like `Claret', `Chablis', `Burgundy' and `Champagne'. Phase-out periods for these names have yet to be determined but the Agreement provides that negotiations on phase-out dates for these names must be concluded by 31 December 1997.

We have used European geographical names to denote a style of wine for more than a hundred years. Migrants often brought these names to Australia and used them to describe a familiar style of wine; the names have become generic. Names like `champagne` have been used to describe a dry sparkling wine. Once protection commences, both European and Australian geographical indications will only be used to indicate the true place of origin of the wine. Thus the name `champagne' will only be used to describe wine made in the `Champagne' region of France.

The Agreement provides for additional phase-out periods to clear stock from wholesalers and retailers. Australian wine made prior to the phase-out period for production labelled with the protected EC names may be marketed by wholesalers for up to three years and by retailers until stocks are exhausted.
Australian winemakers have already begun using varietal and brand names to replace European geographical indications.

The bill also provides for the protection of traditional wine expressions. Words such as "brut" or "reserve" are frequently used to indicate a certain quality or style of wine. Under the bill, traditional expressions may only be used to describe wine which originates in the country in which the expression has been traditionally and consistently used. The lists of both Australian and EC traditional expressions are still under negotiation by the two parties to the Agreement. The bill provides for protection to commence when the traditional expressions are entered in a register. This will occur after negotiations on protection of traditional names are concluded.

The Agreement has the strong support of the peak wine industry body, the Winemakers' Federation of Australia. Wine industry representatives were fully involved in the negotiations on the Agreement from the outset. The Agreement has strong support throughout the European Community.

The bill establishes a Geographical Indications Committee to determine the boundaries of Australian geographical indications. EC regulations require that where wine exported to the EC is labelled with a geographical indication, the boundaries of that region must be defined precisely.

Where does Coonawarra end and Riverland start? This question is just as relevant for Australian wine consumers. By defining the boundaries of our geographical indications, this bill will give greater certainty to enforcement of the Label Integrity Program provisions of the Act, which require winemakers to keep records to substantiate label claims of the vintage, variety or geographical indication of wine. The bill will give consumers the guarantee that when wine is labelled "Coonawarra", the grapes from which the wine was made came from within the defined boundaries of the Coonawarra region.

The Geographical Indications Committee will comprise a Winemakers' Federation of Australia nominee, a nominee of the Wine Grape Growers' Council of Australia and an Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation (AWBC) nominee. The Committee will publish proposed determinations and seek submissions from winemakers and grapegrowers and their organisations on the boundaries of Australian wine regions. There will be appeal rights to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court.

The bill establishes a Registrar of geographical indications and traditional expressions who will be an employee of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The Registrar will list all geographical indications determined by the Committee, list the protected EC names and inform other countries of Australia's protected names.

The Winemakers' Federation of Australia has applied to the National Food Authority to have the Australian Food Standards Code covering wine modernised and brought more closely into line with EC standards. The NFA application, even if accepted in its entirety, will not authorise all EC winemaking practices. There are some EC standards which the Australian wine industry does not want to adopt for wine made in Australia. The bill authorises the import of wine from the EC which conforms with the compositional requirements set down in the Agreement and allows these standards to be varied from time to time by agreement as EC winemaking practises change. The EC practices differ in minor ways and in ways which do not affect health, from the standards set by the National Food Authority for sale of Australian and imported wine. EC wine will still have to comply in all other respects with Australian standards, for example with regard to labelling with alcoholic content.

The EC/Australia Wine Agreement is the first of several agreements on wine we intend to conclude with our major wine trading partners. Work is already underway on developing a wine agreement with New Zealand. The bill therefore amends the objects of the Act to include implementing the EC/Australia Wine Agreement; enabling Australia to implement further international agreements relating to trade in wine; and defining Australian geographical indications for wine. It extends the powers and functions of the AWBC to cover administration of the EC/Australia Wine Agreement and the definition of Australian geographical indications.

The bill creates several new offences. The offences include the false or misleading use of geographical indications and traditional expressions for wine. However, winemakers will continue to be able to use their individual name and the individual name of their predecessor in business, in the course of trade, even where that name is the same as the name of a protected geographical indication.

The bill also amends the Act to allow regulations to be made concerning blending rules for wine and the composition of export wine. These Regulations will not be activated until there has been further consultations with the wine industry, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and the National Food Authority. The bill also allows the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to prescribe the grape varieties which may be used in making wine. This will prevent the use of hybrid grape varieties in export wine, which is a concern in some export markets.
The bill will have no financial impact.

This bill and the Agreement it seeks to implement, presents challenges for our wine industry including the opportunity to consolidate our position in the world market. It represents a landmark commitment by our industry and a true sign that our industry has come of age internationally. It removes technical trade barriers to our wines on EC markets. More importantly, it provides the important basis for continued future access to this market!
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In handling the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 for the opposition, I indicate at the outset that the Liberal and National parties will support its passage.

PARA.TAB: However, what we do not support is a broader issue pertinent to Australia's trade and indirectly to the aims of this bill—that is, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), strutting around the world stage at the Cyprus Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, when he was merely a stone's throw from the Arab world which is a significant export market for Australia that could be further developed. Australia's exports to the Arab nations are currently around the $3 billion mark, and to Israel we export a further $ 1/4 billion worth of goods. But has the Prime Minister, while in that region, bothered to visit any of these, our major customers, in that area? No, he certainly has not. Indeed, there has not been a ministerial visit to the Middle East since the March election. Even Senator Cook, the Minister for Trade, has ignored this very important region. I will say a little more about this matter later in my remarks.

The key amendments proposed in this bill relate to three distinct areas. Firstly, the treatment for the purpose of export market development grant eligibility of expenditure incurred by corporations and individuals under insolvency administration; secondly, the exclusion from grant eligibility of persons with certain convictions; and, thirdly, the lodgement of grant claims on a half-yearly basis.

The bill seeks to tighten up the net through which canny and cunning operators will seek to continue rorting the availability of taxpayer funded grants, and such a move is long overdue. Currently, under the act and under the scheme, those unscrupulous individuals with criminal convictions are able to obtain grants, and this is simply not acceptable.

The bill seeks to ensure that claimants who make export development expenditure while under a scheme of arrangement are eligible for assistance only if the business is certified to be a going concern at the time of that expenditure. This means that the business operations of the claimants must be sound and intact before any further dipping into taxpayer funded grants is permitted, and this, of course, is how the scheme should operate.

The bill also introduces a combination of technical and administrative amendments which seek to protect the scheme's principles and efficiency. It provides for half-yearly grant payments in respect of exporters' early stages of marketing. That will be of great assistance to newly developing exporters.

With particular reference to the bill, sections 11UA and 11UB relate to insolvency. Section 11UA relates to the government's decision in respect of bodies corporate that expenditure incurred while a claimant was under insolvency administration is not claimable unless the claimant is certified to be solvent at the time the expenditure was incurred.

Section 11UB seeks to make expenditure which could otherwise be reimbursed by Austrade incapable of being reimbursed where it is incurred by a person who is under insolvency administration or by a partnership or corporation when a member of the partnership or a director of the corporation is under insolvency administration. Additionally, expenditure by a partnership will not be reimbursed when one of the members of the partnership is a corporation and a director of the corporate partner is under insolvency administration. However, a new owner of a previously insolvent export business—that is, someone who takes over the ownership or management of a business earlier made insolvent—may still make a claim for reimbursement under section 19 of the act.

With respect to criminal convictions, new section 11YA will exclude from eligibility, for up to five years from release of custody, claimants with criminal convictions for breaches of key corporate duties or offences which involve fraud or dishonesty and which carry two years imprisonment.

A sound principle being proposed here in section 13 relates to the requirement for companies to demonstrate an appropriate level of performance before further claims are granted. This is also a timely amendment because it will ensure that companies are making real attempts to emerge as significant export concerns and not simply relying on government grant funding.

These steps will certainly help those Australian exporters who are making ground in the fragile export arena. But it is an indictment on this government that the Prime Minister ignored opportunities to arrange a bilateral visit to one or two Middle Eastern countries to improve our trade and export relationship when he was already visiting a nearby country—that is, Cyprus—for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. It is alarming because the Arab countries of the Middle East and Israel are major customers for our rural products. Given the parlous state that our primary producers currently find themselves in, this is simply not good enough from the leader of this country. In particular, these countries are targets for United States export enhancement program subsidies and subsidised product from the European Community on the very products which we sell to them. So our markets there are under severe threat. The Prime Minister should have ensured that he visited at least one or two of these countries en route to or from Cyprus.

Apart from our exports of grain to the region, the following figures indicate the importance of these markets for our products. The United Arab Emirates, Oman and Kuwait purchased $207.3 million worth of live animals in 1991-92. In the same year Saudi Arabia alone purchased a total of $206.7 million in major exports from Australia, including $80 million worth of sheep and goat meat and $91.9 million worth of cheese and curd. Yet the Prime Minister did not visit Saudi Arabia on his way to or from Cyprus.

The Prime Minister is visiting Indonesia en route home. This is worth while because Indonesia is also a significant market for Australia of some $438 million worth of cotton, minerals and wheat. But that is no excuse for the Prime Minister's overt neglect of the middle-eastern countries and their potential to us as export markets.

While the Prime Minister continues to push the value and importance of our Asian neighbours as export markets and seeks to persuade Australians that they are part of Asia, I remind him that more than 15 years ago, in an address-in-reply debate in the other place, I called for Australia to `turn our face to Asia' as a market for our goods. In the light of the Prime Minister's recent interest in Asia, I do not recall him demonstrating at that time such prescience or any particular interest in Asia as a source of trade for Australia.

An examination of the facts shows a pathetic but dramatic contrast between the reality and the rhetoric as far as our trade with Asia under the present government is concerned. Under 10 years of Hawke and Keating Labor governments, although the global amount of trade in Asia has grown quite significantly, Australia's share of that trade has fallen quite dramatically. This really is a hopeless performance under this Labor government. Our poor performance must be sheeted home to this government's failure to maintain the pace of reform required to allow Australian producers of goods and services to be sufficiently competitive in that market against other countries.

I conclude these remarks by reiterating the opposition's support for this legislation but saying to the government that it is absolutely critical that it quicken the pace of industrial relations reform and taxation reform—getting taxes, particularly input taxes, off the back of business—and continue to reform our waterfront, where the level and pace of reform is still inadequate, and all of those other areas which we on this side of the chamber have been advocating now for some years to ensure that producers of goods and services in Australia are competitive with those of other countries which are taking advantage of the dramatic growth in Asia. Otherwise we will continue to be left behind. While in absolute terms the dollar value of our exports to those Asian countries might increase, our share of that trade will continue to fall as it has under a decade of Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I advert to the details of the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, I express the hope that the new activist direction sketched out by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Alan Griffiths) in the area of industry development will also be adopted for the area of trade, and that this legislation, which seeks to encourage Australian industries to increase exports and to unlock new markets, will be reviewed from that point of view; namely, a more activist stance and a more interventionist stance, with more direct and active support for Australian industries which wish to push into international export markets.

PARA.TAB: The eligibility for the grants included in the bill is determined by the amount of eligible expenditure which a business has incurred in a grant year. One of the major aims of this bill is to limit eligibility for grants to companies, partnerships or individuals who are under insolvency administration by defining their expenditure as non-claimable. This would appear to be a response by the government to the Gregory Symons-Marshall Islands affair. The Australian Democrats welcome this move by the government to protect the scheme's integrity.

The bill also seeks to exclude from eligibility claimants with certain convictions. Proposed section 11YA will make expenditure incurred by a person convicted of certain offences involving fraud and dishonesty which are punishable by at least two years imprisonment non-claimable for a period of five years after conviction or release from custody. This ineligibility applies to companies and partnerships which have either a director or partner who was convicted of the specified offences. Once again, the Australian Democrats support these provisions.

This section is not sufficient to exclude those individuals or companies with eligible claims prior to the conviction. Hence, section 14A proposes to make grants unpayable on claims received from convicted persons where the claim period entitlement is wholly or partly before the conviction. The section makes it quite clear that the grant will not be paid even if the conviction occurred prior to the commencement of this provision, the claim was made prior to the commencement of this section or the claim was made before the conviction.

The Australian Democrats particularly welcome the encouragement being given to businesses in the early stages of developing their export markets. The bill seeks to achieve this by proposing a new section 13A, which allows claims to be lodged on a half-yearly basis in the first three years of grant eligibility. This should reduce the delays between incurring expenditure and payment of the grant, which is of course crucial in assisting the cash flow and viability of smaller businesses. There are many other technical amendments throughout this bill to incorporate this proposed system of first-half payments.

The Australian Democrats believe that the scheme should provide assistance primarily to small businesses which are just getting on their feet. Therefore, we welcome the provision which stops payment of the grant where a claimant's export earnings exceed $25 million for a full-year claim or $12.5 million for the first-half claim. There is, of course, the question as to whether this ceiling should in fact be lower to channel more resources to companies that are smaller, with a smaller turnover, but have the potential for growth.

The provision giving exporters access to additional grants beyond the general eight-grant limit was inserted in the act last year. It applies when they have incurred eligible expenditure for new markets. Clause 20 of this bill proposes to amend section 15 to limit the categories of activity eligible for this extension of grants. In large measure, this provision was necessary because of drafting errors which occurred in the original bill.

I wish to address the point that I foreshadowed as to whether this scheme really provides sufficient assistance to companies and individuals at the lower end of the scale, in the small business sector. The Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1990 increased the minimum expenditure threshold from $10,000 to $30,000. Only two years prior to that it had been increased from $5,000 to $10,000. Furthermore, that amendment made the first $15,000 ineligible for a grant. At the time, the Australian Democrats opposed these amendments in the firm conviction that this cut out a lot of people at the lower end of the business scale who, as events have proved, do have extremely good potential for unlocking export markets.

I foreshadow the following questions to the minister. Has the government assessed the effect of these amendments? How many companies which do have potential have been cut out from this scheme? Does the government intend to review the scheme, particularly these threshold levels which have been increased? I have received a number of complaints from companies that in the early stages of their export activities they cannot possibly finance their expenditure to the threshold levels which the government has introduced. Apart from this fact, which looks into the future of the scheme and its usefulness, I put on record that the Australian Democrats will support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly. The details of the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 have been largely covered by previous speakers. I will curtail my remarks. However, I will make some points relative to the legislation and the system generally. The EMDG scheme is very important, and vitally so to many businesses in Australia.

PARA.TAB: As we all know, business in Australia is about high costs and low productivity. We must try to overcome these things by encouraging people to invest more and improve their plant by extending their markets and so on. They have to get out and find out what productivity is in the rest of the world. We talk a lot about being part of a world economy, but we are doing nothing about trying to catch up with it. This is one avenue that we can use.

We have to be able to see why people should invest in Australia. I noticed yesterday that my colleague Senator Gibson stated that PDL Holdings, Heinz, Gillette, Unilever, Kraft, Shiseido, Johnson and Johnson, Alcatel and Mars have recently chosen to invest in New Zealand instead of Australia. Why? They can do better in business there. In New Zealand, they can employ and invest and get a reasonable return. We have to compete with New Zealand and other countries of the world.

Look at our costs compared with those of New Zealand. Look at the crazy things that add to our on-costs. Earlier in the week, we talked about an $8 per week wage increase. It may be an $8 per week increase for a handful of people in Australia's economy, but it is $12 or $13 for the people who keep Australia afloat, which is those who employ and invest. Nobody seems to consider what $8 per week means to the people who are paying the money. All the government rake-offs that go on the end of it make it quite uneconomical in many cases.

How are the producers of Australia to expand? There must be an EMDG scheme or something similar. Thinking back tonight, I guess that I would have spoken 20 times on EMDG legislation since I have been here. In that time, there have probably been over 100 amendments to it. How can business people in Australia possibly cope with legislation that changes two or three times a year, year after year? How can one plan when one does not know how long anything will last? It is crazy. But still, that is the way we have run it in the past and it is the way that we will apparently continue to run it under this government.

How can business plan? Why do not government members do something about it? I look across the other side of the chamber, when any of them are present, and wonder how they could know. I do not know how many of them have ever employed one person in a productive capacity. I just do not know how we can expect them to know more when they have not had the experience. It is important that honourable senators understand that.

Some people have lain awake at night wondering where the next day's pay for 40 or 50 men will come from when there is not enough money in the bank. There are those who wonder what they will do when an overseas order has been cancelled and the product is ready to shift. Others wonder how they will compete with something that is coming in from New Zealand at a 30 per cent lower price because the shipping costs, as we saw in the Daily Commercial News this week, are 50 per cent less if they deal with New Zealand rather than Australia. How many government members have had to compete with that sort of thing? How do they know what is involved in running a business of this sort?

We just glibly pass a bit of legislation and say, `We will fiddle with the EMDGs again and that will be right'. But it is not like that. We have to get people into productive enterprises. It makes me so perplexed to wonder what we will do to try to get the country moving again.

People who have never wondered how they will pay their business's tax, cope with the recession or look after an employee who is having a bad time really would not know. For people on the receiving end or in a non-productive occupation, it does not show. They do not know until they compete with the real world in either exporting or importing. Until they have employed and paid workers year after year, irrespective of whether things are good or bad, they do not know what it is like. So we fiddle with the legislation and make a mess of it once again.

Australia must produce and export. We have just passed the wool bills. What have we done with them? We have fiddled around the edges of that matter and created a new system. Goodness knows how long it will last. It was just another fiddle with that.

The Blundstone company in Tasmania has operated for over 100 years. It has decided that it must go to New Zealand because it cannot afford to operate in Australia any longer. Part of its business will now be done in New Zealand. That is a disgraceful state of affairs.

We must encourage people to invest and employ and to go into the export market. At the moment, the EMDG scheme is the only scheme that we have, and it is in tatters. Let us look at what we will do to give people some encouragement to do something. In the meantime, I am using this debate as a vehicle for speaking about the scheme in general. We do not oppose the legislation.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 has the intention of bringing Australia's maritime zones into line with those to which Australia is entitled under international law, as reflected in the 1982 Law of the Sea Convention. Primarily, this bill amends the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973. I note that the explanatory memorandum produced for the benefit of honourable senators and members also conveniently states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and a number of other Acts to replace references to the 1958 Territorial Sea and Continental Shelf Conventions with references to comparable provisions in the 1982 Law of the Sea Convention.

Having said that it amends the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 and a number of other acts, it might be worth drawing the attention of honourable senators to the range of acts that need to be amended in some way in order for this purpose to be achieved. There are quite a few of them: the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973, the Admiralty Act 1988, the Customs Act 1901, the Designs Act 1996, the Fisheries Management Act 1991, the Migration Act 1958, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981, the National Museum of Australia Act 1980, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, the Pipeline Authority Act 1973, the Quarantine Act 1908, the Sea Installations Act 1987, and the Whale Protection Act 1980. So the outline on the first page of the explanatory memorandum perhaps does not give a fair enough indication of how much work is involved in making this sort of change, namely, to bring Australia's maritime zones into line with those to which we are entitled under international law, as reflected by this 1982 Convention on the Law of the Sea.

PARA.TAB: The background or purpose of the bill is this: in 1982 the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, otherwise referred to as the 1982 convention, was adopted and signed by Australia. Australia has not yet ratified that convention. That 1982 convention needs 60 ratifications to come into force. At present, as we understand it, it has 56 such ratifications and therefore is quite likely to enter into force in the near future. Apart from the provisions relating to the mining of the deep seabed, it is generally accepted as reflective of international law. The government puts the view that, in relation to the maritime zones, the 1982 convention should in fact govern Australian practice.

The Seas and Submerged Lands Act, which is the act which is primarily amended by this bill, currently refers to the 1958 Geneva conventions on the territorial sea and continental shelf. At the moment, consultations are taking place in an attempt to overcome some of the difficulties that have arisen under the 1982 convention in relation to the provisions dealing with deep seabed mining. As I understand it, the government has indicated that, if these consultations are successful, Australia will then be in a position to give serious consideration to ratifying the convention. According to the government, therefore, it is appropriate now for us to amend our domestic law to bring our practice in relation to maritime zones into conformity with those provided for in the 1982 convention.

In 1979 Australia established a 200 nautical mile fishing zone. In 1983 certain territorial sea baselines were proclaimed by Australia. In 1990 a 12 nautical mile territorial sea was established in place of the previous three nautical mile territorial sea. The current bill will replace the operative provisions in Commonwealth legislation which refer to those 1958 conventions and put in, as I said, references to the 1982 convention. The bill makes it clear that Australia seeks to assert the full rights to which it is entitled under international law in a 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zone.

As indicated in the preamble of the bill, the rights that Australia has in such a zone include not just sovereign rights over both living and non-living resources but also jurisdiction as provided for in international law in relation to the establishment and use of artificial islands, installations and structures, marine scientific research and the protection and preservation of the marine environment. The sovereign rights and the jurisdiction which a coastal state possesses in its exclusive economic zone in regard to these matters are set out in detail in the 1982 convention, the relevant parts of which form a schedule to this bill. According to the government, it will be for future legislation to deal expressly with matters such as pollution control in the exclusive economic zone.

The bill also adopts the definition of the continental shelf in the 1982 convention. The 1958 convention defines the outer limit of a continental shelf in terms of a depth of 200 metres or beyond that to a depth capable of exploitation. Customary international law has recognised that the limit of the continental shelf is the edge of the continental margin and that it does not include the deep seabed. The 1982 convention contains in article 76 a precise definition of a continental shelf. This is a minimum 200 nautical miles regardless of the physical configuration of the shelf. Beyond that distance, where the configuration of the continental shelf allows, however, the limit may extend to a distance not exceeding 350 nautical miles from the baseline or 100 nautical miles from the 2,500 metre isobath. This limit is calculated either by reference to the depth of sediments or the distance from the foot of the continental slope defined by the gradient.

Adoption of the 1982 convention will enable Australia to claim a larger total area of continental shelf than we have been able to do under the 1958 convention. According to the government, the gains made by adopting this new definition outweigh any of the minor potential losses and will in fact bring Australian legislation into conformity with internationally accepted principles. The bill also deals quite expressly with a contiguous zone. This zone extends from the limit of the territorial sea to a distance no greater than 24 nautical miles from the territorial sea baselines.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that the Senate will not sit again before the funeral of the unknown soldier on 11 November, I stand before the Senate tonight to pay my respects to the 102,000 Australian Defence Force personnel who died in active service overseas and who are buried in war graves around the world.

PARA.TAB: I point out that 11 November 1993 will mark a very solemn occasion because the funeral of the unknown Australian soldier takes place at the Australian War Memorial in Canberra on that day. This service will bring back old memories for many Australians and has a special significance for them. Eighty flags from all the nations that provided a last resting place for those men and women who died for their country will fly in honour of them. The inscription on the tomb will read:

SPEECH.PARA: An unknown soldier of the war 1914-1918. He symbolises all Australians who have died in war.

Commemoration services will also be held around Australia at the same time. It will be a time for all Australians to reflect on the past and spare a thought and a prayer for those families who were changed forever because of the supreme sacrifice of their kin.

PARA.TAB: It would be appropriate, following this deeply moving day, if schools in all states re-establish the tradition of having two minutes silence at the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month in memory of our fallen. As a relatively young nation, we must be very cautious not to discard traditions that have a very deep meaning. Of the 102,000 Australians buried overseas, the majority of them were buried in countries where Australian troops fought major battles: France, Belgium and Turkey during World War I and Papua New Guinea, Thailand and Singapore in World War II. Many are also buried in the United Kingdom, which was the principal training ground and hospital area during the First World War.

Staff of the Australian War Memorial are in France at this time to recover the remains of a single unknown Australian soldier killed in World War I. The remains will be exhumed in secret from a cemetery in France. They will then be presented officially to Australia at the French village of Villers-Bretonneux, which has become synonymous with Australian sacrifice on the Western front in World War I. The remains will be flown to Canberra and entombed forever in the War Memorial.

The simple selection method will differ from the British, who chose their unknown warrior by placing a blindfolded British commander in a room with the remains of six unknown soldiers and asking him to make a random choice. But the symbolic nature of choosing somebody's unknown son, finally returning home from where he left so many years ago, remains the same. It cannot help but move the strongest and the coldest heart. So now 75 years to the day after the first world war ended he will finally be laid to rest and may he rest in peace.

I will deem it a great honour to lay a single flower on the tomb of the unknown Australian soldier after the ceremony. It will cause me to reflect on the past and remember the sacrifices that were made to allow us to live in this wonderful free democracy we cherish today. I am sure the English poet Rupert Brooke would excuse me when I say of our dead soldiers, lying so far from home, that there is a corner of a foreign field that is forever Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address briefly the fact that today the Victorian Attorney-General, Ms Wade, delivered a second reading speech on the Crimes Amendment Bill (No.2). This bill is relevant to this parliament to the extent that it contravenes international conventions or treaties which the Commonwealth government has entered into. I understand that several months ago the federal Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) drew the attention of the Human Rights Commissioner to the first edition of this bill. I am not aware that the Human Rights Commissioner has made any pronouncement on this, but I could be wrong.

PARA.TAB: However, today the Victorian Attorney-General produced the second edition of that bill and delivered the second reading speech, claiming that this bill takes account of many of the concerns that were expressed by a number of organisations in Victoria, including the International Commission of Jurists and the Youth Affairs Council. A copy of the second reading speech was faxed to me today, with annotations which clearly show that the main alterations made to the bill were alterations which rectified some minor drafting difficulties. But in substance, the bill remains as it was in the first draft.

The bill addresses three areas. It gives police quite extensive powers to obtain the names and addresses of persons suspected of committing an offence, to fingerprint a person charged with or reasonably suspected of committing an offence, and to conduct, following the consent of a magistrate, a body search, or to obtain hair, blood and other samples with the assistance of a medical practitioner.

The difficulty with this bill is that it applies to young persons above the age of 15. For example, the Victorian Attorney-General claims that the provisions in the area of obtaining fingerprints will bring the state of Victoria into line with the provisions that obtain in other states. I have had a search conducted and found that this is simply not true. In most other states there is a requirement for a court order, the order of a magistrate or the authorisation of the officer in charge. In almost all cases in almost all states, if the person concerned is under 16 or 14, that person must be in custody before fingerprinting can be carried out.

Clearly, we are not here to obstruct the lawful endeavours of police to apprehend criminals. However, it is quite a different matter if police are given powers which are in contravention of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which Australia has ratified. Here we have a bill which delivers, in effect, young persons into the power of police to do as they wish.

I wanted to put this on the record tonight. I want to advise the Senate that I will be referring the matter to the Federal Attorney-General tomorrow with a request to follow up his original referral to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I want to see whether we can suggest to the Attorney-General in Victoria to defer passing this bill and to conduct further examination to ensure that we do not pass a bill which is in contravention of international treaties to which Australia is a party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may recall the speech I made some weeks ago in relation to a lady by the name of Nola Sillars. Nola Sillars took her life out of frustration while waiting for the Australian Securities Commission to deal with her request for information which was lodged under the Freedom of Information Act.

PARA.TAB: In the course of my address I read to the Senate portions of a letter sent to me by the Australian Securities Commission dated 15 September 1993. This was just a couple of days after Nola Sillars took her life. Honourable senators will know my anger and frustration over that case.

Today I received another letter from the Australian Securities Commission signed by the Regional Commissioner—I assume for Western Australia—Mr Murray Allen. I wish to read this letter to the Senate because it does not improve the situation. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator O'Chee
I refer to my letter dated 15 September 1993 to Lisa Gates of your office.

It has been brought to my attention that the fifth paragraph on page 2 of that letter does not accurately reflect the Commission's position regarding the availability under FOI legislation of reports provided to the Commission pursuant to Corporations Law s533 or (Companies Code s418). The Commission has in fact in the past considered the release of such reports both in general and in particular circumstances. In some cases the report has been released and in other cases the report has been considered exempt from release.
Every application pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act must of course be considered on its merits and in the particular context.
I apologise for this error.
Your sincerely
Murray Allen
Regional Commissioner

That is a stunning piece of information because the letter it sought to correct was one which was written to me to pass on to Nola Sillars saying that the commission had not had cause to examine whether section 533 reports or section 418 reports under the companies code could be released under FOI.

PARA.TAB: Now the commission is saying, `Well, in fact, we have looked at this matter before both in general and in particular. We look at every case on its merits'. It still has not dealt with the fact that there was an FOI application made for this information. It still has not said whether this information in this particular case should or should not be released.

This letter is nothing short of an insult in the way in which it deals with this matter—in its insensitivity and in its failure to progress the matter any further. I would have thought that the commission would have had the decency to do something and at least give a straight answer. This letter does nothing at all to rectify the situation. I cannot hide my frustration over this matter. I wish I could be more patient with these people, but unfortunately with all the mess up that we have had to date I am afraid I cannot be.

I want to put on the record that this sort of letter shows that certain people in the Australian Securities Commission—and I am sure Mr Allen did not write this letter, I am sure he signed it because someone else wrote it for him—do not understand what the situation is all about. The person who wrote this letter never understood why the application was made in the first place and must think that this letter is going to solve all the problems. This letter does nothing to solve the problems. I seek leave to table this letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak further on this matter tonight. I do not think that I can progress it any further in my present mood because I am just so annoyed and frustrated. I want it on the record that this is not good enough. I hope that when those concerned in the Australian Securities Commission read this speech in Hansard—as I am sure they will do—they will recognise that they have to do much better than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a couple of matters tonight. Firstly, I want to comment on Senator Sandy Macdonald's remarks about the return of the unknown soldier on 11 November, which will mark the 75th anniversary of the end of the First World War. It is a moving tribute to the sacrifice of those 60,000 young Australians who died in the First World War—all of them far away from Australia. About 47,000 of those soldiers died in France.

PARA.TAB: In the early 1980s I had the opportunity to make a private visit to France, and I made the effort to visit Villers-Bretonneux, Amiens and the River Somme to see the war graves of the Australian forces. It is a particularly moving and sombre experience to visit Villers-Bretonneux and see something like 10,000 to 11,000 names engraved on the wall of that Australian war cemetery. Those Australians died in the epic battle of March and April 1918.

I do not think most Australians realise that that battle was in fact a turning point in the First World War and that it was the Australian divisions that stopped the last gasp German advance that nearly won the war for Germany in early 1918. In fact, when the whole of the British 5th Army disintegrated, the Australian divisions were marched from Flanders and around Passchendaele south to Villers-Bretonneux. They went straight into battle and stopped the German advance. Then on 25 April 1918, in a major counter attack, the Australian divisions defeated the Germans around Villers-Bretonneux and started the German retreat. This was the turning point of the war.

It is most moving to be at Villers-Bretonneux and to see the memorial and the streets named after towns in Australia and to witness the respect which the local French people have for the Australian forces and those who died there. All the way along the Amiens-Cambrai road for nearly 60 miles there are various Australian war graves for the various divisions of Pozieres and so on.

Senator Macdonald's remarks were very appropriate and we all support them. The ceremony on 11 November will be a very fitting one. I hope that it helps Australians to understand their history—the extraordinary contribution that Australians made in the First World War and their sacrifices. In proportion to the size of our population our casualties were about the heaviest. It should also be remembered that every soldier who died in France and elsewhere overseas was a volunteer. The rest of the armies of Europe were raised by conscription. All the Australian soldiers volunteered to go and fight.

When visiting Villers-Bretonneux some weeks ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made this point to the French when discussing their present agricultural policies. He said that if he had told these young Australian volunteers defending French sovereignty that their contribution would be paid back by France's present economic policies they might not have been so keen to go. I think it is worth pointing out to the French that in the two world wars Australians have laid down their lives to defend the French and French sovereignty and to liberate France. I wish the French would remember that. Nevertheless, the ceremony on 11 November will be a very moving moment. I think Senator Macdonald is to be congratulated on his remarks tonight.

The other matter I wanted to mention briefly relates to an area in my portfolio. It has come to my attention tonight that Dr David Kemp, the shadow minister for science technology and export development, has issued a statement based on a speech he made in the adjournment debate last night in the House of Representatives. It attacks remarks I made—or was reported to have made—in the Herald-Sun newspaper on 22 October. The paper claimed that I said scientists were `grey haired men in cardigans'. What the story in the press failed to do was give the context and explain where I made those remarks. I want to put the record straight on the context of those remarks not only for Dr Kemp but also everyone else.

Last week, on Thursday, 21 October, I had a meeting with some of the youth ANZAAS congress 1993 delegates. They were a group of young people who attended the ANZAAS congress 1993 in Perth. About 300 young people from high schools and secondary schools around Australia attended the congress. Most of them came from Western Australia. At the end of the congress, four of them were elected to make a report to me about their impressions of the congress and ways to improve the role of young people in science.

On Thursday of last week four of them came to Canberra and presented me with a very good report on the impressions and issues with respect to young people and science. It was the most well-written and precise report that one could hope to receive. In the discussion with them that followed, at which some science journalists were present, including one from the Sun-Herald, one of the issues that the delegates raised was the lack of women being encouraged to pursue a career in science. The youth delegates believed that this was due to there being a lack of role models of women in science for other women to follow.

During that discussion, I did say that, when one observes science meetings, one cannot help but have an impression that science is overwhelmingly made up of grey-haired men in cardigans, in view of the lack of women

SPEECH.PARA: who are not represented in science. That is the context in which I made the comment. It was not in any way meant to denigrate the role of scientists, as Dr Kemp remarked that it was. Of course, he based that on a report in the Sun-Herald that did not put into context my remarks.

PARA.TAB: I do not resile from the fact that I have consistently argued for programs to raise women's consciousness of—and encourage them to go into—science and engineering courses. I will continue to do so. I think those professions are diminished by not having an appropriate balance of our women members of society participating. For Dr Kemp, and even the journalist in the Sun-Herald, who had a very brief story which took my remark out of context, I hope that clears things up. I hope the science community sees that I am more interested in getting women into science than I am in making comments denigrating male scientists.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
